webTitle: Amid the chaos of Sierra Leone, those who can are fleeing

fields.headline: Amid the chaos of Sierra Leone, those who can are fleeing
fields.standfirst:
UNMASIL - UN mission
Sierra Leone Web
Background: Sierra Leone's troubled times
Audio: Chris McGreal live from Freetown, 9th May
fields.trailText: Sierra Leone's capital, Freetown, was gripped by foreboding last night as gangs of gun-toting fighters cruised the city and the roads were jammed with refugees and soldiers.
fields.body:
Sierra Leone's capital, Freetown, was gripped by foreboding last night as gangs of gun-toting fighters cruised the city and the roads were jammed with refugees and soldiers.

No one can be sure who fired first, but yesterday at least four more people were added to the growing list of victims of the country's brutal nine-year civil war after a gun battle near the house of the rebel leader, Foday Sankoh.

It happened after marchers - some of them children whose arms had been hacked off in earlier fighting - descended on Mr Sankoh's home to demand the release of about 500 UN peacekeepers being held by his group, the Revolutionary United Front.

In the chaos that ensued, unarmed protesters were gunned down by heavily armed rebels as peacekeepers stood by. The killings provoked fighting between the rebels and government soldiers in other parts of Freetown. Many people fled their homes.

At the back of everyone's mind is fear. Fear of a repeat of the massacres and mutilations that occurred during a rebel invasion of the city early last year.

Hundreds of evacuees, clutching passports and suitcases, were last night cramming into a former hotel in west Freetown, spurred on by news of the arrival of 250 British paratroopers preparing for a mass airlift today.

Among the evacuees at the gate was Alan Webster. "I packed this bag two days ago because I guessed this was going to happen," he said. "I don't want to leave the country, I just want to go to the airport and see what happens. They are very unsafe these people. You cannot predict them at all."

US citizens were permitted into the British evacuation groups but other nationalities were turned away because officials said they were not Britain's responsibility. Many embassies have already evacuated most or all of their staff.

A Sierra Leonean woman, whose nine-year-old daughter is a British citizen, waited with the girl in the hotel courtyard. She said rebels had killed her husband and four of their children last year by setting their home on fire. "I don't want to lose her too," she said as she waited to send the girl to safety.

The helicopters worked all day until dusk. By then most of the city's residents were off the streets. It was time to hide, and hope.

The debris of the day's battles littered streets. The gates were ripped off Mr Sankoh's house and the outside of the building was riddled with bullets, suggesting somebody finally fought back. It was probably the government army.

Mr Sankoh was in the house during the afternoon's shooting but his whereabouts last night were unclear. A government army intelligence officer, Second Lieutenant F A Silike, said the military were looking for the rebel leader.

Several thousand people joined the "peace demonstration" to Mr Sankoh's home carrying placards reading "We want peace" and chanting: "Sankoh, Sankoh, you have a bad mind." As it snaked through the city the march grew in size. Many shops and businesses closed in solidarity - or because they feared its consequences.

The protest was goodnatured, but as it drew close to the rebel leader's home the crowd grew tense and bunched together, as if to seek protection in numbers. It stopped just a few feet short of the gate. Some began stoning the house and breaking windows.

No one can be sure who fired first, but it is likely to be rebels inside the house. Some were seen with rocket-propelled grenades and machine guns. At least four people were killed, some execution-style as the rebels emerged from the house to shoot men at close range.

Demonstrators complained afterwards that the UN peacekeepers who had been guarding the house, in part to keep an eye on Mr Sankoh's whereabouts, did nothing to protect the unarmed crowd.

"If they [the rebels] are shooting at people when there are UN people there they should shoot back," said Foday Jamai, one of the protesters.

Sierra Leone's information minister, Julius Spencer, was also perturbed. "Security for the area was in the hands of the UN. They had troops in the area. I cannot see why the government should be controlling Foday Sankoh," he said.

"The UN have to tell us if they are incapable of controlling the situation and we will take over."

The shooting at Mr Sankoh's house sparked gun battles between rebels and government soldiers across Freetown, leaving an undetermined number of others killed and wounded.

The British Foreign Office has now called for all UK passport holders to leave the country.

fields.headline: Delays prolong cricket fixing agony
fields.trailText: The cricket world's attempts to show it is serious about eradicating corruption from the game were embarrassingly undermined yesterday by the revelation that match-fixing inquiries in Pakistan and South Africa have been delayed yet again.
fields.body:
The cricket world's attempts to show it is serious about eradicating corruption from the game were embarrassingly undermined yesterday by the revelation that match-fixing inquiries in Pakistan and South Africa have been delayed yet again.

Justice Malik Mohammad Qayyum's report on corruption in Pakistan, due to be released today, may now be kept under wraps for several weeks. And South Africa's sports minister Ngconde Balfour said that neither a starting date nor a venue had been set for hearings, scheduled to begin yesterday, into the Hansie Cronje affair.

The Pakistan Cricket Board chairman Tauqir Zia said the Pakistan national president Rafiq Tarar had "certain points" he wanted to "clarify" before the report could be released. "I have been told to seek advice from legal experts," Zia said.

In Cape Town the head of South Africa's inquiry, Edwin King, said: "I can say no more than that it will start sooner rather than later."

The government is still debating whether to shift the public hearings from Pretoria to Cape Town. "We have a very real sense of the urgency of this matter," King insisted, "but if we kick off before things are thoroughly prepared it will have exactly the opposite effect."

These new delays make a mockery of the International Cricket Council's zero tolerance policy against match-fixing announced last week.

Pakistan, in particular, is running out of excuses given that the Qayyum report, which allegedly recommends life bans for Salim Malik and Mushtaq Ahmed, was submitted six months ago.

 The ICC president Jagmohan Dalmiya has again stated he was "in no way involved" with negotiating television rights for a tournament in Bangladesh in 1998.

webTitle: Romsey is more important than the London result

fields.headline: Romsey is more important than the London result
fields.standfirst:
Charles Kennedy may look feeble, but he is a student of political style

Special report: Elections 2000
fields.trailText: Charles Kennedy may look feeble, but he is a student of political style
fields.body:
In modern politics, nothing matters more than the leader. We have a parliamentary system but a presidential impulse. This takes a certain view about power, but a determining one about style. Think of the Tories and you get William Hague: bald, struggling, robotic, Yorkshire. Think of Labour, and there's only one face in front of it and one mind behind. Almost the entire apparatus of party presentation is devoted to the daily manicuring, weekly shaping and permanent controlling, down to the finest detail, of the impression these leaders make on the voting public.

For the last two decades, beginning with the emergence of Margaret Thatcher, this emphasis, ever escalating, has worked pretty well for leaders. It was congruent with the era of mass marketing, and the thirst for personal stories and simplified images. The leader had to be personable and not physically repellent, but also strong, dominant, the master of every crisis, the solver of every problem, first among manifest unequals. This kept Mrs Thatcher where she was for a decade, and put Tony Blair where he is today.

Such a leader-obsession, however, has its dangers, especially when political alienation is growing. From the assorted and contradictory messages in last week's election results, one conclusion nobody could draw is that most voters retain a belief in political allegiance or even in such a modest political activity as going to the polls. This may be the clearest marker of transition from 20th to 21st-century politics. Swept into it is the supreme primacy given to the masterful leader as a role model every party has to follow. For the leader, in a disbelieving age, becomes the person you quickly start to hate, the personification of the politics which, on an unprecedented scale, you've given up on.

One beneficiary of this was Ken Livingstone, with enough distance to please the alienated but enough credibility for those who want some action. The less noticed legatee was Charles Kennedy, the barely visible leader of the Liberal Democrats who observes few of the above norms. For that reason, he doesn't count. For the same reason, he's absolved from hate. In an age when people have many fewer expectations of politicians, demanding mainly that they don't agitate the voters' cynicism, Kennedy's inoffensiveness, his obscurity, his conversational style when he's heard at all, are more than a timely asset. They may signal a politics that's out of others' reach.

The effects were apparent in some of last week's results. The Lib Dems did less well in the south, though not all that less well. In the citadels of old Labour, such as Oldham, they consolidated what they've already got in Liverpool and Sheffield. The main point is their national spread. They're not going away, squeezed between disillusionment with their Labour allies and the resurgent appeal of the official opposition. This could have happened, but didn't. What has been understood for decades as the plague-on-both-your-houses party is becoming something more: a safe haven from the undeliverable posturing of a whole brand of leadership that no longer hits the button.

Kennedy looks like an innocent in this. His interventions at prime minister's question time seem feeble, after the gladiators have exhausted themselves shouting. But he's a student of style. His first appearance as a Liberal candidate came at the age of 22, when he flew back to Scotland from Indiana University where he was writing a student thesis on political rhetoric. I'm told this focused in particular on Roy Jenkins, from whose rotundities the downbeat chat of leader Kennedy could hardly be more different. Arguably he's still more interested in style than content, though yesterday's launch of a high-powered group of economists to study the euro shows he understands what matters. His forgettable presence is part calculated, by a man known to more people as an amusing TV quiz-show presence than a boring politician. But the pitch, unfashionable as it is, aims squarely into the existential crisis of his trade.

He certainly jolted the Tories. While fighting hundreds of local elections, the Lib Dems still assembled the energy to wipe Hague's party out in Romsey, a more important event, in national predictive terms, than Livingstone's capture of London. In a south coast seat, the Hague assault on asylum seekers fell flat. In a semi-rural seat, so did the panic attacks on countryside violence. There are always many explanations for electoral events, always special cases to be made. But in their hearts, Hague and his chairman, Michael Ancram, must know that, even at this time when loyalty counts for little, the Romsey result signalled the deep illness if not yet the death of Tory England.

The challenge to Labour is different. Kennedy was never keen on the collaborationist project of his predecessor, Paddy Ashdown. He dreamed much less about a grand coalition of the centre left, especially when it became clear that Blair wouldn't soon be delivering a referendum on proportional representation. The Lib Dem attacks on Labour have grown spikier. At the back of them, Kennedy flirts with the belief that his party can supplant the Conservatives as the main party of opposition, after Hague is badly punished some time soon for taking his party into a rightist ghetto where only the Daily Telegraph sustains it.

That doesn't make much sense. The condition, as I said, is illness not death. But the Kennedy strategy is nonetheless correct. It may or may not lead to the conclusion Ashdown sought, but it's the only route towards it. Only by being strong can Lib Dems hope to grow stronger still. Blair may once have toyed with gratuitously offering Ashdown a cabinet seat, but that period of generous dreaming is gone. Normal power politics, rightly, takes over.

The Lib Dems will never get PR except by impressing on Labour that this is the only way for the centre left, composed of two sympathetic but different parties, to keep Britain on a progressive path. That's what they will do by increasing their seats, as Labour lose some of theirs. The Labour tactical voters who swept the Lib Dems home in Romsey are thus the key to a paradoxical outcome. They're supporting a cause that transcends a party structure which people have little faith in. Voting to keep the Tories out, they support a party bent on weakening Labour as the only way to get a voting system that will benefit itself.

What we've just learned is that there's a better chance of this happening. The electorate is multiparty. Contradiction suits it. The same voters do different things at the same time. They reject the models of allegiance and discipline dinned into us from political birth, and cultivated with ever more frenetic displays of pseudo-mastery by Blair and Hague. These look like old politics. The people more in sync with the times hang loose, with fewer pretensions, more catholic friends and a quieter voice.

hugo.young@theguardian.com

fields.headline: Kennedy steps up pressure
fields.trailText: Charles Kennedy, the Liberal Democrat leader, yesterday stepped up pressure on Tony Blair to join the single currency when he established a commission to investigate British membership of the euro.
fields.body:
Charles Kennedy, the Liberal Democrat leader, yesterday stepped up pressure on Tony Blair to join the single currency when he established a commission to investigate British membership of the euro.

Amid mounting frustration among pro-Europeans at the prime minister's tentative approach to the euro, the Lib Dem leader said he had decided to fill the vacuum created by the government's "inactivity".

The commission, which will include Willem Buiter, soon to be an ex-member of the Bank of England's monetary policy committee, will report on the steps Britain needs to take to join the euro.

Mr Kennedy thinks Gordon Brown's five economic tests to assess if Britain is ready to join the euro are designed to provide the government with an excuse for doing nothing. The commission will examine a sixth test - what steps Britain should take to tackle the overvaluation of the pound.

Mr Kennedy said: "The chancellor's view is that we should wait until all his ducks are in a line and he will then give us the benefit of his wisdom. Our view is that we should work pro-actively to get the ducks in a line. We must work to get the right conditions for a successful entry."

The Lib Dems want urgent action on the euro because of the damage being inflicted on manufacturing by the high pound.

"The last three to four years have been a great missed opportunity for Britain," Mr Kennedy said. "We could have joined in 1997 and there would have been significant gains for business. Rover might now be on a firm footing."

webTitle: England pick Jerusalem and Fat Les for Euro 2000

fields.headline: England pick Jerusalem and Fat Les for Euro 2000
fields.trailText: Words written by the poet and mystic William Blake in 1820 will resound over the airwaves from tomorrow and, the FA hopes, from thousands of English supporters' voices in Belgium and the Netherlands this summer.
fields.body:
And did those feet in ancient time ever wear the thought of Fat Les singing Jerusalem?

The classic hymn, more usually associated with the Royal Albert Hall - with England rugby union rather than soccer - and the street-cred band have been improbably brought together by the Football Association to make England's official Euro 2000 song.

So the words written by the poet and mystic William Blake in 1820 will resound over the airwaves from tomorrow and, the FA hopes, from thousands of English supporters' voices in Belgium and the Netherlands this summer.

The traditionalist may recoil in disgust at the very thought of this techno cover version of the 84-year-old hymn (Sir Charles Hubert Hastings Parry composed the melody during the first world war). But, says Mark Perryman of the England Members Club, which helped choose the song, Jerusalem "has been treated with respect, yet, sound-wise, brought up to to date". It has a "serious" drum track.

The three-man collective, called Fat Les 2000 for the project, are equally enthusiastic. The actor Martin Allen says: "Everyone has heard Jerusalem, most of us have sung it and all of us know some of the words. Frankly, it's a cracking good hymn."

Allen, Alex James of Blur and the artist Damien Hirst are joined by a 60-piece orchestra and four choirs for the CD, which will be released by Parlophone on May 29. It will be accompanied by a Band Aid-style promotional video featuring the trio, the England team and an appearance by Michael Barrymore.

It is far cry from Vindaloo, the raucous offering from Fat Les which, along with the hugely popular knockabout Three Lions by the Lightning Seeds together with David Baddiel and Frank Skinner, lost out to Top of the World by Echo and the Bunnymen and the Spice Girls for England's official song for the 1998 World Cup.

But Posh and co lost out commercially to both rivals, with Three Lions (Football's Coming Home) enjoying huge popular appeal since Euro 96 and topping the charts.

The FA's chief executive Adam Crozier says of Jerusalem: "We want our fans to leave behind their own club loyalties and join together as England fans. Fat Les 2000 are exactly the right artists to make this happen."

fields.headline: Dixons considers selling Freeserve
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Dixons, the electrical retailer, yesterday confirmed that it was considering the sale of its 80% stake in Freeserve, Britain's largest internet service provider.
fields.body:
Dixons, the electrical retailer, yesterday confirmed that it was considering the sale of its 80% stake in Freeserve, Britain's largest internet service provider.

The move is likely to spell the end of Freeserve as an independent operation if, as is widely expected, the company is sold to a European telecoms company or a rival ISP.

Several bidders are understood to be waiting in the wings, including Energis, BT and Deutsche Telekom's T-Online, which is Germany's largest ISP.

Freeserve was floated last year by Dixons on the London stock market and is now valued at more than £4bn.

Under the terms of the flotation, Dixons is allowed to sell half its shareholding in August, lowering its stake to 40%. The company said it was actively considering several options, though it refused to confirm that Goldman Sachs had been retained to carry out the review.

Dixons said in a statement the review "may or may not include a sale or distribution of all or part of its holding."

Shares in the no-subscription internet service provider rose 2.1% to 278.25p.

"As the leading online consumer ISP portal in the UK, Freeserve has strategic importance within a fast consolidating pan-European landscape," Peter Bradshaw, internet analyst at Merrill Lynch.

Miles Saltiel, analyst at WestLB Panmure, said T-Online - which is majority owned by Deutsche Telekom - was the most likely buyer.

Freeserve has 1.9m users, a third of the dial-up internet users in Britain.

Revenues have come mainly from a share of telephone call income but this is under pressure with rivals starting to offer as much internet as you want for a flat fee per month.

Some think Freeserve is big enough to weather the storm and smart enough to keep its users and make money from advertising to them and getting them to buy goods online.

fields.headline: Brown talks up single currency
fields.standfirst: Finance ministers stop short of intervention on foreign exchanges
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown last night sought to talk up the ailing European single currency in a bid to ease the pressure of the strong pound on Britain's manufacturing sector.
fields.byline: Mark Milner  and Andrew Osborn  in Brussels
fields.body:
Gordon Brown last night sought to talk up the ailing European single currency in a bid to ease the pressure of the strong pound on Britain's manufacturing sector.

In his first overt intervention in support of the euro the Chancellor said the current weakness of the single currency, which he acknowledged was causing "great difficulties" for UK manufacturers, could not be justified by "economic fundamentals".

Mr Brown's remarks echoed comments from the finance ministers of the 11-country euro zone, meeting in Brussels, though Treasury sources suggested the Chancellor was acting on his own initiative, rather than in concert with his European colleagues.

The finance ministers were clearly worried about the fall in the euro's value. It has lost a quarter of its value against the dollar since its launch at the beginning of last year.

"We share a common concern about the present level of the euro which does not reflect the strong economic fundamentals of the euro area," they said in a statement.

Their comments, however, did not make any mention of the possibility that the European Central Bank might use its massive foreign exchange reserves to intervene on the foreign exchanges in support of the single currency, though a number of euro-11 policy-makers were at pains to stress it remained a possibility.

"This instrument exists and is available," said Joaquim Pina Moura, the Portugese finance minister and meeting chairman.

Laurent Fabius, France's new finance minister went further. "For economic reasons, for psychological reasons and for political reasons we need a strong currency," he said.

Claude Juncker, Luxembourg's finance minister, accused the financial markets of being irrational. "I don't understand financial markets and I have to take note of the fact that they don't understand us - but they are irrational, not the ministers of finance," he said.

The lack of an explicit reference to intervention, however, knocked half a cent off the euro. It fell from $0.90 to $.8950, little more than a cent above its lowest level.

Nick Parsons at Commerzbank in London said he was not surprised the finance ministers had not mentioned threats of intervention. "That's not the way it works, but enough people in the market expected it so the euro fell."

Rob Hayward at Bank of America said intervention could not be ruled out. "The market is cautious but the risk is still that the euro will gradually head lower, though at a more cautious pace," he said.

But financier George Soros, who made vast sums in 1992 speculating against the pound, warned that the euro risked becoming a "one-way bet" for the foreign exchange markets and could fall below $0.80.

fields.headline: Settling down
fields.standfirst: Getting a career after travelling
fields.trailText: 9 May: I spent my 20s travelling. Now I am 30 and employers don't want to know.
fields.body:
The problem

I spent my 20s travelling, working overseas and doing various jobs, including becoming a qualified journalist and spending two years on a weekly newspaper.

Now I am 30 years old and ready to commit to a career. I want it to be in the non-profit sector but I feel as if my age and the fact I have done so much travelling is going against me. I am more reliable than a 20-year-old, fresh from university who has seen nothing of the world and will soon get disillusioned about and leave to do precisely what I did. It is so frustrating trying to convince employers I am an intelligent woman with a huge range of useful work skills and experience. Jo Harper

The solution

The problem is that you might be ready to commit to a career but potential employers don't know this. All they can see is a track record that screams short-term to them. While you may have spent the last ten years gaining valuable experiences and skills in different jobs and countries, to the employer, you are someone with wanderlust, who cannot stay in the same job or location for more than five minutes.

So, the question is, how can you turn the apparent pitfalls of your varied experiences into the advantages that they really are? I think you are going on the wrong track if you think that the problem is trying to convince employers that you are intelligent with a huge range of useful work skills and experience - this is probably not contested. The hurdle you need to overcome is convincing them, not that you can do the job, but that you are going to be around long enough for them to invest in you.

To achieve this, your covering letter with your application needs to be blunt and to the point. You need to state clearly that, while you have benefited enormously from travelling and a variety of jobs, your travelling days are over and you are looking for a permanent post.

You should also look carefully at where you are targeting your applications. I wonder whether you are actually selling yourself short and going for jobs that you are far too skilled for, if you are competing against 20-year-old graduates? Find yourself a mentor in the industry (by ringing up various companies, even ones who reject you, and arranging meetings or chats with key personnel who may be able to give you some tips or even work experience) who can help you with your marketing and help you get a foot in the door.

Be persistent - you will get there in the end!

Dr Sandi Mann is author of Psychology Goes To Work and Hiding What We Feel, Faking What We Don't

fields.headline: Risk rewarded
fields.standfirst: Moloko Manchester University ****
fields.trailText: Moloko Manchester University ****
fields.body:
In the film Gremlins a group of young people purchase a couple of cuddly hairy creatures, only to get them home and watch, alarmed, as they develop teeth, revel in mischief and cause utter havoc. A similar thing is happening with Moloko.

The Sheffield funksters take their name from A Clockwork Orange and their two Ibiza anthems-turned-global smashes, Sing It Back and The Time Is Now, are as indicative of their overall direction as a cuddly thing in a box points to a wrecked house.

Thought of as a fly-by-night chart act, they're actually on their third album of deranged funk. More significantly, main man Mark Brydon has an experimental pedigree as long as his guitar- playing arm. With house pioneers Funky Worm and Krush, and 80s avant-funk band Chakk, Brydon has spent a lifetime challenging dance music audiences, and is not about to stop now.

The first song Moloko play sounds like a madder version of Funkadelic, fronted by Marlene Dietrich; the second hints at PiL's Metal Box and Siouxsie Sioux. Later the band conduct an experimental onstage collaboration with a local DJ, Winston. The sounds of the audience scratching their heads are almost audible, but any hints of restlessness are easily tempered by the more accessible contributions of singer Roisin Murphy. Toning down the dark sex doll act of earlier tours, she is now somewhere between Cilla Black and an alien nation gameshow hostess. At one point duetting (rather hideously) with a guitarist, she even quotes local anti-heroes Happy Mondays; later she drops the pizzazz to confess, "You're a very open-minded audience."

Gradually, the crowd's thirst for enormous dance numbers is rewarded with carefully placed slabs of riotous disco. But M-People this isn't. Closing proceedings with a shock segue of Sing It Back and Donna Summer/Giorgio Moroder's electronic masterpiece I Feel Love is not a crowdpleasing move but a brave one that could have easily left Moloko's own anthem looking second-rate by comparison. That it works stunningly carries an underlying message: on this form, Moloko can play with the best.

webTitle: Redundancy ploy to save Rover costs

fields.headline: Redundancy ploy to save Rover costs
fields.standfirst: Rover in crisis: special report
fields.trailText: BMW will tomorrow consider issuing protective redundancy notices to Rover's 9,000 Longbridge workers to cut the cost of sacking them.
fields.body:
BMW will tomorrow consider issuing protective redundancy notices to Rover's 9,000 Longbridge workers to cut the cost of sacking them.

The German company's management advisory board is to discuss the move today ahead of tomorrow's supervisory board meeting in Munich.

Giving formal three-months legal notice of the job losses would reduce pay-offs and allow any buyer of the plant - or, failing a sale of the business, BMW itself - to impose the redundancies. Components suppliers are said to increasingly believe that the Alchemy option is more viable than the Phoenix plans. The mood on the West Midlands taskforce appointed by the government to deal with the impact of job losses is said to have swung away from the Phoenix consortium.

The taskforce met yesterday and a member said: "Hard-headed businessmen fear Phoenix is just not a goer. We will know shortly - but if they reduce the number of cars they would make it is more and more like Alchemy without the drive."

John Prescott, the deputy prime minister, yesterday said the government had no "magic wand" to save jobs at Rover or at Ford, which is expected to announce later this month that it is ending car production at Dagenham, Essex.

He said that the government recognised the pressure of the strong pound on manufacturing companies but would not change its economic policy.

First Union Corporation, a large US banking group, emerged yesterday as the main financial backer for the Phoenix bid.

Burdale Financial, the London subsidiary of the North Carolina based bank, yesterday confirmed that it had offered to put up £200m to provide Phoenix with working capital for Rover. But the offer is subject to the results of due diligence inquiries into Rover's financial condition and prospects.

Many industry experts believe that Phoenix's plan to build 200,000 Rovers a year is not viable - and that BMW might return to its original plan: selling the bulk of the Rover car business to Alchemy Partners, the London-based venture capital firm which ended talks with the German car maker last week.

BMW has threatened to close Rover if it has not reached agreement to sell the company by the end of the month.

The directors of the German car company are expected to have a rough ride over their handling of the Rover affair at the annual meeting on May 16. Industry sources say that they want to wrap up a Rover deal by then in order to divert some of the flak from shareholders.

Two Japanese car companies, Honda and Toyota, denied reports that they were in talks with Phoenix.

fields.headline: Shivers of history
fields.standfirst: Royal Ballet/ The Diaghilev Legacy Royal Opera House, London ****
fields.trailText: Royal Ballet/ The Diaghilev Legacy Royal Opera House, London ****
fields.body:
The Royal Ballet's current celebration of Diaghilev's Ballets Russes offers heady riches of colour, music and dance history. Even though it spans just 14 years of repertory, its stylistic range feels like decades. Mikhail Fokine's The Firebird (1910) - once considered pioneering in its muscular, folkloric energy and exotic colour - now looks like an intimate descendant of 19th-century ballet, while Bronislava Nijinska's Les Biches (1924) inhabits a sharply 20th-century world. Though it flaunts a far more classical virtuosity than The Firebird, the choreography's sly comments on sexual mores - both on and off the stage - evoke a sophisticated and very modern sensibility.

Both works have been danced by the Royal before but Vaslav Nijinksy's legendary L'Apres-Midi d'un Faune (1912) is a company premiere. This ballet is a stark, irreducible original, and under the excellent direction of Anne Hutchinson Guest the Royal's revival produces a genuine shiver of history. When the curtain first opens on Bakst's molten, sensuous backdrop, with the Faun lying in a pool of antique light, it is like seeing a much reproduced painting spring to life.

The dancers perform with real care, finding dramatic truth in the choreography's stiffly archaic poses without trespassing beyond their austere stylistic bounds. Carlos Acosta (dancing with the second cast) can't quite repress his habitual laddishness but his alert, feral energy makes the Faun a true savage, while Irek Mukhamedov (dancing with the first) is very monumental, very iconic. Zenaida Yanowksy, outstandingly, finds an innocence and gravity in the role of the Chief Nymph that are almost spookily of another era.

The Royal is also giving its first performances of Nijinsky's lost Bloomsbury ballet Jeux (1913), as reconstructed by Millicent Hodson and Kenneth Archer. Hodson and Archer carefully describe their staging as being "after Nijinsky" since they had no notation to work from, only old photographs, sketches and descriptions.

When it was first premiered in Verona this version of Nijinsky's erotically ambiguous but formally severe trio had a staccato, imagistic quality. The more ambitiously worked Royal staging foregrounds an element of joined-up dancing that, rightly or wrongly, dilutes the ballet's strangeness. Yet Nijinsky's spirit still haunts the choreography's mechanistic rhythms, its solidly sculpted poses and oddly oriental detail, and both casts perform with an intelligence that gives real theatrical integrity to this admittedly hybrid piece.

Some may argue that Hodson and Archer shouldn't meddle with a revival whose authenticity they can't guarantee. The rest of us are glad to get even a sidelong view of this extraordinary period vignette.

Until May 20. Box office: 020-7304 4000.

fields.headline: Loo days
fields.standfirst: You can tell a lot about a company from its toilets, says Judi James
fields.trailText: Firm favourites: You can tell a lot about a company from its toilets, says Judi James.
fields.body:
What do your company toilet facilities tell you about the way staff are perceived in your firm? Quite a lot if we study the recent furore over the unisex loo, the latest business cultural exchange to cross the Atlantic.

A figment of the imagination

First I have to say I don't believe the male/female toilet really exists at all in the US. My money is on the fact that the thing is just some great big urban legend dreamt up by the scriptwriters of Ali McBeal. That it was seen as a bit of a wheeze in America but that they then thought an even greater joke would be to ship it across to the UK to see if we fall for it, like we fell for those other two cultural jokes - dressing down and the open plan office. And guess what - it worked. I think workers in the US secretly wear navy suits and sit in their own private offices, using their own little mono-sex loos, laughing their socks off at us.

Toilet imaging

The message from the unisex loo may be that your company is progressive, keen to change with the times, and possibly a bit naive and barking into the bargain.

But what about the other forms of corporate hospitality? Here is the low-down on the loos on offer at a company near you:

The school run

This company toilet is run along strict lines by an anonymous but omnipotent concierge who must have done her training at an army boot camp. The handwash water is scolding and the soap smells of carbolic. There is a ceiling-high auto air-freshener with a sensory trip-switch that dispels clouds of lavender-scented CS gas the minute you stand near it and raise the pollution levels.

There are notes pinned everywhere, telling you to FLUSH! and NOW PLEASE WASH YOUR HANDS! There is a basket of pot-pourri next to the taps and a six-pack of air freshener waiting beside it in case of environmental emergencies.

Image: Your company is run along school lines, possibly by an anally-retentive puritan who believes you are not to be trusted. This company will be a hard one to progress in until you have proved yourself to be very grown up, which probably won't happen until you are clearing fifty. There is no scope for creativity in this place. They relish detail and traditional procedures. If you come up with a new idea you will need to prove how closely it matches one already in existence.

The hi-tech

This toilet is like a shrine to minimalism and modern design. No-one really knows how it all works but no-one likes to let on, so staff watch one another surreptitiously for clues about the hand-drier and door locks, a bit like watching other diners to see which knife to use in a posh restaurant.

There are no knobs, switches or lids visible to the naked eye. If you manage to suss out the well-concealed paper towel dispenser you will never find the bin to put it in and will probably emerge with a couple stored in your handbag, to throw away once you get home.

Image: This company relishes the cult of the new. If you are over thirty you may possibly need to start hunting for a new job. Knowing how this toilet functions is vital to business success. Image is all in this company. If you want to impress this boss make sure you sport a pair of weirdo designer-frame specs and a palm-size laptop.

The pamper parlour

This toilet is like a celebration of womanhood. Every need is catered for, including some you never knew you might have. There are perfume sprays, sewing kits, hand-cream dispensers, hair combs, machines selling tights and an industrial skip-load of personal hygiene products.

Image: Don't be too fooled by this feminity-fest. Rather than relishing their female staff this company could really rather fear them. If the delights on offer are a little too comprehensive, and even include deodorants and tooth cleaning kits, it may be that this is the equivalent to a corporate sheep dip.

This company wants its women hassle-free, spruced up and looking good. By providing everything in the one small area the idea is that nothing bad leaks out back in the office, like laddered tights or dandruff. If you want to do well here make sure you are immaculately turned out. One hair out of place and you could be banished to the bog until you improve.

Workers' paradise

This toilet is the one where colleagues gather to continue business discussions. It is decorated in exactly the same style as the boardroom and hosts similar lighting. There are chairs in groups for longer discussions and the company tannoy can page you in there even louder than it can outside.

Image: There really is no hiding place in this company, which will want its pound of flesh in terms of commitment and hours worked, and then some. Welcome to the world of the power lunch, the working commute and the evening homework. If you cherish your private and social life it could be time to move onward and upward.
fields.bodyText: What do your company toilet facilities tell you about the way staff are perceived in your firm? Quite a lot if we study the recent furore over the unisex loo, the latest business cultural exchange to cross the Atlantic. A figment of the imagination First I have to say I don't believe the male/female toilet really exists at all in the US. My money is on the fact that the thing is just some great big urban legend dreamt up by the scriptwriters of Ali McBeal. That it was seen as a bit of a wheeze in America but that they then thought an even greater joke would be to ship it across to the UK to see if we fall for it, like we fell for those other two cultural jokes - dressing down and the open plan office. And guess what - it worked. I think workers in the US secretly wear navy suits and sit in their own private offices, using their own little mono-sex loos, laughing their socks off at us. Toilet imaging The message from the unisex loo may be that your company is progressive, keen to change with the times, and possibly a bit naive and barking into the bargain. But what about the other forms of corporate hospitality? Here is the low-down on the loos on offer at a company near you: The school run This company toilet is run along strict lines by an anonymous but omnipotent concierge who must have done her training at an army boot camp. The handwash water is scolding and the soap smells of carbolic. There is a ceiling-high auto air-freshener with a sensory trip-switch that dispels clouds of lavender-scented CS gas the minute you stand near it and raise the pollution levels. There are notes pinned everywhere, telling you to FLUSH! and NOW PLEASE WASH YOUR HANDS! There is a basket of pot-pourri next to the taps and a six-pack of air freshener waiting beside it in case of environmental emergencies. Image: Your company is run along school lines, possibly by an anally-retentive puritan who believes you are not to be trusted. This company will be a hard one to progress in until you have proved yourself to be very grown up, which probably won't happen until you are clearing fifty. There is no scope for creativity in this place. They relish detail and traditional procedures. If you come up with a new idea you will need to prove how closely it matches one already in existence. The hi-tech This toilet is like a shrine to minimalism and modern design. No-one really knows how it all works but no-one likes to let on, so staff watch one another surreptitiously for clues about the hand-drier and door locks, a bit like watching other diners to see which knife to use in a posh restaurant. There are no knobs, switches or lids visible to the naked eye. If you manage to suss out the well-concealed paper towel dispenser you will never find the bin to put it in and will probably emerge with a couple stored in your handbag, to throw away once you get home. Image is all in this company. If you want to impress this boss make sure you sport a pair of weirdo designer-frame specs and a palm-size laptop. The pamper parlour This toilet is like a celebration of womanhood. Every need is catered for, including some you never knew you might have. There are perfume sprays, sewing kits, hand-cream dispensers, hair combs, machines selling tights and an industrial skip-load of personal hygiene products. By providing everything in the one small area the idea is that nothing bad leaks out back in the office, like laddered tights or dandruff. webTitle: Halifax to give away Wap phones

fields.headline: Halifax to give away Wap phones
fields.standfirst:
Halifax
E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Halifax is aiming to almost double the number of Wap (wireless application protocol) phones in the public's hands as it tries to entice customers to its new internet bank with the lure of 150,000 of the new mobile gadgets.
fields.body:
Halifax is aiming to almost double the number of Wap (wireless application protocol) phones in the public's hands as it tries to entice customers to its new internet bank with the lure of 150,000 of the new mobile gadgets.

The phones will be handed out by Intelligent Finance (If), Halifax's electronic bank, which is due to launch in early July. Describing the deal as "earthshattering", If said it had the stash of Wap phones, of which there are only 200,000 currently available, as a result of an agreement with BT Cellnet.

Jim Spowart, chief executive of If, said customers could pre-register for the phones from the time of yesterday's announcement. They will be sent to the first 150,000 customers who open current accounts into which salaries are paid, and who are also holders of If credit cards.

None of the terms of the If products are yet released, although the bank tantalised its rivals yesterday by promising it would be making a number of announcements between now and the launch.

The move to offer Wap phones, worth approximately £100 each, comes amid a race by the banks to win new customers, particularly over the internet. It also typifies attempts by the former building societies, whose customers are traditionally in the mortgage and savings areas, to try to lure current account customers from the "big four" clearing banks who between them control 80% of current accounts in the country.

Mr Spowart, who joined Halifax after setting up Standard Life's bank, has a target for 500,000 in the first year of operation. He insisted that the move to offer Wap phones was not a cheap gimmick and promised that his five products would be extremely competitive and unique.

Wap phones allow users to access the internet, and BT Cellnet, which is supplying the phones free to Halifax, predicts that by 2003 more people will access the internet by phone than by personal computer.

If, which is planning a £20m advertising campaign, is only one part of Halifax's plan to boost the number of its 2m current account customers. It also has a Halifax-branded internet site which it said was receiving 5,000 new customers, not all for current accounts, each week.

The announcement by If followed Abbey National's attempt to boost its current account business by launching a new internet banking service. If is not the first bank to offer Wap services - Woolwich already such a banking facility.

Halifax's shares gained 31p to 597p yesterday while Abbey National, also buoyed by speculation about a bid by Barclays, rose by 26.5p to 775.5p.

fields.headline: Perpetual admits £1.25bn bid talks
fields.trailText: Perpetual is waiting for a queue of suitors to form at its door after announcing last night that it is in talks about being taken over.
fields.body:
Perpetual is waiting for a queue of suitors to form at its door after announcing last night that it is in talks about being taken over.

Shares in the fund management group jumped by 18% after it publicly acknowledged the negotiations.

Any deal could not be agreed without the support of Martin Arbib - who founded the firm in 1974 - and his family. Together they control 45% of the group, which is based at Henley-on-Thames, Berkshire. The news lifted the paper value of their stake by more than £75m to £525m.

Amvescap, the largest public fund management group listed on the London stock market, was reported to be in talks with Perpetual, but it is understood not to be the only interested bidder.

In a stock exchange announcement forced by press speculation, Perpetual was careful not to reveal the identity of its bidder.

For its part, Amvescap made no mention of any interest in Perpetual in an announcement of its own confirming that it is in discussions about buying Trimark Financial Corporation of Canada.

Perpetual, the subject of regular takeover rumours, is expected by City analysts to command a price tag of at least £1.25bn.

Roger Cornick, deputy chairman of Perpetual, said that the group was interested in any potential bidders revealing themselves - and he indicated that the current takeover talks might not be restricted to a single bidder.

"What I think will emerge from these circumstances is that - if there is somebody who wants to acquire us - they will put their hand up or forever hold their peace," said Mr Cornick.

Mr Cornick indicated that Mr Arbib, who remains in day-to-day control of the company, was in no hurry to sell.

"I think Martin Arbib's concerns are that the expectations of investors are met, that there is a stable future for staff and value of shareholders," Mr Cornick said.

The advantage of having a stable, supportive owner meant that the group need not be forced to sell out to the wrong bidder.

"We've always said we see ourselves as an independent company going forward," he said.

Perpetual made its stellar reputation selling personal equity plans in the 1990s, although Mr Arbib, who has homes in Henley and Barbados, has reduced his stake in in recent years.

The fund manager has been dogged by takeover speculation since its closest rival, Jupiter, was bought by Commerzbank of Germany. Over the years, Perpetual's name has been linked with suitors as diverse as NatWest and Goldman Sachs.

While Perpetual's shares rose yesterday, Amvescap suffered an 8% fall in its share price, with investors apparently worried that it might be enticed to pay too much for Perpetual.

The Atlanta-based fund management group is best-known in the UK for its Invesco funds.

fields.headline: Standard Life group campaign
fields.trailText: A group of Standard Life policyholders yesterday launched a campaign against carpetbaggers who want the company to float on the stock market.
fields.body:
A group of Standard Life policyholders yesterday launched a campaign against carpetbaggers who want the company to float on the stock market.

The Standard Life Independent Members Organisation (theslim.org) says ending mutual status would damage the bonuses paid out to policyholders and be bad for investors.

A rival body claims windfalls worth up to £5,000 would be paid to its 2.3m policyholders if the company is floated.

fields.headline: Riotous virtuosity
fields.standfirst: Kirov Orchestra/ Valery Gergiev Royal Festival Hall, London ****
fields.trailText: Kirov Orchestra/ Valery Gergiev Royal Festival Hall, London ****
fields.body:
It sometimes seems crass to talk of a direct link between the music of a particular country and the characteristics of its national performance traditions. But throughout the Kirov Orchestra and Valery Gergiev's concert, it was impossible even to consider that Prokofiev, Mussorgsky, Liadov and Tchaikovsky could have written their music with any other orchestral sound in mind.

The Kirov's ensemble is full of bold contrasts between a voluminous brass sound, reedy, rough-edged woodwinds and vigorously forthright strings. Its collective sound matches precisely the broad brushstrokes of music like Prokofiev's ballet Le Pas d'Acier. A partly propagandist vision of the ceaseless industry of post-revolutionary Russia, Prokofiev's music originally accompanied choreography of parading commissars and citizens, and the activity of Russian factories. His orchestration is similarly utilitarian, with instruments assigned single, repetitive tasks.

Chout (The Buffoon), another of Prokofiev's ballet scores written for Diaghilev, tells a grimly improbable tale of a man who tries to sell his fellow villagers a whip that resurrects the dead. The story inspired some of Prokofiev's most gleefully barbaric music, and allowed the Kirov players and Gergiev to show off their riotous virtuosity.

The furious drive of Gergiev's approach to Prokofiev also defined his performance of Rimsky-Korsakov's famous arrangement of Mussorgsky's Night on the Bare Mountain, which glowered with dark, obsessive intensity. There was more occult mystique in Liadov's Kikimora. Possibly influenced by Dukas's L'Apprenti Sorcier, Liadov depicts sorcery with a monothematic texture and arcane bassoon interjections.

But the touchstones for musical representations of Russian fairy tales are Tchaikovsky's three great ballets. Gergiev presented the final act of The Sleeping Beauty. This was an exceptional performance, despite a horribly out-of-tune piano.

Gergiev's interpretation of The Sleeping Beauty was underpinned by a symphonic seriousness of purpose. He characterised the often tiny dances with a thrilling rhythmic vitality, while maintaining a sure grip of the ballet's overall shape. The climactic pas de deux and concluding Apotheosis were charged with both vivid attention to detail and clinching structural significance. Diaghilev introduced The Sleeping Beauty to western audiences in London in 1921, and the effect of this performance was as illuminating as those first performances must have been.

webTitle: 'Problem' at top of ICC, fears MacLaurin

fields.headline: 'Problem' at top of ICC, fears MacLaurin
fields.trailText: Lord MacLaurin admitted yesterday that the ICC "has a problem" if documents alleging that David Richards, the CEO, and Jagmohan Dalmiya, the president, were involved in negotiating television rights for a one-day tournament prove to be irrefutable.
fields.body:
Lord MacLaurin, the chairman of the England and Wales Cricket Board, admitted yesterday that the International Cricket Council "has a problem" if documents alleging that David Richards, the chief executive officer, and Jagmohan Dalmiya, the president, were involved in negotiating television rights for a one-day tournament prove to be irrefutable.

A report from Doordarshan, the Indian state broadcaster, contradicts Richards' statement last week denying categorically that Dalmiya had been involved in negotiations over the rights to televise the ICC knockout tournament held in Bangladesh in October 1998.

Dalmiya had been on the receiving end of previous allegations emanating from India about the part that he played in the negotiations. The ICC president has vehemently denied any wrongdoing and has instigated legal proceedings against a Doordarshan consultant who had been called in to investigate what the company suspected were irregularities in the negotiations.

A report written on March 10 1998 by Rakesh Bahadur, who was then deputy director-general (commercial and sports) of Doordarshan, suggests that not only was Dalmiya involved in the negotiations with the television service and the three other companies - TWI, WorldTel and CSI - who were bidding for the rights but that Richards was aware of this and was actually involved in the process himself.

In the course of his letter, Bahadur says: "It had become very clear in Calcutta that TWI were also going to increase their bid amount and Mr Bill Sindrich of TWI, London was constantly in touch with Mr Dalmia [sic].

"The revenue-sharing formula was arrived at after consultations with Mr Dalmia and as per his advice.The revised bid offer was acceptable to ICC and communication to this effect was given by Mr Dalmia on 5th March 1998.

"Mr Richards went over the bid clause by clause and sought clarifications wherever required. He then suggested that I should follow up the negotiations with President, ICC Mr Jagmohan Dalmia at Calcutta."

The authenticity of the report has been vouched for by Doordarshan's deputy director-general (finance) P K Seth and the chief executive officer at the time, S S Gill, both of whom countersigned the 27-page document, and by Gill's successor as CEO, Dr K Ajarwal, who confirmed as much from New Delhi on Sunday.

MacLaurin said yesterday that the report would be circulated to the members of the ICC for discussion.

"It's clear we have a problem now," he said. "We had no idea about this when Mr Richards put out the statement on behalf of Mr Dalmiya, or indeed until after the meeting had finished.

"I have to look at the information available and share that with my colleagues on the board and then see where we go from there.

"We need to see the report and I understand it is on its way. It will be circularised to board members and then under Malcolm Gray, because he is the deputy president, the board can take any decision that it sees fit.

"I think it is fair to say though that if the subsequent evidence comes out and it is irrefutable evidence that the press and public have been misinformed, then we have a problem."

Dalmiya, along with all the other delegates at last week's emergency meeting of the ICC, signed a declaration of integrity. His three-year term of office ends next month, when he is due to be succeeded by Gray.

 India's coach and former test captain Kapil Dev was reduced to tears as he denied match-rigging allegations in a television interview to be shown on BBC1's On Side programme on Wednesday. Kapil has begun legal action against Inderjit Singh Bindra, a former president of India's Board of Control for Cricket, over the accusations.

fields.headline: McGrath relishes beef with Yorkshire
fields.standfirst:
Worcs 173-8 Yorks 164-9
Worcs win by nine runs
fields.trailText: Worcs 173-8 Yorks 164-9 Worcs win by nine runs
fields.body:
For two disgruntled umpires, the phrase "The Headingley Experience" meant only the name of the ground's official caterers, who refused them their complimentary hot lunch and caused them to stalk off to the committee room vowing that there would be no game unless they found one.

For Yorkshire's players, "The Headingley Experience" had equally disagreeable connotations. It meant a second meeting in a week with Glenn McGrath, the Australian fast bowler, whose idea of a National League frolic is to trap fingers against bat handles with deliveries that would not look out of place in the final throes of an Ashes test.

Yorkshire were entirely preoccupied with the threat of McGrath, who had returned 9-6-9-4 at New Road a week earlier but still finished on the losing side. This time he had to settle for two for 22, but ensured revenge all the same.

Yorkshire's innings remained in abeyance until McGrath's new-ball spell had finished. David Byas struck a boundary through midwicket that irked McGrath, so much that he immediately had Byas caught at the wicket and then ran out Craig White from long leg.

McGrath's two overs in mid-innings coincided with further subsidence, although this time it was caused by the slow left-arm of Richard Illingworth, who for all his lengthy exile remains the essence of Yorkshire tenacity. Richard Blakey slog-swept to deep midwicket, Darren Lehmann edged to Rhodes, and Illingworth allowed himself a gruff word and an unflinching frown by way of celebration.

Matthew Wood had shown a welcome return to form with a championship century against Derbyshire in the week, but any assumptions that his luck had turned were disproved by a brief burst of malevolence from the pitch, as David Leatherdale reared one into Wood's helmet and then had him lbw on the bootstraps.

That Yorkshire got so close owed much to a striking debut from Victor Craven, a sturdy 19-year-old left-hander from Harrogate, whose 28 from 33 balls ended with Reuben Spiring's catch against the midwicket boards and an ovation.

Worcestershire's innings was hurried along in its early stages by the left-arm seam of Ryan Sidebottom. His three free-range overs for 37 were chiefly responsible for bringing Yorkshire's chickens home to roost.

webTitle: Jacobs run-out helps Pakistan wrest control

fields.headline: Jacobs run-out helps Pakistan wrest control
fields.standfirst: Pakistan 288 West Indies 174-6
fields.trailText: Pakistan 288 West Indies 174-6
fields.body:
Even with the whole morning session lost to rain, the West Indies were finding it difficult to bat out the third day of the first test against Pakistan at Bourda yesterday.

Shortly before tea, with the score on 174 for six, and on a wicket good enough to allow the Pakistanis to recover from 39 for five to 288 all out, the fragility of the West Indies batting had once more been exposed by good spin and pace bowling and, on at least one occasion, even without any bowling at all.

A training manual communication error between Shivnarine Chanderpaul, taking the strike on his home ground, and the wicketkeeper Ridley Jacobs, the last of the recognised batsmen at the bowler's end, had the latter run out so easily that he did not even attempt to get back to the non-striker's end.

Chanderpaul never took his eyes off the ball as it ran down to short third man until Jacobs was standing next to him.

The first time the batsmen looked at each other was immediately before Jacobs turned to walk back fretfully to the pavilion.

A run-out was a luxury the West Indies could not afford, far less one that could have shattered the team spirit so carefully nurtured by the new captain Jimmy Adams, and particularly after Adams, batting solidly and confidently yesterday, was out to a spectacular catch by Younis Khan in the slips in the first over of the day.

With Pakistan's captain Moin Khan having the choice of high-quality spin and pace from Mushtaq Ahmed, Wasim Akram and Abdur Razzaq, who on Saturday fell 13 runs short of a maiden test century, it was challenging enough not to be out to the bowling.

The other wicket to go before tea, that of Chris Gayle, also went far more easily than it ought to have with the score on 130 and four wickets down.

The ball hung in the air long enough for Wasim Akram to brew a cup of tea before taking an easy catch at mid-off.

Chanderpaul, whose last innings on his home ground produced a century, had his work cut out to turn the game back towards the West Indies.

Hometown support was solidly behind him, though. In Guyana, touring Indian and Pakistani teams can often find strong backing among the local Asian population, but Moin Khan's team managed to alienate the crowd by continuous appealing when batsmen were plainly not out.

webTitle: Still boring after all these years

fields.headline: Still boring after all these years
fields.trailText: Martin Kelner on the end of the season: "When the videprinter becomes the most effective instrument of torture since the rack was invented."
fields.body:
There is a lot to be said for Mark Lawrenson's view that in a world in which millions of people go hungry, and millions more suffer acts of unspeakable cruelty, the scoring or missing of a goal in a football match is an irrelevance it almost demeans us to discuss.

Actually, that may not be the view of the Mark Lawrenson you see on Match of the Day, but the Mark Lawrenson who appears on Alistair McGowan's Big Impression is frankly sick and tired of soccer and everyone involved in it. Invited by Gary Lineker, whom McGowan mimics with unerring accuracy, to enthuse over some piece of outrageous skill, Lawrenson is inclined to shrug and ask, "What's the point of it all?"

Although the impersonation neither looks nor sounds particularly like the former Liverpool defender, it is a brilliant piece of work, an impression rather than an impersonation. McGowan has cleverly picked up on a certain world-weariness in Lawrenson's voice, and taken it to its logical but ridiculous extreme.

What is worrying is that I frequently find myself nodding in agreement with the pretend Lawrenson, particularly at this time of the season when the level of hysteria surrounding soccer is turned up a notch as promotion and relegation issues are settled.

Am I alone, for instance, in remaining utterly unmoved by the question of when and if Wimbledon will recover their legendary "spirit", which apparently involves a certain amount of gung-ho football, but rather more mooning out of the coach window on the journey back from away matches?

"Wimbledon are the gang that aren't crazy any more," lamented Garth Crooks on Football Focus. On Sky's Hold The Back Page, journalists David Lacey, Joe Lovejoy and Paul Hayward agreed that a contributory factor to Egil Olsen's demise may have been his unaccountable inability to see the funny side of having lemonade poured over his head, or whatever it is Wimbledon's Crazy Gang are reputed to do.

Olsen also baffled the players with strange tactics, said Lovejoy, of the Sunday Times. "There's nothing particularly complicated about zonal defence," sniffed my colleague David Lacey. Advantages of working for a quality newspaper, you see.

They were still banging on about the Crazy Gang spirit on Radio 5 Live's Sportsweek yesterday, when Sue Thearle took breakfast with Vinnie Jones and John Hartson, and asked the question exercising the nation. Did the last-minute equaliser against Villa mean the Wimbledon spirit was back?

Her other big question concerned the possibility of Vinnie returning to Selhurst Park, God help us, as manager; probably one of the more ridiculous rumours of the week, given the state of Jones's burgeoning film career. To the surprise of those of us who watched Lock, Stock and Two Smoking Barrels and found it only marginally preferable to having all our teeth removed without an anaesthetic, Jones has become a real star.

The man goes fishing with Brad Pitt and Nicolas Cage, so he must really be itching to return to the glamour of Selhurst Park. In the midst of this end-of-season melodrama, though, any rumour or half-baked piece of speculation is liable to be believed.

Sky has a particular problem when the rest of the media starts treating football as a matter of life and death, since they routinely treat it as such all the rest of the time anyway. So Jeff Stelling found himself on Soccer Saturday like the chap in Spinal Tap switching the control on his amplifier up to No11.

"It's an afternoon of dry mouths and sweaty palms," he screamed, "When the videprinter becomes the most effective instrument of torture since the rack was invented." Well, call me old-fashioned but I should say that device for attaching your genitals to a car battery might possibly just outpoint the videprinter.

It was a close run thing as to who had more completely lost any sense of proportion; Stelling, or the Ipswich fan who phoned Radio 5 Live to say she and her husband had driven from Suffolk up to Lancashire during the week to place a curse on Maine Road and say a prayer at Ewood Park.

I have made the journey from Central Lancs to Ipswich myself, and it is not something to be lightly undertaken, not if those road works are still there, just outside Kings Lynn.

You would have thought the presence of George Best on Soccer Saturday, returning after his recent spell in hospital, might have put soccer into some sort of more realistic perspective for Stelling and his colleagues, but they remained dogged in their pursuit of the "spirit", like it was some sort of Holy Grail.

"Have you found the spirit again?" a breathless reporter asked Wimbledon's caretaker manager Terry Burton after the match. "The spirit is very much alive," replied Burton and a grateful nation sighed.

As Alistair McGowan's Lawrenson might say, "Is it really that important who goes up or down? I mean, who cares?" Although that is not necessarily a point of view I would want to put to an Ipswich Town fan.

webTitle: Gallant Calais deprived by controversial penalty

fields.headline: Gallant Calais deprived by controversial penalty
fields.trailText: Juventus stayed on course for a record 26th Serie A title when they beat Parma 1-0 yesterday thanks to a header from Alessandro Del Piero.
fields.body:
Antoine Sibierski scored twice, including the winner with a controversial 90th-minute penalty, to give the holders Nantes a 2-1 victory over Calais of the Fourth Division in the French Cup final at the Stade de France last night.

Calais, who beat two First Division sides including the then league champions Bordeaux on their way to the final, went in at half-time one up after their winger Jérme Dutitre had given them a 34th-minute lead.

Sibierski brought Nantes back into the game with a 50th-minute equaliser before bringing Calais' cup run to an end with the winner after the substitute Alain Caveglia had executed the most outrageous of dives in the penalty area and the referee pointed to the spot.

Juventus stayed on course for a record 26th Serie A title when they beat Parma 1-0 yesterday, thanks to a header from Alessandro Del Piero, the injury-prone striker's first goal from open play since October 1998. Juventus now go into the last game of the season with a two-point lead over Lazio, who beat Bologna 3-2.

Croydon completed the women's double by clinching the league title with a 6-0 win over Aston Villa, a week after beating Doncaster Belles in the cup final. Tara Proctor, Joanne Broadhurst and Carmaine Walker each scored twice in the first half.

Deal Town won the FA Vase at Wembley, the midfielder Roly Graham scoring with an 87th-minute volley.

The final of the Carlsberg Pub Cup, also played at Wembley on Saturday, was won 2-1 by The Victoria, from the tiny village of Earl Soham in Suffolk.

fields.headline: 'We've always had Premiership supporters'
fields.standfirst: Manager Joe Royle pays tribute to the loyal and long-suffering blue army
fields.trailText: Manager Joe Royle pays tribute to the loyal and long-suffering blue army.
fields.body:
When the prize was taken, the hundreds of Manchester City supporters who had been locked out and had watched from a steep bank with a squinty view of one penalty area, swept down towards the ground in a scene stolen from Braveheart.

They charged the gates like revolutionaries and shared their noisy ecstasy with those within, who officially numbered 6,000 but were in reality about twice that.

At the final whistle they flooded the ground like a tide of light blue water, covering the playing area. The great thing about being Manchester City is that every match is a home fixture.

City, though, the "cock-up kings" according to their former chairman Franny Lee, have shot themselves in the foot on so many occasions that they take the field with a heavy limp.

Under Alan Ball, the manager born with a wooden spoon in his mouth, they once took the ball into the corner to play out time during a 2-2 draw with Liverpool. A point, they thought, would be enough. It wasn't and they were relegated.

This explains why their supporters have developed a nice line in black humour. It is dry and wry, gloomy and phlegmatic. The mood is darker and deeper than at probably any other club. There is a persevering masochism here. They appear to have been coached by the followers of the England cricket team.

Their manager, Joe Royle, has some humour too. "We're runaway second," he quipped yesterday. "We played like pigs in labour. But some pigs fly. After all that's happened to this club I think we deserved a kiss from Lady Luck.

"We have always had Premiership supporters. Now we have Premiership football too."

Their supporters watched this match with a sort of referred pain as the news of Ipswich's match against Walsall came in through their headsets.

Either side of half-time it all started to go wrong. First Matt Jansen, the best player on the pitch, scored for the clearly superior Blackburn side.

Just after the break Blackburn hit the woodwork twice, to add to their two timber-rattling efforts of the first half. And then came the terrible news from Portman Road: Ipswich were winning.

At this point any football crowd worth its salt and inflatable bananas would have hurled noisy abuse at its players. Instead, City's looked glumly at their boots and exchanged fatalistic shrugs.

But once Shaun Goater volleyed City level the light blue masses pulled off their shirts and shouted their support and an unlikely confidence coursed through the visiting side.

Great club. Great supporters. Top manager. Pity about the team. There is a shortage of real talent, if you except the goalkeeper Nicky Weaver, Mark Kennedy and Gerard Wiekens, the latter not figuring in yesterday's line-up.

Their defence is also elderly and ponderous. Yesterday, when attacked directly and at pace, they appeared static and bewildered.

It is reasonable to assume City would not have made it without their supporters, who averaged over 28,000 in the Second Division last season. They are a miracle.

Royle, who played for the 70s City side against the likes of Juventus, was known as Cadbury in those days because of his soft centre. Yesterday he again showed his softer side.

Richard Jobson said: "We were awful in the first half. But the boss didn't rant and rave. He told us we still had 45 minutes to rescue it."

webTitle: Watford smile their way to relegation

fields.headline: Watford smile their way to relegation
fields.trailText: Middlesbrough 1 - 1 Watford
fields.body:
A banner unfurled by Watford fans before the game proclaimed: "We're out of your league!" It was from the celebrations 12 months ago when Premiership status was achieved, and had become newly appropriate now that Graham Taylor's team is heading back to the First Division. At least, as the diehard Hornets supporters sang, they are "going down with a smile".

Middlesbrough supporters might have been able to raise a grin, too, if they could have felt confident that Juninho, on loan from Atletico Madrid, will still be around next season. A pre-match poll showed they have made his signing Robson's No1 priority as he prepares to spend up to £20m on new players.

Juninho has indicated he is prepared to stay. "I am very comfortable here," he said. "The manager gave me the chance to play again. I just wanted to play. After the season, I will sit down and talk about what is best for the club and best for Juninho."

The away fans' antics at least eased the tedium of an opening half-hour before Watford displayed the type of dreadful defending that has seen them concede 77 goals in the Premiership.

The Middlesbrough defender Robbie Stockdale harried David Perpetuini into an underhit back-pass that induced a collision between the two players and the goalkeeper Chris Day. Stockdale recovered best to force in his first Boro goal, but even he resisted elaborate celebrations, settling for an embarrassed shrug.

Darren Ward's first goal for Watford in the 68th minute brought a deserved equaliser and added to Taylor's conviction that despite such a poor season his players are going down with a number of plus points to their credit.

He is also happy at least to be battling for promotion back to the Premiership with the club on a sound financial footing. Watford's playful fans, who brought a smile to a chill north-east afternoon, will probably be glad to clutch at that straw too.

webTitle: Title deeds merely whet Ferguson's appetite

fields.headline: Title deeds merely whet Ferguson's appetite
fields.trailText: Man Utd 3 - 1 Tottenham
fields.body:
They raised their scarves and voices dutifully, screaming out their approval as if this was a sudden unexpected triumph rather than the latest act of serial winners.

It was a familiar sight. As if to hint that summer is reluctantly on its way, the sun blazed down from unbroken skies as, sweat-stained but beaming, Roy Keane accepted the trophy and it was held high.

Fleetingly it did not matter that a sixth Premiership title in eight years had been won without apparent discomfort. And the sight of a content bunch of footballers hand in hand with their bemused offspring was more than sufficient to engender scenes of mild pandemonium.

And yet, amid the euphoria, you could still sense a certain hollowness. It was not sufficiently potent to ruin the day but tangible enough, just, to cause even the most joyous of smiles to droop at the edges.

Winning domestic honours may be what Sir Alex Ferguson's players do best but it is not what they want to do most. A decidedly sloppy performance at home to Real Madrid last month and the Champions Cup was surrendered; it ensured that what followed would be deemed an anticlimax.

It is continuity in the European arena which the United manager will need to provide if he is to slip into retirement hailed as a legend rather than merely feted as the man who returned grandiose entertainment to the Theatre of Dreams.

And afterwards he gave his first indication that he would like to extend his stay rather than slip quietly into retirement once his current contract expires. "I'd like to stay here after my current two years are up," he admitted. "If it is time to move on I have no problem with that, but it would be nice to play some part and remain attached to the club.

"I will remain in football and I've already had a few offers along those lines."

Of course the game itself was to become fodder for the orgy of self-congratulation that this sort of party invariably comes to represent, each rapier thrust by United, be it from central midfield or down the flanks, simply serving to ratchet up the fervour.

Tottenham, for whom David Ginola did not feature even on the bench, presumably for his recent remarks about about the club's second-class status, were out of their depth and nervously treading water from the off. Unable to halt the progress of David Beckham down the right and Ryan Giggs on the left, the white shirts gave themselves up to the inevitable.

Sol Campbell kept his finger in the dam for as long as he could but United's finishing was again exquisite and long before the interval all the arguments had been decided in the hosts' favour. After Ole Gunnar Solskjaer had risen to head home at the far post, Beckham steered a real belter into the top corner. It was a goal of vision and artistry which drew rich applause from the watching Eric Cantona.

Punctuating those goals was Tottenham's one meaningful contribution, Chris Armstrong's flashing header from Darren Anderton's fine cross. Briefly Tottenham hinted at further resistance but once their old boy Teddy Sheringham had fired a ferocious drive beneath the crossbar after Solskjaer had outfoxed the otherwise solid Chris Perry they did not seem bothered.

Ginola was, though, and said as much later. "Playing against the best teams brings out the best in me and we all know they don't come any bigger than Manchester United. I am bitterly disappointed.

"I have to ask myself why the management don't pick me for the big games, why don't they want me? The only other time I have been dropped this season was for our biggest game so far, when we played Kaiserslautern in the Uefa Cup." They lost that one too.
