fields.headline: Ternent intoxicated by Clarets
fields.trailText: Scunthorpe 1 - 2 Burnley
fields.body:
The Burnley manager Stan Ternent projects a tough image at times but the facade cracked as the Clarets returned to the First Division after a five-year absence. They are promoted at the expense of Gillingham who are in the play-offs for the second successive year and blew their chance of automatic promotion after losing 1-0 at Wrexham.

Burnley is Ternent's first and probably last football love. He made his league debut for them as a player 33 years ago and has always kept his connection with the town, despite working at Crystal Palace, Chelsea and Bury as a coach and manager.

His voice faltered as he described his feelings about the triumph and eventually, after being hoisted shoulder-high and losing his shirt to celebrating fans who had invaded the pitch and stands, he shook his head at further questions and retired to the privacy of the dressing room.

It is Ternent's third promotion in five years but this one means a little more than the two he achieved at Bury, with the manager describing it as the proudest day in his football life. But it was left to the much-travelled striker Ronnie Jepson, signed by Ternent more than once, to put it into perspective.

"When he arrived the place was in a mess," said the 36-year-old. "I've been at a few clubs in my time and one or two had problems but I'd never seen anything like this. The gaffer had to sort it all out and it's not been easy. I think they were close to sacking him once or twice, and maybe he was ready to walk out at times, but they stuck with him and they were right. He lives and breathes Burnley, this job is his life."

Ternent's first task may now be to persuade Ian Wright to spend next season at Turf Moor although after the game the former Arsenal striker for once declined to talk.

Despite falling behind to Mark McGregor's spectacular 30-yard effort in the 11th minute, Gillingham had plenty of opportunities to seal the three points they needed. Gillingham's manager Peter Taylor said: "We had too many people who let the occasion get to them. At the moment everyone is feeling down and sorry for themselves but by the time we play Stoke next week we will have picked ourselves up."

webTitle: Tent caves in on Smith's flying circus

fields.headline: Tent caves in on Smith's flying circus
fields.standfirst: Chester's fall is marked by fallings-out between owner and managers
fields.trailText: Chester 0 - 1 Peterborough
fields.byline: Dominic Fifield at the Deva stadium
fields.body:
In the end there was no fairytale ending, no wild scenes of hysteria - and no consoling the home supporters. Only despair.

"Two goals, that was all it took," sighed one fan. "How many times did we hit the woodwork this season? Why is this happening?"

Chester began this match one off the foot of the league, their destiny in their own hands. They ended it bottom on goal difference and, after 69 years, a non-league club. As their manager Ian Atkins conceded: "It just wasn't to be."

In truth the writing was on the wall during an excruciating build-up which was perversely cheerful, horribly premature. The Tannoy announcer wished Peterborough luck in the play-off in a veiled plea to let City prevail here, adding: "This could be a wonderful day."

For an hour of this game Chester were home and dry. News that Brighton had scored against Carlisle and that Exeter were taming the Shrews brightened a nerve-racking first half. At the interval Chester had effectively climbed to 22nd in the division. Supporters basked in the sunshine. It took only five minutes to shatter their world.

First, news arrived that Exeter's goalkeeper had thrown into his own goal, quickly followed by Mickey Brown adding a more conventional second. As anxiety spread, Peterborough replaced Zat Knight with Ritchie Hanlon.

Never has a substitute's first touch been so devastating, Hanlon rifling a shot wide of Wayne Brown in the Chester goal. There was a collective intake of breath as the ball struck the left-hand post, a split-second of wild expectation as it promised to ricochet to safety, then utter despair as the spin took it in. City had dropped two places in the blink of an eye.

Then, with seconds remaining, rumours of salvation spread like wildfire. Exeter had tied it up: it was 2-2 and City were alive. As the stands erupted in hope, Paul Carden hit the visitors' bar. But even as the ball bounced into touch, reality dawned. The whistle sounded and the terrible truth filtered through from Devon. "I hope whoever spread that rumour feels proud of himself," sighed the distraught Tannoy.

The Deva, swollen by a crowd of 4,905, sang in defiance. Some vented their anger at Terry Smith, the American who took Chester from the brink of extinction and transformed them into a viable business, only for his five-month stint as manager prior to Atkins' arrival to leave City with four wins in 24 games and propping up the table. "It was a complete circus," said Brown.

Sitting hunched in the boardroom, Smith appeared to have lost sight of reality. "I don't think today affects the long-term future," said the former American football coach. "The Conference is a tremendous league. We've achieved 10 of the 11 goals I set at the start of the season." The 11th was promotion to the Second .

Atkins had failed, he said. "The club has spent massive amounts of money signing 12 players since January, doubling our player wage bill."

"We haven't spent a penny and resources have been tight," retorted Atkins, a member of Shrewsbury's most successful side. "I couldn't have done any more."

Smith faces his former manager Kevin Ratcliffe at a Football League tribunal today, when the man who led the Shrews to safety seeks £200,000 in outstanding compensation from his time at the Deva. It is hard to envisage just where Chester can find such money. Or, indeed, much hope.

fields.headline: Shadow over Swans' triumph
fields.trailText: Rotherham 1 - 1 Swansea
fields.body:
The death of a Swansea supporter on Saturday night after he was trampled by a police horse outside the ground before the match rendered grotesque and inconsequential the between-times battle for the divisional title.

Fighting with bricks and sticks broke out before and after the match and play was held up twice in the closing stages as police - some mounted, others with riot shields - kept fans apart and cleared two pitch invasions.

There were 23 arrests, mostly for public-order offences. The fatal injury occurred near 2.30pm, about the time the Rotherham manager Ronnie Moore, out on the pitch, was celebrating promotion by signing a new three-year contract. It sealed the success of the two Ronnies: Moore the striker also gained promotion with Rotherham.

The club owe as much to their chairman Ken Booth, who balances their books with £10,000 a week. It would be cheap to suggest that he makes his money from scrap and gives it to rubbish. The match was a mess but Rotherham played the more adventurous football.

fields.headline: Rams stay in the fold
fields.trailText: Derby 0 - 0 Newcastle
fields.body:
When Bobby Robson replaced Ruud Gullit as manager of the struggling Magpies back in September he seriously thought the club's Premiership future would depend on the last weekend of the season.

But a run worthy of a top-seven team, despite a stack of injuries, has lifted Newcastle to a respectable position. Mid-table obscurity? Not if you're a Geordie diehard.

Rather than Robson feeling end-of-season jitters it was his friend of 30 years Jim Smith, Derby's manager, who faced the threat of relegation, which was finally lifted by this draw and by results elsewhere going the Rams' way.

Robson did not begrudge Smith the point after a drab display by Newcastle. "Quite frankly it hasn't hurt me too much today for Jim to get a point," he said. "He's always worked within financial constraints, always out of the glamour of the big clubs."

Derby's 10 home defeats, the worst record in the Premiership after Watford and Sheffield Wednesday, hobbled them after last season's eighth-place finish. "I must admit I was relieved when I knew that Leicester were leading 2-0 with 20 minutes to go," Smith said. "We never really felt in the second half of the season that we would go down but when you keep losing at home it's hard to turn things round."

There are promising signs, however. The striker Malcolm Christie is surely a star of the future and on Saturday Smith introduced another of his crop of young players, the 18-year-old Adam Murray, who had a fine debut. And Georgi Kinkladze, until he went off injured at half-time, looked as though he had regained his appetite for English football, with several defence-splitting runs.

webTitle: Kev gives Kev a choice message

fields.headline: Kev gives Kev a choice message
fields.trailText: Sunderland 1 - 0 West Ham
fields.byline: Adam Sills at the Stadium of Light
fields.body:
If Kevin Keegan allowed himself a self-satisfied smile when Sunderland's fans started chanting "England's No1" it must quickly have turned into a frown when he realised that the object of their passion was not the coach but the man who would be King Kev of Euro 2000.

For Kevin Phillips is undoubtedly ready to announce his talent to the world in the Netherlands and Belgium, yet incredibly there is still doubt whether Keegan, an onlooker here, will give him the chance.

The striker has scored 30 goals in 35 games; only Andy Cole and Alan Shearer have scored more in the Premiership since its inception. But he remains, it seems, in a queue behind Shearer, Emile Heskey, Robbie Fowler and Michael Owen, jostling for position with Cole for the final striking place in Keegan's squad of 22.

"The manager told me at half-time that Kevin Keegan was here and I thought I had a good game so hopefully he's gone away with some positive thoughts," he said.

What is more likely is that Phillips's flying form and versatility muddled Keegan's mind still further by giving him another possibility to mull over.

With Niall Quinn as his partner for the majority of the first half, Phillips caused mayhem in West Ham's defence and the dominance of the home side was confirmed after 14 minutes when he released Nicky Summerbee and converted the winger's return cross with a powerful header.

Harry Redknapp immediately switched to four at the back to try to nullify the threat but Phillips reiterated his case for an England place after Quinn's departure with a knee injury, when he had to seize the initiative himself.

He has been the main inspiration behind Sunderland's highest league finish for 45 years, but Saturday's party might have been spoiled when Paolo di Canio was bundled over by Chris Makin in the box. Redknapp was rightly convinced his side should have been awarded a penalty but he did not wish to take any credit away from the opposing striker.

"His goalscoring ability and enthusiasm make him an excellent player," he said. Phillips and the Sunderland faithful have done all they can to make Keegan think likewise.

webTitle: Handyman Sorvel gets out Crewe's do-it-yourself survival kit

fields.headline: Handyman Sorvel gets out Crewe's do-it-yourself survival kit
fields.trailText: Barnsley 0 - 2 Crewe
fields.body:
Crewe successfully used their do-it-yourself survival kit yesterday against a Barnsley side apparently happy to take things easy before the serious business of the play-offs starts.

Neil Sorvel, who scored the first and made the second for Rob Hulse, was once released but was re-employed in a Bosman signing after an impressive spell at Macclesfield. Yesterday's performance alone justified the decision of his manager Dario Gradi.

Avoiding relegation became largely academic when Sorvel volleyed a sharp, angled effort from 15 yards after Rodney Jack had opened up the chance.

By that time the pressure on Crewe had been eased by Ipswich putting Walsall under the cosh at Portman Road, but they made sure of another First Division season with a second when Hulse, who had been on the pitch as a substitute for only three minutes, lashed in a ball from Sorvel.

"It doesn't get any easier," said Gradi. "This is the hardest it's been since we came up but the players have responded. I told them I needed better players this season and they have been better.

"If we had gone down we might have lost two or three of them but now I don't think that will happen, and if we can strengthen a little we can live a bit easier because we have some exceptional kids."

However, Barnsley's stroll in the sun did not impress Dave Bassett, who had left out Craig Hignett, Neil Shipperley, Steve Chettle and Eric Tinkler.

"I'm not happy and I've told them in no uncertain terms," he said. "If some of these players are left out of the play-offs they can't knock on the door and complain. But a bit of it might be my fault. I've been easy in training and maybe they all got the deck chairs out."

webTitle: Guide us, Brown, thou great redeemer

fields.headline: Guide us, Brown, thou great redeemer
fields.trailText: Exeter 1 - 2 Shrewsbury
fields.body:
We got on the scrumpy and did not return home until noon yesterday, bleary, unshaven and relieved. For offshoots of a Congregationalist family that counts as dangerously hard partying. Heavens, we even skipped chapel.

We were celebrating Shrewsbury's worst season in the League - or at least the end of it, the part that one fan's T-shirt prematurely and hyperbolically called "the Great Escape".

Until about 4.15 on Saturday, nothing about it had been great. A team with crocked strikers, a makeshift midfield and an abundance of alarmingly diffident central defenders had won only two of their previous 23 games.

Then on came Mickey Brown. Kevin Ratcliffe's tactical astuteness, which we apologise for ever doubting, this time met with spectacular reward. Within three minutes Shrewsbury were 2-0 up and Brown was claiming both goals.

Ratcliffe had put Brown, a 5ft 9in winger, on for John Gayle, a 6ft 3in centre-forward, brilliantly lulling the Exeter defence into believing they did not have to jump for crosses any more. Brown got his head to the first one he saw and the Exeter goalkeeper Danny Potter - blessings upon him, his family and anyone who knows him - shoved it into the corner of his net.

Forty seconds later Peter Wilding flicked on a corner at the near post and Brown headed the second. My brother, who until that point had maintained a discreet objectivity amid the home supporters, began to leap about with an abandon not seen in our family since we gave up woad.

We had a few anxious moments - Exeter pulled one back and then Gareth Hanmer fouled their substitute, oh, at least three inches outside the penalty area - but the team had just about done enough.

Brown was hoisted on to supporters' shoulders and his kit was claimed by souvenir hunters. Later he signed our programme in an elegant if indecipherable hand, which an hour earlier had been writing club legend.

We do not expect much in the way of success from our team. We expect them to frustrate us and make us despair, and occasionally redeem themselves. By those lights then, our season worked out just fine.

webTitle: Up with the loyal and Royle blues

fields.headline: Up with the loyal and Royle blues
fields.trailText: Bolton 1 - 0 Norwich
fields.byline: Oliver Kay at the Reebok Stadium
fields.body:
When the prize was taken, the hundreds of Manchester City supporters who had been locked out, and had watched from a steep bank with a squinty view of one penalty area, swept down towards the ground in a scene stolen from Braveheart.

They charged the gates like revolutionaries and shared their noisy ecstasy with those within, who officially numbered 6,000 but were in reality about twice that. At the final whistle they flooded the ground like a tide of light blue water. The great thing about being Manchester City is that every match is a home fixture.

City, though, the "cock-up kings" according to their former chairman Franny Lee, have shot themselves in the foot on so many occasions that they take the field with a heavy limp.

Under Alan Ball, the manager born with a wooden spoon in his mouth, they famously took the ball into the corner in 1996 to play out time during a 2-2 draw with Liverpool. A point, they thought, would be enough. It wasn't and they were relegated.

This explains why their supporters have developed a nice line in black humour. It is dry and wry, gloomy and phlegmatic. The mood is darker and deeper than at probably any other club.

Their manager Joe Royle has some humour too. "We're runaway second," he quipped yesterday. "We played like pigs in labour. But some pigs fly. After all that's happened to this club I think we deserved a kiss from Lady Luck.

"We have always had Premiership supporters. Now we have Premiership football too."

Their supporters watched this match with a sort of referred pain as the news of Ipswich's match against Walsall came in.

Either side of half-time it started to go wrong. First Matt Jansen, the best player on the pitch, scored for the clearly superior Blackburn side. Just after the break Blackburn hit the woodwork twice, to add to their two timber-rattling efforts of the first half. And then came the terrible news from Portman Road: Ipswich were winning.

But once Shaun Goater volleyed City level the light blue masses pulled off their shirts and shouted their support and an unlikely confidence coursed through the visiting side.

Great club. Great supporters. Top manager. Pity about the team. There is a shortage of real talent, if you except the goalkeeper Nicky Weaver, Mark Kennedy and Gerard Wiekens, who did not figure in yesterday's line-up.

Their defence is also elderly and ponderous. Yesterday, when attacked directly and at pace, they appeared static and bewildered.

It is reasonable to assume City would not have made it without their supporters, who backed the team with an average attendance of more than 28,000 in the Second Division last season. They are a miracle.

webTitle: Fighting in Freetown as paras arrive to evacuate Britons

fields.headline: Fighting in Freetown as paras arrive to evacuate Britons
fields.trailText:
An advance force of 250 British paratroopers arrived in the Sierra Leonean capital Freetown today to evacuate foreign
nationals if necessary.
fields.body:
An advance force of 250 British paratroopers arrived in the Sierra Leonean capital Freetown today to evacuate foreign nationals if necessary.

Meanwhile a pitched battle erupted around the home of the rebel leader Foday Sankoh after at least 15 peace protesters were shot and wounded there. Some reports said four people had been killed in the fighting.

The fighting, a fresh setback for a UN peacekeeping mission which is struggling to maintain control in the West African country, appeared to pit Sankoh loyalists against fighters from a rival group or groups.

Lieutenant Commander Tony Cramp said the paras were there to stage a "rapid, safe and secure evacuation". He said the British troops would be stationed at Lungi international airport across an estuary from the main city.

Shortly afterwards, fighting erupted around Sankoh's residence on a hill in the west of the city. Rival fighters used automatic weapons and rocket-propelled grenades, triggering a mini-exodus of civilians living nearby.

Sankoh is at the heart of a stand-off with the United Nations, which accuses his men of attacking peacekeepers and of holding up to 500 of its soldiers and support staff hostage inland. Several thousand chanting peacekeepers marched to Sankoh's home carrying placards calling on him to respect a 1999 peace deal that he signed with and the elected President Ahmad Tejan Kabbah. It was not immediately clear who opened fire on the crowd of about 5,000 people but witnesses said that some demonstrators were seriously wounded and at least one may have been killed. Witnesses said that the initial shooting, which lasted two or three minutes, broke out after some protesters started stoning Sankoh's residence.

On the diplomatic front, the regional power broker Nigeria called an emergency summit of Sierra Leone's neighbours for tomorrow.

The UN secretary-general, Kofi Annan, called again today for a rapid reaction force to aid peacekeepers in Sierra Leone and authorised the evacuation of 266 UN civilian staff. Some 500 U.N. peacekeepers are missing or have been taken hostage by the rebel Revolutionary United Front (RUF), 400 of them Zambians.

"The secretary-general continues to stress that, in addition to UN efforts, a rapid reaction force may be needed in Sierra Leone as soon as possible to assist in restoring conditions conducive to the resumption of the peace process," UN spokesman Fred Eckhard said. "The secretary-general also has authorised the relocation of non-essential civilian staff of the UN mission." Some 266 staff will be pulled out while 55 civilian staff will remain.

So far the United States, Britain, France and other European nations have said they will not take part in a rapid reaction force.

fields.headline: Patients 'should not be guinea pigs'
fields.trailText:
A report into hospital ventilator trials during which 28 premature babies died and 15
were left brain-damaged has called for tighter controls to ensure patients are not used as "guinea pigs" in
clinical tests.
fields.body:
A report into hospital ventilator trials during which 28 premature babies died and 15 were left brain-damaged has called for tighter controls to ensure patients are not used as "guinea pigs" in clinical tests.

The report, published today, considered claims from some of the parents of the 122 premature babies involved in the trials that they had not been told the treatment was experimental. It follows a 15-month inquiry into controversial research work involving child patients at the North Staffordshire hospital in Stoke-on-Trent. The inquiry team, led by West Midlands director of public health Professor Rod Griffiths, also recommended new measures to ensure that valid parental consent was obtained.

The report focuses on experimental treatment using a new type of ventilator on 122 premature babies at the hospital, and also deals with separate research involving the controversial covert video surveillance of parents suspected of abusing their children in hospital. The experiment was led by paediatrician Professor David Southall, who was suspended from the hospital in December 1999. Parents of some of the babies claim the results of the experiment do not compare favourably with conventional treatment.

The inquiry team said today that they had referred to the General Medical Council claims that parents' signatures on consent forms had been forged.

The government said today it accepted all the recommendations made in Professor Griffiths' report and had already begun putting them into place.

But health minister Lord Hunt said there still needed to be a "culture change" in the NHS to empower patients.

The Continuous Negative Extrathoracic Pressure (CNEP) ventilator worked by putting babies in low-pressure tanks which forced their lungs to expand, a move intended to aid their breathing.

The inquiry into the research at the hospital was triggered when Llin Golding, Labour MP for Newcastle-under-Lyme, was approached by a family affected by the ventilator treatment. Carl and Debbie Henshall's daughter Stacey died on the machine in February 1992. Her sister Sofie, born in November 1992, suffered brain damage and is permanently disabled. Mr Henshall claimed the couple had never given their consent for the treatment.

Ms Golding met the Henshalls and then approached the Department of Health, which ordered the inquiry.

Another parent, Sharon Bradley, whose autistic son Stephen was put on the ventilator after he was born at 34 weeks, said she had no idea he was going to be involved in a trial. Stephen is unable to speak due to severe autism and learning difficulties, and studies have led his mother to believe his problems are linked to his early treatment. She said: "I was told that this treatment was a safer, gentler method of ventilation - it was less invasive because there were no tubes and it would teach my son to breathe for himself. There was no mention of a trial or experiment."

A spokesman for the Bristol Heart Children Action Group, Steve Parker, said the Staffordshire case highlighted the pressing need for stricter rules on consent. The issues facing the parents were very similar to those faced in Bristol, where dozens of parents learned years after the deaths of their children that doctors had retained hearts and other organs following post mortems.

"All these issues are about the principle of 'informed consent'," he said. "It is all about people knowing what is to done to their child and having the chance to make a decision."

Prof Griffiths told a news conference in Birmingham that he could not say whether or not any child had died or suffered brain damage as a result of the CNEP trials.

He said the children involved were gravely ill and that mortality rates among a similar study group were broadly similar to those in the CNEP trials.

He said research guidance needed to be developed, brought up to date and issued in a bid to retain public confidence in medical research with the NHS.

Prof Griffiths also called for new guidelines to ensure children's welfare is safeguarded during covert surveillance of children deemed at risk of harm from their parents, step-parents or carers, after controversial research showed that 34 out of 39 parents suspected of cruelty to their children had tried to harm them when left alone.

Five parents admitted killing other children and 34 were convicted of offences on evidence from the team, according to reports.

fields.bodyText: A report into hospital ventilator trials during which 28 premature babies died and 15 were left brain-damaged has called for tighter controls to ensure patients are not used as "guinea pigs" in clinical tests. The report, published today, considered claims from some of the parents of the 122 premature babies involved in the trials that they had not been told the treatment was experimental. It follows a 15-month inquiry into controversial research work involving child patients at the North Staffordshire hospital in Stoke-on-Trent. The inquiry team, led by West Midlands director of public health Professor Rod Griffiths, also recommended new measures to ensure that valid parental consent was obtained. The report focuses on experimental treatment using a new type of ventilator on 122 premature babies at the hospital, and also deals with separate research involving the controversial covert video surveillance of parents suspected of abusing their children in hospital. The experiment was led by paediatrician Professor David Southall, who was suspended from the hospital in December 1999. Parents of some of the babies claim the results of the experiment do not compare favourably with conventional treatment. The inquiry team said today that they had referred to the General Medical Council claims that parents' signatures on consent forms had been forged. The government said today it accepted all the recommendations made in Professor Griffiths' report and had already begun putting them into place. But health minister Lord Hunt said there still needed to be a "culture change" in the NHS to empower patients. The Continuous Negative Extrathoracic Pressure (CNEP) ventilator worked by putting babies in low-pressure tanks which forced their lungs to expand, a move intended to aid their breathing. The inquiry into the research at the hospital was triggered when Llin Golding, Labour MP for Newcastle-under-Lyme, was approached by a family affected by the ventilator treatment. Carl and Debbie Henshall's daughter Stacey died on the machine in February 1992. Her sister Sofie, born in November 1992, suffered brain damage and is permanently disabled. Mr Henshall claimed the couple had never given their consent for the treatment. Ms Golding met the Henshalls and then approached the Department of Health, which ordered the inquiry. Another parent, Sharon Bradley, whose autistic son Stephen was put on the ventilator after he was born at 34 weeks, said she had no idea he was going to be involved in a trial. Stephen is unable to speak due to severe autism and learning difficulties, and studies have led his mother to believe his problems are linked to his early treatment. She said: "I was told that this treatment was a safer, gentler method of ventilation - it was less invasive because there were no tubes and it would teach my son to breathe for himself. There was no mention of a trial or experiment." A spokesman for the Bristol Heart Children Action Group, Steve Parker, said the Staffordshire case highlighted the pressing need for stricter rules on consent. The issues facing the parents were very similar to those faced in Bristol, where dozens of parents learned years after the deaths of their children that doctors had retained hearts and other organs following post mortems. "All these issues are about the principle of 'informed consent'," he said. "It is all about people knowing what is to done to their child and having the chance to make a decision." fields.body:
IN-SOL-UBLE

To White Hart Lane once more, and the continuing debate as to how rubbish Spurs will be next season. Pundits, punters and papers alike seem confident that they will be very rubbish, not fit to wear the shirt, and an insult to a 500-year tradition of amazing fantastic attacking football etc. The club meanwhile is convinced that George Graham's team will be far from rubbish - the anti-rubbish in fact. But which side has got it right?

Take the issue of Sol Campbell. If you listen to the media, then the Spurs captain is absolutely definitely on for a move to Old Trafford this summer. David Pleat, Director of Football at Spurs (pull a string in his back and watch him say "no"!) is of a different mind. "Sol has said that he won't be going anywhere this summer," he said today. "Whatever happens, he will stay and see out his contract."

You may find this strange, seeing as Campbell himself has always maintained he would only decide on his future this summer. But for Pleat the summer is now. "The sun is now shining, it is summer, and we are talking with Sol literally now," he said, while literally talking to 5 Live.

Another non-issue is the future of David Ginola. The mercurial (ie poisonous if you eat him) Frenchman has featured less and less for Spurs of late. Many, including the estimable Richard Littlejohn*, believe that Ginola is being forced out of the club. Ginola himself has said: "If I cannot start, I will not play." But here's George Graham: "David has an important part to play for Tottenham next season. I want him to stay." Clearer now? Thought not.

*Has anyone else noticed a complete lack of resemblance between the affable liberal-minded Richard Littlejohn of the BBC's 6:06 and the rabid right-wing Sun columnist of the same name? Are they by any chance not related?

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

To subscribe, send a mail to euro2000-request@footballunlimited.co.uk with 'subscribe' in the subject line.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

M. FERGUSON'S HOLIDAY

"756, 755, 754." That's the sound of Money Martin Edwards last week, joyously counting down the number of days before the Imperial Lord Ferg's retirement on his special Red Devil's abacus (a snip at £69.99 from the club shop). "Noooooooooooo!!!" That's the blood-curdling scream that coming from Mart's bathroom yesterday, after he read Fergie's announcement in the News of the Screws that: "I'd like to stay here after my current two years are up." "He f@*#ing wants what?!!!" will no doubt be Mr Edwards exasperated reaction today. Because Ferg has outlined his plans after his contract runs out in 2002 - and it's the sort of role that could keep him at the club forever AND burn a hole big hole in his chairman's pockets. "I would like to travel and see certain places properly, like Australia, South America or China where I've never been," Ferg tells the Scotsman. "In football we travel the world, but we don't get a chance to see these places."

Fair enough you might think. But wily old Ferg believes he can do it on the cheap, by acting as a kind of global ambassador for the club. The sort of role which will involve him passing around the Ferrero Roche during receptions on his luxury United yacht, engaging in psychological mind-games with various heads of state, and not much else.

"Retirement for me would be about remaining just active enough to spread out the week," Ferg happily admits. "Two or three days' work and three or four days off to pursue other interests. And the odd fortnight here or there to allow me to visit the countries I've talked about."

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"If I believe what I hear I am scared - I will have to play myself next season!" Arsene Wenger on the Overmars/Petit/Parlour to Barca/Real/Enfield rumours.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

WORSER AND WORSERER

Keep your votes coming for the Fiver's worst player of the season 1999-2000. The shortlist is comprised of: Chris Sutton, Mickael Silvestre, Dagenham Davor Suker, Wim Jonk and Steffen Freund, and the results will be announced on Friday. Have your say at the.boss@theguardian.com

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THANK GOD FOR ACCOUNTANTS

With the future of the game up in the air, football is crying out for leadership. The game needs decision-makers as never before, men and women who will take the tough choices to benefit the sport they love. Sadly there aren't any of them around, so we're going to have to make do with a bunch of opinionated accountants instead.

Deloitte and Touche have just completed their annual survey of Premiership fortunes and have found that while the average income of a Premiership club has risen to £33.5 million , so has expenditure, with every side apart from Leeds, Aston Villa and Man Utd spending over 50% of their income on wages.

The bean counters have put their minds to it and decided that such hefty spending is not healthy. "Liverpool might see themselves slipping back into being an average club and want to do something about it", said Robert Elstone, one of D&T's top team. "But the money has to be borrowed and that increases debt, which must be paid back eventually." But while it may be ok for Liverpool, "For someone like Southampton with a limited income, it is a huge risk."

All of which suggests that if you're not big, you shouldn't bother. Or as D&T put it so smartly: "Within any key formula of economic value the key driver is probably the size of the fan base." But rather than trying to redress the imbalance in a system that had worked ok for over a century D&T reckon that "the Premier League table of the future may feature large single-team cities or regions" and that today's discoveries "might even prompt a few Football League mergers." Let's hope so eh?

Get more exciting figures here.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE RUMOUR MILL

Rangers have bid £10m for Juventus' former Sheffield Wednesday star Darko Kovacevic. But Kovacevic insists he is happy in Italy and has bad memories of his last stay in Britain. "I am a loyal person, first to my wife, family and friends and then of course to Juventus," he said. "According to my contract, I'm obligated to the club until 2004 and I'm happy."

Chelsea could move for both Gareth Barry and Gary McAllister this summer. Apparently Gianluca Vialli has asked John Gregory to name his price for central defender Barry.

Marc Overmars is likely to stay at Arsenal next season. The Dutch winger had been tipped for a move to Barcelona but, after the Gunners qualified for the Champions League last weekend, he appears to have changed his mind. "I am pleased we have made it because I have to play at the highest level," he said, adding "I see a lot of good things happening here."

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

NEWS IN BRIEF

Manchester City chairman David Bernstein has promised to bankroll Joe Royle's Premiership campaign. He said: "We will be able to raise the money. I am confident Joe will have whatever resources he will need to keep the club in the Premiership. His requests are always sensible, and he has done a really wonderful job."

Kevin Keegan has guaranteed Graeme Le Saux a place in his Euro 2000 squad - if he can prove his fitness. Keegan said: "I'll be absolutely delighted if he is considered fit enough to play in the cup final or in one league game and then the cup final. If he was fit then, there's no doubt about it, he would be in the squad."

Dundee have confirmed that the contracts of manager Jocky Scott and his assistant Jimmy Bone will not be renewed when they expire in the summer.

Notts County chairman Derick Pavis is preparing to sell the world's oldest league club. He said: "All things being equal, Notts County will have a new chairman and new owners by the start of next season."

Fat Les 2000 will release their version of Jerusalem - England's official song for Euro 2000 - on May 29th. The FA will donate all of its proceeds from the record to the NSPCC's Full Stop Campaign.

Dundee United have signed a new three-year £500,000 shirt sponsorship agreement with TFG Sports.

ITV: Big Cup weekly (12.35am) Bayern v Real, it's the game that's got the country talking.

Football extra (1.05am) Which is why it's on before the terminally dull finish to the English league season.

Channel 5: Dutch football (3.45am) NIC NAC PADDYWACK Breda v FC Ironscheide.

Major League Soccer (4.55am) Dallas Cheezy Dips v Columbus Concubines.

fields.trailText: Italian football was in a state of turmoil today after a controversial refereeing decision all but handed the Serie A title to Juventus.
fields.body:
Italian football was in a state of turmoil today after a controversial refereeing decision all but handed the Serie A title to Juventus.

Juventus were 1-0 up yesterday against Parma yesterday when Fabio Cannavaro appeared to have headed home a 90th-minute corner. But referee Massimo De Santis disallowed the strike for pushing in the penalty area - an opinion which was not backed up by television replays.

Juventus' victory kept them two points ahead of the Rome club, with just one match to play, and left a furious Lazio president Sergio Cragnotti claiming that his team were moral victors in the championship.

Lazio could have faced their final match level on points with Juventus, opening up the prospect of a play-off for the title. Instead, Cragnotti was left calling for a complete overhaul of Italian football and insisting his team were the real champions.

"Our football has to be completely re-built," he said. "Everybody, whether they are fans or not, saw what happened in Turin - and no one is able to explain why that goal wasn't allowed.

"Everything that led up to it was perfectly normal. If anything the Juventus players were committing the fouls - first trying to hold back Crespo and then Cannavaro. But the referee disallowed it. Why, I don't know."

He warned: "It's not going to change the result, but Lazio are going to make their voice heard where it counts. For the second season in a row, the championship is ending with the clear signal 'everything's against Lazio'. "Once again, there's been a lack of sportsmanship and also a lack of professionalism by those who carry out certain duties."

Cragnotti said he cannot wait for a pan-European league to emerge - one that employs full-time professional referees.

He summed up: "Lazio deserve the league title, both morally and for their football. We've shown that we're clearly superior in the head-to-head matches, and that it wasn't by chance that we beat the league leaders (last month). "For me, Lazio have won the league."

The front-page headline of the Corriere dello Sport supported Cragnotti, screaming: "We're sorry, but it's a scandal", referring to "the incredible decision by the referee".

"I have seen a colossal injustice ... and something has to be done," wrote editor Mario Sconcerti, as the theory that Italian referees help Juventus to become champions was advanced for the second time in three years.

Juventus edged Inter Milan to the 1998 title in what was dubbed 'The Season of Poison' because of a series of dubious refereeing decisions in the champions' favour.

Italy's biggest sports daily, La Gazzetta dello Sport, revived those same concerns, headlining "The poisoned league title" on the front page and adding "Mystery foul: Cannavaro's 1-1 not given".

Television replays appeared to confirm Cannavaro's version of events - that the penalty area confusion was no different to what happens with every corner and that there was no major infringement.

fields.standfirst: Everything your need to know about French letters and other rubbers on the net
fields.trailText: Everything your need to know about French letters and other rubbers on the net
fields.body:
1. Once they were sold by the barber as something for the weekend, but now they have a whole week of their own.

2. Yes, National Condom Week is here: schools, surgeries and health clinics will display posters and leaflets promoting contraceptives.

3. It aims to teach children and young people that condom use is essential. A puerile little rhyme may help you remember.

4. For a start, education may cut Britain's high levels of teenage pregnancy.

5. But condoms aren't just there for contraception - they also prevent the spread of sexual diseases.

fields.headline: How the race was won
fields.standfirst: From Dick Wittington to Ken Livingstone
fields.trailText:
1189
The first lord mayor of London takes office.
fields.body:
1189
The first lord mayor of London takes office.

1397
Dick Whittington becomes lord mayor of London for the first time. He went on to serve three more terms between 1397 and 1420.

1965
The Greater London Council (GLC) supersedes the London County Council, established in 1888.

1981
Ken Livingstone is elected leader of the GLC and initiates a raft of progressive policies which infuriate the Conservative prime minister, Margaret Thatcher.

1986 Margaret Thatcher's government abolishes the GLC.

May 1997
The Labour party is elected with the manifesto promise: "Following a referendum to confirm popular demand, there will be a new deal for London, with a strategic authority and a mayor, each directly elected."

May 1998
In the referendum, 72% of voters say "yes" to a new government for London.

February 1999
The government awards Norman Foster and Partners the contract to build the new London assembly on the banks of the Thames.

March 1999
Broadcaster Trevor Phillips joins Jeffrey Archer and Ken Livingstone in announcing his desire to become London mayor.

28 July 1999
Glenda Jackson resigns from her post as minister for transport in London and announces her bid to become Labour's official candidate for mayor.

12 August 1999
Susan Kramer becomes the Liberal Democrats' candidate for London mayor after a ballot of all party members.

1 October 1999
Jeffrey Archer wins a ballot of London Tories to become the Conservative candidate for mayor. Former transport minister Steven Norris is well beaten.

30 September 1999
Labour's minister for London Nick Raynsford announces he will seek the Labour nomination for London mayor.

8 October 1999
Despite ruling himself out of the running just months earlier, health secretary Frank Dobson says he will run for Labour's nomination in the mayoral race.

11 October 1999
Nick Raynsford abandons his short-lived attempt to be London mayor and backs Frank Dobson, the candidate favoured by Tony Blair.

15 October 1999
A poll finds that Ken Livingstone will easily win the race to become mayor of London even if he loses the Labour selection battle and stands as an independent.

20 October 1999
Trevor Phillips pulls out of the race to be Labour's candidate for London mayor to become running mate and potential deputy mayor to Downing Street's favourite, Frank Dobson. Glenda Jackson angrily rebuffs speculation that she too will stand down.

27 October 1999
Tony Blair publicly supports Frank Dobson for the first time.

1 November 1999
The data protection registrar confirms she will investigate whether Frank Dobson broke the law in obtaining a list of London Labour party members to assist his campaign.

18 November 1999
After much speculation, the Labour party allows Ken Livingstone to compete with Frank Dobson and Glenda Jackson in a ballot of MPs, party members and unions to select the party's candidate to become London mayor.

20 November 1999
Jeffrey Archer is forced to resign as the Conservative party's mayor candidate after newspaper allegations that he asked a friend to lie ahead of the libel case against the Daily Star he won 13 years ago.

6 December 1999
Maverick Tory MP, Teresa Gorman, puts herself forward as a potential Conservative candidate for London mayor on behalf of "cabbies on the street and the ordinary Londoner".

7 December 1999
The Conservative selection committee bars Ms Gorman from standing.

11 December 1999
Steven Norris, the new favourite for the Tory nomination who lost to Lord Archer in October, is now banned by the party's selection committee from standing.

14 December 1999
After intense pressure from the Tory leadership Steven Norris is swiftly reinstated by Conservative high command to compete for the Conservative nomination with Paul Lynch, Mark Kotecha, Andrew Boff, Baroness Hanham and Baroness Miller.

16 December 1999
Former Sex Pistols' manager Malcolm McLaren launches an independent campaign to be London mayor.

5 January 2000
Ken Livingstone and Glenda Jackson are finally given the list of London Labour party members - three months after a senior Labour party figure was alleged to have passed the list to Frank Dobson. Mr Livingstone and Ms Jackson compile a dossier of unfair Millbank practices.

17 January 2000
Steven Norris is selected to be Tory candidate for London mayor at the second attempt. He beats rival Andrew Boff by a convincing 12,903 votes to 4,712.

20 February 2000
Helped by intensive support from Tony Blair and the Millbank party machine Frank Dobson narrowly wins the Labour party mayoral candidacy. Mr Dobson gets 51.53% of the vote to Ken Livingstone's 48.47% after Glenda Jackson is eliminated. Ken Livingstone calls it a "tainted" result - he won a majority in the members and union section of the ballot - and demands that Mr Dobson stand down.

21 February 2000
Ken Livingstone's independent candidacy is widely predicted, although he refrains from confirming whether he will stand.

22 February 2000
The House of Lords votes down the government to support a Tory call to allow candidates a free mailshot to voters, accusing ministers of refusing a freepost primarily in order to deny publicity to Ken Livingstone should he run as an independent. An amendment to the Greater London Authority Act 1999 is included in the Representation of the People Act 2000 which entitles every candidate to a freepost mailshot.

6 March 2000
After two weeks of speculation, Ken Livingstone finally announces he will run as an independent candidate in the London mayoral elections.

7 March 2000
A Guardian/ICM poll gives Mr Livingstone a 55-point lead over Frank Dobson.

8 March 2000
A retired publisher from the south London adds to Frank Dobson's woes. Frank S. Dobson emerges to say he will stand for mayor as well, threatening split the "Dobson" vote.

12 March 2000
Labour's Frank Dobson rebuffs image-makers' suggestions that he could improve his chances by shaving off his beard.

15 March 2000
A House of Commons committee finds Ken Livingstone guilty of failing to declare £158,599 earned from regular commitments - speech-making and newspaper articles. He is forced to apologise to the Commons.

17 March 2000
It emerges that the man who complained about Mr Livingstone's earnings is the former treasurer for the short-lived mayoral campaign of Frank Dobson's running mate, Trevor Phillips.

21 March 2000
Virgin Radio DJ Chris Evans doubles his £100,000 donation to Mr Livingstone after Frank Dobson jokes about red-heads.

27 March 2000
Frank Dobson's mayoral rival and namesake, Frank S. Dobson, withdraws from the mayoral race.

2 April 2000
It is reported that senior Labour sources, including pollster Philip Gould, expect the party's official candidate, Frank Dobson, to lose to Ken Livingstone.

3 April 2000
Mr Livingstone is formally expelled from the Labour party. Malcolm McLaren pulls out of the mayoral race.

4 April 2000
Another allegation of financial impropriety against Ken Livingstone turns out to have little foundation. An alleged £40,000 from Mr Livingstone's own company to help him buy a holiday home turns out to have been a £23,076 loan repaid well before he bought a house in Brighton.

10 April 2000
Ken Livingstone attracts criticism from the City of London and from Jewish groups for claiming: "The international financial system kills more people than world war two. But at least Hitler was mad."

12 April 2000
Tony Blair turns out for the first time in support of Frank Dobson's campaign. The prime minister praises Labour's official candidate for his "integrity and courage", but promises to "work with whoever's the mayor".

13 April 2000
An opinion poll cuts Ken Livingstone's lead in the mayoral race by 12 points to 49%, although he still commands a 33-point lead over Steven Norris, who moves into second place, one point ahead of Frank Dobson.

17 April 2000
Ken Livingstone publishes his manifesto, which presents a slight retreat from his previously cast-iron guarantees to fund tube modernisation by bonds and introduce a congestion charge for motorists.

25 April 2000
Frank Dobson becomes the final candidate to launch their manifesto. He also unleashes a fiercely negative campaign against Ken Livingstone, who would, he claims, cost motorists driving into London regularly £300 a month.

28 April 2000
The latest opinion poll gives Ken Livingstone a seemingly unassailable 34-point lead over Steven Norris. Mr Livingstone says he will apply to rejoin the Labour party after the election.

2 May 2000
The campaign against Ken Livingstone hots up as rivals seek to link him to the anti-capitalist demonstrations in London. A disillusioned aide also tells the Times he quit working for Mr Livingstone because he feared the independent candidate would be "a danger to London". Mr Livingstone says he had never heard of the aide.

3 May 2000
The traditionally Labour-supporting Mirror tells its readers to vote for Tory candidate Steven Norris in the mayoral elections. "Norris would be a better mayor," editor Piers Morgan says. The Guardian chooses not to make a choice.

5 May 2000
Ken Livingstone is elected mayor of London with over 700,000 votes - although technical problems hold him up.

fields.headline: Livingstone seeks grand coalition
fields.standfirst:
Assembly: Labour in London faces jobs dilemma

The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: The Labour party in London is split over whether to take up Ken Livingstone's unprecedented offer of jobs in his new Greater London assembly administration. The nine Labour members of the assembly will meet today and tomorrow to discuss the offer of the post of deputy mayor to Nicky Gavron.
fields.byline: Patrick Wintour, Nick Watt  and  Vikram Dodd
fields.body:
The Labour party in London is split over whether to take up Ken Livingstone's unprecedented offer of jobs in his new Greater London assembly administration. The nine Labour members of the assembly will meet today and tomorrow to discuss the offer of the post of deputy mayor to Nicky Gavron.

Mr Livingstone again appealed to the 25 assembly members to abandon party loyalties and work together in a grand coalition. He said he found it profoundly depressing that the four parties on the authority were already operating with four different sets of whips, caucuses and disciplines.

"We're not much bigger than a dinner party. We should be able to sort some of these things out without all these structures."

But one member of the Labour group said: "It may be that the most effective position we can adopt is to remain in opposition. The danger is that Ken will take the credit for the things that go right and we will end up taking the blame for the things that go wrong. We have to think about what will be best for Labour in terms of retaining seats with minimum losses at the next general election."

One source claimed there was a majority to delay a decision.

However, Ms Gavron, who will meet Mr Livingstone this morning to discuss his offer of the deputy mayorship for a year, is an enthusiast for his new coalition politics and privately feels certain her Labour colleagues will expect her to accept.

Mr Livingstone sees her as acting as the bridge between the mayor and the assemby, as well as being responsible for strategic planning in his cabinet.

The Labour group's decision will set the broader framework for the relationship between Labour and Mr Livingstone in the run-up to the next general election. Tony Blair spoke to Mr Livingstone for 20 minutes on Saturday, and Downing Street hinted strongly yesterday that they would be willing to see Labour GLA members serve in the Livingstone adminstration.

Labour won nine seats in the assembly, the same as the Conservatives, with three falling to the Greens and four to the Liberal Democrats.

One of Mr Livingstone's first appoinments at the weekend was Lee Jasper, a radical black activist, who will advise the mayor on race relations and liaison with the Metropolitan Police.

Mr Jasper, secretary of the National Assembly Against Racism, was a member of Scotland Yard's lay advisory group set up in the wake of the Stephen Lawrence report. In October last year he resigned after a row over allegations that its members who counselled black and Asian victims at the Paddington rail crash were cold shouldered by police officers.

He believes the police should be stripped of the role of training new recruits and internal discipline, with a greater role for the community.

In a speech to the National Assembly Against Racism, Mr Jasper said: "Let's be clear about it, you can't ask the police, as they are currently constituted, to reform themselves. What has to happen ... is the break up of the institution of the police."

Kumar Murshid, a second adviser named at the weekend, yesterday said that the Duke of Edinburgh was "an unreconstructed racist" and called for the abolition of the monarchy.

"Prince Phillip is a waste of time," Mr Murshid told the Sunday Telegraph. "He says things which indicate that he is, frankly, an unreconstructed racist."

Mr Murshid, chairman of the National Assembly Against Racism, is a Labour councillor in Tower Hamlets.

Mr Jasper will also advise on equality, including women's issues, sexual orientation and disability.

Mr Murshid is expected to be an adviser on economic regeneration.

webTitle: Elections in 2001 less and less likely

fields.headline: Elections in 2001 less and less likely
fields.standfirst:
Elections 2000: special report
New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Monday, 5.30pm: The chances of the Labour government holding a general election next spring look significantly slimmer after last week's polls, says political correspondent Lucy Ward.
fields.body:
The chances of Tony Blair's government marking the fourth anniversary of its 1997 election landslide with a spring general election next year look significantly slimmer in the wake of the local and London mayoral polls.

Earlier today, Gordon Brown became the most senior member of the government to hint that the next election could be delayed beyond the widely predicted date of May 2001. On Radio 4's Today programme, the chancellor stressed that Labour was playing for the "long term" and was implementing "radical and sometimes controversial measures" which would take some time to deliver.

His comments add public impetus to the weight of backroom pressure on the prime minister from senior cabinet colleagues to resist going to the country for a fresh mandate until autumn next year.

Ministers including Peter Mandelson and Mr Brown - Labour's two leading election strategists - deputy prime minister John Prescott and leader of the house Margaret Beckett are all understood to oppose an election this May.

Under UK electoral rules, the prime minister chooses the general election date and is not bound, as in other countries, by a fixed term, though the maximum period between general elections in peacetime is five years.

The prime argument which may persuade Mr Blair to delay a poll until the autumn is the concern that May 2001 may be too early to demonstrate government delivery of key promises and to renew enthusiasm among disillusioned core supporters.

By confining itself to Tory-set spending limits for its first two years in office, the Labour government left voters hanging on for noticeable change, party sources acknowledge.

"Now that the money really is going in, it seems wiser to wait until people really see the evidence in schools and hospitals rather than rush in when the Tories can still claim we haven't made a difference," says one MP.

One advantage of a May general election would be the scope to use next year's Budget (in March) as a springboard, sending voters to the polls buoyed at the prospect of tax giveaways or cash for public services. On the other hand, others argue, an autumn poll would allow the promised money to have filtered through to the voters' pockets.

Mr Blair will have to choose the key point which will allow the government to sell its message of "a lot done, a lot to do": too early, and the difficulty of conveying the first part is clear; too late - into the fifth year, say - and the momentum of the first Blair term could flag.

Labour strategists will also have an eye on the polling strength of William Hague's Tories, with reference to the third part of the Labour election mantra: "a lot to fear from the Tories".

Analysis of general elections since the war shows that, on average, governments go to the country once every four years, with that period being the optimum one for prime ministers to choose when they are strongly enough placed to do so.

John Major's experience in 1997, when the struggling Tories delayed polling day for the full five years in the hope that events could save them from inevitable defeat, will be fresh in Mr Blair's mind.

However, he will also be aware of the dangers of permitting election speculation, thanks to the experiences of one of his own Labour predecessors, Jim Callaghan. In 1978, the then Labour prime minister allowed it to be understood that he would go to the country in the autumn, then shied away from the prospect until the following spring amid suggestions that the result would be a hung parliament.

One Labour source said: "Tony Blair is likely to want to scotch all this speculation soon, as he has with talk of reshuffles, and say 'I haven't made up my mind yet, and when I do the decision is my own.'"

fields.body:
Channel 4 last night was investigating death threats received by the comedian Ali G from the neo-Nazi group Combat 18.

The threats, in a letter to the channel's headquarters in London, are being taken seriously by executives. The note to the Jewish-born satirist was handwritten and contained anti-Semitic and racist language. It said he would be killed.

It was passed on from Channel 4 to TalkBack, the independent production company that makes Da Ali G Show. It was reported that a researcher opened the letter, which was addressed to the star using his real name, Sacha Baron Cohen.

It is thought that he was a target because he is Jewish and imitates black people and their culture. A Channel 4 spokesman said yesterday: "This kind of thing happens quite a lot, but not from Combat 18, of course, and we are taking it seriously."

The Sunday Mirror yesterday quoted a police source as saying: "Sacha is extremely worried about these threats. He has been told they should be taken seriously, and his personal safety is now his main focus."

Combat 18 started out providing security for the British National party. It takes its name from the position of Adolf Hitler's initials in the alphabet: 1 for A and 8 for H.

High-profile black and Asian people, and those in mixed relationships, have also become its targets. The boxer Frank Bruno and his wife, Laura, were subjected to a race-hate campaign.

Bruno's mother, Lynette, received abusive phone calls and was sent letters from Combat 18 saying it was going to "blow her head off". Mark Atkinson, a leading member, was jailed in 1997 over that campaign.

Sharron Davies, a former Olympic medalist, and her then husband, Derek Redmond, were sent hate letters when they married in 1994.

Three years ago a letter bomb concealed in a video cassette was sent to their house in a campaign by Combat 18 and Danish fascists.

Other celebrities targeted include the newsreader Anna Ford, the actor Vanessa Redgrave and the entrepreneur Sir Alan Sugar. Martin Bashir, a reporter on the Tonight with Trevor McDonald programme on ITV, is also understood to have received racist threats.

Ali G, 28, who lives in north London, has received critical acclaim and huge audiences for his show, in which he sends up black culture, celebrities and the public.

The Sunday Mirror said the threats made to him would be added to a database, with the names and details of more than 19,000 known or suspected racists in an attempt to link racially motivated crimes and target persistent offenders.

Ali G is in the US researching a new programme for Channel 4 and is planning to star in a music video with the singer Madonna. He was unavailable for comment.

webTitle: Optimism ahead of Unionist ruling council vote

fields.headline: Optimism ahead of Unionist ruling council vote
fields.trailText: Ulster Unionist deputy leader John Taylor today forecast victory for his leader David Trimble when the ruling council votes on the IRA's offer to bury its weapons for good.
fields.body:
Ulster Unionist deputy leader John Taylor today forecast victory for his leader David Trimble when the ruling council votes on the IRA's offer to bury its weapons for good.

As the government faced fresh pressure to retain the name of the Royal Ulster Constabulary in a bid to persuade the Unionists to accept the IRA's proposal, Mr Taylor said he believed delegates would back a return to government with Sinn Fein, the IRA's political arm.

Mr Taylor said: "There are still some hiccups, but I think they will be overcome. It will go to the Ulster Unionist council meeting and if this goes the way I personally foresee it going, I believe it would be approved strongly by the council."

With the Good Friday accord apparently back on track, he claimed the republican statement had been a significant breakthrough, going further than many people imagined. The unionist council is expected to vote on Saturday week, just two days before the planned re-establishment of the power-sharing executive and assembly at Stormont.

Even as Unionists welcomed the IRA move, they demanded concessions on government plans to overhaul the RUC. Although the Northern Ireland secretary, Peter Mandelson, insisted that he had no plans to change the proposed new title - the Police Service of Northern Ireland - close associates of Mr Trimble warned that the demand to incorporate the RUC name in some way would have to be met.

Unionists say the RUC name has become such an emotional issue that if Mr Trimble hopes to have any chance of persuading a majority of his ruling council to accept the IRA offer, Downing Street will have to yield to the unionist demand.

But Mr Mandelson in Belfast today offered no hint of flexibility. He said he had no intention of moving away from the government's proposals to change the name as part of the sweeping reforms announced by former Hong Kong governor Chris Patten.

Nevertheless, there is renewed optimism that a lasting peace is within reach after the IRA's announcement on Saturday that it would soon start to disarm. The British and Irish governments say the IRA pledge should clear the way for restoring power to Northern Ireland's administration on May 22, some three months after Westminster re-imposed direct rule.

"There are a number of issues which we have had concerns about and which we have been pursuing with the government and we are hoping to get a response from government on those issues in the course of the next few days," Mr Trimble said. He acknowledged, however, that the IRA statement agreeing to put its arms "beyond use" appeared to break new ground.

The IRA has always rejected disarmament as equivalent to a surrender in its fight for a united Ireland. But the kind of disarmament now being offered would not require the IRA to hand over weapons publicly, only to identify the locations of its secret stockpiles.

fields.headline: Power play
fields.standfirst: Is there a market for a website about the US media? One young company thinks so - even after the Wall Street scare. Jane Martinson reports
fields.trailText: Is there a market for a website about the US media? One young company thinks so - even after the Wall Street scare. Jane Martinson reports
fields.body:
Most elevators in New York zip straight from the 12th to the 14th floor in order to let the sleeping gods of lift luck lie. In an old building near the Hudson river, however, a hand-operated lift creaks to a halt on the 13th floor, delivering visitors to the offices of the new internet company Powerful Media.

Such omens have not gone unnoticed at the company as it prepares to launch a keenly anticipated new website this week. But Deanna Brown, chief executive and co-founder, is defiant in the face of such superstition. "The number 13 has always brought me good fortune," she says.

But it appeared to have deserted her last month when a stock market "correction" saw investors bailing out of all but the biggest internet companies. As this crisis of confidence reached a climax, Powerful Media was attempting to finalise the second round of financing for Inside.com, a fledgling website devoted to the media and entertainment industries.

Earlier websites, such as TheStreet.com or Salon, had been crushed by the sell-off and were trading at or near all-time lows. What's more, these companies had tried, and failed, to charge a subscription fee for their services. Inside.com is to offer only a basic service to non-subscribers.

Kurt Andersen and Michael Hirschorn, two stalwarts of New York's old media scene and co-founders of Powerful Media, admitted to feeling distinctly "queasy" as the market for technology companies tanked. But Brown, who has worked on four other media launches, said she took heart from the confidence of venture capitalists. "In the middle of it all, Lehman venture capital called to commit [money]," she says, with just a hint of satisfaction in her voice.

Powerful Media managed to raise $23m in the cruel days of April, $3m more than it had expected.

Andersen, 45, has lived to regret his comment that raising money for a dot com today was as "easy as getting laid in 1969", but the money helped boost staff morale. The company had recruited more than 65 people, many of whom lured from secure jobs at some of the most respected US news organisations by stock options. Brown says that, following the successful fundraising, "notes were sent out to confirm that we were still in great shape financially and that there would be no repercussions from the market correction."

One consequence, however, has been the outpouring of invective against Inside.com, some of it from old media rivals. Peter Bart, editor of Variety, the entertainment daily, wrote: "Given the turmoil of the moment, even Powerful Media may soon change its name to Not-so-Powerful Media."

Less self-interested critics have raised more serious questions about the company's business model. Any number of studies now show that web surfers do not like to pay for online information. The only media website to charge a subscription fee - the Wall Street Journal - succeeds because it is required reading for business executives throughout America and is usually paid for by employers.

How many of these employers will pay for a fledgling website about the media itself? The business plan for Inside.com is forecasting 100,000 subscribers within the next three years, with 30,000 signing up this year. What's more, the company expects subscription revenues to help generate profits within three years. Rivals have scoffed at such projections but Brown says, "We have written the business plan as a business plan and not as an internet business plan."

She goes further: "We are definitely a business tool, similar to the Wall Street Journal. The difference between us and them is that they have a 100-year-old brand."

The other difference is the office. Hirschorn, the 36-year-old ex-editor of Spin magazine, wore shorts and trainers as he sat amid wires, masking tape and shiny new iMacs last week and demonstrated the wonders of Inside.com. The fairly standard home page is full of information and promises to go "inside TV, film, music, media and books" as well as offering various other features. "The message I think it should send, and which will be surprising, is that it is a serious business tool," he says.

Surprising because both Hirschorn and Andersen are known for creating satirical or cultural magazines. Andersen admits his friends were probably expecting something "wacky".

Wacky does not necessarily work in today's newly discerning internet world, however. The emphasis on business users is good for business at Inside.com. Hirschorn's riposte to doubters is to say: "I agree that it's very difficult for a consumer site, with the possible exception of those focused on business or sex, to make money." The idea being that Inside.com will be required surfing at work.

Inside.com is to offer a frequently updated diet of breaking news and analysis, combined with a series of useful tools. These range from customised industry rankings to a publishing product that aims to track the status of an idea from feature to book to script.

There is a gossipy "Inside Dope" section as well as a Power Index that allows users to vote for the most powerful people in the relevant industries and a weekly mogul horoscope.

Hirschorn believes that the growth of broadband and wireless access to the internet will spur future growth. Other plans include expanding internationally and launching a print magazine in partnership with traditional media companies.

New recruits, suddenly faced with four-year share options that may not be worth as much as they had originally hoped, appear to welcome the company's culture of new age casual and age-old profit concerns. Richard Siklos, Inside.com's business editor who joined from Business Week, says: "I feel uncomfortable being a dot.com guy. If I came in here and there were a bunch of people on skateboards I would think 'What am I doing here?'"

Siklos has also taken to calling the company a "contrarian" investment choice in recognition of the fact that dot.com companies are no longer fashionable among investors.

The three founders say that their business plan does not include plans for a stock market listing. "We don't necessarily have an exit strategy," says Brown. "Our goal is to build a business and manage that business to take advantage of financial opportunities." After last month, most analysts think the opportunities are more likely to come from a trade buyer than a share offering.

When asked about the worst moments of the past few weeks, both Hirschorn and Andersen talk of the innumerable technical glitches they have endured. "My eyes are having problems focusing," said a weary Hirschorn. Andersen, wearing the only jacket in the office, admitted to "pining" for a return to novel writing. He plans to do so at the end of this year when he will sit down to write an already commissioned novel set in the 19th century.

There have been some bright spots in the past two weeks. Headline-grabbing stories, from Microsoft to the dispute between Time Warner and Disney, proved how hot the site would be, says Hirschorn. "In this time of unprecedented flux, excitement and terror we are setting ourselves up as the people to really work through the issues." He could have rubbed his eyes as he said so: proof, if needed, that he wasn't crossing his fingers at the same time.

webTitle: Disney concern over internet stranglehold created by AOL/Time Warner merger

fields.headline: Disney concern over internet stranglehold created by AOL/Time Warner merger
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: A senior executive of Walt Disney this weekend called on the US government to stop a merged America Online/Time Warner from abusing its cable television monopoly.
fields.body:
A senior executive of Walt Disney this weekend called on the US government to stop a merged America Online/Time Warner from abusing its cable television monopoly.

Preston Padden, a Disney executive in charge of the entertainment group's lobbying efforts, said the soon to be merged media and internet group would gain a market stranglehold even worse than that of Microsoft, which has been found guilty of abusing its monopoly of the software market.

Tensions between Disney and Time Warner escalated last week when the cable company cut Disney's programmes from its service after a dispute over transmission terms.

Disney had asked Time Warner to pay more for its popular ABC channel, which carries a number of top-rated shows such as Who Wants to be a Millionaire?

Analysts recognised that the dispute was about far more than the contract terms, however, as Disney sought to get political mileage out of Time Warner's access to millions of US homes through its cable network.

Speaking at a discussion on the internet hosted by the New Yorker magazine on Saturday, Mr Padden said the dispute was about nothing less than control of the web.

He accused Time Warner of "a remarkable display of monopoly power" before going on to criticise AOL, the world's largest internet service provider, for what he called "content cul-de-sacs".

Mr Padden, who was seated next to Joel Klein, the head of the government's anti-trust efforts which brought the landmark legal case against Microsoft's monopoly, then chided Mr Klein and his department for doing little about such abuse.

"You worry about Microsoft and here you have a company that creates content cul-de-sacs merging with a company that cuts off ABC," he said.

Mr Padden's remarks were well-timed, as the proposed AOL/Time Warner merger is under review by two government regulators, the federal trade commission and federal communications commission.

"The government is going to have to step in and set some ground rules," Mr Padden told an audience that included Michael Eisner, the head of Disney.

However, Disney has stopped short of calling for the merger to be blocked and did not issue a formal complaint against it, unlike several consumer groups.

Mr Padden's remarks drew some critical comment from another panellist. Candace Carpenter, the head of iVillage, a website aimed at women, accused Disney of leading efforts to hurt her company in its early days and said: "The concept of Disney as the underdog is an amazing one."

In his comments to the audience, Mr Klein said that the government preferred to let the market decide most issues, though he strongly criticised monopoly abuses.
