fields.headline: The internet's weak link
fields.trailText: Linking is good: that's the start point. Isn't that what the net is all about - pointing people to other interesting places to visit to learn more about an issue?
fields.body:
Linking is good: that's the start point. Isn't that what the net is all about - pointing people to other interesting places to visit to learn more about an issue?

Take Chechnya: readers can find the inside story from Chechen rebels and the Russian government without looking too hard. Both sides offer fascinating insights into what's going on. But if you were to ask a Chechen or a Russian for their opinion you might get another view. You're linking to the site of a terrorist or an oppressive state, take your pick.

But the hard truth is that sometimes sites have to link to places we don't like very much - how do I or anybody else have the right to censor another site, to deny access? The strength of the net is its roots in the free flow of communication - to give a window to an increasingly smaller world and to make it easier to find the answers to the questions.

The problem is, links are starting to raise more questions than answers. The prevalence of hategroups - the anti-everythings who range from sad loners to violent supremacists - and their use of the net as a platform is posing the question: can mainstream websites go on linking unquestioningly?

The net is so unfathomably big now that a simple query to Yahoo! or Alta Vista can bring back thousands of replies. So, people need to know which are the key sites, and which are the ones that will add to their understanding of an issue. Of course, not every website carries links but links are the currency of the net. It's one of the ironies: you want your site to be as sticky as hell, but users won't come if you don't take them on to other interesting places.

Legally, publication of a website assumes you want to be linked to it. And it's a strange circular game: the more places you're linked from, the more traffic you get. The more sites you link to, the more people use you as their gateway to the net.

It doesn't need much imagination to see what can happen. Compiling copy on paedophile rings, would you link to paedophile sites? I doubt anyone would be able to justify that. But if you were compiling a report on the far right and wanted to illustrate how it is pre senting itself, is it any better to link to a Nazi group's site?

The internet is an information forum: by denying your readers a link, you are undoubtedly censoring them and restricting their access to information.

It's how the choice is made that is key. Making sure it adds to the understanding of an issue is the point, and the line between that and gratuitousness is a very fine one. The law's not much help to site editors in handling this dilemma - there's only been one case in the UK on linking, which was a judgment over the Shetland Times' headlines being reproduced on another site.

The Hatewatch site brings up all these points and deals with them. Under the quote "how it infuriates a bigot, when he is forced to drag out his dark convictions" from author Logan Pearsall Smith, it lifts the rug on the world's nastiest sites, exposing the activities of extremists everywhere. It's basically a set of links: if you want to know what extremists are up to, here is the place to look: white supremacy, neo-nazism, anti-semitism next to black racism and anti-arab sites. It is a dictionary of hate.

But surf around Hatewatch and you realise pretty quickly that it doesn't endorse these sites, or glamorise them: it exposes them. In much the same way as the magazine Searchlight uses the activities of racist groups to expose them.

The opposite to Hatewatch is, ironically, the Simon Wiesenthal centre's site, which publishes an inventory of hate sites - without much in the way of context at all.

A basic disclaimer is often just a cop-out. There's no point saying you're not responsible for the content of another site and then linking to it without explaining what it is. But context is everything. If hate sites are linked to unquestioningly, how is a user to know that this is the site of a Nazi group and that is the home of a respected academic? fields.headline: 'I'll never leave the family business'
fields.standfirst: Last week Elisabeth Murdoch shocked the media world by announcing that she was quitting her job as managing director of the Sky Networks to start her own company. Has she renounced her claim to the News Corp succession? She talks babies, family and business to  Janine Gibson
fields.trailText: Last week Elisabeth Murdoch shocked the media world by announcing that she was quitting her job as managing director of the Sky Networks to start her own company. Has she renounced her claim to the News Corp succession? She talks babies, family and business to Janine Gibson
fields.body:
The first clue should have come when she gave up smoking. Elisabeth Murdoch, rarely seen without a Marlboro Light attached firmly to her elegant fingers, abstaining? It's the first sign of pregnancy. If it was an episode of EastEnders - and let's face it, the beings and doings of the Murdoch clan are the media world's favourite Australian soap opera - you'd know immediately that the character was secretly expecting. She even laughs mockingly at how dense the journalists gathered around her at a recent dinner must have been not to realise that her abstemiousness might have had a biological reason. I don't like to say that we ascribed it to her Californian ways.

"So, do you think people are really surprised?" It's Thursday afternoon and she has digested the initial reports of her resignation from BSkyB. "Murdoch quits the family firm"; "Trying to move out of the long shadow of the family empire". The story has everything: young (31), glamorous, rich, blond heiress turns her back on Daddy's global media empire to go it alone. Late in the day her friends confirmed the missing link: she is pregnant by her super-connected partner, PR man Matthew Freud.

Yes, I think people were pretty much surprised. "Yeah . . . Well, I don't know how else they expected it would ever be done, though."

The point, probably, is that few people did expect it ever to be done. Sure, there has been speculation that the managing director of Sky Networks might not always be happy in that rather nebulous role. Certainly the industry knew that her relationship with the previous two chief executives, Sam Chisholm and Mark Booth, was not all it might have been. Perhaps even her friends acknowledged that it would be better for Lis to strike out on her own. None the less, in all the talk of succession to the Murdoch throne, the word was that the eldest child of the second marriage, Elisabeth, was adamant she would take her place in her father's "first among equals" plan. Brothers Lachlan and James might have apparently won greater favour, with Lachlan at 28 marked out as the first of those equals, but she was not, we were assured as recently as last month in a Talk magazine profile, giving up without a fight.

Until Wednesday and the announcement that this Murdoch was leaving.

"For the last six to nine months, I thought at some point in the future I would like to do my own thing, pursue my own opportunities, create my own culture and control my destiny. Yet [at Sky] every single day there's a new challenge, it's the most exciting company in the world, and I don't say that with any note of hype. So you think, 'oh well, I'll do it one day'.

"Then when Matthew and I found out that we were going to have another baby [they already have two children each], it sort of dawned on me that if there was ever a right time to alter my lifestyle and be in control of my own time . . ." She immediately qualifies, rather defensively, "it doesn't mean that you work any less hard - it just means that you are slightly more the master of your own destiny. And this was a really good time to do it. So I think it was a catalyst for me to be like 'OK, I am someone who can do this.' And I also thought that it was a good time from the perspective of where Sky is at the moment.

"It's a difficult decision . . ." She laughs and tails off. "To look around when you've been somewhere for four years, I mean this is partly family to me." Of course it is. It is the family business. "Well, yeah."

Suddenly the Vassar-educated media princess comes on like a guest on Oprah. "But you know what? I'm never leaving the family business. I may be doing something different professionally at the moment, but I plan on having very close ties through that business with I hope our company and other people."

She carries on, now sounding disturbingly like a member of the Mob. "I will always be a part of that business. My brothers and I will always, always be a part of that business so to me it does not feel like leaving the family business . . . I just won't.

"I'm only 31 - I don't see this as something that means I would never, you know, go back to [News Corp] in some way. I think that would be ridiculous to say. Does that make sense?"

It does if you consider the company as something greater than a job to the Murdoch siblings; it is the family. From that, perhaps, comes the urge to have something of her own. To have always been part of it, to have always had the expectations and fought the battles might prove exhausting. Maybe the reported fear of the ex-matriarch, Anna - that her family would be torn apart by Rupert's unwillingness to settle the succession question - was justified. But Elisabeth will have none of the implication that she has taken an easy route out of full-frontal confrontation with her nearest and dearest.

It's still a massive u-turn from the succession plan as it was understood and laid out: three Murdoch siblings, all thrusting to be awarded the big prize by their cautious father. She seems now to prefer to dismiss that as a myth.

"A lot of that comes externally - from external speculation about how we must operate and what our worldview must be. Ultimately the most important thing is, I would say, to sound incredibly Californian about it, self realisation." A deep sigh. "I don't know how to express it other than to say I think there's been an enormous amount of labels and expectations that have been put on [us] and assumptions about all of us and it isn't necessarily the case."

Her father, she says, was "delighted" to hear her plans. "I think he's proud of what I achieved and appreciates my talents and he's really happy for me. He's very comfortable with it and it's not really a big issue. He's excited about the new venture and he's, you know, being a dad . . . I think if I said, 'Dad, I'm packing up, I'm going to be an electrical engineer, I'm going back to school,' that might get a reaction. But my dad is an entrepreneur by spirit and he understands that."

So, alarmingly for the future of the soap, we got the Murdochs all wrong. It's really more like the Brady Bunch than the Ewings. "I don't think you become a different person just because you make a lifestyle choice. I'm still a very ambitious person, I still want to make impact with whatever I do and that's not going to change. I'm staying in the business and I hope to be very successful. It's just about being able to focus on the bits that I love and really about being more flexible in my time."

Aren't Murdochs supposed to be driven by a desire to take over the world? "Being driven by greed is something no one in my family should ever be accused of. It's not about that. It's about the satisfaction you get out of what you do."

Whatever the satisfactions and frustrations of her current role, it is a big step for her to walk away from Sky and the possibility of a different job there - the obvious one that has eluded her is chief executive.

"I'm at a level in my career where I expect to have a certain sense of autonomy. To do anything less would not be particularly satisfying. It's really about deciding at this point I would like to be my own boss, I would like to pick my own team - maybe to begin with on a smaller scale but it will be ultimately very satisfying, [the reason for quitting is] . . . not lack of another job here - being senior executive of a plc is a huge job. But it's a different world to operate in from being the proprietor of your own business."

Is she disappointed that she'll never be chief executive of Sky? "I want to pursue what I'm pursuing but no, no, it's not really been a factor in my thinking in any way whatsoever, no. Good question."

But there was a time, with the launch of Sky Digital, when she was clearly the face and voice of the company, to the point where she submitted to makeovers and fashion shoots in women's magazines to promote the digital proposition. "Exactly, well that came back to bite me in the butt, thank you very much. Everyone was saying 'Why did you do that?' Well, because I had to sell those fucking dishes . . ."

Though the dishes have sold, Murdoch did not make chief executive when Booth quit last year. She is quick to emphasise that Tony Ball, the man appointed over her head, has been utterly supportive about her decision. Reports suggested there had been fallings out at Sky and there were rumours of a "stand-up row" between the two just before she quit. Far from it, she insists: "He has been by far the best person I've ever worked for. He's a leader. He is wonderful." She adds, wrily, that leaving Sky "would have made more sense if it was a couple of years ago. Sometimes timing doesn't quite work out the way you think it's going to work out".

Her job changed considerably with the three bosses she's worked under. Initially, Chisholm put his "graduate trainee", as he liked to refer to her, in charge of satellite installation. Glamorous. "Funnily enough, I think he did it just to give me a hard time but it was a very valuable experience of what this company is all about in terms of the scale of it and the customer service aspect of it and the nuts and bolts of it."

When director of programmes David Elstein left, she was put in charge of programming, then under Ball she took on marketing as well. "It's completely evolved. I got a lot done in original programming and Sky Pictures, with the brand and on air promotion and that was what I needed to do . . ." Though the job is never finished, she says, she has done what she set out to do. She's proud of Sky One ("my baby"), the new Guardian Media Group/Sky joint venture channel Artsworld and her marketing campaigns. Mostly, though, she's proud that two and a half years ago she stood up at Edinburgh aged 29 and told the industry that digital multi-channel television would prove its saviour. "I think it's starting to, I think people get that now. I hope I played a little part in that . . ."

David Bergg has arrived from ITV to run Sky One and Murdoch has launched her new marketing campaign with an animated Sky executive extolling the virtues of multi-channel choice. Sky Pictures, her film venture, has also borne fruit: "We're about to have our first big movie and you think, 'God, I'd love to see another one'. But at least these things are out there in the open now. I can now leave them in very, very capable hands. So this probably isn't a bad time to go. We have addressed some of the issues that we have been carrying for a while."

She won't talk about the new venture much, preferring to wait until she's got something to announce. But she will take the summer off to spend some time with her family, and take the rest of the run-up to the birth putting deals together.

So where will she be in a year? "Very successful, doing fantastic things with my new company and with a healthy new baby . . ." She stops, realising the inadequacy of the answer. "OK, I'll be smoking and drinking and very happy."

The highs and lows of Lis Murdoch's Sky career

Highs

* Being made general manager of BSkyB in February 1996, promoted to head of programming seven months later. Quickly establishes herself as queen of programming at (then) ailing Sky One, with brief to turn the channel into a general entertainment station to rival BBC1 and ITV. "Call me Lis" manner masked ruthless streak.

* Poaching a clutch of A-list stars to bolster Sky's line-up. Barry Norman was prised away from the BBC to front Sky's film coverage, while comedians Harry Enfield and David Baddiel have also been signed up. Viewers have yet to see what Enfield and Baddiel have to offer.

* Commissioning the Uncovered series. The combination of sun, sand and sex in the holiday resort docu-soaps proved irresistible, and the programmes were later snapped up by Channel 4, establishing Sky as a provider of programmes in its own right.

* Dream Team: Murdoch was responsible for the trashy but successful football team-based series which won a clutch of broadcasting awards and is now in its third season. Interest from terrestrial broadcasters.

* Meeting the public relations guru and friend of the stars, Matthew Freud.

Lows

* Continued battles with successive chief executives. Had fiery relationship with her first - Sam Chisholm - who said charitably when ill-health forced him to leave Sky in 1997: "I have a great admiration for Elisabeth." But added pointedly: "We do not agree on everything. Ours is a creative medium - there are always disagreements." Passed over for the top job twice: Chisholm was replaced by Mark Booth, and Tony Ball pinched the top job last year.

* Signing the Duchess of York as a chat-show host and broadcasting Chris Evans's radio breakfast show on the television. Both derided as turkeys.

* Launch party for Sky Digital, masterminded by Freud. Turned into a mudbath at Battersea power station. Freud was said to be so distraught that he was seen kneeling on the ground, clutching his head.

* Losing the first-screening rights to the US series Friends and ER, when Channel 4 snapped them up for £140m last year. The shows were two of the few jewels in Sky One's crown, and their loss was a massive blow.

* The Strangerers sitcom - something complicated to do with aliens - which was universally panned and which even Tony Ball admitted this month was "disappointing".

fields.headline: True Colours
fields.standfirst: Has New Labour been rrapped in the web created by its chief spinners? Roy Greenslade examines the tabloid backlash against Blair
fields.trailText: Has New Labour been rrapped in the web created by its chief spinners? Roy Greenslade examines the tabloid backlash against Blair.
fields.body:
How a newspaper advises its readers to vote on the day before polling is not, frankly, worth the paper it is printed on. If it was the Sun wot won it for John Major, then it certainly wasn't because of that lampooning front page with Neil Kinnock's head in a light bulb. By the time people came to voting day - indeed, before the campaign even got under way - people had already made up their minds where they were going to place their X.

Why can't politicians understand how the process in which they are so intimately involved really works? More importantly, have Tony Blair, Alastair Campbell, Peter Mandelson and Philip Gould, who, we are reliably informed are the most sophisticated media manipulators in history, grasped what has happened to their press strategy?

Before the 1997 election, they set out to woo the support of Tory papers or, at least, neutralise them. This led to the spectacular "success" of the Sun, previously Margaret Thatcher's greatest cheerleader and scourge of Labour leaders from Callaghan to Kinnock, backing Labour months before polling. They also came close to securing the friendship of the Daily Mail, winning over both the proprietor, the late Lord Rothermere, and the editor-in-chief David English, who also died soon after. Editor Paul Dacre remained sceptical but an analysis of the paper's political content in those months reveals that - with the exception of the paper's stand against the euro - there was enough ambivalence in the coverage to cheer Labour.

By chance, Labour peer Lord Hollick had previously assumed control of the Daily Express and gradually moved it into the Blair camp despite the wishes of its chairman, Lord Stevens, who remained loyal to the Tories. Over time the Daily Star also muted its hysterical right-wing stance.

The Mirror, of course, remained steadfast. Among the daily broadsheets, only the Daily Telegraph turned its back on New Labour. But that didn't really matter. Blair and his team had pulled off one of the most astonishing coups by swinging the press behind it. At least, that's the way it seemed at the time.

The reality, of course, was different. The papers which changed their colours had been disgusted with the Tories under Major for years, had undermined his credibility with continual hyper-critical coverage and, having failed to remove him from the leadership, showed no enthusiasm for him to continue.

When Blair assumed the Labour leadership, they were only too delighted to find a man with whom they could do business. After a lengthy honeymoon, the press's love for Blair has gradually waned. And here is the significant point: it has done so largely because editors have reacted against the very notion that they are being manipulated. They have made a fetish of criticising the concept and the practice of so-called "spin" and have turned Campbell, if not into a household name and face, into a Machiavellian bogey figure. It goes without saying that they have done the same to the much more public face of Mandelson. Both men, and surely they realise it, are being demonised by the papers they seek to influence.

What the press has succeeded in doing is to have turned Labour's great plus into a minus. Rather than attacking policy, though they have done that too with increasing frequency in the past year, papers have concentrated their fire on the spinners, unravelling the machinery of government for their readers and holding it up to scrutiny. Yet the response from Downing Street and Millbank has been to redouble the spinning rather than examine the value of the strategy itself.

Campbell has been so keen to keep papers such as the Sun on board, and to have some influence over the content of the Daily Mail, among others, that he has been prepared to accept outbreaks of hostile coverage without daring to abandon his critics. Last week the flaws in that approach, not to mention the dangers, became obvious. On Monday the Sun published a front page editorial which claimed that Blair was "beginning to lose the next general election". He was "in crisis over Rover, NHS, asylum and law and order".

This was not an isolated example of the Sun's growing scepticism. There have been many leaders in the past 12 months attacking Blair. This time, though, with local and mayoral elections looming, Blair felt it necessary to defend himself with a letter which the Sun gleefully trumpeted on next day's page one, giving it a better showing than the anarchist riot in Whitehall.The result? It is hazardous to speculate on how readers react to a single story, but less difficult to guess the effects of the drip, drip, drip of this kind of article.

My reading of the Sun political coverage in all its manifestations since the 1997 election would suggest that its readers have been encouraged to believe that Blair cannot be trusted, that he runs his government with smoke and mirrors and, worst of all, that New Labour is essentially no different from old Labour or the Tories.

Worse for the Blair strategy is the upset his willingness to bend to the Sun's agenda causes his loyal press supporters. It infuriates both the Daily Express and, particularly, the Mirror. Although the Mirror's editor, Piers Morgan, denies that his paper's shock decision to urge its readers to vote Tory in the London mayoral election had anything to do with Blair paying so much attention to the Sun, it probably played a part.

My belief is that what we face in the next election, whether it's next year or in 2002, is voter apathy which will reduce Labour's majority to fewer than 20. Remember, you read it here first.

webTitle: Me and my motor:  Nicki French

fields.headline: Me and my motor:  Nicki French
fields.standfirst: Nicki French is the UK's entry to the Eurovision Song Contest
fields.trailText: What do you drive?
fields.body:
What do you drive?

A Boston green BMW318i and a Rover 214si in slate grey. The BM is my favourite but I'm worried about its image. I expect everyone to sneer and throw white gloss over it.

Why did you buy it?

It was a treat. One year I earned a lot of money so I decided to get a nice comfortable car.

What was your first car?

A Vauxhall Nova, which I named Holly after Holsten Pills who were the sponsors of Tottenham, my team. Me and my "yellow peril' went everywhere together. I used to talk to it constantly.

What did it say about you?

Well... it was small and insignificant!

What kind of driver are you?

I don't like other drivers. I'm very careful. Fast but safe except when I go out of control and crash.

Any bad habits?

Other people would say so - especially my husband - but I think I'm courteous.

Any driving test tales?

I failed three times before passing. My instructor failed me on the third test because I was gripping the wheel too intently. He told me I wasn't in control of the car. But I reckon I did more wrong when I passed than on the tests I failed.

Have you ever crashed/got a speeding ticket/got any points etc?

I've had two crashes. The most recent was a few weeks ago coming off a roundabout in the rain. The car went out of control and hit a stationary vehicle - which shocked the man in it who was busy reading his paper. Thankfully we were all OK.

What do you use your car for?

Motorway bashing and shopping, but I am trying to use the bus and Tube a lot more.

Have you experienced roadrage?

I see maniacs on the road all the time. I saw one idiot weaving in and out of the traffic leaving inches between each car. I almost called the police but he escaped.

What sort of state is your car in?

Perfect because it's just back from being repaired. Inside I try to keep it tidy as I'm constantly offering lifts to people.

What's in the boot/glove compartment?

Old Mars bars (I'm a chocoholic), a spare case for the radio, sunglasses and an ice scraper with a glove.

Have you ever had sex in a car

No - but romantic encounters most definitely.

What music do you listen to on the road?

During the daytime pop from Capital radio. At night Radio 2 and Magic for romantic music. I prefer to drive alone as my husband hates music in the car. I'm really into 70s soul right now.

What would be your dream car?

A Peugeot 406 coupe. Everyone groans when I say that but I like functional small cars.

Who would be your dream passenger?

The person who was about to tell me I'd got to No 1 in the charts or sign me to a huge deal.

The Eurovision Song Contest is on Saturday (BBC1, 8pm).

fields.headline: Kia Clarus
fields.trailText: When I review cars made by Korean companies that only the automotive anoraks have heard of I always seem to reach two depressing conclusions. The first is that although the cars are cheap they're not nearly as good as their big-brand competition. And the second is that despite the low list prices they depreciate horribly fast - which actually makes them bad long-term value.
fields.body:
When I review cars made by Korean companies that only the automotive anoraks have heard of I always seem to reach two depressing conclusions. The first is that although the cars are cheap they're not nearly as good as their big-brand competition. And the second is that despite the low list prices they depreciate horribly fast - which actually makes them bad long-term value.

But this really could be the car that breaks the mould. The Clarus is a big family car that starts at a fiver under £11,000. Even in these post competition commission days that's still dirt cheap, because even the entry level 1.8 SX comes with air-con, central locking and power assistance for the bits that need it. However the £12,495 2.0 GSX is the one to have, because the larger 2-litre engine also comes with ABS brakes and alloy wheels.

I'm not going to claim that this is the best looking family car you'll ever see, nor that the interior is the smartest, but I did a 500-mile day-trip in the Clarus and I climbed out of it smiling. If I'd attempted the same journey in a Vauxhall Vectra I would have had to be winched out, because the seats so uncomfortable.

The Clarus drawbacks aren't too terrifying. The first minus mark goes to the fuel consumption, because the 2.0 litre manual can only manage 27.4mpg overall. And that's simply not good enough if you're a high-mileage driver. The second area of weakness is that the safety equipment isn't great. There are endless warning tones to inform you if you've forgotten to do up your flies or whatever, but you'll only find one airbag. And these days that's 3 short of the full set.

These downsides are indicative of the fact that this isn't what you'd call a cutting-edge car - although that doesn't mean that it isn't well- engineered and it is supported by a 3 year/60,000 mile manufacturer's warranty plus roadside assistance.

So that just leaves one question - will your shiny new Clarus plummet in value the second the Kia dealer waves you off the premises? To find the answer I asked CAP Monitor, whose job it is to estimate the likely future value of today's new cars. And at first sight their estimate of the £12,495 Clarus 2.0 GSX's value after three years and 30,000 miles looks much worse than average for the class - because CAP think the Clarus will be worth just £4,400.

However, the Clarus is far cheaper than big-brand cars in its size category, and for £12,500 you're usually only in Vauxhall Astra territory. Now the Astra is a very good car, and CAP confirm that a £12,495 example will indeed be worth £800 more than the Kia when you come to sell. But if you really need the Clarus's extra space then I bet you'd willingly pay an extra £20 a month or so to keep the kids from disembowelling each other on those long journeys. I know I would.

fields.headline: Size is everything
fields.standfirst: No frills, just power. 70s American muscle cars are cool - and available here, says  Will Hodgkinson
fields.trailText: No frills, just power. 70s American muscle cars are cool - and available here, says Will Hodgkinson
fields.body:
"It's designed for customers who prefer going fast but don't like paying for a lot of irrelevant extras," claimed Motor Trend magazine, of Plymouth's 1968 Roadrunner. "It's the simplest, most brazenly pure, non-compromising budget supercar in history." It's as good a description of a muscle car as any: souped-up, stripped-down, lightweight, two-door American street racers, affordable yet high performance, with monster 8-cylinder engines that had a thermal efficiency to make other drivers see red.

Muscle cars, which lasted from the mid-60s to the early 70s, were designed to fulfil every adolescent boy's fantasy of speed, danger and rebellion, and filmmakers soon caught on to the craze. Starsky and Hutch knew that baddies didn't stand a chance of outrunning their magnificent 1971 Ford Torino; a 1970 Dodge Challenger races through the Nevada desert in Vanishing Point and perhaps most fittingly of all given the typical muscle car fan, hick heroes Bo and Luke could never be the Dukes of Hazzard without their General Lee, a 1971 Dodge Charger Daytona guaranteed to make Boss Hogg sweat like a pig.

The muscle car phenomenon began proper when Mopar, the parts wing of the giant Chrysler corporation, started a performance war in 1966 with the introduction of the legendary 426 cubic-inch Hemi - a race-only engine that was adapted for street use and put into cars like Dodge Chargers and Plymouth Satellites. Soon all of the major companies were producing "budget supercars". These cars were sold on machismo and speed. "It snarls, it quivers, it leaps prairies at a single bound," claimed a 1970 advertisement for the Dodge Challenger; in 1969 pictures of a Plymouth Road Runner appeared above the line: "Goes to show that nothing shrinks time and distance like cubic inches and a good induction system." The Belvedere GTX ad went one step further and claimed the car was "strictly for the 'move over honey, and let the man drive' set".

The golden age of muscle cars was at the end of the 60s. Chrysler led the way, and in 1968 introduced the two most revered muscle cars of them all: the Plymouth Road Runner and the Dodge Super Bee. Plymouth realised that the youth market muscle cars were originally aimed at was being alienated by raised prices caused by an increasing number of "must-have" extras, so the Road Runner was a bare-bones car priced at just under $3,000. Most importantly, its 383ci big-block V-8 engine meant that it could run a quarter-mile in 13 seconds. "You know those cartoons about a rapid bird with a 'beep-beep' voice and a penchant for squashing coyotes?" asked the Roadrunner's advertising copy. "Well, Plymouth's built a car with the same name. And personality. It's horn goes 'beep-beep'. And the beat goes on." Plymouth, formerly seen as staid, now had a rebellious, youthful image.

The Super Bee was even more macho, and the epitome of no-frills performance. Dodge didn't bother including hub caps or hood hinges, but they did add mean-looking hood scoops to keep the 440 Magnum V-8 engine cool, with large red letters pro claiming "Six Pack" on either side of them. Cartoons of a snarling bee decorated the hood, doors and bonnet.

The bubble had to burst sooner or later. Manufacturers went from the reasonably ridiculous to the completely ridiculous, with engines getting bigger and the cars getting faster. But demand for such enormous engines was now on the wane, however, and greater awareness of the dangers of illegal drag racing, combined with stringent pollution laws, effectively killed off the muscle car phenomenon by the end of 1971. Manufacturers responded by attempting to sell similar cars to a more sophisticated market: the pricey 1971 Charger R/T was aimed at the racy businessman who appreciated extras like an automatic sun roof and a dictation machine, but the fast times were over.

Of course, a lot of muscle cars ended up on scrap-heaps or at the bottom of cliffs, but so many were produced that there are still a lot around, and to buy one now costs about the same as the average five-year old family saloon - from £2,000 to £8,000. Although classics like the Roadrunner and the Super Bee are rare and very expensive, equally stylish models like the Plymouth Satellite, the AMC Hornet and the Chevy Chevelle are available in the UK through magazines like Classic American and through dealers like American Car Imports. These don't make very good family cars - although huge, half of the space is taken up by the engine, and seating space is limited due to aerodynamic concerns - and they aren't the most economical cars to run. The most powerful ones, such as Dodge Challengers and Ford Torinos, do as little as nine miles to the gallon, but most will do around 15 to 20. As American pollution control is much tighter than in Europe, American cars will sail through roadside emission tests, and all cars made in 1971 or after take unleaded petrol. And because they were designed to make the owner think they were driving a real racing car, most have double seat belts, head rests, and airbags.

The golden rule with buying any old car is to look for rust. "The cars are easily repairable and the parts to most of the cars are still made," says Josh Collins, proud owner of a 1971 Plymouth Satellite. "But if the engine has rusted you can forget it. You should also look for a car with the original factory fittings - muscle cars are very popular with mechanics because they're so stripped down, so a lot of engines get taken out and replaced." Because parts come from the US, a realistic amount needed to keep a muscle car on the road for a year is about £1,000. Another consideration is size: muscle cars look enormous compared to standard European cars, and domestic garages have to be on the large side to accommodate one.

Muscle cars may not have the sophistication of the more famous, smaller American "pony" cars like Corvettes and Mustangs, but they have power, simplicity and in their own way, a lot of style. Snootier elements of the classic car fraternity enjoy referring to muscle car enthusiasts as people with "Camaro cut" hairstyles (mullets), but what do they know? There are few who grew up in the 70s who didn't dream of taking a spin with Bo, Luke and Daisy Duke in that General Lee of theirs, at least to the end of the road and back.

Classic American Magazine, 01925 625 182; American Car Imports, 020-8889 4545

Another consideration is size: muscle cars look enormous compared to standard European cars, and domestic garages have to be on the large side to accommodate one. Muscle cars may not have the sophistication of the more famous, smaller American "pony" cars like Corvettes and Mustangs, but they have power, simplicity and in their own way, a lot of style. Snootier elements of the classic car fraternity enjoy referring to muscle car enthusiasts as people with "Camaro cut" hairstyles (mullets), but what do they know? There are few who grew up in the 70s who didn't dream of taking a spin with Bo, Luke and Daisy Duke in that General Lee of theirs, at least to the end of the road and back. webTitle: All is not what it seems

fields.headline: All is not what it seems
fields.standfirst: So sophisticated is Labour's spin machine that journalists treat as fact events that haven't happened. It suits newspaper proprietors because it's cheap, argues  Jeremy Paxman
fields.trailText: So sophisticated is Labour's spin machine that journalists treat as fact events that haven't happened. It suits newspaper proprietors because it's cheap, argues Jeremy Paxman
fields.body:
On December 12, the Sunday Telegraph carried a story under the headline, "Tests set to sharpen pupils' spelling skills". It read: "Primary school pupils are to be given annual spelling tests set by the government as part of a new drive to improve children's literacy. David Blunkett, the education secretary, will announce this week that every child between the ages of eight and 11 will be expected to master dozens of officially prescribed words each year." And then it listed some of the words they would be expected to know. Eight year olds would have to be able to spell words such as gnash, knickers and rhyme, nine year olds should be capable of handkerchief, corrosive and resurrection. Eleven year olds would have to be able to spell archaeology and aerodynamic.

Well, it's an entertaining story, and it was immediately picked up by lots of other papers. The following morning the Guardian had the same report, augmented by a few comments from the teachers' unions. Two days later, the Daily Mail said that the Department for Education was so alarmed by falling standards that the new tests had been ordered, not by David Blunkett but by his colleague Estelle Morris. Each newspaper printed lists of the words children would be tested on.

The story was fun because it played straight to every parent's anxiety about whether their child was underachieving. And the lists of words provided an instant parlour game. I know - I played it with an eight year old myself. The story also confirmed prejudices about the uselessness of teachers who had learned their trade in the 70s. And it showed - this was the importance of the story to the government - that the government was taking decisive action to make things better.

There was only one thing wrong with this story. It wasn't true. Or rather it wasn't what it seemed. If you read some of the reports closely, they did not say in so many words what they were taken as saying. You could spot the giveaway words. But the inference drawn was that this was another set of tests which the nation's primary school children would have to sit each year. "Primary schools are to be given annual spelling tests set by the government as part of a new drive to improve children's literacy," in the words of the original article.

I called the organisation in charge of school examinations earlier this week. When are these tests being introduced, I asked their spokesman. "They're not," he said.

"But what about all those news-paper reports last December? You mean they were all balls?" I asked.

"The words are yours," he replied.

It's a small example, and I wasn't being entirely fair. If you read the original report closely, there was nothing actually inaccurate about it. It didn't say, in so many words, that there will be yet another set of national exams. What was really happening was that a booklet was being sent out to primary schools, with ideas for improving literacy, including suggestions about playing charades and the like. But the impression conveyed was another matter. It was, in other words, a story which was very effectively spun.

It doesn't matter much. There are much worse things going on. In March this year, Panorama demonstrated devastatingly how the government plays fast and loose with facts in its attempts to persuade us of how brilliant it is. The programme revealed the ingenious technique of double- and treble-counting figures for investment in the National Health Service, which meant that £10.3bn of additional investment suddenly becomes, hey presto, £21bn. And there was the habit of announcing the same funding increase time and again. So an extra £30m to modernise NHS accident and emergency services was announced not once but four times over several months, so that if you blinked, it looked like £120m. This wasn't anything as concrete as an actual lie. But it was distinctly fishy.

Now, I don't blame the government propaganda machine for doing its job as well as it can. Its business is to make the government look good. The machine is now, in the hands of Alastair Campbell and the Downing Street strategic communications unit, more sophisticated than it has ever been. And you have to admire its brilliance. Damn, the thing's so accomplished that it's able to get newspapers reporting things which haven't been said. In January this year, the Times gave an account of a speech in which Tony Blair savaged Ken Livingstone, when the reality was that the reported remarks were never made. The newspaper was going on a press release handed out before the speech was delivered: when it came to the event itself, confronted by irritable Livingstone supporters, Blair dropped the remarks that had been included in the pre-released version of his speech.

I am sure this was just a genuine mistake, but it is symptomatic of something. So, too, is the phenomenon of reporting things before they happen - as in David Blunkett's announcement of new primary school spelling tests. Poor old Matthew Parris, the Times columnist and former Conservative MP, woke up at 6.30am one Sunday in January to hear Radio 5 Live tell him what the prime minister was "expected to say" in a live interview with David Frost in a couple of hours' time. Call me old-fashioned, but I thought what someone said in an interview rather depended on what they were asked. Alastair Campbell, who is an honourable man, says this "expected to say" line did not come from him. In which case, where did it come from?

On the morning in question, the prime minister's spokesman found himself, he said, in the bizarre position of explaining to a BBC journalist what the prime minister had said in the course of the interview. You might have thought that the journalist could have found out by watching the interview, and discovering whether indeed the prime minister had said what he was expected to say. The journalist explained to Campbell that she had been too busy talking about what the prime minister was "expected" to say on other BBC outlets to watch the interview itself. It's a mad world, my masters.

But there's worse even than this example. On another occasion, also in January, Campbell found himself handing out copies of a prime ministerial speech to journalists. He reports one of them saying "What should we say about it?", to which he replied, not unreasonably, "Read it".

Even this isn't the worst example that I've come across recently. On one Thursday afternoon last December, a senior member of the No 10 staff was in one of the House of Commons bars. He was approached by a Sunday newspaper journalist. "Got anything for me?" said the reporter. "The story I have been working on has collapsed and the newsdesk is demanding a front-page splash." No, said the man from No 10, nothing much happening at all now. To which he got the jaw-dropping reply, "I'll just have to make it up then" - and unbelievably, he did.

A story appeared which was a figment of the reporter's imagination. And, because it was printed on a Sunday morning, all the ministers appearing on all the Sunday political chat shows had to spend the day commenting on a policy that did not exist.

I am told - on good authority from a member of the House of Commons lobby - that this sort of thing is not confined to newspapers published on Sundays which happen to fall on a February 29. Don't get me wrong, I am not seeking to run down my parliamentary colleagues, most of whom are doing their level best to discover reality in a hall of mirrors. Their job is made no easier by the fact that the marketplace has become so ruthlessly competitive. Something very odd has happened.

Once upon a time, in the famous phrase Stanley Baldwin borrowed from Rudyard Kipling, what newspaper proprietors were seeking was power (and as he put it "power without responsibility, the prerogative of the harlot throughout the ages"). But nowadays, it increasingly seems to me that newspaper proprietors are a great deal less interested in power than they are in money. There is a simple rule we could apply here. It is this: good journalism is bad business and too often bad journalism is good business.

Finding things out, as anyone who has done any investigative journalism knows, takes time, and time is money. Resources are now so stretched on some newsdesks that no one can spare the time to research a story properly. The consequence is that they are increasingly dependent on what they are told.

And while demand has multiplied, supply is more or less static. One of the oddest manifestations of this tension is the fight to be first with the story. In a 24-hour news culture, what is the point of a newspaper telling you what you think you already know? That is the explanation for all the "expected to say" stories. It can mean that the actual announcement is scarcely covered before the caravan moves on to the next pre-emptive policy disclosure and another occasion for spin. In this world, if you keep moving fast enough the referee hasn't got time to see the dirty tackle.

So, how do we survive spin? The first thing I think we could all usefully do is to stop whingeing about it. Spin-doctors and their pals are the inevitable accoutrements of democracy in a mass media age. They're on the other side of the fence, that's all.

Our approach ought to be to continue doing what we should have been doing all along. It is our job to find out things that people do not want to have found out. But for journalists to function properly, they have to be given freedom and resources. And those will come only from organisations which believe that their first duty is disclosure, not entertainment.

I suggest that it is a sound principle never to treat any comment from any spokesman for any vested interest with anything other than profound scepticism, never to ask for a story, but to find it out for yourself, and if you are ever given a story to ask first why you are being given it.

There is nothing scientific about our trade. Nor, apart from a few basic tricks, can it really be taught. The great Sunday Times journalist Nicholas Tomalin once listed the three prerequisites for a journalist as being a plausible manner, a little literary ability and rat-like cunning. They remain as true as ever. But essentially journalism is a matter of instinct, the expression of primitive curiosity and an instinctive urge to cause trouble, to be difficult, coupled with an atavistic distrust of anyone in authority

In the spin doctor's ideal world, all is managed, smoothed and predictable. In the journalist's ideal world, all is chaos and confusion. It is our duty to bite the hand that feeds us.

This article is extracted from the Philip Geddes Memorial Lecture, which Jeremy Paxman delivered on May 5

fields.headline: Vote Tory? It's a disgrace
fields.trailText: Gott im Himmel! The Mirror says vote Tory. Well, well, well. Fancy that. Who'd have thought it? But there it was, last Wednesday, in a blue box, with a picture of a smiling Steven Norris: "VOTE TORY." The quip used to be that the only Tories who read the Mirror were those who ran it.
fields.body:
Gott im Himmel! The Mirror says vote Tory. Well, well, well. Fancy that. Who'd have thought it? But there it was, last Wednesday, in a blue box, with a picture of a smiling Steven Norris: "VOTE TORY." The quip used to be that the only Tories who read the Mirror were those who ran it.

May 3's historic plea was on the front page, of course, under the Mirror's socialist-red masthead. It really was, I promise. On the left side as well. And just in case readers missed the request, the paper repeated it in a full length Voice of the Mirror.

That editorial was on page six, nine ahead of a page 15 piece on "Britain's most famous dad" (T Blair, not S Norris). After a ramble round the London mayoral houses, the paper that boasted it was "Loyal to Labour, Loyal to You" after the 1997 election, cried that only Nozzer could stop Ken Livingstone. "Mr Norris is a Conservative," declared the Mirror. "So we, Labour's most loyal ally in the press, are urging Londoners to vote TORY. We hope Tony Blair reflects on this decision as he reads his Mirror this morning. And feels utterly embarrassed by forcing us into it."

The decision to join the Conservative cause was the brainchild of editor Piers Morgan and his deputy Tina Weaver. Just about every other senior executive was opposed. Nozzer was, after all, a minister in a Tory administration the Mirror attacked at every opportunity. And a strong showing would, as it was, be claimed as a victory by a Mr William Hague.

Editorship is all about leadership and Piers, a first time Labour voter at the last general election, would have none of it. Conspiracy theorists who whisper that he was put up to it by the Mirror's "editor-in-chief", Alastair Campbell, are wide of the mark. The word from Canary Wharf's 22nd floor is this was a Piers & Tina show, a plea for attention. Miffed at the publicity rivals at the Sun received when Blair wrote a 975-word reply to a May Day attack, they wanted some of their own.

They were incandescent that a prime minister, a Labour prime minister, could demean himself by writing to their bitterest rivals. When the Mirror editorial said it hoped Blair "feels utterly embarrassed by forcing us into it", I bet they hoped he would regret that letter. So relax, Alastair, you are still in control. It'll all calm down. Piers never liked Frank Dobson, anyway.

I started reading the Mirror when Piers still thought it was something in which to check his hair in the morning. I was at the paper when he joined from the News of the World and had the pleasure of writing for him for five years. Piers, despite what you hear about poor political judgment, is a very good editor. He has breathed new life into the paper, making the news sharper, features better and he's got some great columnists.

Alas he is also notoriously thin-skinned for a tabloid editor, reacting very badly to criticism, particularly from former members of staff. Tough. But as well as giving a lead, editors should also be in tune with their readers. The Mirror last urged its massed ranks of loyal readers to Vote Tory at the 1929 election. You know, the one Labour won. And how did Mirror readers vote when it urged them last week to Vote Tory and back Steve Norris? By voting for, er, Ken Livingstone.

I'm afraid "VOTE TORY" must go down as another own goal. Achtung surrender!

Kevin Maguire is a former political editor of the Mirror

fields.headline: 'I thought Norris would be better'
fields.standfirst:
Mirror editor Piers Morgan explains why his paper switched sides in the mayoral race

The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: Mirror editor Piers Morgan explains why his paper switched sides in the mayoral race
fields.body:
For most Mirror readers the words "Vote Tory" have the same shocking and depressing emotional impact as the words "Time gentlemen please" do on George Best. So let nobody think my decision to recommend they cast their support for Steven Norris, the Conservative London mayoral candidate, was some silly stunt designed to get a few cheap headlines.

No, we backed Norris because we had no other viable option. The mayoral campaign conducted by Labour was one of the most clueless and unedifying spectacles I can recall in recent political history. From the moment that Tony Blair and his top advisers decided the only way to stop Livingstone was to rubbish him, they were doomed to abject failure.

I started receiving the "Get stuck into Ken" calls last summer, and they were pretty unrelenting. Yet it seemed obvious to me that this would simply serve to make this lunatic self-publicist a winning martyr. If there is one thing the British public loves more than giving governments a good kicking, it is backing someone who is getting a good kicking by a government.

The more abuse Labour hurled at him, the more popular he became. To the extent that even when some deeply suspicious financial affairs came to light no voters seemed to give a damn. Short of being exposed as a paedophile, there was nothing anyone could say that was going to have any impact.

To compound this nonsense, Labour chose Frank Dobson as the party's official candidate. A jovial bloke with a disturbingly crude sense of humour who stood nil chance of winning, or even coming second. Frank didn't want to stand, he was always going to be perceived as Blair's poodle, and his whole campaign was utterly stunning in its ineptitude.

When it became clear that he was a goner, the Mirror cleared the front page for a direct appeal to make Mo Mowlam run as a candidate. This decision quickly became a "sinister Downing Street plot to knife Dobson". You can't choose a cheese and pickle sandwich for lunch as editor of the Mirror without political pundits suspecting government involvement. The truth was less sinister. I just thought Mo would make a terrific mayor. She's bright, brave, tough and fun. And she stands as easily with Hillary Clinton as a Brixton market trader.

Our own poll said it all. She got 62% of the vote from Mirror readers, Livingstone just 30% and Dobson an incredible 3%. After reading this, Mo was prepared to stand but only if her friend Frank stood down. He refused. Desperate Labour chiefs, led by Tony Blair personally, tried to persuade him. They realised Mo would beat Livingstone and save their skins. But Frank refused all pleas to fall on his sword. He was damned if he'd be humiliated more than he already had been. So Labour was severely embarrassed, and Mr Blair was made to look a fool. What a farce.

And so to "Vote Tory." The Mirror had to back someone; it was either Steve Norris or Susan Kramer. On balance, I thought Norris would be a better mayor. The fact that he's a Tory was almost irrelevant by this stage.

Anyway, it's nothing new for the Mirror to vote Tory occasionally. The paper urged readers to vote Conservative at two general elections - in 1924 and 1929, specifically to "keep out the socialists".

The reaction to our leader was interesting. Our customer services department took just three calls of complaint from readers, the newsdesk a few dozen. Contrast this with the telephonic meltdown that Achtung Surrender! induced in 1996 and it was clear that most readers accepted why we had reached this decision. fields.headline: Maggie Brown's diary
fields.trailText: * Poor Richard Eyre's proposed new role as Channel 5's chair doesn't chime with reality. Gossips say it was a face-saver for the ex-chief of ITV, but a graceful C5's minority shareholder, United News & Media - for which read Lord Hollick - "went ballistic at the news". UN&M is due to take up the chairmanship in eight months. At best, Eyre could stand in for a few months.
fields.body:
* Poor Richard Eyre's proposed new role as Channel 5's chair doesn't chime with reality. Gossips say it was a face-saver for the ex-chief of ITV, but a graceful C5's minority shareholder, United News & Media - for which read Lord Hollick - "went ballistic at the news". UN&M is due to take up the chairmanship in eight months. At best, Eyre could stand in for a few months.

* Mathew Horsman, City analyst and media writer, has pulled out of writing his eagerly awaited book on (Lord) John Birt's reign at the BBC. When the two men met for a detailed exchange, Horsman realised it wasn't possible - he wants to write an objective, frank appraisal.

* Now it's Professor Tony Garnett. At 64, Britain's most respected but media-shy of TV drama producers (Cathy Come Home, This Life, Cops) has been recruited by Royal Holloway, University of London, to help run a new masters media course for budding TV producers. Garnett says, "I've a feeling media courses are real, not a fad, not like sociology in the 60s. I felt it could only be good for all of us if we learn from each other."

* Freelance journalists working in war zones are putting themselves in ever-increasing danger. Supported by the Guardian and others, the Rory Peck Trust, set up in memory of a cameraman killed in the Moscow uprising in 1993, today launches a fund to send freelance journalists on "hostile environment" training courses. For hacks who think avoiding a hostile environment means not going within 10 yards of the newsdesk a hostile environment, they should be a life-saver.

* We have often said that the freedom of information bill is a wholly inadequate piece of legislation. Surprising support came from Elizabeth France, the commissioner who will administer it. She told a Society of Editors' seminar last week that it was badly and grudgingly drafted.

* Barclay Knapp, president and chief executive of NTL, will deliver the Worldview Address at this year's Guardian Edinburgh International Television Festival. Knapp follows Elisabeth Murdoch, Ted Turner, Bob Phillis and Barry Diller in giving the keynote international speech. He will outline his vision of the future on Saturday August 26.

You can contact Maggie Brown at maggiebrown.media@btinternet.com

fields.headline: Adjust your set
fields.standfirst: US viewers faced blank TV screens as Disney and Time Warner went to war. By  Melinda Wittstock
fields.trailText: When two of the world's largest media giants stop talking, everyone listens. A communication breakdown between Time Warner and Disney became big news last Monday when millions of TV viewers in New York, Los Angeles, Houston and eight other US cities were suddenly deprived of America's most popular broadcast network and forced to endure nearly 40 hours without Oprah, NYPD Blue or Who Wants to be a Millionaire?
fields.body:
When two of the world's largest media giants stop talking, everyone listens. A communication breakdown between Time Warner and Disney became big news last Monday when millions of TV viewers in New York, Los Angeles, Houston and eight other US cities were suddenly deprived of America's most popular broadcast network and forced to endure nearly 40 hours without Oprah, NYPD Blue or Who Wants to be a Millionaire?

A minute after midnight last Sunday, Time Warner - the nation's largest cable operator, as well as the world's largest entertainment group - pulled the plug on the Disney-owned ABC network. Its programmes disappeared from 3.5m homes, replaced with a blue screen bearing the Time Warner message: "Disney has taken ABC away from you. We offered a proposal that would have kept ABC for our customers. Disney said no."

The media went into a spin as it scrambled to cover itself, or at least the hardball antics of the people running the show. The consumer had become a latter-day David caught in the crossfire of two greedy Goliaths engaged in a fight to the death over the future of interactive television on cable TV and the internet. It was a public relations disaster, all the more so for Time Warner as it tries to convince federal regulators to give the green light to its purchase by America Online, the world's biggest internet provider. The tactics of its TV putsch gave a hint of what may lie ahead for hapless media consumers - and competitors - at the hands of a mega-powerful AOL-Time Warner. Angry cable customers jammed the switchboards of both companies, while politicians and pundits talked darkly of the dangers of concentration of media power in too few hands.

In New York, mayor Rudy Giuliani attacked Time Warner as an out-of-touch monopoly: "I can't figure out why the Justice Department has spent so much time on Microsoft and so little on this industry." In Washington DC, Republican senator John McCain was among those threatening hearings on Capitol Hill if the two titans couldn't find common ground. "The average consumer should never be held hostage in these disputes," thundered William Kennard, chairman of the federal communications commission, which is reviewing the AOL-Time Warner deal.

The public furore prompted a temporary truce on Tuesday when Time Warner backed down and restored ABC to its cable systems - at least until July 15, the next negotiating deadline.

But the row shows no signs of abating as the rivals return to the negotiating table. "I can only liken this to the behaviour of a schoolyard bully," said ABC spokeswoman Julie Hoover. Fred Dressler, senior vice-president of Time Warner Cable, countered: "Disney is trying to use its ownership of ABC to extract excessive terms for its cable TV channels."

He said Disney's demand that Time Warner shift the Disney Channel from pay-TV to basic cable and carry two other Disney cartoon and soap opera channels would have increased the bills paid by its 12m subscribers by $300m over 10 years. ABC executives called that number "a complete fabrication, totally bogus".

Under a 1992 federal law, a broadcaster such as ABC has the right to negotiate with cable companies that want to carry its programmes. In the past, the four US networks have used these negotiations to gain cash payments from cable operators, or to secure unused channels on the cable line-up to start new channels. NBC won cable distribution for its news channel MSNBC by threatening to withhold its popular programmes from the cable operators.

But it's not the first time Time Warner has used its monopoly to keep rivals off the cable zapper. Two years ago the owner of CNN couldn't find room for Rupert Murdoch's Fox News Channel in New York. Now CNN is down 30% in the ratings, with both FNC and MSNBC clawing away its audience. That's enough to make Time Warner uneasy at the prospect of having to let Disney's cartoon channel compete with its own Cartoon Network, for instance.

More worrying for Time Warner is the threat from satellite providers with interactive services. The cable industry is battling to stop subscribers defecting to satellite providers, with Disney aggressively promoting DirecTV.

"The real winner in this is direct satellite - this may be the thing that pushes it along," says Max Robbins, TV Guide's senior editor. "Viewers always tend to blame the cable operator - that's who they write the cheques to."

But the stakes are even higher, now cable companies are becoming conduits for high-speed internet access with "broadband" cable. Content providers such as Disney want to ensure they can earn revenue as their programmes become a component of new interactive programming. It's no wonder Disney is trying to scupper the AOL-Time Warner hook-up, or at least agree its terms before the ink dries on the deal.

"If Time Warner has the power now to block the top-rated TV network, one can only imagine what AOL-Time Warner will be able to do in the broadband internet arena," says Jeffrey Chester, executive director of the Centre for Media Education.

"That's the big-picture fight here," former FCC chairman Reed Hundt told the Washington Post. "Disney is gearing up to battle for its survival on the internet."

fields.headline: Time to play hardball
fields.standfirst: Wednesday is the deadline for bids for the next round of rights to Premier League football. With tough-dealing club chairmen looking for up to £2bn and broadcasters desperate not to lose out, it's been a rough game to play in.  David Teather  and  Vivek Chaudhary  investigate
fields.trailText: Think back to 1992. BSkyB was still haemorrhaging money, saddled with £2bn of debt and doubts remained as to whether there was a genuine market for pay-television in Britain at all. Then came Rupert Murdoch's audacious and, at the time, highly controversial grab for the broadcasting rights to football's Premier League. Sky saw off a complacent BBC and ITV and never looked back.
fields.body:
Think back to 1992. BSkyB was still haemorrhaging money, saddled with £2bn of debt and doubts remained as to whether there was a genuine market for pay-television in Britain at all. Then came Rupert Murdoch's audacious and, at the time, highly controversial grab for the broadcasting rights to football's Premier League. Sky saw off a complacent BBC and ITV and never looked back.

In Mathew Horsman's history of the company, Sky High, former chief executive Sam Chisholm recalls that in the weeks before screening its first season of the Premier League it was "like Christmas" at its Isleworth HQ as subscriptions flooded in.

Now fast-forward to early 2000. BSkyB directors begin wooing Ken Bates for a stake in Chelsea Football Club and can't fail to notice the new wealth at Chelsea's Stamford Bridge ground. The cluster of bars and restaurants built into the side of the football stadium are surely the best mock Victoriana that money can buy.

BSkyB eventually paid £40m for a 9.9% share. Privately, BSkyB insiders admit that Bates had been a demanding negotiator. "It was like 'AND I want you to sponsor one of our new millennium boxes . . .'"

The Lazarus-like effect that football had on BSkyB's business has turned the game into a hugely valuable currency for broadcasters - a fact the club chairmen are only too well aware of. The meeting during which the tender document for the next set of broadcasting rights was presented to the 20 clubs last month lasted nine-and-a-half hours and descended into a screaming match between Bates and Tottenham chairman Alan Sugar. "The clubs are the biggest bunch of avaricious bastards I've ever come across," said one media executive.

Long gone are the days when the BBC and ITV ran a cosy cartel to keep the cost of broadcasting rights as low as possible and even threatened to walk away from the game. Their last joint contract in 1986 paid just £6.2m for league coverage over two years. Under the current deal, hatched on the eve of Euro 96, BSkyB paid £670m for five years with the BBC winning a highlights package for £73m.

But the stakes are set to reach extraordinary new heights. On Wednesday, bids will be submitted for the next round of rights, set to run for three years from the 2001/2 sea son. Estimates are that the renewed price, which will be agreed in July, could go as high as £2bn.

The balance of power has tilted even further toward the clubs as BSkyB faces increasingly tough competition from a cable industry which has consolidated from eight players in 1996 to just two, a stronger ITV and OnDigital. A more aggressive Channel 4 and Channel 5 could both be in the running for highlights.

There are several different packages on offer. The most attractive will give the winner the rights to 66 live games per season with matches to be shown on Sundays and Mondays. Another 40 matches will be on offer on a pay-per-view basis and there are two highlights packages which will result in more football on TV than ever before.

Clubs will also be given rights to show matches on their own channels and the internet after they have been broadcast live. Bid documents from broadcasters could be as many as 100 pages long and media companies will have to give a number of assurances over how they plan to televise the game and their handling of the product overall.

Football officials will look closely at the scheduling of games, the packaging of match coverage and ideas for the promotion of the sport. In total, 75 tender documents have been sent out and a number of bids have already been submitted to the Premier League's central London headquarters.

BSkyB's acquisition of a stake in Chelsea has been read by many media pundits as a sign of its nervousness. According to research conducted for the then Monopoly and Mergers Commission at the time of BSkyB's failed £623m bid for Manchester United, around 37% of homes would reconsider their subscription to Sky Sports if it lost the Premier League.

The company today has more than 4m subscribers to its own satellite service and another 5m watching Sky programming through cable or OnDigital. Around two-thirds take Sky Sports which, alongside movies, remains the linchpin for subscriptions. Doug Ellis, chairman of Aston Villa, comments: "If Murdoch hadn't got Premiership football he wouldn't have a company today. BSkyB has almost entirely depended on screening live football. It is their bread and butter."

Since its bid for Manchester United was blocked, BSkyB has taken stakes in Manchester City, Leeds and Sunderland as well as holding on to a 9.9% share of United. NTL, Britain's leading cable company, has pursued the same strategy by buying shares in Aston Villa, Newcastle United and Middlesbrough, while Granada owns 9.9% of Liverpool.

As long as the investments don't go above 10%, a media company can hold as many stakes as it wants although the Premier League has hinted that six may be the limit. A league resolution could be blocked by seven clubs voting against it and concerns have already been raised at Premier League meetings that clubs will vote according to their media affiliations rather than for the overall good of the game. Moreover, anyone familiar with the history of the past two sets of rights negotiations will be aware that personal relationships carry a lot of weight.

"Of course we have to be aware of the media connection between clubs," one source said. "It is something that could affect the outcome of any future television deal. But I would be very surprised if clubs voted as one media company bloc because a lot of questions would be asked, particularly from those clubs that do not have any interest from media companies."

Still, the clubs acknowledge the debt they owe to BSkyB which is widely held to have played a key role in the rejuvenation of the game. In the 80s just seven live First Division games were screened a year, compared to 60 from the Premier League under the current deal.

It is often forgotten that before the huge influx of cash from BSkyB, there were widespread fears of bankruptcy among clubs as the post-Hillsborough Taylor Report forced them into costly redevelopments of their stadia into all-seaters.

BSkyB will also be keen to stress recent innovations such as its interactive service where viewers can chose camera angles and watch replays at will. But loyalty is unlikely to weigh too heavily against the lure of pound signs.

Newcastle chairman Freddie Fletcher recalls the days before Sky Sports: "I remember trying to sell a game to ITV when they had the contract and they would say no because Coronation Street was on. Sky has made an enormous difference and have done an excellent job in marketing and building up the game but that is not to say that someone else might not come along and do even better."

Whichever company wins the main live rights, it will probably be forced to make them available to other platforms, just as Sky Sports is made available to OnDigital and cable. But control over production would put the winner on the map and have other knock-on benefits, particularly when selling add-on premium channels.

In the 1996 rights auction BSkyB faced two rival bids. The first from Lord Hollick's United News & Media which owns the Express newspapers and the Anglia, Meridian and HTV franchises. The second was a joint venture between the then Mirror Group and Carlton Communications.Both effectively outbid BSkyB, but there was an unquantifiable profit-sharing element to both. They were rejected in favour of Murdoch's hard cash and the fact that, at the time, BSkyB was the only bidder with an existing platform to distribute pay-TV.

Hollick at least has made it clear he intends to be among the contenders again. "We were an underbidder last time and would expect to bid, with partners, for some or all of the rights," he recently said.

This time around Carlton has an established pay-TV platform through its OnDigital joint venture with Granada and the ITV companies could make a powerful bid, dividing up the live and highlights packages between them. OnDigital recently set up its own sports channel and its appetite for football was demonstrated by the £75m acquisition of rights to screen the European Champions League over three years. OnDigital's broadcasting director Graham Stanley says talks have already begun with the Premier League and describes the forthcoming negotiations as "highly charged and highly complex".

There has been speculation that an investment bank or two may also be considering a bid and then acting as broker, or as a backer for the League to set up its own pay-TV service. Even Channel 5, which has found football a useful ratings booster, is watching closely. The BBC has long resigned itself to the idea that live rights are now well beyond its ambit.

The main rival to BSkyB is viewed by many as NTL, Britain's biggest cable company, fuelled by cash from investors including Microsoft and France Telecom. Chief executive Barclay Knapp said the company, which owns British Eurosport, will "be at the table" but is reluctant to suggest it will slug it out with BSkyB for the key rights. Nor does he rule out an alliance with other broadcasters to share the rights.

"We heard there were a lot of shenanigans last time round," he says. "We have to show up and see what happens. We've certainly got the money, the platform and the production muscle and so are a very credible bidder. But we are not going to pay any price. We are just about used to the current economic state of play with Sky Sports and are not going to get involved in an epic struggle."

Once the deadline is passed, Premier League officials led by chief executive Richard Scudamore will effectively go into purdah to discuss the merits of each bid. This process is expected to take at least two weeks, with media advisers and lawyers working closely with the league to choose which they consider to be the best in terms of price and marketing.

It is still not clear what form the next stage of the bidding process will take - the most crucial phase comprising the group of final contenders. League officials are still deciding whether the second and final round of bidding should involve sealed bids or an open auction, with the relevant rights going to the highest bidder. It hopes to reach a decision by July but has set a backstop deadline of the start of the next season.

BSkyB is widely expected to retain the core 66-game package. Tellingly, though, the Premier League has reduced the length of the contract from five to three years, conscious of the fact that by 2003 the broadcasting landscape could look very different once again.

There is every possibility that by then the cable industry will have consolidated to one player and legislation will have cleared the way for a single ITV company, providing even more serious competition to BSkyB and potentially driving the cost of rights higher once again. Knapp certainly appears to be a man biding his time. If he fails to win a significant chunk of rights this time he will, he says, simply "reload" and focus on the next set.
