Under the current deal, hatched on the eve of Euro 96, BSkyB paid £670m for five years with the BBC winning a highlights package for £73m. But the stakes are set to reach extraordinary new heights. On Wednesday, bids will be submitted for the next round of rights, set to run for three years from the 2001/2 sea son. Estimates are that the renewed price, which will be agreed in July, could go as high as £2bn. The balance of power has tilted even further toward the clubs as BSkyB faces increasingly tough competition from a cable industry which has consolidated from eight players in 1996 to just two, a stronger ITV and OnDigital. A more aggressive Channel 4 and Channel 5 could both be in the running for highlights. There are several different packages on offer. The most attractive will give the winner the rights to 66 live games per season with matches to be shown on Sundays and Mondays. Another 40 matches will be on offer on a pay-per-view basis and there are two highlights packages which will result in more football on TV than ever before. Clubs will also be given rights to show matches on their own channels and the internet after they have been broadcast live. Bid documents from broadcasters could be as many as 100 pages long and media companies will have to give a number of assurances over how they plan to televise the game and their handling of the product overall. Football officials will look closely at the scheduling of games, the packaging of match coverage and ideas for the promotion of the sport. In total, 75 tender documents have been sent out and a number of bids have already been submitted to the Premier League's central London headquarters. BSkyB's acquisition of a stake in Chelsea has been read by many media pundits as a sign of its nervousness. According to research conducted for the then Monopoly and Mergers Commission at the time of BSkyB's failed £623m bid for Manchester United, around 37% of homes would reconsider their subscription to Sky Sports if it lost the Premier League. The company today has more than 4m subscribers to its own satellite service and another 5m watching Sky programming through cable or OnDigital. Around two-thirds take Sky Sports which, alongside movies, remains the linchpin for subscriptions. Doug Ellis, chairman of Aston Villa, comments: "If Murdoch hadn't got Premiership football he wouldn't have a company today. BSkyB has almost entirely depended on screening live football. It is their bread and butter." Since its bid for Manchester United was blocked, BSkyB has taken stakes in Manchester City, Leeds and Sunderland as well as holding on to a 9.9% share of United. NTL, Britain's leading cable company, has pursued the same strategy by buying shares in Aston Villa, Newcastle United and Middlesbrough, while Granada owns 9.9% of Liverpool. As long as the investments don't go above 10%, a media company can hold as many stakes as it wants although the Premier League has hinted that six may be the limit. A league resolution could be blocked by seven clubs voting against it and concerns have already been raised at Premier League meetings that clubs will vote according to their media affiliations rather than for the overall good of the game. Moreover, anyone familiar with the history of the past two sets of rights negotiations will be aware that personal relationships carry a lot of weight. "Of course we have to be aware of the media connection between clubs," one source said. "It is something that could affect the outcome of any future television deal. But I would be very surprised if clubs voted as one media company bloc because a lot of questions would be asked, particularly from those clubs that do not have any interest from media companies." Still, the clubs acknowledge the debt they owe to BSkyB which is widely held to have played a key role in the rejuvenation of the game. In the 80s just seven live First Division games were screened a year, compared to 60 from the Premier League under the current deal. It is often forgotten that before the huge influx of cash from BSkyB, there were widespread fears of bankruptcy among clubs as the post-Hillsborough Taylor Report forced them into costly redevelopments of their stadia into all-seaters. BSkyB will also be keen to stress recent innovations such as its interactive service where viewers can chose camera angles and watch replays at will. But loyalty is unlikely to weigh too heavily against the lure of pound signs. Newcastle chairman Freddie Fletcher recalls the days before Sky Sports: "I remember trying to sell a game to ITV when they had the contract and they would say no because Coronation Street was on. Sky has made an enormous difference and have done an excellent job in marketing and building up the game but that is not to say that someone else might not come along and do even better." Whichever company wins the main live rights, it will probably be forced to make them available to other platforms, just as Sky Sports is made available to OnDigital and cable. But control over production would put the winner on the map and have other knock-on benefits, particularly when selling add-on premium channels. In the 1996 rights auction BSkyB faced two rival bids. The first from Lord Hollick's United News & Media which owns the Express newspapers and the Anglia, Meridian and HTV franchises. The second was a joint venture between the then Mirror Group and Carlton Communications.Both effectively outbid BSkyB, but there was an unquantifiable profit-sharing element to both. They were rejected in favour of Murdoch's hard cash and the fact that, at the time, BSkyB was the only bidder with an existing platform to distribute pay-TV. Hollick at least has made it clear he intends to be among the contenders again. "We were an underbidder last time and would expect to bid, with partners, for some or all of the rights," he recently said. This time around Carlton has an established pay-TV platform through its OnDigital joint venture with Granada and the ITV companies could make a powerful bid, dividing up the live and highlights packages between them. OnDigital recently set up its own sports channel and its appetite for football was demonstrated by the £75m acquisition of rights to screen the European Champions League over three years. OnDigital's broadcasting director Graham Stanley says talks have already begun with the Premier League and describes the forthcoming negotiations as "highly charged and highly complex". There has been speculation that an investment bank or two may also be considering a bid and then acting as broker, or as a backer for the League to set up its own pay-TV service. Even Channel 5, which has found football a useful ratings booster, is watching closely. The BBC has long resigned itself to the idea that live rights are now well beyond its ambit. The main rival to BSkyB is viewed by many as NTL, Britain's biggest cable company, fuelled by cash from investors including Microsoft and France Telecom. Chief executive Barclay Knapp said the company, which owns British Eurosport, will "be at the table" but is reluctant to suggest it will slug it out with BSkyB for the key rights. Nor does he rule out an alliance with other broadcasters to share the rights. "We heard there were a lot of shenanigans last time round," he says. "We have to show up and see what happens. We've certainly got the money, the platform and the production muscle and so are a very credible bidder. But we are not going to pay any price. We are just about used to the current economic state of play with Sky Sports and are not going to get involved in an epic struggle." Once the deadline is passed, Premier League officials led by chief executive Richard Scudamore will effectively go into purdah to discuss the merits of each bid. This process is expected to take at least two weeks, with media advisers and lawyers working closely with the league to choose which they consider to be the best in terms of price and marketing. It is still not clear what form the next stage of the bidding process will take - the most crucial phase comprising the group of final contenders. League officials are still deciding whether the second and final round of bidding should involve sealed bids or an open auction, with the relevant rights going to the highest bidder. It hopes to reach a decision by July but has set a backstop deadline of the start of the next season. BSkyB is widely expected to retain the core 66-game package. Tellingly, though, the Premier League has reduced the length of the contract from five to three years, conscious of the fact that by 2003 the broadcasting landscape could look very different once again. There is every possibility that by then the cable industry will have consolidated to one player and legislation will have cleared the way for a single ITV company, providing even more serious competition to BSkyB and potentially driving the cost of rights higher once again. Knapp certainly appears to be a man biding his time. If he fails to win a significant chunk of rights this time he will, he says, simply "reload" and focus on the next set.

fields.headline: Hit machine
fields.standfirst: A dance single based on a hit gameshow theme tune? Now there's an idea.. John Dugdale  discovers there's more to TV marketing than teatime trailers
fields.trailText: A dance single based on a hit gameshow theme tune? Now there's an idea.. John Dugdale discovers there's more to TV marketing than teatime trailers
fields.body:
How do you create a hit TV phenomenon? The marketing campaigns for Da Ali G Show and Who Wants to be a Millionaire? show how different media need to be orchestrated when a series is launched, and how carefully the programme's brand needs to be developed when it becomes a matter of fielding rather than making calls, of saying "no" (and maybe, occasionally, "yes") rather than "please".

"When Millionaire started," says Adrian Woolfe, marketing head at the production company Celador, "the key thing was to make people aware of the phone-line, not least because that was the way the prize money was generated.

"There was a sponsorship deal with the Sun, and on-air trails 10 days ahead. Everything promoted the phoneline. There were three media days, which was helpful for the listings magazines, but because of the Sun's involvement the other tabloids weren't too interested. In all publicity for series one cost £250,000 but if you add in the value of on-air trails it could be £2m."

Eighteen months on, the format is licensed to 77 countries, and Millionaire is now "a global entertainment brand," says Pippa Burridge, who handles its publicity at Freud Communications.

Celador retains merchandising rights worldwide, and, for Woolfe, the aim now is "maintaining the integrity and longevity of the brand. So far there have only been a few spin-offs - a book, a board game, a chocolate game and a pub quiz machine - and they've all been very successful. This month we're bringing out a dance single based on the theme tune and an album of the show's music cues. Other brands have blitzed and saturated the market place, but we've been very selective."

The sponsorship deal is no more, and promotion is largely via on-air trails. But there has been a change in the way each series is publicised. Largely avoiding the red-tops, Chris Tarrant gives interviews to broadsheets and mid-market tabloids; and these papers are encouraged to run stories on the team who devised the quiz and how it became an international phenomenon. Once in bed with the Sun and coy about the fact that it's a show that rewards brain-boxes, Millionaire is coming out of the closet.

Perhaps surprisingly, promotion of Da Ali G Show's debut was almost as low-key as that for Millionaire's seventh series. "We did a pretty basic, limited campaign," says Polly Cochrane, Channel 4's controller of marketing. "There was a poster campaign using 90 sites - the average would be about 2,000. We did a lot more than 90 for Smack the Pony.

"Besides the posters there were on-air trails, a little bit of radio and press ads on the first day of transmission.

"Essentially we were just telling people 'it's on'. He was already an icon, people were gagging for Ali G. So we took six options for poster executions by The Creative Partnership to Talkback, and rejected the more elaborate ones - we just went with Ali G - Da Show. The golden rule with comedy is not to make claims for the show.

"We're always being accused of over-hyping things, and of concentrating ads and trails on comedy and US series, but this is the same weight of campaign we did for 15 [a documentary about teenagers], which no one seemed to notice. With factual programmes you don't necessarily get the same 'cut-through' into editorial coverage.

"With Ali G, the PR phenomenon was not fuelled by us: it was more a matter of trying to contain it. We'd have preferred his video [released in November] to be out around the time of the new series. You wonder whether you'll be able to sustain it, how you can stop people writing about it." "We did almost nothing," confirms Matt Baker, Channel 4's head of press and publicity. "He [Ali's creator, Sacha Baron Cohen] won't do any press."

If they were trying to stop press coverage, they failed dismally: the run-up to the series' arrival saw red-top coverage of Baron Cohen and self-styled "real Ali Gs" in Staines. In a reversal of Millionaire's subtle repositioning, a figure first glimpsed in a late-night, studenty Channel 4 series now has the tabloids clamouring for pictures and previews.

fields.headline: Virtual reality
fields.standfirst: One 'fake' documentary and your career is over. Or is it?  Fiona Morrow  meets Dominic Savage, back with a new drama after the furore over Rogue Males
fields.trailText: One 'fake' documentary and your career is over. Or is it? Fiona Morrow meets Dominic Savage, back with a new drama after the furore over Rogue Males
fields.body:
Two years ago Dominic Savage's name was mud. Splashed all over the front page of the Mirror, Rogue Males, his documentary for Channel 4's Cutting Edge strand, was alleged to be a fraud and he was accused of cheating his audience.

The Rogue Males were a group of Salford duckers and divers: men eking out a living on the black market, taking a chance on whatever came up. They were by anyone's standards a motley crew, and Savage shouldn't have been surprised when one of them telephoned to say he was about to go to the papers.

The furore ran and ran: the responses of a somewhat bewildered-looking Savage on Right To Reply didn't satisfy a press hungry for the blood of a television channel perceived to be persistently against the establishment grain. It culminated in an apology from Channel 4, and Savage was left with a damaged reputation and a documentary on his CV guaranteed to be mentioned in any subsequent cases of alleged fakery.

It hurt him more personally than professionally: the work has never dried up, though, he admits, at one point he thought his career might be over. Another documentary for Channel 4, The Outsiders, followed, before he sought sanctuary in drama. Nice Girl is a film for the BBC exploring teenage disaffection, promiscuity and pregnancy, based on actual experience and using documentary techniques. It screens on Thursday.

Savage cites the limitations of documentary as the reason for his change of direction. But the documentary form has always been remarkable for its elasticity. Name a handful of well-known documentary film-makers - Errol Morris, Paul Watson, Nick Broomfield, Fred Wiseman - and you will struggle to find a common method in their gathering and assembling of reality. Documentary truth shouldn't be confused with literalism, but by rushing to condemn Savage and, by implication claiming public vindication for their own work, programme-makers allowed the debate to descend into banalities. The line defining what is and is not acceptable television was being drawn by the tabloid press.

But while the reaction was undoubtedly over the top, Savage was not blameless. Because the men in Rogue Males were constantly on the lookout for a scam, he felt that there was a natural blurring of fact and fiction taking place, and that the film reflected that. Where he went wrong was to lose his own sense of what was real and what was not: "At times he was too vague about what had actually happened," a Channel 4 insider told me. "Taking a post-modernist view is all very well, but you have to remember why you are there with a camera in the first place."

When we meet, Savage accepts that in retrospect he could have been more explicit: "Given that I thought it was important to see those people engaged in these activities, maybe it should have been signposted better. Perhaps the whole thing should have been more dramatic."

He remains adamant, however, that the film was a truthful interpretation of a particular way of life, "There is nothing in me that wants to fabricate, or lie, or make things up. I suppose some people could say I was naive, but I think naivety is an important characteristic of a documentarist, and I've always enjoyed the process of discovery while making a film."

He bears no ill will to Allan Birkin, the rogue male who sold his story to the Mirror: "People in that situation will do anything for a few bob, and to further themselves," he smiles, "so maybe you just shouldn't make contentious films about people who might let you down."

It was the reaction of his peers which stung him: "How can you take a moralist, purist stance? If you felt that strongly about it you wouldn't do it at all, you wouldn't take real people and put their lives on screen, you would just be their friend or something. At times it did feel like I was the sacrificial lamb."

He also thinks that Channel 4 could have handled things better: "There were lots of divisions. The commissioning editor, Charles Furneaux, was very supportive, but perhaps if there had been a bolder, more united response, it might have gone away. Certainly the apology didn't help matters."

The apology was issued by the then recently appointed head of factual programmes, Steve Hewlett. Straight from the BBC, Hewlett felt that an apology sent a clear signal about the new regime and would draw a line under all the fuss. One source suggested to me that Hewlett had done his best, while Michael Jackson didn't take it very seriously to begin with and then didn't have a clue how to handle it. (After the channel was fined £10,000 for inaccuracies in the rent-boy film, Chickens, a fellow executive asked Jackson how much he thought Rogue Males would have cost in a similar action, "Ten quid," was his reply.)

Jackson may have considered the allegations against Rogue Males to be largely spurious (a position with which others privately concur), but the intense press scrutiny did cause many film-makers to reassess their position. The downside was the assumption that authorship was the problem, that somehow the popular docu-soaps were more realistic simply because they didn't take a point of view. More positively, many film-makers chose to hold the debate on camera, making themselves and their interventions obvious to the audience.

For those interested in the point at which fact becomes fiction, drama or docu-drama seemed an appropriate arena in which to continue their explorations. The results have been mixed. Losing no opportunity to gain ground over his arch-rivals on Cutting Edge, Stephen Lambert, then editor of BBC2's Modern Times, announced that the much-admired documentarist Paul Pawlikowski, best known for the sublime Tripping With Zhirinovsky, would be taking on the challenge to try something truly different in Twockers, a film based on the lives of juvenile car thieves.

But Pawlikowski appeared trapped within the newly drawn boundaries, and the film, though nicely directed and acted, had none of the urgency or relevance a documentary might have managed, and lacked the power of a well-written fiction.

If Penny Woolcock's Tina Goes Shopping was more successful dramatically, it also underlined the confusion that labelling such a film can still create. Funded by the documentary department, Tina was a drama created from a documentary imperative, and although Channel 4 went to great pains to explain the process at work, the explanation seems to have left some of the audience behind. Subsequent viewer complaints over a scene depicting the domestic slaughter of a cow highlighted the problem.

Commissioning editor Peter Dale denies that there was any confusion, adding: "I think that what is important is to be absolutely clear to the audience what they can expect to see. This format is possibly the only way to show the lives of people on the margins of our society."

It seems a wise move on Savage's part, then, to be as upfront about his methods and intentions in Nice Girl, the story of a Welsh teenager pregnant and married (like her mother and sister) before turning 16, which was co-funded by the BBC's drama and documentaries departments. "When we started we didn't really know what route we were going to take," he explains. "I didn't know if I would use real people, playing themselves, but it became clear that that was inappropriate and wouldn't have worked." An amalgamation of two real stories, Nice Girl features newly trained actors in an improvised script, written as they went along. Most reminiscent of Ken Loach's Cathy Come Home, the film falls down, ironically enough, at the points where Savage tries too hard to convince us that this is real.

He is aware of the problem: "I tried it, and next time I would do things differently - make sure that certain things that need to be said are scripted. One shouldn't stick too hard to a doctrine, you should do whatever feels right at the time, and there are things in documentary which I might once have tried but wouldn't do now."

Nice Girl: BBC2 Thursday 11 at 9pm

fields.headline: All about my father
fields.standfirst: Martin Amis is one of the most celebrated, and vilified, novelists of his generation.  Here he tells  Alan Rusbridger  why, after the death of his father; Kingsley, he decided to put the record straight - and settle a few scores
fields.trailText: Martin Amis is one of the most celebrated, and vilified, novelists of his generation. From tomorrow, the Guardian is serialising exclusive extracts from his brilliant autobiography, Experience, the most eagerly anticipated book of the year. Here he tells Alan Rusbridger why, after the death of his father; Kingsley, he decided to put the record straight - and settle a few scores
fields.body:
Hear Martin Amis talking to Alan Rusbridger:
About how he knew he'd write about his father
On how he didn't enjoy settling scores
Questioning his own memory
On reactions to his autobiography
About divorce
On when not to write
On why his writing is disliked

This business of writing about writers is more ambivalent than the end-product normally admits. As a fan and a reader, you want your hero to be genuinely inspirational. As a journalist, you hope for lunacy, spite, deplorable indiscretions.

That, as it happens, is not me on Amis: it's Amis on Bellow. But he is right. You read the book, you enjoy it. Then you go along intent on teasing out all the deplorable indiscretions that you feel are so regrettably missing from the text. "You write with commendable restraint about your rift with Julian Barnes . . . perhaps you could - in the relaxed ambience of your sitting room over this agreeable glass of Chardonnay - just tell me what you really feel?"

But two things intervene: one is that Amis is a very practised interviewee. Indeed, he's regularly been at both ends of the microphone over the years and, under questioning, is remarkably disciplined. Time and again he refers you to what he says in his book. And you have to sympathise with that. The stuff about the falling-out with Barnes is there in this new book of his: it is taut, deliberate and precise. Why muddy it with a casual aside? And the other thing is that Amis appears, at this stage of his life (or maybe it was just the day I caught him), remarkably mellow and un-spite-filled. There are pushchairs by the garden gate of his handsome north London house. The interview is punctuated by the counterpoint of child and baby sounds from the kitchen.

And that mellowness seems to inform this latest book, his autobiography, or memoir, Experience. "When I sat down to write it, I thought that scores would be settled - that that would inevitably be part of it," he says. "And when I finished the book, I realised how little of that there had been. And I was surprised at how little I enjoyed the short passages where I do settle a score. There are only two or three of them, perhaps."

And it's true. There is a short, brutal lunge at the writer James Buchan ("a humourless worthy") over a review of Time's Arrow which accused Amis of writing about Auschwitz for "profit". There is the settling of accounts, if not scores, with Barnes. There is some fun at the expense of Eric Jacobs, aka the Biographer. And there is a sharp kick on the shins for his former agent Gillon Aitken. And that is about it on the spite front.

We meet at his home - not quite Camden, not quite St John's Wood, and, pace the fourth estate, certainly not Manhattan. He is just off a plane from Los Angeles, where he has been a) at a literary conference, and b) researching the Californian porn industry. His inquiries in relation to the latter were thorough enough to have included an encounter with an ageing pornographer who specialised in videos devoted to anal sex - "the arse man of the millennium".

He draws on a thin cigarette and tackles the question of why, at 50, he should have turned to autobiography. "I think I always unconsciously knew that I would have to write about my father simply because of the rarity of our case." But it is not simply a book about his father? "It feels like a book about my father. I felt it come upon me after he died, perhaps in the year between his death and the memorial service. A great deal of energy went into just formalising that, and not much work was possible. But I was thinking in the back of my mind, 'Well, now's the time to begin this.'"

The result is, he says, his life "to the best of my recollection", which did not prove infallible. "I thought I had a good memory, but I've already been corrected on a couple of things. One little thing, one really rather serious case of false memory - it was not that I invented anything, but I kind of transposed two events in time. I'm not going to say what they are, but I didn't feel I could change it at proof level. I thought, 'I'll print it and, you know, if there are consequences I'll take them, and then I'll perhaps in future editions add a footnote saying, 'I've got this wrong and it's the other way round.' You trust to the integrity of your memory and then you check the details as much as you can. But I thought I had a very good memory and have now begun to doubt that a bit."

He has never resorted to psychoanalysis and never would. "Certainly not. I would fear that as a magician would fear showing his tricks. Since, as a writer, you're totally dependent on your unconscious, I wouldn't want anyone going in there."

His father, in an attempt to overcome his phobias, had tried analysis. "The psychiatrist after a couple of sessions said, 'You know, the reason that you can't go on an underground platform is that you were an only child and you feared another child appearing in your mother's tunnel.' And Kingsley thought, 'Well, I may be a bit neurotic, but I'm not that daft.'"

The Amis story - senior and junior - is familiar enough to even the casual reader of the mid-market and broadsheet press. The Amis marriages, the Amis divorces, the Amis (senior) ménage, the Amis (junior) dentistry: "the usual stuff", as Amis calls it. And that very familiarity is, he says, part of the point of wanting to write the story himself - to reclaim it from the unauthorised version that is out there.

"It's already public, so much of it, but distorted from all kinds of crazy angles. So that was definitely another attraction: to think that this will be the version that lasts longer than yesterday's Daily Mail, or whatever it might be." Nevertheless, there are things missing from the book that were not missing from the Daily Mail version. He writes briefly about the pain of his own collapsed first marriage, but none of the accompanying circumstances. "I thought I wouldn't do that, because I know my first wife wouldn't want me to; and also, for that reason, I didn't want to either. It wasn't that I was suppressing it. I did try to give appropriate weight to what a dreadful failure that was for me.

"The key to it all was that I remember saying to myself when my parents broke up, 'I'm never going to get divorced, I'm absolutely not going to do it.' So it's a sort of lifelong defeat, whose essence is really that you're doing to your children what was done to you. You are, perhaps, weakening their capacity for love, and that's a solemn and a sombre matter."

The desire to recover some measure of control over his own life story also explains why a dentist should play an improbably prominent role in the book. This is not a book for anyone with a fear of the chair or the drill. There are tooth-by-tooth, month-by-month descriptions of painful progress with syringe, saw and pliers on jaw, gum and teeth.

This may not fall into the explicit category of score-settling, but nor is it there by accident. Casual Amisites will know the saga: Amis Jnr sacks agent (Pat Kavanagh, wife of Julian Barnes) in order to plunder huge advance so as to pay for cosmetic work on molars to accompany mid-life crisis and new wife. No one reading this book will believe that any longer. Ask him if there is too much on the teeth in the book and the mellow mood is almost punctured: "I would have failed entirely in my purposes if there hadn't been too much on teeth. In one of those soul-searching media pieces at the time, I remember Mark Lawson saying, 'There has been a lot written about his teeth, and maybe we should have been told more about the teeth to make sure we got that right.' And I would like to say to Mark, 'Here's more about the teeth, and perhaps you can now see that it wasn't your business.' Tell my dentist that it was cosmetic."

Which does leave the question of the reportedly huge advance, even if it wasn't going on cosmetic dentistry. Was money the sole cause of the split with Kavanagh which led to the severing of the Amis-Barnes friendship? "Well, I mean, Pat was and is a first rate agent, but it - no, I wouldn't say it was money. It got out of control, that whole negotiation, and I sort of wondered why it had got out of control. That might have been the one time in my life where I thought I wanted to see what I was worth, in the middle of other crises. But it was being said that I was holding out in this megalomaniacal fashion for the chimerical half a million pounds. But how can a writer hold out for that? You can't force the issue, but that's how it was being presented, and to such an extent that I felt my only way of surviving it was to jump ship."

Is this really plausible? To pretend it was not ultimately about money seems far-fetched. Amis counters that Wylie sorted out his foreign rights - not handled by Pat Kavanagh and in a mess. But he adds: "What I care about is literary durability. That is all that matters to me, and I'm just happy enough when I have an advance of £250. My father felt that way, too - that such rewards as you got were pleasant but it wouldn't change you, and, even if your books were turned down for publication, you would go on."

He pauses: "How long one would go on remained the great question."

And is he still on non-speaking terms with Barnes? "No. When we meet, we chat, yes. You know, it's not what it was, but it's . . ."

You can say what you like about the English, but they can still surprise you, and I felt profoundly surprised."

If what he's talking about is a brand of Philistinism, then one would expect other English writers to cop it. I used to flatter myself by thinking it was something to do with my fictional prose. I thought my prose put people on their mettle and made them rivalrous and defensive, as if they see themselves stepping into a novel of mine and getting the treatment or something. Valued reader, it is not for me to say this is envy. It is for you to say that this is envy."

But in general, he thought my stuff sniffed of the lamp." He was, maintains his son, "a much sweeter man than his public persona, and I think that in getting that across I can also deal with those times when he was ornery."

The father-son-ness at the heart of the book has not led him to thinking too deeply about questions of heredity, which, like Freudian theory, he considers over-scientistic. "There is a difference between me and my father - and that difference is my mother. Giving in to failures of tolerance was certainly a flaw of his, and I'm on the lookout for it in myself.

"It's not only in positive ways that your parents teach you how to live: they give the occasional negative examples as well. But, funnily enough, he did a pretty good job of raising his [family]. It's not every man whose three children are around him when he dies in the spirit that we were around him." But all this concentration on his relationship with his father has, he says, given him an appetite for the autobiographical. "I obviously did not get enough memoir out of me because I'm writing another memoir at the moment, which is political. So there are reminiscences about Kingsley, you know, once a communist, later a quote, unquote 'fascist' - the fascist lunches and all that. And then my two great friends, James Fenton and Christopher Hitchens, being Trotskyists. So, there's more to come, and perhaps I'm slightly addicted to the form."

For now, he has never felt better. "Finishing The Information was tremendously difficult because I felt so physically awful when my marriage was breaking up, and it is interesting how physical it is. Guilt is not just an intellectual difficulty, it affects the whole body, guilt and remorse. I've never felt keener to get to my study than I am now."

Has fatherhood second (or, on some accounting, third) time round - his two sons followed by three daughters (one entering his life nearly 20 years after her birth) - altered his views on feminism? "No. I wrote a piece about Gloria Steinem in 1984 or so, and she actually converted me because her arguments are irresistible."

webTitle: 20m children victims of war, report says

fields.headline: 20m children victims of war, report says
fields.trailText:
Twenty million children have been uprooted from their homes by war, according
to a chilling new report from Save the Children.
fields.body:
Twenty million children have been uprooted from their homes by war, according to a chilling new report from Save the Children.

The report, War Brought Us Here, lists the worst places in the world to be a child. Rock-bottom is Angola, where no fewer than 1m children have no home.

In Sierra Leone, tens of thousands of children have been mutilated, raped and terrorised. Many have been forcibly recruited by rebels to serve as child soldiers.

"These are some of the most vulnerable children in the world, exposed to violence, mutilation and separation from their families," the report says.

Other black spots include Colombia, Sri Lanka and Kosovo.

The children made refugees by wars in their own countries are the most vulnerable to violence, ill health and hunger, SCF says. They are often beyond international help and at the mercy of those who drove them into exile.

"Providing protection for internally displaced children is a global responsibility," says SCF's director general Mike Aaronson.

The new report comes just two days after former South African president Nelson Mandela and his wife, Graca Machel, announced plans for a world summit on the plight of children, to be held in September.

The summit will be organised by the United Nations Children's Fund, which estimates that 2m children have been killed, and 6m wounded, in conflicts in the past 10 years.

Save the Children
SCF Forgotten Children campaign
US Campaign against child soldiers

fields.headline: Man arrested in Manilla over Love Bug virus
fields.standfirst: Female hacker started love bug
fields.trailText: A 27-year-old man was arrested in the Philippines today after police searched the home of the suspected author of the Love Bug computer virus, which attacked computers across the world.
fields.body:
A 27-year-old man was arrested in the Philippines today after police searched the home of the suspected author of the Love Bug computer virus, which attacked computers across the world.

The couple who owned the Manila apartment were out at the time of the raid, but the man later returned and denied any involvement with the virus, local radio reports said. He was taken away in handcuffs by National Bureau of Investigation (NBI) officers for questioning, officials said.

Gil Alnas, chairman of a local residents' association, said the investigators seized 17 items, including computer magazines, telephones, diskettes, wires and cassette tapes. No computer was taken away.

Federico Opinion, the head of NBI, said agents had obtained a search warrant after three days of fruitless efforts to seize evidence that might point to the source of the virus which penetrated computers last week, including those of Parliament, the Pentagon and the CIA.

The NBI was unable to obtain a search warrant until today because under Philipine laws hacking is not a crime, but officers eventually obtained a search warrant under the Access Device Act, which governs use of codes, account numbers and passwords giving access to different types of devices. The law provides for a maximum punishment of 20 years in jail.

For several days, information culled from various Philippine internet service providers indicated that the programmer of the Love Bug, the most virulent computer virus ever created, was a 23-year-old male living in Pandacan. However, NBI officers said last night that the suspect was a woman.

Speculation about the source proliferated over the weekend, after the virus coursed through computer systems in more than 20 countries.

A computer expert in Sweden who helped the FBI last year to trace the Melissa virus said that the person behind the Love Bug virus was an 18-year-old German exchange student in Australia using the name Michael. Australian police said they had been given no firm evidence to back up the allegation. Meanwhile, in Japan thousands of people returned to work today after a week's holiday to find the virus waiting in their computers. Despite government officials and antivirus software companies issued emergency warnings to computer users not to open suspicious-looking files in their e-mails, the number of infected files soon reached 73,000.

webTitle: Mayor Ken changes the political weather

fields.headline: Mayor Ken changes the political weather
fields.standfirst: Guardian correspondent Will Woodward looks at Livingstone's first day as official mayor
fields.trailText: Monday, 1pm: Guardian correspondent Will Woodward looks at Livingstone's first day as official mayor.
fields.body:
The sun has put his hat on for Ken, just as he did to celebrate Labour's election victory in May 1997.

Even for hardened Kennists, it must have lacked the sheer overwhelming relief of those now-distant May days, when people ran to Whitehall to cheer the man in Downing Street rather than throw bottles at the gates. But there are certain similarities.

Not just because the weather got better. Some people were surprised to find that when Londoners elected Livingstone as mayor, the sky didn't fall in. Like Tony Blair, mayor Ken has made a virtue of getting stuck in to his new post, offering jobs hither and thither, attempting to shrug off his undoubted exhaustion after a gruelling campaign and instead hit the ground running. He'll deserve his summer break.

What it doesn't feel like is Ken's takeover of May 1981, when he grabbed the GLC leadership in a putsch after Andrew (now Lord) McIntosh had taken Labour to victory. No voter can claim they were deceived; Ken's victory on Thursday, even as an independent candidate without a party machine, was one of the least surprising results in election history.

And there's none - well, make that little - of the sense of the left-wing rebels storming the citadel. Who'd have thought in 1981 that Red Ken would one day offer a job to a Thatcherite Tory, as he has to Steve Norris? That Mr Norris - as Ken knows - is highly unlikely to accept it, lessens but does not extinguish the sense that this is a very different time from way back then. Once it was us and them: now the emphasis is on inclusivity, on reaching out.

This is Ken as US-style Democrat, not as leftist bogeyman. There will still be people for the right-wing to get in a lather about, like black activist Lee Jasper, a new official adviser to the mayor. And Ken is already threatening to take the government to court over its public-private plans for the tube. He won't stop being a crack member of the SAS (Super-Awkward Squad).

However, so much of the tone of what mayor Livingstone will be doing in the early days of his rule is to say to Blair: what on earth were you worried about?

But in offering the deputy mayor post to Labour London assembly member Nicky Gavron, and the police authority chairman job to arch-Blairite Lord Toby Harris, Livingstone also lands Number 10 with a dilemma of dilemmas. If they accept, Labour is tied in to a Livingstone administration; there to share the blame if it fails, unlikely to share the credit if it succeeds. If it does work, Labour will soon be hard-pressed to explain why Ken is banned from being a party member.

Still to be continued is the saga of Livingstone's relationship with Labour, the party he loves, would like to lead, and hurt him so by kicking him out. The sub-text, and the text, of so many of his actions, will be about working through his complex and difficult relationship with the party that made him. He desperately wanted to be mayor; but he is a reluctant independent.

webTitle: Paras prepare to evacuate Britons from Sierra Leone

fields.headline: Paras prepare to evacuate Britons from Sierra Leone
fields.trailText: British paratroopers arrived in Senegal today preparing to evacuate British citizens from neighbouring Sierra Leone as rebel fighters threatened to undermine a fragile peace accord with the government.
fields.body:
British paratroopers arrived in Senegal today preparing to evacuate British citizens from neighbouring Sierra Leone as rebel fighters threatened to undermine a fragile peace accord with the government.

Geoff Hoon, the defence secretary, said he was deploying 700 to 800 personnel to the region. A British advance party is believed to be already in Sierra Leone as troops and Royal Navy warships assemble in the region. Mr Hoon said the substantial force was necessary because of the confused and volatile situation in the West African country.

"We have to make sure that they have the resources to protect themselves, as well as those they are seeking to evacuate," he said. He did not explicitly rule out the involvement of British troops in military action to support UN peacekeepers overseeing the deal brokered last July.

Thousands of Sierra Leoneans gathered in the streets of Freetown today, calling for peace and denouncing the rebel Revolutionary United Front. Demonstrators converged on the city's main sports stadium in preparation for a rally to demand that the RUF and rebel leader Foday Sankoh release hundreds of UN staff they have been holding captive for the past week.

"We are on the streets today to show the world that Foday Sankoh is nobody but a monster who wants to kill the people of Sierra Leone," said Abubakarr Sillah, one of the demonstrators.

The Foreign Office urged British nationals to leave Sierra Leone, after the rebels took hostage at least 300 UN peacekeepers and started marching on the capital, Freetown. Another 200 UN peacekeepers are missing in the interior of the country. One of those abducted is a British military observer who had been working with the UN.

The first flight of British troops arrived in Senegal early today. The frigate Chatham, the helicopter carrier Ocean and three support ships are due to arrive off the West African coast in the next few days.

Mr Hoon said the troops would be in place "very quickly" should the situation deteriorate and would remain for "as long as it takes to secure the situation and allow British nationals to leave safely". Five hundred British nationals are estimated to be in Sierra Leone. British military advisers flew into Sierra Leone at the weekend to advise the UN, whose peacekeeping operation is in danger of unravelling. Around a dozen men will be based in Freetown, where they will assess the technical support needed to enhance the effectiveness of the UN force of 8,000. The British team, drawn from all three armed services, was put together in response to a call for reinforcements from UN secretary-general Kofi Annan. Britain's shadow defence secretary Iain Duncan Smith said it was vital for British troops to be kept to a limited and precisely defined mission to aid British nationals, rather than becoming embroiled in the chaos of Sierra Leone's civil conflict.

"The concern I would have is that it is clear in their mandate that they are there to get the British nationals out, but not to get sucked into a civil war," he said. "In these sorts of circumstances, once they are deployed, you don't want them hanging around for any great period of time. Otherwise, what happens very quickly is that they get sucked into that deteriorating situation and will need heavier and heavier equipment and firepower to secure their position."

The much-criticised peace deal brokered by the UN last July was supposed to end one of the most vicious civil wars in Africa during which RUF rebels mutilated and tortured civilians as part of their terror campaign. RUF leader Foday Sankoh was brought into the government as vice-president and his supporters were supposed to give up their arms. But disputes have arisen over power and control of territory, particularly diamond-producing areas.

webTitle: Controversy reigns as Juve edge closer

fields.headline: Controversy reigns as Juve edge closer
fields.standfirst: Sean Ingle on an action-packed weekend across the continent
fields.trailText: Serie A
fields.body:
Serie A

Juventus are on the brink of securing a record 26th Serie A title after an Alessandro Del Piero header - his first goal in open play since October 1998 - helped them snatch a 1-0 win against Parma.

However Del Piero's strike was overshadowed by controversy when Fabio Cannavaro's apparent 90th minute equaliser was disallowed by referee Massimo De Santis. The referee cited pushing in the penalty area as the reason for his decision - a view not supported by television replays.

The decision brought back memories of 1998, when Juventus edged Inter Milan to the title in what was dubbed 'The Season of Poison' because of a series of dubious refereeing decisions in the champions' favour.

Italy's biggest sports daily, La Gazzetta dello Sport, revived those same concerns, headlining "The poisoned league title" on the front page and adding "Mystery foul: Cannavaro's 1-1 not given".

Juve remain two points clear at the top, with just one game remaining. But Lazio ensured the title race will go down to the last weekend of the season with a 3-2 win away at Bologna.

Portuguese international Sergio Conceicao gave Lazio the lead, only for Giuseppe Signori to equalise. But further strikes from Diego Simeone and Marcelo Salas put the game beyond Bologna's reach, despite Signori scoring a second late on.

After the match Lazio president Sergio Cragnotti was fuming about the Juventus decision. "Lazio deserve the league title, both morally and for their football," he said. "We've shown that we're clearly superior in the head-to-head matches, and that it wasn't by chance that we beat the league leaders (last month). For me, Lazio have won the league."

The title will be decided next week, when Juventus travel to Perugia and Lazio host Reggina. If Juventus draw and Lazio win the sides will be tied on 72 points and the championship will be decided by a play-off for the first time since 1964.

Elsewhere, Inter were thrashed 4-0 at home to Fiorentina - the worst home defeat in their 92 year history. Enrico Chiesa scored either side of half-time for the Viola, before Gabriel Batistuta and Mauro Bressan completed Inter's misery.

It wasn't all bad news for the Milan clubs however. A late Andrei Shevchenko penalty earned AC Milan a 1-1 draw away at Roma, after the home side had taken the lead through Zago. The Rossineri are now three points clear of Inter, and look certain to get the third automatic Champions League place.

Torino were relegated after they went down 2-1 away to Lecce. David Sesa put them ahead but goals from Marco Ferrante and Alessandro Conticchio sent them down.

Primera Liga

After throwing away the Primera Liga title twice in the early 1990s, Deportivo La Coruna seem hell-bent on doing the same again this season. Fortunately for them, none of their rivals seem to want to take advantage.

With just ten minutes to go in their match against third-placed Real Zaragoza, Deportivo had one hand on the Liga. Djalminha's low drive had just put then 2-1 ahead, and if they could hold out they would move five points clear at the top - with just two games left.

But then Djalminha suffered a moment of madness. After scoring what he thought was the winning goal, the Brazilian striker wheeled away and removed his shirt in celebration. The referee had no choice but to book him - and unfortunately for Djalminha it was his second yellow card of the match and he was sent off.

Four minutes later, Zaragoza took advantage of the extra man when Xavier Aguardo was left unmarked at the back post. He powered home a header and the game finished 2-2.

Second-placed Barcelona were unable to capitalise on Deportivo's failings however as they continued their woeful run of form with a shocking 2-0 home defeat by Rayo Vallecano.

Rayo took the lead after nine minutes when Jose Antonio Bolo volleyed home Carlos Mestre Lorens' powerful cross. And though Barca dominated possession they only once came close to equalising, with Jari Litmanen blazing over the bar from close range.

Vallecano defended well and always looked dangerous on the break. And three minutes from time Bolo broke away to score Vallecano's second.

After the game Barcelona fans waved white handkerchiefs and called for Louis Van Gaal to be sacked. However the Dutchman has vowed to fight on: "Things don't go as you expect. My thoughts are on how to escape from this slump. We need more aggression, more joy in the way we play the game."

Real Madrid also suffered a shock home defeat to little Alaves, after Azkoitia scored two minutes from time. Alaves are now in fifth position in La Liga, while Real dropped to sixth, leaving them in danger of missing out on Europe next season. Valencia moved into fourth place with a 4-0 win over Real Sociedad. Angulo, Lopez, Carboni and Mendieta scored the goals.

Finally, Athletico Madrid have dropped down into the Segundo Liga for the first time in nearly 70 years after a 2-2 draw with Oviedo.

Oviedo were two goals up through Roberto Losado and Paolo Bento, but when Joan Capdevila grabbed one back after 71 minutes, and Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink hit a 76th minute equaliser, Althletico looked on the verge of a remarkable comeback.

With six minutes remaining Atletico were even awarded a penalty when Hasselbaink was tripped in the box. But the former Leeds striker's weak penalty was easily saved by Esteban.

After the game club President Jesus Gil remained upbeat. "At this moment I don't feel sad. You have to overcome a drama such as this. We are more united than ever and we will confront this problem and fight to return to the First Division."

German Cup final

Bayern Munich notched up their 10th German Cup with a comfortable 3-0 victory over Werder Bremen.

After a tight first half Brazilian striker Elber scored from close range in the 57th minute. Bayern then resisted Werder pressure and goals from Paulo Sergio and Mehmet Scholl in the last ten minutes sealed the win.

webTitle: Nicky Peng on his amazing debut

fields.headline: Nicky Peng on his amazing debut
fields.standfirst: Durham's Nicky Peng, aged only 17, taught the champions, Surrey, a lesson or two  about batting last Tuesday. Making his first-class debut, he scored 98 in a match  dominated by bowlers and when Durham wrapped up a shock victory inside three  days, Peng's team-mates ushered him forward to lead them off the field. It was  Surrey's first Championship defeat for two years. Their captain, Adam Hollioake, described Peng as "the best young player I have ever seen". Peng is in the England Under-19  team and is studying at the Durham Cricket Academy. The day after the match he  spoke to wisden.com about his innings, and again showed a maturity beyond his  years.
fields.trailText: "I thought I'd be nervous when I first got out there, but the wickets fell really quickly so I didn't have a chance to get worried. It was really strange at first, batting against people who you watch on telly. I admire Alec Stewart and love watching him bat but unfortunately I didn't get the chance to play against him. [Stewart was injured.]
fields.body:
"I thought I'd be nervous when I first got out there, but the wickets fell really quickly so I didn't have a chance to get worried. It was really strange at first, batting against people who you watch on telly. I admire Alec Stewart and love watching him bat but unfortunately I didn't get the chance to play against him. [Stewart was injured.]

"It was a slow wicket which didn't suit us, but it didn't bother me. I just got out there and got on with the job. Me and Paul [Collingwood] had to steady things as we were 48 for four at the time. He took a lot of the pressure off me at the start and he made a good 50. He kept on encouraging me and just telling me to keep going. I've batted a couple of times with him in the B&H Cup and it was good to go in with someone I knew. I wasn't too bothered about getting off the mark but it was a great feeling when I did with a cover drive off Ian Bishop. That's one of the few shots I remember.

"Ben Hollioake and Bishop were bowling and then Martin Bicknell came on and bowled really accurately. I probably struggled the most against him in both innings because he was so tight. Alex Tudor added that bit of extra pace, which actually helped me on the slow pitch. I hit a couple off the middle and it all went from there.

"It wasn't until I reached the 40s that I became nervous really. Then it sort of hit us and I got a bit edgy. I got some stick at the start from Adam Hollioake and the others saying I should go back and revise for my GCSEs, but I didn't let it get to me. I expected that sort of thing and I guess a lot of the players are arrogant on the pitch. They have to be, I suppose.

"Paul [Collingwood] and Speighty [Martin Speight] gave me loads of encouragement. Speighty is never shy of having a few words and he told me just to wait for the bad balls and keep going. He said I was going to get nicks because of the pitch and not to worry about them. I got my 50 with two defensive shots which were a bit edgy through the slips but I had them under control all the time.

"I don't remember much more until I got to the 90s with a four and then I got nervous again. The ball before I got out I hit straight back past Ben Hollioake, and that's the one I remember the most. fields.headline: Rumours Unlimited
fields.standfirst: All today's rumours put in a barrel, and shot
fields.trailText: David Ginola will leave Tottenham in the summer, according to the Mirror. The Frenchman has fallen out with manager George Graham after being dropped for Saturday's match against Man Utd, and told the paper: "If I cannot start, I will not play." If the 33-year-old does leave White Hart Lane, Fulham are favourites for his signature.
fields.body:
David Ginola will leave Tottenham in the summer, according to the Mirror. The Frenchman has fallen out with manager George Graham after being dropped for Saturday's match against Man Utd, and told the paper: "If I cannot start, I will not play." If the 33-year-old does leave White Hart Lane, Fulham are favourites for his signature.

The Mirror also reports that Marc Overmars will stay at Arsenal next season. The Dutch winger had been tipped for a move to Barcelona but, after the Gunners qualified for the Champions League last weekend, he appears to have changed his mind. "I am pleased we have made it because I have to play at the highest level," he said, adding "I see a lot of good things happening here."

Brian Kidd is set for a move to Leeds United. The former Blackburn manager is better known as Sir Alex Ferguson's former assistant. The Daily Mail suggests that his role will be to develop the youth system at Elland Road into one that rivals Old Trafford's.

Teamtalk suggest that Celtic striker Mark Viduka is in talks with Leeds over a possible move. Viduka, top scorer in the Scottish Premier League, is expected to leave Glasgow this summer with Chelsea, Tottenham and a clutch of continental clubs vying for his signature. But Leeds are thought to have stolen a march on their competitors as Viduka is keen to play with Australian international team-mate Harry Kewell.

Rangers have made a £10m bid for Juventus's Darko Kovacevic. Kovacevic only joined the Turin giants last summer, but he is third choice striker behind Pippo Inzaghi and Alessandro del Piero. "We have made an offer for this player," Rangers chairman David Murray confirmed. "At the moment, we can say no more than that until we hear something further from Italy."

Everton are ready to part with England under-21 left-back Michael Ball, suggest Planet Football. Walter Smith is strongly tipped to bring Arsenal's Nigel Winterburn to Goodison Park in the summer, and that could signal a bidding war for the 20-year-old Ball. Both Arsenal and Manchester United have been linked with the player in recent seasons.

fields.headline: News in brief
fields.trailText: Neve Campbell suffers 'Shakespeare' stalker, Schumacher off Queer as Folk, Godard plans court drama , Michael Flatley scripts romance, and Cate Blanchett on the casting couch
fields.body:
 Alas, poor Neve... Scream star Neve Campbell is being stalked by a man who thinks he's William Shakespeare. The actress has hired bodyguards, who presumably won't find the be-stockinged fiend difficult to pick out in a crowd. A friend says of the Bardic threat, "the stalker is always writing her love poems dedicated to his 'Juliet' and signed by 'Romeo'. This creep writes long, perverse poems dedicated to her character".

 In news that will come as a relief to fans of the explosions-free original, Joel Schumacher won't direct the American version of Channel 4 hit Queer as Folk. "I would love to do it, but my schedule doesn't permit it", said the action director, threatening nonetheless to remain "creatively involved" in the project.

 Legendary French director Jean-Luc Godard has expressed interest in making a film about tennis, according to reports at Ain't it Cool News. In an interview with Cahiers du Cinema, the doyen of the New Wave posited a 4 or 5 hour saga chronicling match after match at the famous Roland Garros tournament contested yearly in Paris. Sounds a thriller...

 Also at Ain't it Cool News, confirmation that Irish fleet-footer Michael Flatley is to move into the movie business. The Riverdance creator will be sailing into Cannes on May 14 to announce details of a romance he's co-scripted "about a poor guy who falls in love with a rich girl and you have to wait to see what the ending is". Oh dear...

Casting couch

German director Tom (Run Lola Run) Tykwer will make his English-language debut directing Heaven, a Miramax production that will form the first in a trilogy of films based on screenplays by the late Krzysztof Kieslowski. Cate Blanchett is in talks to star, as a Scottish woman who moves to Tuscany and begins a relationship with a young Italian man.

Angela Bassett will star opposite Robert DeNiro, Edward Norton, and Marlon Brando in The Score, in which a young thief (Norton) blackmails an old master thief (who else?) into one last job.

webTitle: Livingstone sworn in as London mayor

fields.headline: Livingstone sworn in as London mayor
fields.trailText: Ken Livingstone heralded the return of democratic government to the capital as the former GLC leader was formally sworn in as London mayor today.
fields.body:
Ken Livingstone heralded the return of democratic government to the capital as the former GLC leader was formally sworn in as London mayor today.

"This is the restoration of democratic government to London and this is a historic moment," Mr Livingstone said as he signed a declaration of office, along with nine members of the newly elected Greater London assembly at a brief ceremony at its temporary headquarters in Westminster.

Mr Livingstone meets Nicky Gavron later today to discuss his offer to her of the deputy mayor position. Reports yesterday suggested Ms Gavron, a Labour councillor and assembly member, had accepted the position, but she confirmed she would consult the Labour party first.

"I want to discuss the details of the role and then, because this is a new style of government with transparency and openness, talk to other colleagues," she said.

Members of the London Labour party are reported to be divided over whether to accept the job offers doled out by Mr Livingstone over the weekend.

Mr Livingstone's announcement that he would like Lord Harris of Haringey to chair the new Metropolitan police authority does not pose a problem for the party, as it is a position decided by the assembly members and not the mayor's personal powers of patronage. Lord Harris will announce his decision tomorrow.

Labour is more concerned by the deputy mayor position, which is directly created by the mayor. If Ms Gavron accepted, she would help lead London development and planning and share a certain degree of collective responsibility with the mayor.

While Mr Livingstone has signalled his desire to rejoin the Labour party he was expelled from last month, the party fears that, should his administration goes astray, Labour members at its core could be tarnished by association with Mr Livingstone.

Mr Livingstone will learn this week whether his attempts to create an inclusive, cross-party administration are to succeed. He offered Green party assembly member Darren Johnson the environment brief, which he is likely to accept, and Frank Dobson a position of "poverty tsar", which he is almost certain to decline.

Liberal Democrat assembly member Lord Tope has indicated he is unlikely to accept Mr Livingstone's offer to head the fire and civil defence authority, preferring the Lib Dems to concentrate on equality and social justice issues.

Mr Livingstone is also waiting to learn whether his former mayoral rivals Conservative Steven Norris and Liberal Democrat Susan Kramer will accept a shared responsibility for the transport brief, an area fraught with future conflict as the mayor and deputy prime minister John Prescott jostle over tube funding.

 Mr Livingstone's declaration

I Kenneth Robert Livingstone, having been elected to the office of mayor of London, declare that I take that office upon myself, and will duly and faithfully fulfil the duties of it to the best of my judgment and ability.

I undertake that, in the exercise of my functions of that office, I will have regard to any guidance with respect to ethical standards issued by the secretary of state under section 66 of the Greater London Authority Act 1999.

fields.headline: Diff'rent role for sitcom star
fields.trailText: Think Ronald Reagan. Think Clint Eastwood. Think Glenda Jackson. Think Gary Coleman? Unlikely as it may seem, the pint-sized former child-star of Diff'rent Strokes is hoping to join the ranks of luvvies-turned-politicos by running for the US Senate
fields.body:
Think Ronald Reagan. Think Clint Eastwood. Think Glenda Jackson. Think Gary Coleman? Unlikely as it may seem, the pint-sized former child-star of Diff'rent Strokes is hoping to join the ranks of luvvies-turned-politicos by running for the US Senate.

Coleman, whose acting career has included movies such as The Fish That Saved Pittsburgh and 1994's Party, as well as the hit sitcom, has announced plans to fight for California's seat in the American legislature. He readily admits that it may be tough to live down his embattled reputation - his career hit the skids when Diff'rent Strokes ended in the mid-80s, and his name has been linked to a series of ever more desperate and despairing gestures to remain in the public eye. His last brush with bad publicity came when he became the unlikely target of assault charges.

Of his bid for political power, Coleman claimed he's considered running in the high-profile New York campaign, but had decided against it because, unlikely Hillary Clinton, he didn't wish to "represent a state I don't know anything about". The celeb has yet to decide under which party he'll run: "I'm such a radical," Coleman's quoted as saying, "I might have to run as an independent".

fields.headline: Backs against the wall
fields.standfirst:
The UN must not abandon Sierra Leone

Background: Sierra Leone's troubled times
fields.trailText: The United Nations mission to Sierra Leone was looking disaster in the face last night. In the space of a torrid few days, four peacekeepers have been killed, several hundred taken hostage, and the power-sharing agreement brokered in Togo last July with rebels of the Revolutionary United Front (RUF) has begun rapidly to unravel.
fields.body:
The United Nations mission to Sierra Leone was looking disaster in the face last night. In the space of a torrid few days, four peacekeepers have been killed, several hundred taken hostage, and the power-sharing agreement brokered in Togo last July with rebels of the Revolutionary United Front (RUF) has begun rapidly to unravel.

Although there are hopes that a new mediation effort will yet calm the situation, fighting reportedly continued east of Freetown while aid workers and foreign nationals wondered whether to flee the jittery capital.

The problem, however, is that a UN decision to abandon its mission would certainly presage an even bigger disaster for the long-suffering people of Sierra Leone. Having finally become involved in trying to rebuild this tragic country after a lengthy, brutal civil war in which many tens of thousands of civilians were killed, tortured and mutilated, the UN must not even think of backing off now.

Since the UN mission was launched last December as a replacement for a Nigerian-led West African force, Foday Sankoh, the RUF leader, has, by stages, put the UN's commitment to the test. The main disagreement is ostensibly about the pace and scope of RUF disarmament; but the prime issues are power and control of territory, particularly diamond-producing areas.

While the 1,600 Nigerians attached to the UN force are familiar with the undisciplined but fearsome rebel army of up to 15,000 men and boys, and with the terrain, the mission's Indian commander and detachments from Zambia, Jordan, Kenya and elsewhere are new to the job. The 8,000-strong force is still one quarter below strength and not yet fully equipped.

These difficulties have been compounded by severe communciation problems and bureaucratic snafus. Diplomatic efforts to defuse the crisis have, meanwhile, been equally chaotic, with Kofi Annan, the UN secretary-general, appealing dramatically to western countries for emergency troop deployments while half a dozen regional leaders engaged in apparently uncoordinated mediation attempts.

Quite apart from the killing and hostage-taking, reminiscent of the UN debacle in Rwanda and its humiliation by the Bosnian Serbs, many UN weapons and vehicles are now in RUF hands. President Frederick Chiluba of Zambia voiced bitter frustration at the weekend, openly calling into question the competence of the force commanders. The proposed UN force for the Congo, and peacekeeping programmes generally, are certain to suffer if the Sierra Leone mission collapses.

It is easy to blame the UN for this shambles - but not wholly fair. The US and other permanent member of the Security Council have steered clear of military engagement in Sierra Leone. Britain, whose involvement has been minimal so far, announced the despatch of 700 troops last night but stressed their role would be limited to assistance with evacuations.

Nigeria, the regional power best able to impose order, complains with justice that it received scant help with the costs incurred by its earlier involvement, and is hard put to do more. Unlike Australia in East Timor (or the US in the Balkans), no heavy-hitter is prepared to show a military lead, to enforce the peace as the essential precursor to the reconstruction of civil society.

The dangerous reality is that the UN mission to Sierra Leone is undermanned, under-funded, undersupported and, at present, almost overwhelmed. The international community can and must do better than this. Its responsibility does not cease just because it is Africa.

webTitle: Gladiator chariots to top of US box office

fields.headline: Gladiator chariots to top of US box office
fields.trailText: The Russell Crowe-led swords-and-sandals epic Gladiator charioted straight to the top of the US box office this weekend, albeit with underwhelming opening figures
fields.body:
The Russell Crowe-led swords-and-sandals epic Gladiator charioted straight to the top of the US box office this weekend, albeit with underwhelming opening figures. Its $32.7m haul may have been the second-biggest so far this year, but the figure falls far short of recent early May hits such as last year's The Mummy or 1998's Deep Impact. Nevertheless, its release is being heralded as the opening salvo of moviedom's juggernaut season: "this", said a spokesperson for DreamWorks, "will jump-start the summer season".

Box office observers calculate that Gladiator's numbers will increase gradually. The year's first $100m budgeter is, unusually for blockbuster releases, an R certificate, only three of which have ever grossed above $200m.

Meanwhile, UK hit Human Traffic was given a restricted and ultimately disappointing release across four sites in LA and one in New York. The Justin Kerrigan-directed comedy about a group of clubbers reaped a screen average of only $2,100.

Nevertheless, its release is being heralded as the opening salvo of moviedom's juggernaut season: "this", said a spokesperson for DreamWorks, "will jump-start the summer season". Box office observers calculate that Gladiator's numbers will increase gradually. The year's first $100m budgeter is, unusually for blockbuster releases, an R certificate, only three of which have ever grossed above $200m. Meanwhile, UK hit Human Traffic was given a restricted and ultimately disappointing release across four sites in LA and one in New York. The Justin Kerrigan-directed comedy about a group of clubbers reaped a screen average of only $2,100.

fields.headline: UK troops for Sierra Leone
fields.standfirst:
Flight from Freetown: Britons evacuated as civil war worsens

Background: Sierra Leone's troubled times
fields.trailText: A battalion of 700 British paratroopers were flying into Sierra Leone last night as the rapidly deteriorating security situation persuaded the government to advise all Britons with no essential reason to remain to leave the west African country.
fields.body:
A battalion of 700 British paratroopers were flying into Sierra Leone last night as the rapidly deteriorating security situation persuaded the government to advise all Britons with no essential reason to remain to leave the west African country.

The first battalion of the parachute regiment, currently the British army's spearhead unit, was landing in Freetown to help evacuate civilians and, if necessary, UN troops.

The mobilisation of the paras, who flew out in three planes from RAF Brize Norton in Oxfordshire, follows the arrival in the Sierra Leone capital on Saturday of a 15-strong "technical assistance" team from the ministry of defence permanent joint headquarters. Two RAF Hercules transport aircraft were on standby in nearby Senegal.

Geoff Hoon, the defence secretary, said he was also deploying the helicopter carrier HMS Ocean, the frigate HMS Chatham and three support ships as a precautionary measure to safeguard the safety of British nationals.

The UN mission to Sierra Leone is in crisis after more than 300 of its peacekeepers, including a British army officer, were taken hostage by rebel forces of the Revolutionary United Front (RUF) led by Foday Sankoh.

At least 200 other UN soldiers, mostly Zambians, are reported missing and may also have been abducted. Four peacekeepers, all Kenyans, are confirmed killed by the rebels.

MoD sources insisted last night that the paras were there solely to assist with UN evacuation plans. "There is no question of [their getting involved in] combative action", a Whitehall source said. There are normally about 500 Britons in Sierra Leone, although some may have left already.

However, there are likely to be fears that British troops could be sucked into the nine-year civil war. According to the UN's spokesman, Philip Winslow, the rebels advanced yesterday to within 40 miles of the capital in defiance of the ceasefire agreement, under which power is shared between Sierra Leone's elected government and the RUF.

Mr Winslow said that UN troops had been involved in clashes with up to 1,000 rebels carrying "infantry-type" weapons and moving in armoured personnel carriers captured from the UN.

There were reports of fighting on Saturday between the important crossroads town of Masiaka and Rogberi, about 40 miles east of Freetown. A Sierra Leone army officer based in Masiaka said rebels had overrun the town of Lunsar to the east of Rogberi, forcing UN troops to pull out.

The UN has a force of around 8,700 troops in Sierra Leone, due to reach its full strength of 11,000 by July.

The foreign secretary Robin Cook announced yesterday that he was cutting diplomatic staff in Sierra Leone, but reaffirmed support for the UN peacekeeping mission.

The move follows the decision of the United States to airlift Americans out of the country. Italy has evacuated 21 of its citizens, leaving some 30 still in Sierra Leone.

Several thousand refugees fled across Sierra Leone's border with Guinea over the weekend, while dozens of aid workers and missionaries were gathering in the capital awaiting evacuation.
