fields.headline: Obituary: Douglas Fairbanks Jr
fields.standfirst: Movie star who picked up his father's swashbuckling style and later cut a dash in high society and royal circles
fields.trailText: Movie star who picked up his father's swashbuckling style and later cut a dash in high society and royal circles, Douglas Fairbanks Jr, has died aged 90
fields.body:
Douglas Fairbanks Jr, who has died aged 90, carried his father's name proudly, though he had to overcome paternal neglect and the comparison with one of Hollywood's legendary stars. Although an attractive and competent actor, he was also runner-up to similar dashing, well-spoken, romantic leads such as Errol Flynn, an exact contemporary, and Ronald Colman. Nevertheless, he managed to carve out a satisfactory career for himself in the movies, and become a prominent personality in other fields.

Despite having all the advantages of a Hollywood kid, his childhood and adolescence were not propitious. Because there could be only one Douglas Fairbanks, his father and mother, Anna Beth Sully, a Rhode Island heiress, referred to their child as "the boy". His Irish nurse pronounced it "bye', and from then on he was called Bye by his family and friends.

Douglas Sr, always insecure despite his stardom, later confessed that he had "no more paternal feelings than a tiger in the jungle with his cub." As Bye grew into a chubby child, and his father was forced on occasions to take his son out, he was obviously uncomfortable at being seen with him. This reserve and restraint rubbed off on the boy. "I never kissed him until he was on his deathbed," Doug Jr recalled.

Out of guilt, his father gave his son a pony, but one day the boy came home to find that his father had given it to Prince Hirohito of Japan. His mother, on the other hand, tried to give him double helpings of love. He was brought up by her from the age of nine when his parents divorced.

The young Fairbanks sculpted and painted from early youth, exhibiting at 13, and made his screen debut at the same age in Stephen Steps Out, an unsuccessful attempt by Jesse Lasky to exploit the magic of the Fairbanks name.

A few years later, when Doug Jr told his father, now married to Mary Pickford, that he wanted to become an actor and not go to Harvard, he threatened to disown his son, and cut him out of his will.

Without his father's financial assistance, Fairbanks accepted bit parts and wrote titles for silent films. Gradually, he started to get juvenile leads, notably in Stella Dallas (1925) as Loise Moran's upper-class beau.

In 1927, he was set to star opposite Greta Garbo in Women Love Diamonds, but when the Swedish star went on strike for more pay, he got Pauline Starke instead. However, the following year he was recompensed by being fourth-billed in Garbo's film A Woman of Affairs.

In 1929, he married up-and-coming star Joan Crawford. His father called her a cradle snatcher (she was five years older than the groom) and an opportunist who wanted to marry a famous name.

Doug Jr and Joan appeared together as a married couple in Women Love Dia monds, but were divorced four years later after she had deceived him with Clark Gable.

From 1930 to 1935, Fairbanks was in great demand, playing, as he remarked, "big roles in little pictures, and little roles in big pictures." The big pictures included Howard Hawks' The Dawn Patrol, in which he was Neil Hamilton's kid brother sent on a fatal mission, and Little Caesar when he was Edward G Robinson's driver with ambitions to gangsterhood.

The best of the smaller pictures were the screwball comedy Love is a Racket, the real-time one-location drama Union Depot, and the boxing melodrama The Life of Jimmy Nolan, with excellent varied performances from Fairbanks. In Morning Glory (1933), he played a writer in love with actress Katharine Hepburn, an unrequited emotion he felt for her offscreen.

The following year, he came to England to play the Grand Duke Peter opposite Elisabeth Bergner in Catherine the Great for Alexander Korda. Fairbanks coped well as the Tsar who loses his wits, while Bergner turned on her over-girlish charm, encouraged by the indulgent direction of Paul Czinna, her Hungarian husband.

Goebbels did not ban the film in Germany but got the Nazi press to call it a film "produced by and starring Jews". (Fairbanks' paternal grandfather was a Jewish lawyer called Hezekiah Charles Ulman.)

In 1935 Fairbanks was living beyond his means, and immersed in an affair with Gertrude Lawrence with whom he starred as the Bohemian Rudolphe in the film Mimi, and in the West End in Moonlight is Silver. However, he managed to raise enough capital to set up his own English-based company, Criterion Productions.

The Amateur Gentleman (1936) - the first and best of three pictures for Criterion, was set in Regency times. He played an innkeeper's son who poses as a gentleman pugilist to gain entrance to the court of the Prince Regent.

His father (reconciled with his son) arrived with Lord and Lady Louis Mountbatten at Elstree to watch the shooting. They were suitably impressed by the largest set built for a British film to date, a 13,000sq ft reconstruction of the ballroom at Carlton House for the Prince Regent's ball. But the picture didn't do as well at the box-office as was hoped, and Criterion struggled on with two more lame productions.

Fairbanks was carrying on an affair with Marlene Dietrich, who used to smuggle him into her hotel room at Claridge's, when he met socialite Mary Lee Hartford at a party given by Merle Oberon. His wild oats sown, he married her in 1938, a marriage that lasted for 50 years until her death.

Meanwhile, back in Hollywood, Fairbanks had made a splendid Rupert of Henzau, the soldier-swordsman in The Prisoner of Zenda (1937) whose confrontation with the film's hero, Ronald Colman, provides the film's exciting climax.

A number of good parts followed, in which he was able to put on his pukka accent and a pith-helmet in British colonial adventures. In fact, his accent bore a striking resemblance to Ronald Colman's distinctive British tones. "By Golly" was one of his favourite expressions.

In George Stevens' Gunga Din (1939) Fairbanks was the gentleman soldier at the side of rough Victor McLaglen and cheeky Cary Grant, a devil-may-care trio fighting a murderous sect of religious fanatics in India. (It was filmed in Lone Pine, California.) In the same year that his father died aged 56, Fairbanks made a conscious decision to emulate his celebrated swashbuckling style.

He took the title roles in The Corsican Brothers (1941), with 21-year-olds Mario and Lucien (Fairbanks was a young-looking 32) setting out to avenge their father's death. The picture was reminiscent of his father's 1922 Robin Hood, and after the second world war Doug Jr gave an acrobatic performance as Sinbad the Sailor (1947), a reasonable attempt to rival his father's in The Black Pirate. In The Fighting O'Flynn (1949), he portrayed a kind of Irish musketeer, scaling walls and leaping across roofs with reckless abandon.

During the war, as a lieutenant commander in the US Navy, Fairbanks had participated in several combined Anglo-American operations (recalled in his memoirs, A Hell of a War) and in 1949 he was made an Honorary Knight of the British Empire for "furthering Anglo-American amity." Other honours he received were the Légion d'Honneur and Knight Grand Officer of King George I of Greece.

After retiring from the screen in the early 1950s Fairbanks, an avid Anglophile, settled in London for many years with his wife and three daughters. He thrived on eminent social and political connections, which included a close relationship with the royal family.

"I am not a socialite," he once declared, "though I seem to have got the reputation for being one. I have some very good friends who happen to be in so-called Society; but Society as such is a bore and holds no fascination for me."

However, whoever was invited to No 8 The Boltons in Kensington, from the highest in the land to the lowliest of hacks, was greeted with charm and impeccable courtesy.

During the 1960s, he introduced and sometimes acted in a British TV drama series Douglas Fairbanks Presents, from which he made a lot of money to add to the fortune gained from the manufacture of popcorn, and from the rights to his father's films.

In 1973 he and his wife sold their London home and settled in Palm Beach, Florida. Soon after, Fairbanks returned to the stage in My Fair Lady in LA and San Francisco, The Secretary Bird in Chicago and Present Laughter in Washington.

In 1976 he appeared at the Phoenix Theatre in London in The Pleasure of his Company in a role that could have been written for him, that of a rich, witty and urbane globetrotter.

In 1990, Fairbanks married again at the age of 81 to Vera Shelton who survives him as do three daughters from his second marriage. Two years later, he was named as the mysterious headless man in a photo used in the Duchess of Argyle divorce case of 1963. He always denied that it was he, though the Duchess was a close friend. By golly, what a life!

webTitle: End of an era as Douglas Fairbanks Jr dies, aged 90

fields.headline: End of an era as Douglas Fairbanks Jr dies, aged 90
fields.trailText: Douglas Fairbanks Jr, a member of one of Hollywood's great screen dynasties and one of the few remaining links to the silent movies era, died yesterday aged 90.
fields.body:
Douglas Fairbanks Jr, a member of one of Hollywood's great screen dynasties and one of the few remaining links to the silent movies era, died yesterday aged 90.

The actor, producer, author and businessman who was awarded an honorary knighthood in 1949 for "furthering Anglo-American amity" made his film debut 77 years ago in Stephen Steps Out.

His father was one of the original movie swashbucklers, his stepmother was actress Mary Pickford, the first of his three wives was Joan Crawford, and he claimed to have had affairs with Marlene Dietrich and Gertrude Lawrence.

It was once said of him: "The trouble with Douglas Fairbanks Jr is that he likes everything he sees - and he sees everything."

Fairbanks was born in New York but spent much of his time in London, where he studied painting and sculpture, and made his West End debut in Moonlight is Silver in 1934.

His business interests ranged from ballpoint pens to film production and he appeared in about 75 movies, including Catherine the Great, The Prisoner of Zenda, Gunga Din, Little Caesar, Sinbad the Sailor and State Secret. Yet he always regretted not writing a play.

"I never tried to emulate my father. Anyone trying to do that would be a second-rate carbon copy," he once said. "I was determined to be my own man, although having the Fairbanks name did make it easier to get into an office to see someone."

Fairbanks was the first US officer to command a British flotilla of raiding craft in a commando operation during the second world war. He served under Lord Mountbatten.

The actor became a friend of the Queen and Prince Philip and entertained them at his house in London.

"Entree into the Fairbankses' home is a hundred times more difficult that getting a ticket for the coronation," a columnist wrote.

"I've led an enormously lucky life," Fairbanks said in 1989. "I've done what I wanted to do. I worked hard and played hard, and it was all tremendously rewarding. I just wish it could go on and on and on."

webTitle: G7 fiddles as heat on euro is turned up

fields.headline: G7 fiddles as heat on euro is turned up
fields.standfirst: Economic and Monetary Union: special report
fields.trailText: If ever there was a case for another bout of G7 intervention in the foreign exchange markets it is now. Since January last year, the euro is down by almost a third against the dollar, while the once mighty German mark has fallen by 60% against the greenback in five years.
fields.body:
Sometimes it's Washington, London or Paris. Sometimes it's somewhere more exotic. But on almost any day of the year, officials from the Group of Seven industrial nations will be up there in the skies en route for another round of jawing about the global economy.

Every now and then, the officials give way to the central bank governors and the finance ministers at the apex of the G7 system. Four times a year they meet, chat, have lunch or dinner (normally both), issue a communiqué, hold a press conference and then fly out.

In the past 15 years an inordinate number of air miles have no doubt been accumulated by all this globe-trotting, but it is now perhaps time to ask a rather pointed question: what is the purpose of the G7?

In theory, the answer is simple. The G7 is there so that the leading industrial nations can exchange information, coordinate macro-economic policies and oversee the smooth running of the global economy by ironing out any little wrinkles that appear from time to time.

Originally, this meant sorting out problems caused by currency misalignments in an era of floating exchange rates, with the highpoint the 1985 Plaza Accord which launched co-ordinated intervention to drive down the US dollar.

The Plaza Accord was a success. Indeed, it could be said that America's industrial renaissance in the 90s was, in part, caused by the devaluation of the dollar between 1985 and 1987, since it removed one of the factors hastening US de-industrialisation.

Intervention went out of fashion in the 1990s, but Plaza showed that intervention can work, provided the action by central banks is coordinated and determined.

The case for defence

And if ever there was a case for another bout of G7 intervention in the foreign exchange markets it is now. Since January last year, the euro is down by almost a third against the dollar, while the once mighty German mark has fallen by 60% against the greenback in five years.

For the European Central Bank this is all a terrible embarrassment, given that all the talk in the run-up to monetary union was about how the euro was going to be a macho currency that would challenge the dollar for global supremacy.

(That, incidentally, was what all the euro enthusiasts in the UK said pre-1999 when they warned that the only way to prevent sterling from becoming the seven-stone weakling of the foreign exchanges was for Britain to embrace monetary union. Funny that).

The silver lining to the euro's decline is cheaper euroland exports, giving a considerable boost to industry. Even so, there is a political cost to devaluation-induced growth, as John Major found in the aftermath of Black Wednesday.

A plunging currency saps political legitimacy, something of a problem if your aim is ever-closer European integration.

When the euro fell below 90 US cents last week, alarm bells started to clang in Frankfurt and Brussels, with the first indications that the ECB might rouse itself from its torpor and take action to defend the single currency.

Wim Duisenberg, fresh from his Wilsonian "euro in your pocket" remarks on Friday should tell every member of the ECB board, every finance minister and every two-bit politician across Europe to button their lips.

But actually the crisis of the euro is no longer a problem just for the ECB. Japan's faltering recovery is not being helped one bit by the yen's appreciation against the euro, while the impact on the US threatens to be catastrophic. It is the global implications of recent currency movements which make it vital that the G7 becomes involved.

The US is already running a trade deficit of around $30bn (£19bn), a figure which is slightly distorted by last year's rise in oil prices but is on a definite upward trend nevertheless. For the past two months, US exports have been falling as the loss of competitiveness has fed through to manufacturing, while the strength of domestic demand is sucking in imports.

The dollar's over-valuation does for the US economy what the pound's over-valuation does for Britain. Firstly, it throws the economy out of kilter by over-stimulating the sheltered parts of the economy at the expense of the tradeable sector. Secondly, it attracts hot money into the country to finance the current account deficit because investors perceive no currency risk. Finally, it makes the inflation figures look deceptively good, even at a time when there are clear signs of overheating.

As the International Monetary Fund pointed out in last month's world economic outlook, the stability of the global economy requires a re-balancing of the world's three big blocs, with slower growth in the US and faster - domestic-led - growth in Europe and Japan.

If that happens, the US current account deficit should start to come down, the US might avoid a hard landing and Wall Street could be spared a full-scale blow out. However, that is precisely the opposite of what has happened since the IMF spring meetings.

Current account surpluses are rising in Europe and Japan, while the US's external position is deteriorating month by month.

Balancing act

Asked what should be done about this, the lowliest economics undergraduate would have little trouble coming up with an answer. To some extent, the rise in the dollar is explicable given the strength of the US economy.

Growth of 7% and the likelihood of a widening interest-rate differential with euroland guarantees some appreciation of the dollar, but not this much. The present euro/dollar rate is a classic example of a currency overshoot, and the danger is that the herd instinct of markets will make dealers keep selling euros even if they think they are under-valued.

The G7 had the opportunity to address the problem of the euro when it met in Washington last month. Instead, in a five-page communiqué (with a four-page annexe), all it managed was the blandest assertion that exchange rates should reflect fundamentals.

"We will continue to monitor developments in exchange markets and cooperate as appropriate." Hot stuff, huh? Hardly surprisingly, the markets saw this for the meaningless bilge it was.

What is needed now - at the very least - is a toughly worded G7 statement stressing that the fall in the euro has gone too far and that central banks stand ready to act in concert to push it higher. Given the number of short euro positions in the foreign exchange markets, that might have the desired effect.

But if necessary, the G7 should be prepared to use its considerable firepower to back up its rhetoric, coupled - as was the Plaza Accord - with specific policy commitments by member nations to ensure more balanced growth.

At root, the reason for inaction is political. It's election year in the US, and there's no great desire to do anything that might rock the boat and prick the stock market bubble this side of November.

Europe's politicians don't really care where the growth is coming from so long as it is coming from somewhere, and only the Japanese seem willing to intervene aggressively.

That's all very well, but if the G7 is not going to step in to the foreign exchange markets at a time such as this, there seems little point in having one at all.

The G7 has reserves worth almost $700bn but if it is never going to use them, then they might as well be spent cancelling developing country debt or building hospitals and schools.

Officials can be spared their jet lag, the tax payer can be spared the expense of shuttling them around the world. It is time to put up or shut up.

fields.headline: Zimbabwe farmer beaten to death
fields.trailText: A white farmer died in hospital in Zimbabwe early today after being attacked by supporters of President Robert Mugabe.
fields.byline: Andrew Meldrum  in  Harare  and  agencies
fields.body:
A white farmer died in hospital in Zimbabwe early today after being attacked by supporters of President Robert Mugabe.

He was the first white farmer to be attacked in nearly two weeks and the third to die in the three-month-old land reform crisis.

Police said that Alan Dunn had been assaulted on his farm in the Beatrice area about 50 miles south of Harare during a confrontation with a gang of war veterans. He suffered severe head injuries and both his arms were fractured. He was taken to Harare hospital where his condition had been described as critical.

At least 19 people have died in political violence - mainly members of the opposition Movement for Democratic Change (MDC) - since war veterans invaded hundreds of white-owned farms saying they were stolen during the British colonial era.

Mr Dunn was said to have been a regional executive committee member of the MDC which said he had been persecuted for his political beliefs.

"This is part of a well-orchestrated widespread campaign of violence directed at MDC supporters by Zanu-PF, backed by President Robert Mugabe," said David Coltart, MDC's secretary for legal affairs.

"This is one of a dozen serious assault incidents reported to the MDC secretariat in the last 24 hours. Other critical cases involve senior MDC leaders [across the country]."

Four more farms in the south of the country were also invaded yesterday, according to the Commercial Farmers' Union.

Another group of 200 war veterans invaded the factory and workers' quarters of the Zimbabwe Fertiliser Company on the outskirts of Harare, beating up employees, some 300 of whom live on the site. Mr Mugabe's supporters went from house-to-house, smashing windows and dragging out the inhabitants.

webTitle: Mugabe terror moves from farm to factory continue reign of terror

fields.headline: Mugabe terror moves from farm to factory continue reign of terror
fields.standfirst: Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: Fresh violence erupted in Zimbabwe yesterday as one group of President Robert Mugabe's supporters beat a white farmer unconscious and another went on the rampage in a Harare factory.
fields.body:
Fresh violence erupted in Zimbabwe yesterday as one group of President Robert Mugabe's supporters beat a white farmer unconscious and another went on the rampage in a Harare factory.

Violence from Mr Mugabe's supporters is blamed for the deaths of 18 supporters of the opposition Movement for Democratic Change (MDC) since April 1.

Alan Dunn, a farmer in the Beatrice area, 50 miles south of Harare, had his skull and both arms fractured by a gang of Mr Mugabe's supporters yesterday afternoon. Harare's Avenues clinic said Mr Dunn was in a "serious condition".

Four more farms in the south of the country were also invaded.

Another group of 200 war veterans invaded the factory and workers' quarters of the Zimbabwe Fertiliser Company, on the outskirts of Harare.

The war veterans had warned the factory manager last week that his staff were all supporters of the opposition MDC and that he should hire Zanu-PF supporters or risk violence.

Yesterday the war veterans broke in and began beating up workers, 300 of whom live in staff quarters at the factory.

Mr Mugabe's supporters went from house to house, smashing the windows, dragging out the inhabitants and beating them. Police were present but they took no action.

In Masvingo, a Mugabe stronghold in southern Zimbabwe, there were demonstrations by 1,000 supporters of the MDC. Two men wearing shirts with the Zanu-PF logo were beaten up at the rally.

The MDC leader, Morgan Tsvangirai, told protesters: "Mugabe has told people they can invade farms, but if we have no tobacco we have no foreign currency, which is why the country is suffering with things like fuel shortages

"Zanu-PF has created an environment where everyone now lives in fear. Because of this, farmworkers cannot work and business is declining."

As the MDC rally was taking place the leader of the squatters, Chenjerai Hunzvi, said that supporters of the ruling party must seek out British passport holders and force them to leave Zimbabwe.

Speaking at a Zanu-PF rally in Glen Norah, south of Harare, he stepped up the party's anti-British rhetoric by saying that the 20,000 people eligible for British passports among the country's 70,000 white citizens were not just welcome to leave Zimbabwe, they must do so.

British passport holders who want to stay should share their land and throw away their British passports, he said.

Meanwhile economists in Harare have warned that Zimbabwe's economy is expected to contract by at least 5% this year.

President Robert Mugabe's "scorched earth" economic policies may produce short-term political gains but will wreck the economy, they said.

The instability is also affecting neighbouring economies, including Malawi and South Africa.

Inflation is 50% and rising and the maintenance of a fixed exchange rate has made several key sectors such as mining and agriculture unprofitable.

This has led a group of Zimbabwean business leaders to write an open letter to Mr Mugabe calling for a fair election.

South African business leaders have also called for an end to the violence.

webTitle: The art of doing a deal while staying sane

fields.headline: The art of doing a deal while staying sane
fields.trailText: Imagine going through a messy divorce and then having to continue living with your spouse afterwards. Closing the venture capital deal for Rools, which we did last week, has sometimes felt a little like this.
fields.body:
Imagine going through a messy divorce and then having to continue living with your spouse afterwards. Closing the venture capital deal for Rools, which we did last week, has sometimes felt a little like this.

Three separate investors were involved in our funding negotiations and this brought advantages and drawbacks. Although each had the same overall objective - to maximise the return to their shareholders - they each had a different view of how their investment should be structured.

This partly reflected the different sizes of investment pools and risk profiles, but it made reaching agreement - even on relatively simple points such as the number of directors on the board - more tricky.

When more than one investor is involved, there is a danger that they might collude to force an even better deal from the company. This needs careful management and entrepreneurs should be prepared to stick to their guns. Saying no to a potential investor can require some nerve, particularly when a deal appears to hang in the balance.

Entrepreneurs also have to resist the temptation to agree to things that are not necessarily in their interest just to enable the deal to proceed. We found it interesting that we were able to find solutions to every problem by getting each party to concede some ground, even where the initial positions taken by each party appeared to be completely irreconcilable.

Having more than one investor involved had distinct advantages, giving us a stronger and more balanced investment structure than might otherwise have been the case. The investors' pooled experience ensures that restrictions placed on the business (for example, on the need to obtain board approval for major expenditure) do not have a detrimental effect on its future commercial success. Each venture capitalist brings with it an existing portfolio of investments so we also gain access to a network of valuable industry contacts.

We were extremely focused on the negotiations but also mindful that when the deal was done, we were going to have to work effectively with our investment partners for a long period of time. It was important for us to remain pragmatic and restrict our less helpful reactions to the negotiations. Good legal advice is invaluable and Rools' lawyer did a great job dealing with some of the trickier points and ensuring the deal reflected what we agreed.

After five long lawyer-laden meetings between ourselves and the three investors, we finally closed our deal. We were too busy and tired from the emotional roller coaster ride to celebrate immediately, but on reflection we realise that we have learnt a lot and that even this experience has, at times, been fun. I suppose that would sum up the whole startup challenge.

 Adam Hamdy and Guy Mallison are the founders of Rools.com, a service enabling teenagers to shop online, which has secured up to £7m from investors Europ@web, Zebank and Dawnay Day Lander.

fields.headline: IRA slaughters last sacred cow
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: On Saturday morning, the final sacred cow of violent republicanism - the IRA's self-proclaimed right to wage war on behalf of the Irish people - was sacrificed for peace.
fields.body:
On Saturday morning, the final sacred cow of violent republicanism - the IRA's self-proclaimed right to wage war on behalf of the Irish people - was sacrificed for peace.

The IRA's weekend announcement that its weapons would not only be put beyond use, but also that independent observers inspect their arsenals is unprecedented in republican history.

Compared to previous armed campaigns that ended without the goal of Irish unity, the May 2000 IRA statement is a decisive break in the three century-long tradition of violent republicanism.

When the IRA's six-year long border campaign ended in 1962, the organisation's leadership issued a "dump arms order" to its volunteers. Republican spokesmen today may try to draw a parallel between the 60s IRA leadership's move to dump arms following the disastrous border campaign and the Provisionals' initiative to break the deadlock in the Irish peace process.

There is however one critical difference between the 1962 IRA order and today's historic switch. Allowing independent observers to inspect IRA arms dumps and verify that the weapons have been put beyond use is an alien concept for those in the republican community brought up to believe that only the IRA and no one else controls the guns that were smuggled into Ireland to resist British rule.

The "old IRA" of the 60s would never even have countenanced the idea of independent observers ensuring that their arms dumps were sealed and that for a very good reason. The IRA's intention in dumping arms in February 1962 was a tactical rather than an ideological retreat; they had every intention of using the guns again.

Republican sceptics will view this aspect of the Provisionals' new initiative, with some justification, as a retreat from one of the sacred principles of IRA ideology - that the organisation has given up its claim to be the sole legitimate army and indeed political authority in Ireland.

They will argue that outsiders, namely the ANC's Cyril Ramaphosa and the former Finnish President Martti Ahtisaari, have effectively been given a veto over the IRA's ability to use the threat of armed struggle to drive the republican agenda forward.

David Trimble is a keen student of Irish history and understands the historic shift in republican ideology represented by the weekend announcement. The trouble is his party, particularly its ruling body, the 860 strong Ulster Unionist Council, include many people many who have a less sophisticated view of the world. Many see the world in simple black and white moral terms, "bad terrorists and good democrats".

The leader of the Ulster Unionist Party is aware that Northern Ireland politics is akin to a three-dimensional chess match and that he faces in Sinn Fein some of the deftest players of strategy and propaganda in the democratic world.

Trimble knows this is the best deal he will get from the IRA and that in reality it represents a major concession to unionism. It would be ironic if his party's council chooses to play moral draughts rather than strategic chess, and thus rejects an offer from the IRA that will lead to the end of armed republican insurrection in Ireland.

fields.headline: email: Jonathan Cook @ Bucharest
fields.trailText: It's 2am, a heavy shower has failed to wash away the heat of a spring night, and I am searching for one of the thousands of "non-stop" shops that service Bucharest by day but rarely seem to be open after midnight. There are no cars or pedestrians, but the silence seems wrong.
fields.body:
It's 2am, a heavy shower has failed to wash away the heat of a spring night, and I am searching for one of the thousands of "non-stop" shops that service Bucharest by day but rarely seem to be open after midnight. There are no cars or pedestrians, but the silence seems wrong.

As finally I spot a manned kiosk, a black shape moves from the shadows to block my path, only its eyes and teeth visible. Suddenly behind me is a growling outline of what looks like a wolf. The pair erupt into noise and, in an instant, normality is restored: a late-night chorus of whining, howling and baying from hundreds of strays fills this little corner of the Romanian capital.

Bucharest's 2m humans have long been used to sharing their city with a population of feral dogs estimated at up to a quarter of a million - possibly the largest in Europe. The animals can be seen everywhere: they promenade in packs through the parks, scavenge among dustbins, wander in and out of cafes for titbits, and cover long journeys by riding the metro.

I escaped my confrontation unscathed. (I followed the advice of a local guide, and stood my ground, showed my teeth and pretended to throw something at the pair.) Reports suggest not everyone is so lucky - some 300 locals are treated each month for bites.

As the population of strays has grown over the past decade, so has the competition for food, making the dogs ever more aggressive. Although the city authorities have been reluctant to admit there is a dog problem, belatedly they have started to act, exhorting residents to take the strays along to sterilisation centres. So far the response has been poor.

Surprisingly, given the menace they represent, there is almost universal fondness for the strays. Most residents know the dogs that "belong" to their apartment block and feed them as though they were pets.

Such indulgence is not as bizarre as it sounds - it is born of a lingering sense of solidarity. The strays, like so many humans here, were the victims of the late communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu and his attempts to create a country fit for the "new socialist man".

In the 1980s, Ceausescu set about demolishing rural communities so that he could graft on to the countryside Soviet-style heavy industry. In practice, his systematisation programme was as imaginative as its name: tens of thousands of Romanians were forced from the land and into huge estates of high-rise concrete. They lost the two things that most symbolised home - their garden allotment and their dog.

Lumi, who works for a publishing firm in the capital, says many Romanians regard the strays as a final link to their past: "There is a strong tradition here of owning a dog and my parents, like many others, had to abandon theirs when they moved.

webTitle: Baby tests inquiry expected to criticise hospital

fields.headline: Baby tests inquiry expected to criticise hospital
fields.trailText: A hospital trust is expected to be criticised by a report published today into trial medical procedures carried out on premature babies allegedly without informed parental consent.
fields.body:
A hospital trust is expected to be criticised by a report published today into trial medical procedures carried out on premature babies allegedly without informed parental consent.

An inquiry was opened last year after claims that tests involving a ventilator at North Staffordshire hospital were linked to a number of deaths. The continuous negative extrathoracic pressure (CNEP) incubator used suction to expand babies' lungs from the outside, rather than the standard method of pushing air down a tube in the throat, which can damage delicate tissues.

Of 122 premature babies treated with CNEP, 28 died and 15 suffered brain damage. The hospital insists this was no worse than the record of standard ventilators, stressing that babies who need breathing assistance are often very ill.

The CNEP trial was being run by David Southall, a leading consultant paediatrician, who was suspended after the allegations. Professor Southall previously attracted criticism about a trial which aimed to study links between cot death and air travel. It exposed babies to 15% oxygen to simulate the effects of flights.

The current inquiry, headed by Rod Griffiths, director of public health for the West Midlands, was ordered by the government in February 1999 after parents complained that experiments had been conducted without their consent. The hospital said consent was obtained from all the parents who took part in the study. Some later claimed their signatures had been forged, provoking a separate police inquiry. Both the police investigation and a further inquiry being conducted by the General Medical Council have been put on hold pending the outcome of Professor Griffiths's report.

Gloria Brown, two of whose babies died after spending time on the CNEP machine, told police that the signature on the consent form later shown to her was not hers.

The signature is dated January 10 1992, the day Joshua was born by caesarean section after a 27-week pregnancy. Mrs Brown says she has been told by a paediatrician that after a general anaesthetic and morphine, her writing would have been distorted.

A second woman, Debbie Henshall, also claims the signature she has seen is not hers. Her baby Stacey died during treatment in the CNEP machine and a second, Sofie, who also went in the machine, later developed cerebral palsy.

fields.headline: Conquering the big blush
fields.standfirst: Crippling shyness can seriously affect your work. But you can fight the urge to hide under a desk every time a colleague says hello.  Fiona McNeill  reports
fields.trailText: Embarrassing moments in the office - we've all had them. Maybe your cheeks burn with shame at the memory of a limbo-dancing incident at the Christmas party.
fields.body:
Embarrassing moments in the office - we've all had them. Maybe your cheeks burn with shame at the memory of a limbo-dancing incident at the Christmas party. Perhaps your colleagues still tease you about the time you mistook the new finance director for the delivery man. There's nothing worse than making a fool of yourself in front of colleagues. But for most of us, mercifully, gaffes this bad are rare.

If you are seriously shy, however, every day feels like a minefield of potential blunders, and even something as simple as answering the phone can leave you wanting to hide under the desk. It's natural, of course, to feel anxious before a job interview or an important meeting. But people who are extremely shy can feel that it seriously interferes with their lives, restricting their ability to do their job properly.

"Shy people feel that everyone is looking at them and judging what they do," says Cary Cooper, professor of organisational psychology at the University of Manchester Institute of Science and Technology, "but the opposite is true. People take much more notice of extroverts in the workplace. In certain roles, this can be a handicap. You may be producing the work, but if you're not noticed you may not get the recognition that you deserve."

Cooper believes shyness comes from the family background: for example if shy people had dominant parents or siblings, they may have grown up feeling overwhelmed. But, he stresses, this doesn't mean you are stuck with it. "Lots of people are shy and they learn to cope with it. If your role at work requires you to deal with people, or you have power and influence, you learn to act the part."

Hazel Montgomery agrees. As a seasoned temp, she is constantly starting new jobs and meeting new people, so she often feels self-conscious. "You develop ways to appear more confident than you feel inside," she says. "I find it helps to ask a few questions when you're new, find out where the toilets are, whether there's a coffee machine, that kind of thing. It breaks the ice."

One of Montgomery's coping strategies is to make sure she always says something in a meeting, to show she is paying attention. "But I usually wait for someone else to speak first, so I don't feel so nervous. My pet hate is when someone leans over me to show me something. It makes me feel all panicky, like I'm back at school. I usually go and get a drink of water to allow me to calm down."

Lynne Crawford is a therapist specialising in shyness. She uses a variety of techniques including psychotherapy and neuro-linguistic programming to treat her clients. "You have to teach the subconscious more flexible ways of behaving," she says, "and you treat the mind and body together. Emotions are stored in the body, and allergies, for example, can often make shyness worse."

She suggests people relax before important meetings by listening to comedy tapes. "You should also get up and move about," she continues. "The body becomes rigid when we're anxious. Concentrate on sitting in a relaxed, yet alert position. Try to visualise the last time you felt like that, perhaps when you were with friends, and notice your posture. Recreate that posture in meetings."

It's all about taking your time, and resisting the urge to panic. "If you find yourself drying up in the middle of a speech," says Crawford, "just stop and take a sip of water to recover. It's useful to have a couple of well-prepared jokes ready to help you."

Crawford also uses homeopathy in her work. "Lycopodium is a good remedy for self-esteem and it's also good for the liver," she says. "Shy people often have a lot of anger or fear and that affects the liver. Belladonna is good for blushing - take it as soon as you feel yourself starting to go red."

And the simplest trick? "A smile is universal. It makes you look more approachable so your colleagues will make the effort to come to you. And there is a lot of truth in the old saying, 'keep your chin up'. If you hold your head upright, it allows serotonin, the happiness hormone, to reach the brain more easily."

But a bit of reticence in the workplace isn't necessarily a bad thing, says Cooper. "People tend to like shy people. They show their vulnerability and they're not as threatening as extroverts. They're also better at focusing on their work and they are good listeners, so people confide in them. We need shy people in the workplace - think how unbearable it would be to work in an office full of extroverts!"

fields.headline: The sec's files
fields.trailText: •A novel idea
fields.body:
A novel idea

Do you spend lunchtime at your desk, book in hand? Orange Talks Books at Work is an initiative to get people to set up reading groups with workmates. Orange, sponsor of the women's literary prize, has arranged for five authors, including Jim Crace and Helen Dunmore, to visit workplace reading groups nationwide to discuss their novels. They will also be available to answer questions online. Visit the website at www.bol.com for more details on getting involved.

Building on skills

Developing skills is the theme of this year's PA Plus conference, aimed at senior PAs and secretaries. The third such event to be organised by Executive PA magazine, the conference will take place on May 18 at the Radisson Edwardian Vanderbilt hotel in London. Speakers include Jackie Grant, chair of the Institute of Qualified Private Secretaries, Graeme Payne from OAG, and Andrew Pettingill from Reed Employment. The event includes lunch and a cocktail reception and costs £48. Tickets and details from Emma Warne on 020 7336 6633.

 A 24-hour business

As the nine-to-five routine goes out of the window, people need access to business facilities round the clock. The world's first 24-hour business centre opens in London next month. The concept from Regus, which provides fully serviced offices and meeting rooms on a short-term basis, will be tested at its Lombard Street centre in London's banking heartland. The centre will open from 6am on Monday to midnight on Friday, and weekends when necessary, to help businesspeople involved in global projects and those who need to work flexibly.

 Site for jobseekers

Looking for a job in the public sector? A new website aims to bring together vacancies across the sector to offer jobseekers a centralised source of information. For easy searching, the site, www.jobs4publicsector.com is broken down into civil service, education, local government and NHS. Applicants can store up to five versions of their CV on the website and Jobs4 will alert users by email when a suitable position arises.

 Paper perfect

An innovative way to keep your papers in perfect order: Esselte has devised a vertical hanging system, Sorted, which offers a concertina of coloured files joined together. The files can be stretched out and hung on their own hook, or packed away to fit in a briefcase or laptop bag. Write-on and rub-off tabs make labelling easy. Sorted systems begin with six files and cost from £9.99. Contact Esselte on 020 8282 1000.

Compiled by Penny Cottee, editor of Executive PA magazine

fields.headline: The office gossip
fields.trailText: It may come as a surprise to discover that the Inland Revenue has outgoing sums of money as well incoming, but according to Jason Jones, 28, the taxman's bank accounts are definitely a two-way street. "I am responsible for reporting cashflows in and out of the Revenue's bank account to the Treasury," he says. "Obviously that includes money paid in by members of the public, but there are also a lot of outgoing monies, too - into things such as Post Office Counters and the Working Family Tax Credit."
fields.body:
It may come as a surprise to discover that the Inland Revenue has outgoing sums of money as well incoming, but according to Jason Jones, 28, the taxman's bank accounts are definitely a two-way street. "I am responsible for reporting cashflows in and out of the Revenue's bank account to the Treasury," he says. "Obviously that includes money paid in by members of the public, but there are also a lot of outgoing monies, too - into things such as Post Office Counters and the Working Family Tax Credit."

Jones's day begins by ensuring that the previous day's figures quoted to the Treasury match the Revenue's bank statements. "It's basically a tick-back exercise - it takes about an hour, and I check that all the figures tally." As most of the figures run into millions, it's not hard for Jones to spot a mistake. "It's rare that the figures don't match, but if there is a problem I'll get on to the bank, or whichever accounts office it involved. It may simply be that they forget to fax over the figures."

Most of Jones's work involves collating that day's figures. "Information comes in constantly and I feed it into a spreadsheet. The key to this job is concentration, and I find the answering machine really helpful. If I had to answer the phone all the time, I'd never keep track of the figures."

It sounds fiendishly complicated to be keeping the nation's fiscal affairs in order, but Jones admits the system is quite simple. "Money gets paid into various accounts in Scotland and England, then all that money is transferred to one main account, and then finally into our Bank of England account. It's that final sum that should tally in my figures."

But there is more to his job than numbercrunching. "It's important to have a break from staring at the computer," he says. "We have couriers to transport money from offices to the bank, and I help with the administration of that. If the couriers don't turn up, or there's a problem, I'm one of the people who has to find out what's happened."

In addition, Jones administers the banking charges and fees for Revenue accounts. "Nat West is our main bank and it charges for the services it provides. As a lot of money goes through our accounts, the charges can be complicated and I have to check up on what we have banked, what services we have used and ensure the fees are correct."

In between all this, Jones has to keep inputting the figures to ensure that the Treasury gets its facts at the correct time. "At 11am we give them an estimated figure for the day, and then for the next four hours I'm constantly updating the spreadsheet. The deadline for an exact figure is 3pm - after that things generally calm down a bit." He has the following advice:

* Try to have the best relationship possible with people you deal with regularly. This will mean figures come over promptly, and they'll be happy to help you if any problems arise.

* Report problems as soon as you are aware of them. "If I realise I've missed a payment I let the Treasury know rather than wait until they find out when they check the figures."

* Intersperse statistical work with other duties - otherwise concentration definitely slips.

webTitle: Phoenix to offload its unsold cars

fields.headline: Phoenix to offload its unsold cars
fields.standfirst: Rover in crisis: special report
fields.trailText: The Phoenix consortium, led by former Rover chief executive John Towers, has arranged to sell the world's entire stock of unsold Rover cars to an American bank to secure the funding for its bid to take over Longbridge.
fields.body:
The Phoenix consortium, led by former Rover chief executive John Towers, has arranged to sell the world's entire stock of unsold Rover cars to an American bank to secure the funding for its bid to take over Longbridge.

Details of the package - which involves First Union Bank of North Carolina paying Phoenix £200m for around 30,000 cars sitting on forecourts or storage compounds - emerged as Mr Towers held further discussions with BMW on Sunday. The deal with First Union was agreed on Friday afternoon.

BMW has imposed a deadline of the end of May for progress on selling Rover before it moves to shut Longbridge. It is expected to make an announcement either tomorrow or on Wednesday on whether it belives the Phoenix approach is viable.

Some 24,000 jobs are at risk if it decides that Mr Towers's financing is too flimsy, although insiders say there remains a slim chance that the orginal Rover bidder, the venture capital group Alchemy Partners, may be able to resurrect its own takeover plans.

Although little known in the UK, First Union is America's sixth-largest bank.

Its involvement follows the failure of any of the major British banks to grant a £200m overdraft facility which was at the heart of the original Phoenix package - alongside a £500m up-front payment from BMW for taking over the running of the car plant.

The Towers team hopes that by using what is essentially a large factoring deal - selling on the rights to the proceeds from the expected sale of goods - they will be able to cover Rover's losses for two to three years. By then, Phoenix hopes that productivity improvements will have pulled the business into the black.

Little detail has emerged on Mr Tower's direct plans for Rover, other than an initial declaration that it would preserve volume production in the Midlands.

But there has been speculation that as Phoenix has struggled to get firm financing, so its business plan has had to be scaled back in order to minimise losses.

Privately, Phoenix insiders say the atmosphere of crisis surrounding Longbridge, and relief among the unions over its survival, should enable new management to push through changes and job cuts which would not have been possible under normal circumstances.

But deep doubts remain over the lack of an alliance between Phoenix and a major motor manufacturer who might help to fund the development of Rover models. Such involvement, bringing crucial research and design skills, is seen as crucial to the plant's long term future.

Currently, Mr Tower's plans are thought to rest on out-sourcing such work to smaller specialist firms, but the funding for it remains unclear.

Its involvement follows the failure of any of the major British banks to grant a £200m overdraft facility which was at the heart of the original Phoenix package - alongside a £500m up-front payment from BMW for taking over the running of the car plant. The Towers team hopes that by using what is essentially a large factoring deal - selling on the rights to the proceeds from the expected sale of goods - they will be able to cover Rover's losses for two to three years. By then, Phoenix hopes that productivity improvements will have pulled the business into the black. Little detail has emerged on Mr Tower's direct plans for Rover, other than an initial declaration that it would preserve volume production in the Midlands. But there has been speculation that as Phoenix has struggled to get firm financing, so its business plan has had to be scaled back in order to minimise losses. Privately, Phoenix insiders say the atmosphere of crisis surrounding Longbridge, and relief among the unions over its survival, should enable new management to push through changes and job cuts which would not have been possible under normal circumstances. But deep doubts remain over the lack of an alliance between Phoenix and a major motor manufacturer who might help to fund the development of Rover models. Such involvement, bringing crucial research and design skills, is seen as crucial to the plant's long term future. Currently, Mr Tower's plans are thought to rest on out-sourcing such work to smaller specialist firms, but the funding for it remains unclear.

fields.headline: A huge and mighty step
fields.standfirst:
Now Ulster's unionists have to say yes

Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: They did it while the rest of the world looked the other way. In Britain, the political classes were fixated on elections in England not noticing the long hours and intense nights underway in Belfast.
fields.body:
They did it while the rest of the world looked the other way. In Britain, the political classes were fixated on elections in England not noticing the long hours and intense nights underway in Belfast.

There, away from media scrutiny, a handful of people were working around the clock to rescue a situation that all too many had presumed doomed. Incredibly, it looks as if they have succeeded - through a combination of diplomacy, ingenuity and sheer determination.

The deadlock was between a Unionist movement that demanded IRA guns and an IRA that would not give them up. The Unionists said they could hardly sit in government with politicians who had recourse to a private army.

Republicans explained that they could not persuade people who had given their lives to a cause to make a gesture that, to them, symbolised surrender. The result was an impasse that crippled the peace process from the early 1990s until now. Decommissioning was the Gordian knot.

The breakthrough has come with a decision not to untangle the knot, but to cut through it altogether. The IRA's weekend statement ingeniously sidesteps the entire problem.

The provos will not hand over their guns to the British enemy -the gesture of humiliation the organisation could not wear - but will instead "put them beyond use". The method is to dump them in places where they can be inspected by trusted outsiders. It is decommissioning, but not surrender.

The elegance of the idea is in the detail. The IRA imagines the process running in tandem with a downscaling of the British presence in the province, with troop numbers in South Armagh beginning to fall.

That is important, allowing the organisation to believe that what is happening is not defeat - but the withdrawal from the battlefield of two armies which have fought each other to "an honourable draw".

This is not the explicit moral equivalence which so repelled the British military brass, but a kind of implicit equivalence which will have done much to placate republicanism's hardliners.

Finally, the choice of international inspectors is inspired. By asking the former African National Congress general secretary, Cyril Ramaphosa, to act as a verifier, London and Dublin have found a man who not only enjoys worldwide respect but also specific credibility with the IRA: they regard him much as they regard themselves - as a veteran of an armed, liberation struggle.

Who deserves credit for this piece of smart thinking? Close to the top of the list is a man who is hardly a household name: the Irish foreign minister, Brian Cowen.

According to a document leaked last week, Northern Ireland officials regarded Mr Cowen as a mouthpiece for Sinn Fein. They were wrong. Instead he did what none of the other players in this process had done before: he asked what the IRA might say yes to.

Everyone else had pushed the provos on what they refused to do - urging them to crack under the pressure - while Mr Cowen asked the IRA how they saw decommissioning and how they might one day do it. With that as his starting point, he built on the first yes until he got more.

Help clearly came from Martin McGuinness and Gerry Adams. They kept on making the case for politics, rather than violence, within republicanism even when events conspired to undermine them and strengthen their internal critics.

Tony Blair always believed they were serious. So did this newspaper. But others did not and they duly excoriated those who dared be more hopeful. Today those critics should reflect on whether their actions helped or hindered the search for peace.

Mr Blair also deserves praise: he certainly gets it from those on the ground. They believe that he showed a suppleness rare for British politicians in Northern Ireland and not a little courage - by daring to take on the fainthearts in the British military establishment who tend to prefer the status quo to taking risks for peace. He also invested huge amounts of political capital and time in the process: on Tuesday he talked with Gerry Adams for seven hours straight.

What now? The ball is firmly in the court of the Ulster Unionists. David Trimble has made encouraging noises, but he has to move cautiously: even when progress is as obvious as this. He knows there are rejectionists within his own party who, with the decommissioning issue all but resolved, will simple shift their intransigence to a new issue: the name of the Royal Ulster Constabulary. He knows too that his party's ruling council will meet again within a fortnight and that that body came close to sacking him last time it gathered.

For all that, Mr Trimble can afford to be brave now. He can face down his own rejectionists by telling them that the peace process has brought the IRA further than any of them ever believed possible. Republicanism has found a way to move from war to politics in its own terms. Mr Trimble needs to claim credit for that - and to persuade unionism to accept it and rejoice in it. In a word, unionism needs to learn to say yes.

fields.headline: Jumping on the brandwagon
fields.standfirst: Dot.coms have spent millions on advertising but still can't get their message across. Meg Carter hears why
fields.trailText: Dot.coms have spent millions on advertising but still can't get their message across. Meg Carter hears why.
fields.body:
Just six months ago they promised a lucrative new source of income for adland. Now, however, dot.coms stand accused of misspending their advertising millions and failing to understand the concept of branding. To some the reason is simple: too many of these new start-ups are run by greedy entrepreneurs interested only in a fast buck. Others, however, suggest ad agencies themselves are to blame.

At the heart of this debate is the claim by a number of leading agencies that many dot.com brands have mistaken having a wacky name, an eye-catching logo and a pocketful of mouth-watering promises for having a brand.

"Most dot.com advertising passes you by - you see it and wonder what the hell it was about," says Robert Bean, chairman of ad agency BANC. "They don't understand branding because of the rush to market which is counter-productive to the steady, consistent planning the development of strong brands requires. 'Life is great with MSN' - what does it mean?"

Key to the prosecution's case is the large amount of money spent on mass market advertising campaigns which, in the race to get famous, simply shout loud - rather than explaining the product or conveying to the consumer any reason to buy or trust the newcomer with his or her well-earned cash.

Spontaneous consumer awareness of an advertiser's name is not the same as the consumer having an understanding of and attachment to a particular product, however. As a result, says Charlie Tuke-Hastings, general manager of brand communications agency Yellow Line, which recently launched Littlewoods' Bet 24/7 online service, consumers are starting to greet such communications with: "Oh no, not another dot.com ad".

"Branding needs to be so much stronger in the fast-moving dot.com market because few dot.coms have any physical presence, and there is no reason other than a name and a promise for anyone to trust these companies, let alone for anyone to buy," he says.

Another pitfall has been attempting to win consumers with funky images and efforts to appear cool before getting the product right. In a recent survey by Mori/ICL, only 8% of consumers said quirky brand identities were important in choosing an internet bank. More important was that the bank had an established high street name behind it and could be trusted - a priority cited by 77%.

Without doubt a number of high-profile dot.coms should have focused on the quality and consistency of their product before trying to raise awareness - last year boo.com, for example, launched a £20m-plus ad campaign (featuring sportswear-clad geeks capering through New York) before it had finished building its site.

Others, meanwhile, have ignored the basic rule that to be a trusted brand they must do as they say - a lesson yet to be learned by computer giant Compaq, which last week refused to honour a deal advertised on its website promoting £350 PCs for sale at £1.

As a result, weak or non-existent branding will be a root cause of the anticipated imminent shake-down in the dot.coms sector, with many falling by the wayside simply because they failed to develop a relationship with the consumer, predicts Caroline Chandy, director of planning at Publicis.

"There are few true online brands," she says. "Few have delivered a consistent promise - which is all-important at a time when service is all. A lot have damaged themselves by not delivering a consistent, quality product. They are relying on consumer curiosity to 'give them a try'." This will precipitate the demise of many, she believes, because the market is already crowded, and consumers just don't have the time to try them all.

But in spite of all this, some industry observers suggest ambitious dot.com entrepreneurs are not the only ones guilty of greed. Paul Longhurst, managing director of Quantum New Media, whose clients include Thomas Cook.com, points out that few dot.com entrepreneurs are marketing experts - which is why they turn to agencies for advice. "Many campaigns have ignored the basics - like, what's the proposition, why should the consumer buy the product? But I'd question: just who is guilty of thinking only in the short term?"

It's ironic, he adds, that many dot.coms which have concentrated their not inconsiderable marketing budgets on mass-market TV and poster campaigns have failed to capitalise on a key ingredient of the dot.com business model: the potential for interactive, personalised communication and building a relationship with the consumer.

"Not enough attention is being paid to one-to-one advertising communications," Longhurst says. "Which is not to say that TV and posters are inappropriate - both make it extremely difficult for rivals to build their brands - but it does mean dot.com advertisers and their agencies should be taking a more thoughtfully, strategic approach."

His point is endorsed by Mike Murphy, managing director of entertainment service e-bop, which started out focusing on mass market magazine advertising but has recently reduced this significantly in favour of 'viral marketing'.

"Viral marketing is subtler," says Murphy. "It's about using a variety of channels to create a buzz and generate word of mouth so potential customers hear about us and recommend us to their friends. Sticking up billboards or spending on ITV creates awareness, but not a brand."

So far this year a number of dot.coms have had to rethink their positioning and advertising approach. QXL, Excite and Freeserve are just three who have been forced to take stock, Bean says, after launching with all marketing guns blazing. And others, like lastminute.com, could do well to follow their lead, he believes.

"In my view, lastminute.com has positioned itself as a bargain basement when it could have been presented as an added-value premium proposition - an opportunity for the spontaneous and wilful spending of money on a whim. It would require a major repositioning for them now to be seen as a premium brand."

Such a re-think could have financial benefit for many dot.coms, he suggests. "To be meaningful brands, dot.coms need to develop a relationship with the consumer. And to do so they must wilfully exclude some people to actively include others. Those like Amazon who believe they can be all things to all people do not have a strategy conducive to developing meaningful relationships." Get it right, says Bean, and they may well find consumers willing to pay more for their service.

fields.headline: New media diary
fields.trailText: • HRH Sophie Wessex joins the darlings of the dot.com revolution this week. Together with her PR partner at R-JH, Murray Harkin, she is part of a consortium of six investors backing 5@6, an internet start-up which plans to launch five websites by the end of the year. The first, ladsaway.com, is a great outdoors travel site aimed at grown-up Harry Potters with an interest in elephant polo and polar ice-cap trekking. It will be followed shortly by girlsaway.com, a "de-luxe" travel site, which, according to co-founder Tim Oldfield, Sophie "is likely" to be consulting on, and 360me.com, a "personal information database" for Wap technology, which can be used for everything from match-making to recruitment and wedding lists - very handy for the in-laws, then.
fields.body:
 HRH Sophie Wessex joins the darlings of the dot.com revolution this week. Together with her PR partner at R-JH, Murray Harkin, she is part of a consortium of six investors backing 5@6, an internet start-up which plans to launch five websites by the end of the year. The first, ladsaway.com, is a great outdoors travel site aimed at grown-up Harry Potters with an interest in elephant polo and polar ice-cap trekking. It will be followed shortly by girlsaway.com, a "de-luxe" travel site, which, according to co-founder Tim Oldfield, Sophie "is likely" to be consulting on, and 360me.com, a "personal information database" for Wap technology, which can be used for everything from match-making to recruitment and wedding lists - very handy for the in-laws, then.

 Lastminute's starry blond co-founder Martha Lane Fox has been keeping a low profile since becoming the focus of the new phenomenon: dotbomb stock rage. These days she only talks at conferences which are 200 miles offshore from Helsinki. Billed as "one of the most respected entrepreneurs in the business", Martha is going to be talking on How to Build a Worldclass Economy (and then lose it all) on a two day e-challenge cruise in the Baltic Sea on May 16. Joining her on the panel of speakers on good ship Silja Symphony will be Ann Winblad of Hummer Winblad Venture Partners, America's most famous venture capitalists.

 PA's much-hyped virtual newscaster, green-haired cyberbabe Ananova, has (shock horror) been denounced as "a sham" by rival News1st. Writing in the-bullet.com's 'guerilla' new media news channel, Alt, News1st's chief executive John Bartram complains that the huge amount of publicity she received was gained under the "false" premise that she was the world's first virtual newscaster, when they launched their service with no fewer than four presenters two months earlier. His moan was that his press releases were "binned" by the world's media. Result: "almost no public interest". Boo hoo.

 James Cramer, chief executive of TheStreet.com, the online business news service which until recently was the epitome of dot.com slick, has warned that the company will "choke on losses" unless it can turn a profit before its cash runs out, and is rumoured to be considering a return to old media. The crisis seems to have bypassed its sister site TheStreet.co.uk, however. The newly-appointed editor Nils Pratley assures us they are "quite stable, with independent funding - in fact, we are recruiting."

 One is pure rock and the other is roll, roll, roll, but they are both linked to new media start-ups: Iron Maiden's Bruce Dickinson is launching a heavy metal website with backing from investment bank IHC; while Andrew Marr, former editor-in-chief of the Independent, is in the line-up of hopefuls for editor of Salon.com's UK cultural website, launching in the autumn.

webTitle: Desktop icons No 18: The computer mouse

fields.headline: Desktop icons No 18: The computer mouse
fields.standfirst: 'There's no such thing as a clear desk at the end of the day'
fields.trailText: Scientists have never been ones for catchy brand names. In 1968, Douglas Englebart proudly unveiled his newest creation to the world: a little wooden contraption on wheels with a red button on top, called "the X-Y position indicator for a display system".
fields.body:
Scientists have never been ones for catchy brand names. In 1968, Douglas Englebart proudly unveiled his newest creation to the world: a little wooden contraption on wheels with a red button on top, called "the X-Y position indicator for a display system".

Snappy, eh? His colleagues at the Stanford University research institute thought not, and nicknamed his innovation "the mouse", inspired by its similarity to the little rodents, but also possibly because they had rather more marketing sense.

The not-so-furry friend to man was nurtured in laboratories by both Xerox and Apple computer teams. It finally broke out into the big wide world in 1983, when the first commercial mouse was launched, dangling off the side of the Apple Lisa.

Breeding as fast as its hot-blooded namesake, the computer mouse has now overrun offices, homes and pretty much anywhere it can plug itself in. The plague shows no sign of abating. In fact, new species have recently started to emerge, displaying ever greater levels of independence.

Deskless mice can be waved around in front of your computer screen instead of using those boring old horizontal hand movements, though an unfortunate side-effect may be that your colleagues will assume that you are completely bonkers.

You could also add to your reputation as the office loony by using the all-new cordless mouse. It won't get tangled up in its own tail, but it will be free to run amok among the leaning towers of paper you affectionately call your desktop filing system. Never mind that deadline, you've got a rodent to find. Shhhhhhh, I think I can hear him clicking . . .

Who is he? Ex-electrical engineer and MD of a French food production company. Now founder and CEO of bepaid.com (US and UK).

What's the clever idea? "Full-screen ads have existed on the internet, but there has been no general acceptance, so the solution was to introduce them to users and open up a small compensation for them. The user selects how he wants his compensation at registration - by cheque, beenz (the web's currency), paypal.com (paying friends over the net) or, an extra incentive, by choosing to donate it to their favourite charity. Then, tell your friends and you get 13% of what they get. Actually 20% in total, since if you register a friend or he registers through your referral link, and then some friend of his registers through his link, you get 7% of that reward too."

What's the thinking behind it? "People have to think about going to the website. That's problematic, so why not make the offers come to the user instead, according to interests or habits. People spend money on the web. Now it's time to earn. That's where the referral scheme comes in. You get money by telling other people, but you don't have to watch their ads. It's all viral."

How does it work? "In the way the user comes to our website and fills in information about himself. He doesn't have to give us all the information, we will not track him, but he is valued for the information. When he has done that, he gets to download some small macromedia software which fits on his computer and checks our database regularly to see if someone has targeted him. As soon as someone has, the software lets the user know, and he just says 'I want it', 'I want it later', or whatever. If they accept the ad, a kind of television appears on the user's screen and an ad is shown which is almost full-screen, 800x600 pixels with motion and sound. Our method is a lot of disturbance, cool disturbance, but for a short time - 10, 20, 30 seconds. Similar to TV adverts. And you get compensation. With other companies, you have a constant banner on your screen and a very low payment per hour."

Possible shortcomings? "That the ad agencies are not fully prepared to produce these ads. So we produce quite a few of them."

fields.headline: Slow death of local government
fields.standfirst:
The rise of the mayor is the downfall of the city council

The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: The prime minister is to be congratulated. At least in one respect, the local government elections worked out as he intended. London has a mayor who is totally free of the "tribal" party loyalties which Tony Blair so despises.
fields.body:
The prime minister is to be congratulated. At least in one respect, the local government elections worked out as he intended. London has a mayor who is totally free of the "tribal" party loyalties which Tony Blair so despises.

Instead of comparing rival programmes, the voters contrasted the perceived personalities of the candidates in exactly the sort of policy-free contest for which the enthusiasts for directly elected mayors always hoped.

Admittedly, the "reformers" did not anticipate being landed with Ken Livingstone. They wanted a mayor who shared their view that ideology had no place in local government and that running a great city is not very different from running a big business.

But another blow has been struck against party politics in local government. As a byproduct, immense damage has been done to local government in general. The more mayors we have, the less power the city and county councils will enjoy.

The election of a London mayor has nothing to do with the devolution of power from Westminster and Whitehall. Livingstone will chair a police committee which assumes some of the powers which were once reserved for the home secretary. But most of his other responsibilities will be either representational or an aggregation of duties which were previously performed by the boroughs.

Meanwhile, behind the facade of photo opportunities, real local government will be downgraded. In Birmingham, where - more than a hundred years ago - Joe Chamberlain argued that the city's water supply was too vital a service to be owned by private enterprise, the council is relinquishing its role as a housing authority. Owning all those dilapidated tower blocks did not make councillors popular. But it did make them important.

There was a time when local government really mattered. At the end of the second world war, the great city councils were responsible for police, hospitals, social security, fire brigades, water, sewerage and transport. They raised whatever level of local taxes voters would support and ran municipal enterprises ranging from abattoirs to building contractors. More often than not they did it very well.

Nobody now suggests that the management of the health service or the administration of welfare benefits should return to the town and county halls - even though the government seems far from satisfied with the present arrangements.

But we should not be surprised by the constant pathetic turnout for local elections. Councils do not seem important enough to justify walking down the road to the polling booth.

The notion that local government can be rehabilitated by putting ballot boxes in supermarkets is typical of a government which constantly confuses style and substance. Local government will seem interesting only when it becomes important again.

Yet the slow emasculation continues - leaving the power to influence schools' policy as the responsibility which gives big councils clout. And that is being eroded.

The Butler Act called education a "national service locally administered", but for years "administration" was defined more broadly by the government than the dictionary.

Now schools manage their own budgets and appoint their own staff. I have never been sure why headteachers want to pay their own gas bills. But, if they think they spend money more wisely than local bureaucrats, I am happy for them to wrestle with their computers.

What worries me is the powers which are being passed upward to the Department for Education and Employment or to one of its agencies - power to determine the content of the curriculum, power to close "failing" schools, power to instruct teachers to test their pupils at designated intervals, power to prevent the reorganisation of secondary education, power to extend selection by creating specialist schools and technology colleges and power to impose a pattern of teachers' salaries which, were it left to negotiations between employers and employees, would not even be on the agenda.

These days the DfEE is effectively run by the prime minister. So it is reasonable to assume that its centralist tendencies are part of Blair's dislike of conceding power to anyone outside his tight little circle.

David Blunkett knows how effective local government can be. His fault, as in so many things, is a failure to fight hard enough for what he knows to be right. And the biggest battle lies ahead.

No government since the war has believed so devoutly in the healing powers of private enterprise. Now we are solemnly told that when a local authority school is not up to standard, its performance can be improved by handing it over to a plc. So the destruction goes on.

Ken Livingstone, the front man for the mayor of London farce, helps the process along. No doubt he will do the idea of real local government more damage during the next four years.
