fields.headline: Final offer
fields.standfirst:
This is as far as the IRA can go. Rejection by Ulster's unionists will mean only one thing - a return to war

Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: The latest IRA offer to allow the UN diplomat Martti Ahtisaari and the former ANC negotiator Cyril Ramaphosa to inspect IRA arms dumps is a significant marker, a boundary division between a future peace, or a future return to war.
fields.body:
The long road to peace in Ireland is littered with human corpses, false political dawns and failed breakthroughs. But the latest IRA offer to allow the UN diplomat Martti Ahtisaari and the former ANC negotiator Cyril Ramaphosa to inspect IRA arms dumps is a significant marker, a boundary division between a future peace, or a future return to war.

The IRA have made their final offer. There will be no IRA surrender, no handover of weapons, and no television cameras recording IRA armalites being sawn in half. There will be no "decommissioning" as the word was understood both by Ulster's unionists and the media.

Instead there will be this convoluted, partial, remote-control process where Ahtisaari and Ramaphosa, hidden in the back seat, will be bundled around the bogs and lakes of County Donegal at night to be shown selected IRA dumps filled with selected IRA weaponry.

The arms inspectors, men of impeccable credentials, will in turn, no doubt, report back that there is no threat to the peace process from the IRA.

It may not seem like a lot. But it is a big concession for the IRA. Knowledge of the location of major IRA arms dumps was and is the republicans' most closely guarded secret. The standard IRA sentence for the betrayal and loss of even one rifle was a bullet in the head.

Men, like the Derry IRA informer Frank Hegarty, have been ruthlessly killed for betraying their locations. For the IRA to allow any outsider to glean any knowledge of the whereabouts of even part of its arsenal is an unprecedented departure.

In essence, it is a political gesture by the IRA to enable the unionist leader David Trimble to claim some kind of victory, an IRA concession, and so squeeze his party back into the assembly.

And if all goes well, if the assembly is restored, if power flows from the crown to nationalist Ireland and the unionists play ball, then there is the promise of more.

"In that new context the IRA leadership will initiate a process that will completely and verifiably put IRA arms beyond use."

It remains to be seen when the IRA will declare "this new context" - an irreversible move towards nationalist Ireland - to have come into being.

But there is no doubt that the IRA leadership have taken cognisance of the British government's difficulties in finessing a deal with the unionists.

Both the republican and unionist leadership have to give a bit, now and again, to help the other side.

The next standard question is: will it be enough to appease the unionists and David Trimble's critics like Jeffrey Donaldson? But standard questions in Ulster have a way of misleading both questioner and the audience.

A better question would be: is there any more compromise to be wrung on the whole decommissioning issue in Ulster?

The true answer is no. Decommissioning was always a chimera. The IRA were never going to decommission/surrender/hand over product. And it did not matter anyway.

Physically it will always be just as easy to kill your political enemy in Ulster today, and tomorrow, with a handgun or a bomb as it was 10 years ago.

What is crucial in the equation is political support for violence. Peace processes work not by decommissioning guns but by decommissioning support for political violence. People talk to rather than shoot each other.

"Decommissioning" has always been a bogus concept. It was introduced into the Ulster peace process in 1995 by John Major's government as a political brake to essentially exert British control.

It is now being used by anti-agreement unionists like Donaldson and David Burnside to sabotage further political progress.

As a concept "decommissioning" remains useful to these critics because it masks their true intentions; not to share power, to bring down the assembly, to beat the Orange drum, and hopefully provoke a bit of war to shore up the union. The only republicans they want to meet are dead republicans.

So of course the latest IRA gesture on arms dumps will not satisfy these critics either. They will want more "concessions".

Many of their supporters in Britain will echo their demands. But their case is founded on the politics of destruction.

The real debate will be among those who do genuinely hope for peace. Does anyone seriously believe there is more to be gained, less blood to be lost, by hammering away at the futility of IRA decommissioning?

It is David Trimble's job, with the discreet support of the British government, to win that argument and save Ulster unionism from its worst self-destructive urges.

As Ahtisaari and Ramaphosa have seen on the far more violent stages of Kosovo and South Africa, there comes a point in peace negotiations where there are no more concessions to be squeezed. And where there is a stark choice of warily going forward or returning to the nightmare ground.

The IRA have made a gesture, and it is a gesture, however imperfect, that can be used to dissolve the decommissioning impasse.

We can take that gesture and use it to carry us further down the peace road. Or, of course, we can reject it and turn in the other direction towards war and a renewal of the Troubles.

comment@theguardian.com

fields.headline: Blair urged to delay election
fields.standfirst:
Cabinet fears growing loss of support

New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Tony Blair is being urged to respond to Labour's drubbing in local elections by delaying a general election until the autumn of 2001, or even spring 2002, to give the party greater time to re-enthuse its core support and deliver on its key promises.
fields.body:
Tony Blair is being urged to respond to Labour's drubbing in local elections by delaying a general election until the autumn of 2001, or even spring 2002, to give the party greater time to re-enthuse its core support and deliver on its key promises.

Cabinet ministers thought broadly to oppose an election next May include the Northern Ireland secretary, Peter Mandelson, the deputy prime minister, John Prescott, the leader of the house, Margaret Beckett, the education secretary, David Blunkett, and the health secretary, Alan Milburn.

Some cabinet ministers are also pressing Downing Street to slow the frenetic pace of often repetitive announcements, warning that they are alienating an already cynical electorate. They stress that if Labour has another two years to govern, ministers need to pace themselves.

Until now it had been assumed that Mr Blair would seek re-election after four years. Prime ministers are often wary of going the full five-year term, fearing unforeseen events will box them in and destroy them in the final months.

But one cabinet minister at the heart of election planning said: "The longer the period in government, the greater the delivery. Waiting lists and class sizes won't go in the wrong direction. The more we wait, the more we will deliver."

As the cabinet spent a third day digesting the meaning of the local election setback, Mr Blair sent out a message in an interview that he was determined to continue governing for the long term. The chancellor, Gordon Brown, will also insist today that he will not resort to gesture politics to win back Labour's disillusioned heartlands.

But behind this bland stabilising message, there is deep concern in the cabinet that Labour has somehow lost its touch and become bogged down in the administration and managing of Whitehall.

In a frank interview on BBC TV's On The Record, Mr Prescott said Labour's core support had not turned out because "most of all they felt we weren't delivering. I heard that constantly from people."

He also implied Mr Blair should go the full five years: "I would say to the electorate it is a five-year programme that we talk about here and that they expect us to deliver on."

Mr Prescott, reflecting a widespread cabinet view, said the decision to stick to Conservative spending pledges in the first two years of the Labour government meant the electorate was only now starting to feel the impact of the extra spending on health and education.

"Most of the resources we are now pouring into the public services are only just beginning to materialise, so now we have got to get that over to people," he said.

Ministers also believe the electorate might punish the government if it went to the polls a year early when it had a Commons majority of 180 and no obvious need to seek a fresh mandate.

Mr Prescott openly admitted that the government may have made a political blunder in increasing the basic pension by only 75p a week and allocating most extra resources to the £150 winter fuel payments instead. He said it was no good governments "being intellectually convinced that this is the best way to help the poorest pensioner if pensioners on the doorsteps don't believe its benefitting them."

Another cabinet minister called for a big shake-up, but not a revolution. "First, we have to show we are on people's side. We presume because we are delivering, the electorate knows about it and they feel it. They don't.

"Secondly, we have to be much better at anticipating what is coming up. The horrible explosive cocktail that hit us last month - pensioners, asylum seekers, crime, Tony Martin, Section 28 - had been building up for a long time, but nobody managed to anticipate it.

"Thirdly, in the run-up to 1997 we managed to make politics interesting, but we have got bogged down and immersed in government. We have lost that and we are not touching young people."

The cabinet minister at the heart of the day to day political combat said: "I have come to the conclusion that what people would like is a period of silence from us. They would like a break from it. They just want us to deliver, be competent and be trustworthy."

It is expected that Mr Mandelson will stay as Northern Ireland secretary, working alongside Mr Brown on the general election strategy. There had been speculation that Mr Mandelson would return to mainland politics as cabinet office minister, giving him time to plan the election strategy, but he believes that would be a mistake.

If devolution does successfully return to Northern Ireland, it is thought Mr Mandelson would have the spare time to increase his election-planning workload.

webTitle: Therapists share £12m in landmark equal pay victory

fields.headline: Therapists share £12m in landmark equal pay victory
fields.standfirst: Welfare reform: special report
fields.trailText: A group of women speech therapists is to share £12m in back wages to settle a landmark equal pay battle that began 14 years ago.
fields.body:
A group of women speech therapists is to share £12m in back wages to settle a landmark equal pay battle that began 14 years ago.

The 351 NHS staff, who celebrated a European court victory six years ago, will finally receive compensation worth an average of £34,000 within a few weeks. Under the deal negotiated between the Department of Health and MSF union officials the highest awards will be £70,000.

Liz Panton, a Newcastle city health trust therapist and one of the 351, said: "We have waited so long. The whole profession will be celebrating."

The legal action established the right of predominantly female workforces to be compared with similar professions dominated by men. The therapists started it in 1986 under the Equal Pay Act, forced two years earlier on a hostile Tory government by the European Commission.

fields.headline: Airport guards 'beat up concert pianist'
fields.standfirst: British-based performer to bring assault case against German police
fields.trailText: An internationally renowned Russian pianist based in Britain was last night preparing to sue German police for criminal assault after being beaten up by immigration guards at Munich airport and deported to London only hours before he intended to give a solo concert performance.
fields.body:
An internationally renowned Russian pianist based in Britain was last night preparing to sue German police for criminal assault after being beaten up by immigration guards at Munich airport and deported to London only hours before he intended to give a solo concert performance.

Boris Berezowsky, 31, an acclaimed classical pianist who has lived in Britain for the past eight years, said he was held for five hours at Munich's Franz Josef Strauss airport on Thursday night and had his head smashed against a brick wall by officers from Germany's Bundesgrenzschutz border police before being expelled from the country.

"It appeared that my visa was not in order," he said yesterday. "When I requested an emergency visa to let me play at the concert, the border police took absolutely no notice.

"They just grabbed me from behind and smashed my head against a wall in their office. They ripped my jacket off and threatened to put handcuffs on me.

"I was treated like a dog. I have never experienced anything like it. The German police were simply out to humiliate me."

Mr Berezowsky said that his agent had now instructed lawyers to sue the Munich border police on grounds of criminal assault.

The pianist, once described as capable of dwarfing a grand piano, has a musical reputation to match.

He graduated from the Moscow conservatory under the tutelage of Eliso Virsaladze, made his London debut in 1988 at the Wigmore Hall, and two years later won the prestigious gold medal at Moscow's International Tchaikovsky competition.

Robert Maclennan, the Liberal Democrat MP, who is a friend of Mr Berezowsky, told the Guardian last night: "This was an appalling incident and shameful policing. I hope suitable amends will be made in Germany."

Mr Berezowsky, who has performed with most of the world's top orchestras, had been invited to give a solo performance at the prestigious Schwetzingen festival near Munich on Friday night.

During his detention by six Bundesgrenzshchutz officers in an office at Munich airport on Thursday, he said, he was refused permission to contact the British and Russian consulates in Munich. After being assaulted, he was bundled on to a Lufthansa flight back to London the same evening.

In London the next day staff at the German embassy apologised for the incident and issued Mr Berezowsky with a visa for Germany immediately, the pianist said yesterday.

He returned to Munich at the weekend and is now staying with friends in the city before continuing his European tour of recitals.

The Munich border police refused to comment on the incident yesterday despite, at the weekend, being asked by Peter Steiber, an organiser of the Schwetzingen festival, to provide an explanation.

Mr Berezowsky's German agent, Jens Becker, said in a statement at the weekend: "The German border police were empowered to issue an emergency visa for urgent entry cases at the airport. But they refused point blank."

Despite Germany's reputation as the recipient of the largest number of refugees in the EU, mistreatment of foreigners is not infrequent among the German police and border guard units.

There have been several incidents of police violence against foreigners in Hamburg, Munich and Berlin.

fields.headline: Wings and a prayer
fields.standfirst:
It's six months since EgyptAir flight 990 crashed into the Atlantic, killing all 217 people on board. But still the Americans and Egyptians are fighting over what - or who - was to blame. Julian Borger and Khaled Dawoud report

EgyptAir flight 990 crash: special report
fields.trailText: It's six months since EgyptAir flight 990 crashed into the Atlantic, killing all 217 people on board. But still the Americans and Egyptians are fighting over what - or who - was to blame.
fields.body:
Six months have gone by since EgyptAir Flight 990 plunged out of a clear night sky into the sea off the Massachusetts coast, taking 217 people with it. But there has been no definitive verdict on its fate, which remains lost in a haze of Middle East politics and East-West distrust.

In the course of that six months, US and Egyptian intelligence officers have flown to and fro across the Atlantic, the inquiry has been on the point of being handed to the FBI, and an EgyptAir pilot has attempted to defect to Britain with a promise to tell the whole story. But the twists in the tale have served only to put off a conclusion.

At the heart of the matter is a reserve EgyptAir co-pilot, Gamil Al-Batouti and a three-word prayer he uttered before turning off the Boeing 767's autopilot and putting the plane into a steep dive. The words were preserved on the flight voice recorder.

"Tawakilt ala Allah", Al-Batouti said. I put my faith in God. It is the sort of phrase normally mouthed on the brink of a weighty decision or difficult task. To US investigators, it immediately raised the spectre of an act of suicidal lunacy.

Egyptians were outraged. This rush to judgment, they believed, owed more to a prejudiced view of Islam as some cruelly fanatical creed than to solid detective work. The prayer could have been a prelude to some desperate attempt to avoid a disaster, such as a collision with another plane. Meanwhile, conspiracy theories began to circulate in the Middle Eastern press, suggesting the plane had been brought down accidentally by a US missile fired from a secret mid-Atlantic base.

Much of the public relations battle has surrounded Al-Batouti's state of mind. He was a veteran nearing retirement in the knowledge that he would never make the grade as a full pilot, but he seemed to have accepted his destiny. Much of his wages went towards medical treatment in the US for his daughter, who suffered from a serious skin condition.

In the immediate aftermath of the crash, Al-Batouti's sister-in-law, Amira Dahi, told reporters from the Al-Ahram newspaper that he had been acting out of character during his final stopover in the US, and that he hadn't been to see his relatives on this visit as he normally did.

Both the NTSB and the FBI have sent investigators to Cairo but have privately complained to US journalists that their Egyptian counterparts, while generally helpful, have been slow to respond to requests to look more closely into Al-Batouti's private life.

Meanwhile, the Egyptian government has hired two law firms to advise it on strategy, along with public relations consultants and independent aviation safety specialists. One of the latter, Kevin Darcy, a crash-investigation consultant for Safety Services International, said he believes the Egyptians were given a raw deal because they were foreigners.

"Imagine that the accident had occurred on a US-flag carrier," Mr Darcy said. "The airline and the pilots union would quite correctly be outraged at the flood of leaked information and the rush to judgment based on incomplete and circumstantial evidence."

Two weeks after the accident, just as the civilian National Transportation Safety Board was on the point of declaring the crash a criminal matter and passing the investigation to the FBI, Cairo stepped in to stop the transfer, flexing all the muscle it could muster.

The head of Egyptian intelligence, Omar Suleiman, flew to Washington to take part in the investigation. He was also there to remind his US counterparts that they depended on his agency to keep track of Middle Eastern terrorist movements.

Even more importantly, Egyptian support has been vital to the US administration's push to secure an Israeli-Arab peace accord before President Clinton leaves office. In late March, Egypt's president, Hosni Mubarak, came to see Clinton in Washington and discussed the EgyptAir crash and the stalled US attempt to forge an agreement between Israel and Syria. On emerging from the meeting, Mubarak reaffirmed his support and refused to characterise Clinton's diplomatic efforts as a failure. Neither he nor the US president said anything substantive about the EgyptAir crash.

Into the middle of this diplomatic impasse flew Hamdi Hanafi Taha, another EgyptAir pilot, who arrived in Heathrow with a plane-load of passengers in February demanding political asylum, declaring that he wanted "to stop all lies about the disaster", and heaping blame on his airline's management. FBI and NTSB investigators flew in to interview him, but he was reportedly of limited use to them. Taha had his own axe to grind with EgyptAir having clashed over his strict Islamic principles.

The Home Office refused to comment on Taha's status, but an Egyptian embassy spokesman in London said that his appeal for asylum had been turned down and that he would soon be returning to Cairo to face the music. Meanwhile, the crash investigators were told to keep looking. A new salvage operation was launched in March to find more wreckage on the sea-bed off Nantucket island. The jet's second engine was found as well as some of the cockpit controls. But the joint team of US and Egyptian investigators have yet to find any mechanical malfunction.

"Examination of engine data from the digital flight data recorder, and visual inspection of the engines indicate that the engines were operating properly," Jim Hall, the NTSB chairman, told a congressional committee last month. "Based on the evidence we have seen thus far," he added, "we have found no indication of a mechanical or weather-related event that could have caused this crash. We are not yet prepared, however, to state the cause of the crash and we are continuing the investigation with the assistance of the Egyptian government."

His remarks have been interpreted in Washington as a coded complaint about foot-dragging in Washington and Cairo, in the interests of stable bilateral relations. NTSB sources say the same basic facts have remained unchanged. There was no evidence of a fire, explosion or any sort of malfunction at the time the autopilot was turned off. No alarm had sounded in the cockpit before the plane was put into its steep dive. The alarms only went off as the plummeting plane approached the speed of sound, at which point the plane's pilot can be heard on the voice recorder re-entering the cockpit and demanding: "What's happening?"

A few second's later the pilot cries "Pull with me!", and at about the same time the elevator flaps move in opposite directions. An attempt is made to increase the engines' power but after a moment, they are switched off, and the flight recorders stop working.

For the Egyptians, the unusual elevator movement is evidence of a malfunction or sabotage in the plane's tail. For the US team, it show's a pilot and a co-pilot struggling at cross-purposes. If that is the case, a piece of metal called a "torque tube", which normally ensures that the flaps move together, should have been broken in two.

That tube, investigators hope, will finally provide the "smoking gun" for the fate of EgyptAir 990. But an NTSB spokesman on Friday said he could not confirm it had been found. Even if it is, it is hard to imagine it will be enough to convince everyone, especially in the Arab world, that a trusted pilot simply took the controls and pointed a plane full of people towards the ocean.

fields.headline: First IRA arms 'sealed in days'
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: The Northern Ireland secretary Peter Mandelson is considering a programme of demilitarisation in Northern Ireland before Ulster Unionists meet in two weeks to discuss accepting the IRA's unprecedented offer on arms and re-entering government with Sinn Fein.
fields.body:
The Northern Ireland secretary Peter Mandelson is considering a programme of demilitarisation in Northern Ireland before Ulster Unionists meet in two weeks to discuss accepting the IRA's unprecedented offer on arms and re-entering government with Sinn Fein.

Mr Mandelson, expected to hold talks with security chiefs today, believes the IRA's upbeat statement on Saturday represents a major reduction of the threat it poses. But, with dissidents' groups strong in some areas, he is adamant that no risks will be taken.

The RUC chief constable Sir Ronnie Flanagan will have the final say about troop reductions and the removal of watchtowers, particularly contentious in hardline republi can areas. But security sources conceded yesterday that the IRA had come close to saying its 30-year war was over.

Mr Mandelson is also preparing to unveil a concession on the RUC name to bolster David Trimble, leader of the Ulster Unionists, as he approaches the make-or-break meeting of his ruling party council. The policing bill, to be published this week, is expected to refer to the Police Service of Northern Ireland (incorporating the RUC).

Mr Trimble is planning to address all 18 of his party's constituency associations before May 20, when the 860 members of its ruling council are to meet. If they accept the IRA initiative, the power-sharing executive will be restored two days later.

The IRA is believed to be ready to invite the two newly appointed arms inspectors to examine the first cache of weapons on May 21. The dump would then be sealed, and the former Finnish president Martti Ahtisaari and the former ANC secretary general Cyril Ramaphosa would be able to return regularly to check the arms remained secure.

The IRA pledged to "initiate a process that will completely and verifiably put the IRA arms beyond use. We will do so in such a way as to avoid risk to the public and misappropriation by others and ensure maximum public confidence."

The offer falls short of promising the destruction of the weapons, which unionists wanted. The IRA now has until June next year to put all arms beyond use.

Mr Mandelson is confident the move at last resolves the arms issue. His comments indicated it was the best and last chance for the Good Friday agreement.

He said: "It is the jump were were looking and hoping for following the Mitchell review last autumn. It didn't come.

"And that's why I think that this is so significant. It is a real historic chance now for Ireland, and I don't think that these are conditions that we are going to be able to reproduce in the future."

One Ulster Unionist source said last night: "This is as good as it gets. This is the win or bust." Another said: "We would be damn fools to walk away from this. There would be nothing left to negotiate. If we walk away, the IRA will have a mandate to carry on killing people."

Mr Trimble said: "We want to ensure this form of the process of inspection is part of an overall process leading to full and complete decommissioning."

webTitle: Police horse tramples fan to death

fields.headline: Police horse tramples fan to death
fields.trailText: Security videos and blood alcohol tests will be studied by detectives unravelling how a football fan was trampled to death by a police horse at the weekend.
fields.body:
Security videos and blood alcohol tests will be studied by detectives unravelling how a football fan was trampled to death by a police horse at the weekend, after drunken fighting which dealt another blow to Britain's hopes of hosting the 2006 World Cup.

Film from club cameras at Rotherham United has caught the sequence of events as South Wales brewery drayman Terry Coles, 41, was hit by the horse as police struggled to get 100 Swansea City fans to their seats while rival fans hurled bottles and other missiles at each other.

Furious friends of Coles, a separated father-of-two, said the horse had been "cantering and out of control" and placed a wreath at Swansea's ground with a message invoking the 1989 Hillsborough tragedy: "Another death at the hands of South Yorkshire police."

But the force, whose reaction after the accident was praised by Coles' wife, Christine, said the CCTV film appeared to show the horse trotting and fully under control when the fan turned into its path without looking.

The mounted officer, described as "very experienced" by South Yorkshire police, was taken off duty suffering from shock after the accident - the first death involving a police horse in Britain for more than 20 years.

The independent Police Complaints Authority began an inquiry yesterday, and announced that it would be led by an officer from outside South Yorkshire police. South Yorkshire is holding its own investigation, helped by South Wales.

"This is a very sad day for football," said South Yorkshire assistant chief constable Tim Hollis, who also heads Britain's police-planning for European football competitions.

"The vast majority of supporters who came to the match were law-abiding, genuine football fans who wanted to enjoy what was an important game for both teams.

"The sadness is that small numbers of supporters on both sides conducted themselves in such a way that there were significant policing problems and this tragic death."

A woman mounted officer was injured in a separate incident before the sell-out Third Division Championship decider, and 20 fans from Rotherham and Swansea were charged with public order offences yesterday.

Fighting broke out after heavy drinking in the town centre, and 10 arrests had been made before the Swansea fans were funnelled into single-track Millmoor Lane, which leads to the turnstiles.

Coles, who lived in the Morriston area of Swansea, died in hospital from spleen and kidney injuries.

His wife, who travelled to Rotherham to identify the body, was being comforted at home yesterday with her children, Matthew, 13, and Natalie, 11.

The couple parted three years ago but remained friends. She said: "My daughter has a season ticket and went to all the home games with Terry but she wasn't allowed to go to away games because he was always aware that things could turn nasty. So much drinking goes on before the matches."

Mr Hollis said that the match, which saw two pitch invasions before a 1-1 draw gave Swansea the Third Division title, was considered high risk and 117 officers were on duty to cope with 11,000 fans.

A civic reception for Swansea yesterday was cancelled.

"The vast majority of supporters who came to the match were law-abiding, genuine football fans who wanted to enjoy what was an important game for both teams. "The sadness is that small numbers of supporters on both sides conducted themselves in such a way that there were significant policing problems and this tragic death." A woman mounted officer was injured in a separate incident before the sell-out Third Division Championship decider, and 20 fans from Rotherham and Swansea were charged with public order offences yesterday. Fighting broke out after heavy drinking in the town centre, and 10 arrests had been made before the Swansea fans were funnelled into single-track Millmoor Lane, which leads to the turnstiles. Coles, who lived in the Morriston area of Swansea, died in hospital from spleen and kidney injuries. His wife, who travelled to Rotherham to identify the body, was being comforted at home yesterday with her children, Matthew, 13, and Natalie, 11. The couple parted three years ago but remained friends. She said: "My daughter has a season ticket and went to all the home games with Terry but she wasn't allowed to go to away games because he was always aware that things could turn nasty. So much drinking goes on before the matches." Mr Hollis said that the match, which saw two pitch invasions before a 1-1 draw gave Swansea the Third Division title, was considered high risk and 117 officers were on duty to cope with 11,000 fans. A civic reception for Swansea yesterday was cancelled.

fields.headline: Lifeline offered to rural schools
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: The government will tomorrow announce a drive to keep Britain's smallest rural schools alive, telling local education authorities that ministers, in the interests of local communities, will overrule their decisions to close them.
fields.body:
The government will tomorrow announce a drive to keep Britain's smallest rural schools alive, telling local education authorities that ministers, in the interests of local communities, will overrule their decisions to close them.

The schools minister, Jacqui Smith, will reveal figures showing the action taken by the government to date to save hundreds of rural schools.

At the same time, the Local Government Association will acknowledge the importance of such schools, but will urge them to work more closely together to share facilities and to consider a broader use by the community.

According to Department for Education figures, in England there are 7,900 small primary schools with fewer than 200 pupils, and about 850 small secondary schools with fewer than 600 pupils. But England's smallest school - in Lancashire - had just nine pupils, while 23 schools had fewer than 45 pupils last year.

The incoming Labour government published guidelines in 1998 making it more difficult for local education authorities to close small schools serving remote areas. The then school standards minister, Stephen Byers, announced a "presumption against closure" of rural schools, as "villages lose a vital focus, families come under pressure to move, and the knock-on effect on other services sets up a spiral of decline".

In a speech to a conference organised by the LGA, Mrs Smith will underline the government's determination to continue with this policy and to overrule local education authorities' attempts to close schools.

A spokesman for the Department for Education said yesterday: "We make no apologies for the fact that in many cases we are overturning these decisions, and we will continue to do so."

In its report, Education in Rural Communities, due to be published tomorrow, the association says that the "chocolate box" myth of idyllic country life has been dispelled over the last few years, with greater recognition of the deprivation and social exclusion that exist in some rural areas.

But it highlights the problems of isolation experienced by pupils, staff and governors in rural schools.

"Staff and governors may have little interaction with colleagues in other schools, hampering the dissemination of good practice and the building of support networks," the report says.

"Pupils have fewer opportunities to mingle with same-age peers from other schools, which may have detrimental consequences on their social development.

"Secondary school pupils, in particular, may have long journeys to school, which may remove their opportunity of participating in after-school activities."

There were associated problems in recruiting staff and governors. And resources and accommodation tended to be poorer. An Audit Commission report had noted that about a quarter of schools with fewer than 35 pupils, and less than 40% of schools with between 35 and 64 pupils, had a school hall.

The LGA says its members "should encourage smaller schools to work in collaboration with each other and with other schools, and should work to facilitate and support the process. This may be particularly useful in the development of IT, and the use of other shared facilities."

Recognising the particular problems of transport, it says: "Authorities - not just LEAs - should consider school transport as part of an integrated transport strategy."

webTitle: Former MI6 officer gets top post at BP

fields.headline: Former MI6 officer gets top post at BP
fields.trailText: A retired MI6 officer has been appointed to a top post at BP-Amoco, the British-based oil company, the Guardian has learned.
fields.body:
A retired MI6 officer has been appointed to a top post at BP-Amoco, the British-based oil company, the Guardian has learned.

John Gerson was director of security and public affairs at the agency and was embroiled in attempts to suppress disclosures by the former MI6 officer Richard Tomlinson.

Mr Gerson took early retirement from what was effectively the post of deputy head of MI6 at the end of last year. Last month he became one of BP's vice-presidents for government and public affairs. His appointment was approved by the cabinet secretary, Sir Richard Wilson.

MI6 has close links with oil companies, the "revolving door" syndrome, in the same way as armed forces officers have close links with defence companies. Rolls-Royce has employed former MI6 officers to help win contracts in the Middle East, and merchant banks have taken some on.

During the first reading of the intelligence services bill, Lord Mackay, the conservative lord chancellor, told peers in 1994 that MI6 protected the "economic wellbeing" of the country by keeping "a particular eye on Britain's access to key commodities, like oil or metals". He added: "The profits of Britain's myriad international business interests... and the jobs of a great many British people are dependent on the ability to plan, to invest and to trade effectively without worry or danger."

webTitle: BBC woos stars to stem talent drain

fields.headline: BBC woos stars to stem talent drain
fields.standfirst: The future of the BBC: special report
fields.trailText: The BBC is deploying an aggressive strategy to retain its highest-paid staff and attract new faces in an attempt to stem the talent drain it has suffered over the past year.
fields.body:
The BBC is deploying an aggressive strategy to retain its highest-paid staff and attract new faces in an attempt to stem the talent drain it has suffered over the past year.

Top names at the corporation are to be given new shows, and executives are scouting around other channels with a view to poaching the most successful stars.

The BBC revealed at the Rose d'Or television festival in Montreux yesterday that Terry Wogan - at the centre of controversy over critical remarks he made about his bosses at the weekend - is to get his own game show on BBC1. A new series of the comedy, Absolutely Fabulous, has been commissioned, and comedians Steve Coogan and Paul Whitehouse are developing sitcoms. New game shows are planned, including one presented by Anthea Turner and her sister Wendy.

At the same time, executives have been attempting to lure from Channel 4 the satirist Sacha Baron-Cohen, better known as Ali G, and the risqué comedian Graham Norton. Both approaches were unsuccessful; Ali G's next show will almost certainly be with Channel 4, while the station has just concluded a "golden handcuffs" deal with Norton.

The BBC is unperturbed, however, and will continue to woo stars from its rivals. Ant and Dec, who present the highest-rated Saturday morning children's programme for ITV, are already fronting a Saturday night game show on BBC1. One BBC executive predicted they would become big BBC stars in the next few years.

Critics have accused the corporation of failing to nurture its stars. Noel Edmonds continued to be paid large sums of money long after his Saturday night show, House Party, was axed. He complained later that his ideas for new programmes were never given serious consideration. Gaby Roslin was lured to the BBC with a lucrative contract, but executives have yet to hit upon a high-profile vehicle for her.

Over the past year, the corporation has lost a number of top stars. Des Lynam, the sports presenter, and Ross Kemp, the former EastEnders actor, have defected to ITV.

In an interview yesterday, Wogan fuelled the debate when he said: "I have no loyalty for the BBC. The BBC doesn't care about me, it doesn't give a toss about me." The remarks put a question mark over his new show. A BBC source said: "It's very foolish to bite the hand that feeds you." Wogan, 61, who has just signed a multi-million-pound contract to continue presenting his Radio 2 breakfast show, acknowledged last night that the corporation's attitude towards its stars had begun to change.

Wogan's planned new show, Versus the Nation, will involve lone contestants pitting their wits against viewers phoning in. Earlier, David Young, the BBC's head of light entertainment, said in Montreux that stars like Wogan were key to the BBC's success. "He's like a stick of rock with the BBC running through it."

The Montreux festival ends tonight with the announcement of the golden rose awards, and a number of popular British programmes have been nominated. Meanwhile, Channel 4 said it was not worried about the BBC's approaches to its big names. "It smacks of desperation. The BBC is bereft of talent," one senior executive said.

Viewer quest has criminal intent

The BBC's plan to win back prime time viewers includes a big budget game show in which contestants take on the mind of a criminal to win.

In The Heist, four people who have never met before must work together to crack a complex security system and pull off a big robbery. Targets will include banks, art galleries and stately homes.

A futuristic set will be created at the BBCs television centre in west London.

David Young, the corporation's head of light entertainment, described the new show as a "cross between the Crystal Maze and Reservoir Dogs".

There will be a shadowy "Mr Big". The BBC hopes to attract a top actor with a menacing voice to play the role of the unseen host. Michael Caine and Vinny Jones have been mooted.

Experts will devise complex security systems for the contestants to crack. Cash prizes will be on offer, and the ultimate winners will be given a chance to flee the country to holiday in exile in a gangster's paradise.

"It's a bit of escapism," Mr Young said at the Montreux festival yesterday. "Everyone probably fancies the idea of robbing a bank, and we are giving viewers a chance to do it."

The show would clearly be entertainment and would not encourage criminals. "It's not going to be giving any crime secrets away. It will be about teamwork and about achieving a goal, rather than learning to be a burglar."

Contestants will be security-screened to exclude former convicts.

fields.headline: Monday briefing
fields.trailText: Over view of Sunday Business, Observer, Sunday Telegraph, Sunday Times etc
fields.body:
Sunday Business

Retailer Dixons has appointed Goldman Sachs to look at the options for its 80% holding in internet service provider Freeserve.

Nasdaq , the New York hi-tech stock market, is likely to take a shareholding in the planned iX merger of the London and Frankfurt stock exchanges, effectively producing a three-way merger.

Investment group Amvescap is expected to launch a £1.2bn takeover of rival fund manager Perpetual within the next three weeks.

Observer

The strength of sterling is threatening 3,000 jobs at the Llanwern steel plant in south Wales, owned by Corus .

Ernst Malmsten and Kajsa Leander, co-founders of online retailer Boo.com are being forced to give up their management roles as the price for continuing financial support from luxury goods group LVMH and the Benetton clothing empire.

Rover's future was hanging by a threat at the weekend over when potential bidder Phoenix can raise the necessary funding.

Sunday Telegraph

Barbara Cassani, the head of low-cost airline Go, wants her new boss at British Airways , Rod Eddington, to demerge her airline within six months.

Michael Portillo, the shadow chancellor, will launch a fresh attack on Labour's economic record today, using a new report showing that income tax paid by the average household has soared over the past three years.

The Phoenix consortium claims to have secured the finance to bid for Rover , but refuses to reveal the identity of its backers.

Sunday Times

The Bank of England will use this week's inflation report to warn that earnings growth is unsustainable and that domestic demand is growing too fast, indicating that further rises in interest rates are still likely.

Marks & Spencer is expanding its financial services division to cover home, travel and car insurance.

The Phoenix consortium hopes America's sixth largest bank, First Union Bank of North Carolina , will plug the £200m hole in its plan to take over Rover.

Sunday Express

Staff at Goldman Sachs see the lock-up agreement which prevented them selling Goldman shares for a year expire today. Since the American investment bank's flotation, its share price has almost doubled.

Marbles, the credit card run by HFC Bank , is to launch technology which allows customers buying online to keep their card details secret while making purchases.

IoS

NTL boss Barclay Knapp has ruled out bids for either cable rival Telewest or mobile phone group Orange.

Liberty , the Regent Street store company, will this week receive an £68m offer from Marylebone Warwick Balfour, which wants to transform Liberty into an internet retailer.

Low profile talks between BMW and venture capitalists Alchemy have hit a new sticking point over the £100m of losses run up since discussions over the future of Rover began.

Mail on Sunday

Barclays is contemplating a £15bn bid for rival Abbey National . Chief executive Matt Barrett and chairman Sir Peter Middleton are said to have ignored advice from the bank's advisers to focus on European acquisition and e-banking ventures instead.

A whispering campaign in the City is targeting BT finance director Robert Brace, who has described claims that he is about to be ousted as "complete fiction."

webTitle: Hoteliers bite back at the mighty midge

fields.headline: Hoteliers bite back at the mighty midge
fields.trailText: The tiny midge of the Scottish highlands has been turned into a rapacious giant of an insect in a tourist brochure which is enraging hoteliers for its "exaggerated" warnings about the creature.
fields.body:
The tiny midge of the Scottish highlands has been turned into a rapacious giant of an insect in a tourist brochure which is enraging hoteliers for its "exaggerated" warnings about the creature.

Thousands of the brochures, bearing the Highlands of Scotland Tourist Board logo, have been distributed around the region, showing the blood-sucking insect - size, 2mm - magnified 500 times and up against Aberdeen university researchers in protective gear head to toe, trying to be "a less attractive source of the midges' next blood meal".

"Beware the highland midge," the warning goes. "Smaller than a pinhead and with a taste for blood, it can make your life a misery." The region's most voracious predator is already renowned for spoiling more holidays than the weather and has even prompted a debate in the House of Lords. But the hoteliers insist the 30,000 information packs are bumping up the insects' threat - they have retaliated by removing the pages from the folder, produced by Landmark Press.

Brian Murphy, who runs a guesthouse in Fort William, said: "Midges are a nuisance, but they are not quite the creatures from the black lagoon being portrayed."

David Hayes, managing director of Landmark, said: "We were just trying to make the packs more interesting. The midge is part of the highlands' natural history. With hindsight, this was a mistake."

fields.headline: Worm's eye
fields.trailText: Those with long-ish memories may have spotted a certain irony in the stock exchange heading out of British control just as Rover, the car maker, appears to be heading back home after six years abroad.
fields.body:
Those with long-ish memories may have spotted a certain irony in the stock exchange heading out of British control just as Rover, the car maker, appears to be heading back home after six years abroad.

When BMW snapped up the remains of what had been British Leyland, there was much stern talk from City circles about the need for UK types to shed their "obsession" with ownership and to grasp the simple fact that it mattered not whether the share certificates were held in Birmingham, London, Frankfurt or points east.

The Square Mile was given an opportunity to demonstrate its faith in this principle rather more quickly than it can have expected.

A few months after Rover was sold, Britain's oldest merchant bank, Barings, was brought to its knees by a £800m rogue trading scandal.

The damage this did to British investment banking can be measured by the fact that within a few years just about all the City's major houses had passed into foreign hands.

Now the exchange itself is going into "partnership" with Frankfurt, and already there are signs that this is the type of partnership best exemplified by the television detectives Randall & Hopkirk, and no prizes for guessing which one is deceased.

In parallel with all these urgings and exhortations to abandon our obsession with ownership has been a similar volume of proselytising on behalf of the nation the view that companies themselves need no longer actually own anything.

fields.headline: A menace on the shopfloor
fields.standfirst: Debate: Charlotte Denny
fields.trailText: The Confederation of British Industry - having watched the decline of organised trade unionism in this country - is calling for reform of employment tribunals in an attempt to curb the "compensation culture".
fields.body:
Spare a thought for the Confederation of British Industry. Having watched the decline of organised trade unionism in this country, the employers now find a new menace stalking the workplace - lawyers. The CBI is calling for reform of employment tribunals in an attempt to curb the "compensation culture".

In a submission today to Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary, the CBI says: "There are clear signs of an increasingly litigious culture in which more people try to resolve disputes by threatening legal action".

Applications to employment tribunals almost tripled between 1989 and 1999, reaching almost 164,000 last year.

"Most companies feel they are in a no-win situation because they face substantial payouts if they lose and irreparable reputation damage even if they win," says the CBI.

There could be another reason for the increase: because people are no longer union members and so have nowhere else to turn.

A recent paper from the Centre for Economic Performance documents the decline of the unions (Union Decline in Britain, Stephen Machin, CEP April 2000).

In 1979, there were 12m union members, 53% of the workforce. By 1998 this had fallen to 7m. The proportion of workers covered by collective bargaining fell from 70% in the 1980s to less than 45% by the mid-1990s.

In the 1980s some employers took advantage of an anti-union climate to drive unions out - but the main reason for the fall in membership was the failure of unions to organise in new workplaces.

"This paints a rather bleak future for unions," the CEP's Steve Machin notes. "The relentless decline in union presence through the 1980s and 1990s, and the increasing proportion of new union-free workplaces are unlikely to be reversed easily."

Without a union, employees often lack a voice in the workplace and a forum to resolve grievances before they escalate.

Another recent CEP paper shows the presence of unions narrows pay differentials, for example between men and women and between black and white workers - the very issue at the core of many tribunal cases. (Unions and the Sword of Justice, David Metcalf, Kirstine Hansen and Andy Charlwood, CEP, April 2000)

Unionised workplaces make greater use of objective criteria such as job classification and tenure in setting pay - rather than subjective criteria such as merit where managers' prejudices can sway their judgement. Unions act as a "sword of justice" in the workplace, a major egalitarian influence on the British labour market, the paper concludes.

With no win, no fee legal representation, the cost to an individual of taking an employment dispute to court is low and the CBI says this has led to more trivial complaints. It wants tribunals to discourage claims with little chance of success and to award costs more often against those making frivolous claims.

"This is not a threat to anybody's legal rights," says Digby Jones, the CBI's director general. "It's about fine-tuning the system so that it works better for employers and employees. We have to show that tribunals are for administering justice not for playing games or having a punt for some sort of cash windfall."

But perhaps employers should consider an alternative solution: encouraging the rebirth of unions in their workplaces. With an outlet for their frustrations through collective representation, employees would be less likely to go to law.

Unions have incentives not to pursue vexatious cases with employers because they have long term relationships at stake - and are less likely to waste time on cases which have no chance of success. Lawyers face an entirely different set of incentives.

webTitle: SFO chief is offered new term

fields.headline: SFO chief is offered new term
fields.trailText: Serious fraud office chief Rosalind Wright is set to become the first two-term director in the agency's 12-year history, it is understood. The crown prosecutor is interested in serving beyond the expiry of her five-year stint in summer 2002, and the government is keen for her to extend her successful stretch at the SFO.
fields.body:
Serious fraud office chief Rosalind Wright is set to become the first two-term director in the agency's 12-year history, it is understood. The crown prosecutor is interested in serving beyond the expiry of her five-year stint in summer 2002, and the government is keen for her to extend her successful stretch at the SFO.

No final decision has been taken on either side, but the government is anxious to bring to the SFO the same stability at the top that it has promoted at other bodies in the financial and commercial world, such as the Bank of England and the financial services authority.

Mrs Wright, who took over the sometime troubled anti-fraud unit in 1997, has been credited with an improved public image and a reduced failure rate in court. Aged 57 last November, she would certainly be able to serve another four years and, given possible changes to official retirement policy, might be able to complete a full second five-year stint.

This would make her the first two-term director since the SFO was established by the 1987 Criminal Justice Act. The first chief, John Wood, left in summer 1990 to become director of public prosecutions in Hong Kong, and was succeeded by QC Barbara Mills. But by April 1992, Mrs Mills was on her way to become Britain's first female director of public prosecutions after the resignation of Sir Allan Green, and she was replaced by Clifford Chance litigator George Staple.

Mr Staple served the full five years, from 1992 to 1997, during which the office came under repeated fire over a number of high profile problems. In 1993, tycoon Asil Nadir skipped bail and has never returned to face trial; in 1994, George Walker, founder of Brent Walker, was cleared after an expensive fraud trial and in 1996 Kevin and Ian Maxwell were found not guilty of defrauding pension funds.

But Mr Staple was credited with having steered the SFO through its worst storms and is thought to have been offered the chance to remain for a further period, which he declined. Now a QC, he has returned to Clifford Chance.

Mrs Wright, educated at University College, London, and called to the bar at the Middle Temple in 1964, served in what is now the crown prosecution service from 1969-87, latterly as head of the fraud division in London.

She moved to become head of prosecutions at the stockbroking regulator, the securities and futures authority.

fields.headline: Rover jobs threat dents confidence
fields.trailText: The threat of thousands of job losses in Britain's motor industry has contributed to a plunge in confidence among high-street retailers, according to the insurance group CGU.
fields.body:
The threat of thousands of job losses in Britain's motor industry has contributed to a plunge in confidence among high-street retailers, according to the insurance group CGU.

Although consumer spending is still rising, customers also feel gloomier, with their concerns aggravated by interest rate uncertainty and stock market wobbles.

CGU's index of confidence among shopkeepers has fallen from 106.2 to 101.3 this month - the lowest level since its launch in November last year.

Many are concerned that 24,000 workers will lose their jobs if BMW carries out its threat to close Rover's Longbridge car factory in Birmingham. Ford is reported to be pondering the future of its Dagenham plant, increasing worries about large-scale unemployment.

Cees Schrawers, managing director of CGU Insurance, said: "Even though consumers are spending more this month, longer term confidence is being impacted by current uncertainty in a number of areas."

Shoppers are forecast to spend £47.1bn this month, £300m higher than in April. However, consumer confidence has edged down from 109 to 108.8.

The one sector still believed to be booming is discount factory outlets. According to the consultancy Retail Intelligence, shoppers are flocking to such centres to flee "rip-off" prices in the high street.

The number of factory outlet centres will reach 37 by the end of the year. Retail Intelligence estimates that such stores had takings of £1.2bn last year, representing 0.6% of overall retail sales - double the proportion they accounted for three years ago.

Increasingly elaborate offerings have helped lure customers, with many centres boasting multi-screen cinemas, adventure playgrounds, restaurants and cafes.

British operators are looking to capitalise on this success by moving abroad, with 20 centres planned for continental Europe.

fields.headline: Fury at Vodafone's £300m saving
fields.trailText: Mobile telephone groups BT Cellnet and One2One are preparing for a battle with the government over what they claim are unfair terms being extended to rival Vodafone Airtouch over its payment for a third generation mobile phone licence.
fields.body:
Mobile telephone groups BT Cellnet and One2One are preparing for a battle with the government over what they claim are unfair terms being extended to rival Vodafone Airtouch over its payment for a third generation mobile phone licence.

The Department of Trade and Industry has granted Vodafone a delayed payment period of up to 180 days after the auction ceased on April 27, which is claimed to give the company a £300m advantage.

None of the other four winners of the five licences for third generation phones - BT, One2One, Orange and a newcomer to the UK market, Telesystem International Wireless - have been granted such a concession.

These four operators must make their first payments on the licences tomorrow, paying at least half the fee immediately with the remainder due in instalments over the next 10 years.

The government's auction of five licences to operate third generation mobile telephones raised an astonishing £22.48bn. These phones will be able to provide fast, high-quality internet access as well as speech and data communications.

Vodafone has been granted a delayed payment period because of its ownership of Orange, which came about through its takeover of German mobile phone group Mannesmann.

Under the terms of the auction, no two companies in the same ownership could bid for a licence.

The delayed payment by Vodafone of 180 days is intended to cover the period in which Vodafone intends to demerge Orange.

One2One is understood to have claimed that Vodafone could save more than £300m in interest by being able to delay payment on its licence. Both it and BT want the same terms extended to the other mobile phone operators.

A BT spokesman said yesterday: "We are obviously confident and hopeful that we can easily and amicably achieve agreement with the government."

Both companies are now in discussions with trade secretary Stephen Byers.

The DTI said last night that it was not in "BT's or anyone else's interest to challenge the auction rules in this way".

There is now the prospect that the auction could be challenged in court if BT and One2One are unable to achieve a satisfactory outcome to the negotiations.

"The government is satisfied that the third generation auction rules were fair to all parties and that they provided an effective auction and complied with domestic and European law," the DTI said.

webTitle: Hilton chief ready to step down

fields.headline: Hilton chief ready to step down
fields.trailText: Hilton Group's chief executive, Peter George, looks likely to quit the company in order to spend more time with his new wife in America.
fields.body:
Hilton Group's chief executive, Peter George, looks likely to quit the company in order to spend more time with his new wife in America.

Contrary to widespread speculation, he is not going to replace the leisure group's non-executive chairman, John Jackson. In a surprise decision, Mr Jackson, 70, will hang on to his job for at least another year.

Hilton's new chief executive will be David Michels, who heads the group's hotels division. He was chief executive of Stakis, which Hilton bought for £1.3bn last year.

Ever since the takeover of Stakis, Mr Michels, 53, has been tipped to take the top post. He is popular in the City for his straight-talking, brash style.

Widespread rumours about the reshuffle could force Hilton to make a statement this week. If not, the moves will be announced at the company's annual meeting at the end of the month.

Mr George's resignation will end a 37-year career with the group. He joined the company's Ladbroke betting business in 1963 and has been on the board since 1980.

Mr George, 56, has won praise for keeping the group's betting business stable despite the onset of the National Lottery. He recently announced plans to launch an offshore betting operation. However, his ambitions to buy the Coral betting chain were thwarted by regulators.

Mr George is reported to have blamed the break-up of his first marriage on overwork. He recently remarried, and his wife lives in the US.

News that Mr Jackson is to remain chairman could raise eyebrows in the City. Some institutions, including the fund management group Hermes, oppose board members staying on into their seventies.

Friends of Mr Jackson say he is still very active - he is chairman of another FTSE 100 company, the biotechnology group Celltech.

fields.headline: Female hacker started Love Bug
fields.standfirst:
Female hacker started Love Bug

FBI - NIPC Advice & Warning
Sophos virus information
fields.trailText: The hacker behind the Love Bug virus that attacked computers across the world is a woman in the Philippines who might never be charged with any offence, it was claimed yesterday.
fields.body:
The hacker behind the Love Bug virus that attacked computers across the world is a woman in the Philippines who might never be charged with any offence, it was claimed yesterday.

Police believe that the hacker, assumed previously to be a man, is a 23-year-old computer student from the heavily-populated middle-class Manila neighbourhood of Pandacan.

As new details began to emerge of the source of the virus, a National Bureau of Investigation official in Manila warned that the intense publicity surrounding the Love Bug might scupper attempts to catch the perpetrator.

"We fear that she has destroyed by now all evidence that could link her to the hacking," he said.

Frustrations were clearly running high as investigators battled against the Philippines' sluggish judicial process.

Nelson Bartolome, head of the bureau's anti-fraud and computer crimes unit, revealed he was having trouble securing a search warrant needed to seize computers belonging to the suspect.

"We're trying to find a judge who will understand this emergency but it's Sunday and I am not betting on it. We are ready with all the documentation, we have the witness, we already conducted a surveillance," he said.

"We have a suspect area and a suspect. The problem is the judge."

Even when a search warrant is signed, police are not convinced the case will be closed. "It was only the computer used to launch the virus that was traced but anybody could use that computer," said a police spokesman.

"The user here is invisible, it could be anybody. The difference is that the person we have identified is the registered owner of that computer."

Experts say that new variants of the Love Bug could appear in the next few weeks. Already, copycat versions in the form of Mother's day messages, jokes and anti-virus warnings have been detected.

It is estimated that the virus will have caused $1bn worth of damage to industry by today.

Speculation about the source proliferated over the weekend. A computer expert in Sweden who helped the FBI last year to trace the Melissa virus said that the person behind the Love Bug virus was an 18-year-old German exchange student in Australia using the name Michael.

"The Love virus was activated in the Philippines but it is not certain whether Michael was there in person," said Fredrik Bjorck, a systems researcher at Stockholm university. Australian police said they did not have enough evidence to launch an inquiry.

Microsoft chairman Bill Gates is using the virus to argue against US government proposals to break up his corporation and place a ban on new end-user features to Windows.

"Updates to Windows and Office technologies that could, for example, protect against attacks such as the Love Bug virus would also be much harder for computer users to obtain," he writes in Time magazine.

The virus first spread through two email addresses on the Manila internet service network Supernet, operated by Access Net. The addresses the hacker used - spyder@super.net.ph and mailme@super.net.ph - have been frozen.

Even though it started in the Philippines, computers there and in much of Asia were largely unaffected because of holidays last week. The Chinese government warned computer users to look out for the virus when they return to work today.

The virus first spread through two email addresses on the Manila internet service network Supernet, operated by Access Net. The addresses the hacker used - spyder@super.net.ph and mailme@super.net.ph - have been frozen. Even though it started in the Philippines, computers there and in much of Asia were largely unaffected because of holidays last week. The Chinese government warned computer users to look out for the virus when they return to work today.

webTitle: Rifkind urges Hague to be moderate

fields.headline: Rifkind urges Hague to be moderate
fields.standfirst:
Tories Party should espouse 'principled pragmatism'

Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: William Hague was facing pressure yesterday to return to the centre ground when the former foreign secretary Sir Malcolm Rifkind led calls for the Conservative leader to adopt "moderate rhetoric".
fields.body:
William Hague was facing pressure yesterday to return to the centre ground when the former foreign secretary Sir Malcolm Rifkind led calls for the Conservative leader to adopt "moderate rhetoric".

After the Tories' humiliating defeat in the Romsey byelection, Sir Malcolm called on Mr Hague to follow the example of Tories in Scotland, who are reaching out to new voters.

Ceri Evans, campaign manager for Steve Norris's run for London mayor, said Central Office should take a leaf out of Mr Norris's book and appeal to middle of the road voters who believed in "principled pragmatism". Mr Hague should resist calls from shadow ministers who wanted to exploit race as a campaigning issue.

There were signs yesterday that Mr Hague is heeding the calls of moderate Tories. He confirmed that he would be offering Mr Norris a job in Central Office, expected to be a vice-chairmanship with a special communications role.

However, the appointment is likely to cause tension among shadow ministers. One was dismissive of Mr Norris's mayoral campaign, saying that he had been out-polled by the party's assembly candidates.

The task facing the Tories, who are privately devastated by the Romsey loss, was underlined yesterday by Sir Malcolm, who said Mr Hague "had a mountain to climb". Moderate Tories were alarmed by Mr Hague appearing to pander to core Tory voters when he pledged to detain asylum seekers and spoke out for the jailed Norfolk farmer Tony Martin.

Sir Malcolm pointed to the Tory leader in Scotland, David McLetchie, who is wooing Liberal Democrat and Scottish National Party voters.

"To win their support will require hard effort, attractive policies and a moderate rhetoric," Sir Malcolm, president of the Scottish Conservatives, said in a speech at Bridge of Allan, Stirlingshire. Tories were "showing themselves to have such qualities at Holyrood".

The Norris camp said his mayoral campaign should form the model for the Tories' general election campaign. Mr Evans said Mr Norris had succeeded by "maximising the non-core vote with the minimum damage to the core vote".

"Steve's strength is that he is a dyed in the wool Thatcherite free marketeer who believes in a tolerant, inclusive society," Mr Evans said, views that "do not need to be mutually exclusive".

The Tory leadership insisted last night that Mr Hague had not lurched to the right and that he was addressing issues that concern all voters. In the coming weeks, he will speak on health, education and the environment to show that he is not a single issue politician.

Mr Hague said on BBC1's Breakfast with Frost that the Tories' success in the local elections, when they picked up seats in areas such as Wigan, Greater Manchester, showed that the party was reaching out beyond its core voters.

fields.headline: Kosovo now
fields.trailText: You give a one-sided account of life in Kosovo (Fear stalks Kosovo's remaining Serbs, April 28).
fields.body:
You give a one-sided account of life in Kosovo (Fear stalks Kosovo's remaining Serbs, April 28). When Nato forces arrived, 50 people were being murdered a week. This has fallen to an average of five - too many, but comparable with a large European city. A thousand schools have been reopened. Much of the country is peaceful; 3,800 small arms have been destroyed and 10,000 more handed in by former members of the KLA. The second multiethnic class of the Kosovo Police Academy has graduated and joined the local multiethnic Kosovo Police Service. The class contained 170 pupils, including 34 Serbs. The need for round-the-clock protection for individual Serbs in Pristina is reducing as the situation improves.

Martin Howard
Ministry of Defence

fields.headline: Chippy toffs
fields.trailText: According to John Vidal (Does your daddy know you're here? G2, May 5): "No one is more qualified than a public schoolboy to recognise dictatorship, fascism, human rights abuse and inequality."
fields.body:
According to John Vidal (Does your daddy know you're here? G2, May 5): "No one is more qualified than a public schoolboy to recognise dictatorship, fascism, human rights abuse and inequality." And to think we've been listening to those whingers from Tibet, Ethiopia, East Timor and Chile for years. Give them a spell in a public school and they'll soon stop their moaning, eh? Will the Guardian call for a public schoolboy relief fund to be set up? Where should I send my donation?

Edinburgh

webTitle: Prescott sticks to his plans for Tube

fields.headline: Prescott sticks to his plans for Tube
fields.standfirst:
The London mayor: special report
New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: John Prescott and Ken Livingstone, London's newly elected mayor, appeared last night to be heading for confrontation after the deputy prime minister made clear he had no intention of backing down over plans to part-privatise the London Undergound.
fields.body:
John Prescott and Ken Livingstone, London's newly elected mayor, appeared last night to be heading for confrontation after the deputy prime minister made clear he had no intention of backing down over plans to part-privatise the London Undergound.

Hopes of an accommodation between the government and Mr Livingstone, who made public ownership and control of the Tube a central plank of his election platform, faded when Mr Prescott insisted there would be no concessions.

Mr Livingstone said he hoped "we can sit down and sort it out sensibly" and believed that once the contracts were finalised, Mr Prescott would be "in a position to say this isn't a particularly good deal and back out of it".

But Mr Livingstone added that if the government did try to "push ahead with a deal that is bad for London, you would have to consider going to a judge and saying, well, is this really right?"

Mr Prescott retorted that "all sorts of people threaten to take me to court".

He added: "I have an obligation to bring in the public-private partnership," he told the BBC's On the Record programme, "to provide best value and if I do that, we get on with the contract".

Negotiations with Mr Livingstone would only cause further delays in securing investment for modernisation.

Mr Prescott's defiant defence of the government's Tube policy - only the official Labour candidate, Frank Dobson, supported it during the mayoral campaign - comes as he faces a Labour backbench revolt in the Commons this week over his plans to part-privatise air traffic control.

The rebellion over the 51% sell-off scheme is expected midweek during the report stage of the transport bill.

Last month the prime minister conceded that if Mr Livingstone won the mayoral election on an anti-privatisation ticket, it would "make it much more difficult to get the work done in the way we want it".

The government has the power to force through its public-private partnership, but faces an outcry if it ignores Mr Livingstone's mandate against the scheme.

fields.headline: Human rights in Iran
fields.trailText: Geneive Abdo (Is it the Jews or Iran on trial here? May 5) seems oblivious to the fact that the fate of 13 individuals hangs in the balance.
fields.body:
Geneive Abdo (Is it the Jews or Iran on trial here? May 5) seems oblivious to the fact that the fate of 13 individuals hangs in the balance. Thirteen Jews are accused of serious crimes, the maximum penalty for which is death, yet Ms Abdo seems to think the burden of proof falls on them.

Is it really any surprise that there is scepticism in the west? The 13 have been incarcerated for over a year without access to legal representation; when they were allowed to choose counsel, the families' lawyers were disqualified and the defendants are now represented by court-appointed counsel. Meanwhile, the prosecutor in this case is also the judge.

The Iranian authorities have said that the accusations have nothing to do with the defendants' religion and claim that eight Muslims have also been arrested, but the names of these other accused have never been publicised.

Why has no evidence been made public? If the Iranian authorities feel the need to convince "the western sceptics", why don't they release some evidence of the crimes instead of footage of the prisoners "confessing"? The claim that it took them a year to figure out that they must release some details is astonishing in its naivety, its abdication of any sense of due process and its indulgence of those who claim to have a case against the Jews. Is it western bias that has led governments to convey their concerns to the Iranian authorities or a legitimate concern for human rights?

Eldred Tabachnik
President, Board of Deputies of British Jews

fields.headline: Candy Man
fields.trailText: It was a great pleasure to read Eddi Fiegel's review of the new Anthony Newley CD, On a Wonderful Day Like Today - the Anthony Newley Collection (British Cool Started Here, Friday Review, May 5).
fields.body:
It was a great pleasure to read Eddi Fiegel's review of the new Anthony Newley CD, On a Wonderful Day Like Today - the Anthony Newley Collection (British Cool Started Here, Friday Review, May 5). When Newley died in April last year, the response in this country did not do justice to a great talent. There has been no showing of his films on television, and the obituaries in the national press seemed to draw attention to his human frailties and deficiencies, rather than celebrate his remarkable success. This included your own obituary.

At last we have a reviewer who is able to celebrate this great Englishman and his work. Let us hope that it starts a real revival and appreciation of the legacy of films and music that Newley produced.
Geoff Clifford
Charlbury, Oxon
geoffc@clara.net

fields.headline: Raw deal at playtime
fields.trailText: Dr Adrian Potts (Letters, May 5) is wrong to denigrate those with an English literary bias.
fields.body:
Dr Adrian Potts (Letters, May 5) is wrong to denigrate those with an English literary bias. Einstein bemoaned the fact that many scientists did not possess enough "imagination and creativity" required to make those huge leaps in scientific thinking that changed our understanding of the world. This lack of a creative imagination among British industrialists has been responsible for more than the Rover debacle and Dr Potts would do well to note that the biggest butcher of British manufacturing was that well-known Oxford scientist, Margaret Thatcher.
John Payne
London
John_Payne@baconsctc.co.uk

 Pokemon cards have spoilt my life at school (Letters, April 29). I used to always look forward to playtime. But now Pokemon cards have taken over the school, playtime isn't fun anymore. Whenever I want to play with somebody they are trading Pokemon cards, having a Pokemon battle or telling people who don't have them how great Pokemon cards are. Pokemon, Pokemon, Pokemon. How I can get my playtime fun back?
Eleanor Penfold (age 9)
Corwen, Denbighshire

 We are informed that Margaret McDonagh (38) and Sally Morgan (40) used to be bitter enemies (Blame game begins in wake of defeat, May 6), but then the information dries up. The age of the key players is obviously vital to the story, so when are you going to tell us tell us how old Jim Fitzpatrick, Frank Dobson, Trevor Phillips, Jonathon Powell and Tony Blair are?
Jon Nott
London
jon_nott@hotmail.com

 I was a little puzzled to see the film Dunkirk described as an epic Ealing Studios version of "the famous beach landing" (The Guide, May 6). Was it being run backwards?
Ted Dutton
Hereford
