webTitle: Ministers urged to respect rank and file

fields.headline: Ministers urged to respect rank and file
fields.standfirst:
Labour Party stalwart warns that divisions could threaten electoral success

New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: One of Millbank's most senior former officials has warned that the Labour Party headquarters and the rank-and-file members are deeply alienated from one another, threatening a collapse in party activism and a low turnout in the next election.
fields.body:
One of Millbank's most senior former officials has warned that the Labour Party headquarters and the rank-and-file members are deeply alienated from one another, threatening a collapse in party activism and a low turnout in the next election.

The warning has been given by David Pitt-Watson, the party's assistant general secretary until last year.

He suggests that unless Millbank learns to trust and respect its volunteers it will turn the Labour Party into a version of the US Democrats.

Mr Pitt-Watson is the most senior and loyal figure from within the party machine to admit that the relationship between Millbank and the party rank and file is in need of repair.

A paper setting out his analysis of the relationship will form the starting point of a post-local elections inquest between leading Blairities in the party and Millbank and Downing Street officials.

Mr Pitt-Watson, the party's finance director for four years, said: "If you are the assistant general secretary and address any Labour party meeting it is more than likely that an argument will develop about the degree to which the government has allowed the party and its policies to become a marketing proposition: designed to win votes, but with little heed paid to the values for which we all joined and dedicated ourselves.

"Such an argument can readily become heated with the party apparently in opposition to the government which it sought to put in power for 18 years."

Urging the leadership to respect the party, he warned a dangerous cynicism was rife in the party about the organisational reforms being pushed through the party, including the introduction of policy forums, rather than conference to shape policy.

"Cynics in government will say the forums are a place where ministers are subject to ill-informed and unhelpful criticism. Cynics from the party say the forums are at best talking shops at worst a way to sideline the debate. That cynicism is hugely dangerous because it threatens to undermine the primary process we have for co-ordinating the party on the ground with the party in government.

He added: "If party members use them to foment opposition, party leadership will ignore them. If on the other hand, party leaders ignore what is said in the forums, or fail to give credit to the party for the influence it had in writing the manifesto, then they will be discredited amongst members."

He also urged the party not to become over-reliant on focus groups, saying they can be helpful in establishing a marketing proposition, but they are not a substitute for representative democracy.

He claimed that Labour could still develop into a party of the British people if more attention were devoted to recruiting members and to campaigning in local communities.

If it did not, he said, the danger would be a second term win without being the government of the people. "As a result the electorate will not simply bother to vote. Our activists won't bother to get out of their chairs. We will win the battle, but we will not win the war."

Mr Pitt-Watson, drawing on his own own experience of Millbank, also admitted that a culture gap had opened between the party headquarters and the rank and file.

He said: "The culture which underpins Millbank's speed, dedication and professionalism can have a cost. This is because its professionalism stands in contrast to the way the party is orgnised on the ground.

"Labour on the ground is a voluntary organisation. It will not, cannot, and arguably should not be able to respond in the way that a professional organisation can. As a result the culture of Millbank grates with that of the larger party.

"Because Millbank and the party in the country operate in these two different political cultures, party members can think of Millbank as distant, arrogant and controlling when it has no intention to be so. And to the professionals, the party on the ground looks like a bunch of amateurs and it treats them accordingly.

"The party cannot just be professional since if you don't engage the people, you will end up with a government which seems distant and arrogant. And of course we see those stresses day in day out, as we observe our government in power."

He added: "There is article after article about the government becoming too remote and we hear dire warnings about heartland votes. And this despite the minimum wage, the working family tax credit, £20bn each on health and education, the proud litany of our achievements."

fields.headline: Vote of no confidence
fields.trailText: Surely politicians like John Prescott, who have defended the first past the post voting system as being in Labour's best interests, will now have to think again (Blame game begins in wake of defeat, May 6).
fields.body:
Surely politicians like John Prescott, who have defended the first past the post voting system as being in Labour's best interests, will now have to think again (Blame game begins in wake of defeat, May 6). As all remaining complacency about a foregone conclusion to the next general election is shattered, Labour would do well to remember that FPTP historically helps the Conservatives. In these council elections, all held under FPTP, Labour lost nearly 600 seats on a relatively small swing. Labour lost to the Conservatives in the FPTP elections to the GLA and has only achieved a balanced position thanks to the proportional top-up.

Labour's only good news was that those "dreadful" Liberals managed to defeat the Tories in Romsey, thanks to massive tactical voting by Labour supporters. Lib Dem voters are unlikely to return this support in Labour marginals, if John Prescott gets his way and the government ditches its promised referendum on voting reform.
Nina Temple
Director, Make Votes Count nina.mvc@btinternet.com

 The result of the Romsey parliamentary byelection yesterday was further evidence of the need to change our electoral system. No one would suggest that only 3.8% of voters in Romsey support the Labour party. Clearly Labour voters recognised that their candidate would not win and that the only way they could deny the Conservatives a win was through a tactical vote for the Liberal Democrats. There is surely something crazy about a voting system which drives the intelligent voter to vote for other than their favoured candidates. With a preference-voting system, such as the alternative vote, Labour supporters would have been able to achieve the same outcome by voting Labour, but with Liberal Democrat as a second preference.
Dr Ken Ritchie
Electoral Reform Society

Clearly Labour voters recognised that their candidate would not win and that the only way they could deny the Conservatives a win was through a tactical vote for the Liberal Democrats. There is surely something crazy about a voting system which drives the intelligent voter to vote for other than their favoured candidates. With a preference-voting system, such as the alternative vote, Labour supporters would have been able to achieve the same outcome by voting Labour, but with Liberal Democrat as a second preference. fields.headline: Death row
fields.trailText: While the state-sanctioned killing of Christina Riggs in Arkansas (Mother executed for killing her children, May 3) should be condemned by all civilised people
fields.body:
While the state-sanctioned killing of Christina Riggs in Arkansas (Mother executed for killing her children, May 3) should be condemned by all civilised people, it ought not to surprise those familiar with a profoundly disturbing aspect of judicial procedures in the US - a phenomenon known to abolitionists as "voluntary" executions. Christina Riggs is the 23rd death row prisoner who has opted out of the appeals process and agreed to be put to death by the state since the beginning of 1998. As Amnesty International stated: "Whatever motivates prisoners to consent to their execution, whether mental or physical illness, remorse, the severity of the conditions of their confinement, or pessimism about their appeal prospects, it does not absolve the state from the fact that it is engaged in a premeditated human rights violation and is participating in a cycle of violence."
Brian Crowther
Leeds
brian@bcrowther.demon.co.uk

fields.headline: Cash for councillors
fields.trailText: I thoroughly endorse George Monbiot's arguments (Let's pay local councillors, May 4).
fields.body:
I thoroughly endorse George Monbiot's arguments (Let's pay local councillors, May 4). More than 15 years ago, I and colleagues at the University of the West of England studied the pressures on local councillors (Councillors in Crisis, Macmillan, 1991). One of our central recommendations was the payment of a salary.

Monbiot concentrates on the policy implications of our "voluntary" tradition. Our main focus was on the detrimental effects on the lives of councillors and their families: the most dedicated told us of marital stresses, estrangement from their children, loss of promotion at work (occasionally even dismissal), loss of leisure, severe stress and ill health. There were also obvious implications for recruitment: those who can afford to take on such demanding role without payment form an increasingly restricted section of the local community. Fifteen years on, I am pleased that serious consideration is being given to the payment of senior councillors.
Dr Jacqueline Barron
Bristol

 I served for 20 years as a councillor. Many who had the leisure willingly gave their time to meetings. In my view, much of that time was unnecessary. The result was that we had few young working men and women. The young women councillors we had were, like myself, supported financially by a working husband. Young working men and women simply could not afford to give the time and effort necessary for the considerable calls that are made on a councillor. Let us pay them.
BH Johnson
Cambridge

 George Monbiot might not be so bullish about paid councillors if he lived in the borough of Hammersmith and Fulham, where the concept of cabinet government was pioneered. Labour councillors have awarded themselves substantial salaries as "full-time" members of the cabinet executive, yet nearly all of them continue to hold down their daytime jobs. The mayor is paid £37,500.

Hardly surprising that at the GMB's national public service conference the Fulham branch delegate supported a motion asking for the abolition of the cabinet system. It does nothing to enhance local democracy, despite the claims of those who benefit from it, namely the highly paid politburo in charge of the authority.
Bert Schouwenburg
GMB regional organiser

 Of course councillors should be adequately compensated for the time spent on approved council duties. But in Sefton, the three party leaders have carved up the top-cat jobs between them taking £21,000 to £24,000 and the key decisions are now being made by a tight-knit group with less transparency than ever. There are no new whizz kids on the horizon, and there is widespread indifference, scepticism and downright hostility to politicians of whatever party. The council tax has gone up by over 11% in two years and Sefton now spends £600,000 pa and rising on its unaccountable councillors.

Mr Monbiot disparages the calibre of of retired people, but among them there are an increasing number of qualified and experienced people with the energy and ability to make a real contribution to local democracy without expecting a splendid salary and pension.
Tom Egan
Southport

 I do not have an excess of time on my hands. I am a full-time working solicitor and do voluntary work at my local CAB and women's refuge. To my knowledge, the overwhelming majority of local Labour councillors in St Albans work full-time. Perhaps Mr Monbiot has too much time to spare and might consider standing for his local council?
Sinead Coyle
St Albans, Herts sc@failte60.fsnet.co.uk

fields.headline: Mardi Grass
fields.standfirst: Australia's Hemp Olympix go with a bong
fields.trailText: Olympics with a difference were celebrated in Australia yesterday, opening with a Mardi Grass, to celebrate this region's highly respected cannabis crop.
fields.byline: Christopher Zinn in Nimbin, New South Wales
fields.body:
Olympics with a difference were celebrated in Australia yesterday, opening with a Mardi Grass, to celebrate this region's highly respected cannabis crop.

The distinctly unathletic Australia Hemp Olympix 2000 attracted thousands of pro-marijuana campaigners to the town of Nimbin, 400 miles north of Sydney - a sort of sub-tropical Woodstock.

Judges awarded gold medals for bong hurling, the fastest joint roller and the most artistic joint.

Local police turned a blind eye to a marijuana market and the Cannabis Cup awarded to the finest outdoor-cultivated plant.

"The police had to get out of the way or they'd get trampled," said long-time resident and documentary film maker Paul Tait.

"Tourists say the cops must be bent here because there is so much dealing in the open. But they're not, they're lovely men," said Nimbin's GP, Dr David Helliwell, who admits to being a pot smoker and is trying to introduce Dutch-style hash coffee houses to regulate the drug market.

The speed rolling contest involves making a three-paper reefer as fast as possible while the artistic competitors have 10 minutes to produce their creations. All joints must be smokable by the judges.

Bob Clarke, from Morree, was speed winner of the past two years and took gold again in 19.6 sec. "I have been coming here for five years and have never been arrested or hassled," he said. "I always seem to win a bag of pot too."

All competitors and judges passed the mandatory drugs test, to make sure they were all stoned.

But if the Hemp Olympix can teach the Sydney organising committee for the Olympic Games a thing or two about sportsmanship and good humour, perhaps they could learn something from the official Olympics.

The judges of the joint-rolling contest were so out of it, even before the initial heats, that they forgot to bring a stopwatch or even a cigarette lighter.

webTitle: 'Our arms will stay silent' says IRA

fields.headline: 'Our arms will stay silent' says IRA
fields.standfirst:
Text of the IRA statement

Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: "The leadership of the IRA is committed to a just and lasting peace. We have sustained that commitment despite the abuse of the peace process by those who persist with the aim of defeating the IRA and Irish republicans.
fields.body:
"The leadership of the IRA is committed to a just and lasting peace. We have sustained that commitment despite the abuse of the peace process by those who persist with the aim of defeating the IRA and Irish republicans.

"Republicans believe that the British government claim to a part of Ireland, its denial of national self-determination to the people of the island of Ireland, the partition of our country and the maintenance of social and economic inequality in the Six Counties are the root causes of conflict.

"The maintenance of our cessation is our contribution to the peace process and to the creation of a future in which the causes of conflict are resolved by peaceful means. For our part, the IRA leadership is committed to resolving the issue of arms. The political responsibility for advancing the current situation rests with the two governments, especially the British government, and the leadership of the political parties. The full implementation, on a progressive and irreversible basis by the two governments, especially the British government, of what they have agreed will provide a political context, in an enduring political process, with the potential to remove the causes of conflict, and in which Irish republicans and unionists can, as equals, pursue our respective political objectives peacefully.

"In that context the IRA leadership will initiate a process that will completely and verifiably put IRA arms beyond use. We will do it in such a way as to avoid risk to the public and misappropriation by others and ensure maximum public confidence.

"We will resume contact with the Independent International Commission on Decommissioning and enter into further discussions with the commission on the basis of the IRA leadership's commitment to resolving the issue of arms.

"We look to the two governments and especially the British government to fulfil their commitments under the Good Friday agreement and the joint statement. To facilitate the speedy and full implementation of the Good Friday agreement and the government's measures, our arms are silent and secure. There is no threat to the peace process from the IRA.

"In this context, the IRA leadership has agreed to put in place within weeks a confidence-building measure to confirm that our weapons remain secure. The contents of a number of our arms dumps will be inspected by agreed third parties who will report that they have done so to the IICP. The dumps will be reinspected regularly to ensure that the weapons have remained silent."

 (signed) P O'Neill

fields.headline: The weapons
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: The exact size of the IRA's arsenal is unknown but the RUC and the Garda estimates that its cache - stored mainly in the republic - includes:
fields.body:
The exact size of the IRA's arsenal is unknown but the RUC and the Garda estimates that its cache - stored mainly in the republic - includes:

 At least 2.6 tonnes of Czech-made semtex stored in bunkers under remote fields

 More than 1,000 rifles, including 650 AK-47s, mostly supplied by the Libyan leader Colonel Muammar Gadafy in the 70s and 80s

 About 20 Russian heavy-calibre armour-piercing machine-guns

 At least 12 heavy machine-guns

 600 handguns, including almost 100 Webley revolvers

 1,200 detonators

 115 hand grenades

 Up to 1.5m rounds of ammunition

 Nine SAM-7 ground-to-air missiles

 Dozens of medium-range anti-tank guns

 46 rocket grenades

 11 rocket launchers

 Seven flame throwers

The breakaway Real IRA has a small number of rifles, handguns, machine-guns, unknown quantities of semtex, detonators, homemade mortars and grenade launchers.

The Continuity IRA has small quantities of rifles, pistols, semtex and detonators and is believed to have a huge M79 grenade launcher.

Loyalist paramilitary groups also control more than 800 weapons, including 80 machine-guns, 75 rifles and 675 handguns, and large quantities of Powergel, a commercial explosive.

The inspectors

Cyril Ramaphosa played a significant role in ending apartheid in South Africa, as the former secretary general of the African National Congress, and has long-standing links with Sinn Fein.

The lawyer and former trade unionist was elected to the ANC post in 1991 and was the chief negotiator in the protracted constitutional bargaining with the white minority National party before the transfer of power to an elected majority government in 1994.

Ramaphosa went on to chair the constitutional assembly that drafted a permanent constitution which included protecting the rights of the Afrikaner minority. At 47, he is now one of South Africa's leading businessmen with extensive publishing interests.

The surrender of ANC arms after a 30-year guerrilla war against white rule was a key element of the negotiations leading to the elections and Ramaphosa had regular contact with Sinn Fein leaders in the early 90s.

He also visited Northern Ireland after the Good Friday agreement in a "neutral and independent" capacity to share the ANC's experiences with Sinn Fein and to help sell the accord to its followers.

Martti Ahtisaari, the former Finnish president, is an experienced negotiator who acted as the EU envoy during the 1999 Kosovo conflict.

A veteran UN diplomat and former UN under-secretary general, he won Finland's first direct presidential election in 1994, leaving office in February this year.

UN secretary general Kofi Annan called on him to act as a peacemaker in Kosovo last year. Ahtisaari joined the Russian envoy, Victor Chernomyrdin, in Belgrade to deliver a peace plan to the Yugoslav president Slobodan Milosevic in June 1999, which paved the way for the eventual end of Nato's air campaign.

He is also chairman of the International Crisis Group, and probably the only world leader to have a sausage named after him; after his election as president his supporters renamed a Finnish delicacy Mara, after his nickname.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Iran's reformers celebrated victory in parliamentary run-off elections yesterday despite what many saw as heavy-handed bias in favour of the losing hardliners by various state bodies.
fields.body:
Reformers win Iran election

Iran's reformers celebrated victory in parliamentary run-off elections yesterday despite what many saw as heavy-handed bias in favour of the losing hardliners by various state bodies.

"The attacks against the reformist movement over the past weeks have been unsuccessful - it gained 71.2% of seats in the second round of voting," a spokesman for President Khatami said.

The closure of 16 pro-democracy publications in the lead up to Friday's elections days deprived the reformers of their only publicity vehicle.

Many reformers feared that a demoralised electorate would stay away from the ballot boxes and allow for a strong showing by their conservative rivals.
Reuters, Tehran

Arrest for US embassy attack

Russian security services yesterday arrested a man suspected of involvement in a shooting in March last year outside the US embassy in Moscow, a spokesman said.

The suspect was being questioned by the FSB, the country's chief intelligence agency. He would probably be charged with terrorism, the spokesman said.

Coinciding with protests against Nato involvement in the former Yugoslavia, gunmen tried unsuccessfully to fire grenade launchers outside the US embassy.

A gunman shot several rounds from an automatic weapon into the embassy wall. No one was hurt in the attack, and the gunmen sped away when police opened fire.
AP, Moscow

37 drown in ferry sinking

At least 37 people died when an overloaded ferry carrying more than 100 passengers sank yesterday off Ambon island, about 1,600 miles east of Jakarta. Rescuers found 37 bodies and have rescued 56 survivors.

The issue of overloading is a chronic problem in Indonesian shipping, and maritime disasters are frequent. Insurers say weight regulations are routinely ignored and enforcement is sporadic at best.
AP, Jakarta

Stalin statue back in Georgia

Khashuri, a small town in Georgia, replaced a monument to Josef Stalin, the Soviet Union's Georgian-born dictator, yesterday after it had spent 40 years in a warehouse.

The unveiling was timed to coincide with tomorrow's Victory Day holiday, celebrating the Soviet army's defeat of Nazi Germany in 1945.

The statue had been removed by decree of then Soviet leader Nikita Khrushchev, who denounced Stalin's purges in the 1930s that killed millions of people.
AP, Tblisi

Mass signals truce in Mexico

An outdoor Roman Catholic mass attended by 50,000 people in Mexico City - the first in 76 years - may signal the end to decades of conflict between the church and the Mexican government.

Despite assurances that Jesus Christ is "no competition" for the politicians many remain uneasy at the idea of the church playing a more forceful role.
Reuters, Mexico City

Police provide escape route

Roadblocks went up around the northern town of Ioannina after a 28-year-old man, arrested for drugs possession, escaped custody by driving off in an unguarded police car.

Police sources said that two officers, who left the suspect alone to investigate what look like a drug deal, are likely to face disciplinary action.
AP, Ioannina, Greece

fields.headline: Foul play
fields.trailText: I was a member of the Bath University Football Club tour to Romania in 1981 (Rugby Gladiators thrown to the Romanian lions, May 4).
fields.body:
I was a member of the Bath University Football Club tour to Romania in 1981 (Rugby Gladiators thrown to the Romanian lions, May 4). We were told we had a match against a "Romanian Youth team", only to find we were taken to the Dinamo Bucharest stadium, where we toiled against a team of highly skilled footballers in front of a crowd of 10,000 spectators in 90 degree heat. It was only afterwards that one of our hosts translated the newspaper article, indicating that we had played against the full Dinamo side containing seven Romanian internationals and we had been billed as an "English Second Division Team".

In losing 6-0, I think we put up a credible performance. I was marking Georgescu, a player who had won the Addidas Golden Boot award. I sympathise with the Dorchester Gladiators, but a translation error - I think not, the Romanians like to win.


Alan Day
Cookham, Berks

fields.headline: Unbridled ride to rights
fields.standfirst:
Devolution has brought a year of surprises for the Scottish legal system. From October, England too has shocks in store, says Clare Dyer

Devolution in Scotland: special report
fields.trailText: Devolution has brought a year of surprises for the Scottish legal system. From October, England too has shocks in store, says  Clare Dyer
fields.body:
The tiny ad in the Help Please column of the latest Law Society Gazette looks innocuous, even baffling, unless you happen to be in the know. But for lawyers at the Crown Prosecution Service, it's a red letter warning: the Human Rights Act is coming. Not that they needed it: CPS lawyers have been training for months in the run-up to the Act, which comes into force on October 2.

Headed "Speed Cameras", the ad says cryptically: "Identity of driver obtained under s172 RTA 1988 Human Rights Act. If you are advising clients in this area, please contact box A28/01." It's a signal that lawyers are poised to jump on a bandwagon already rolling in the Scottish courts, where they have been able to invoke the European Convention on Human Rights since the Scotland Act, bringing in Scottish devolution, became law a year ago.

The result has been a year of surprises for the Scottish legal system. He added: "Prophetic or what?"

It was a right enjoyed by everyone, including "those whom the police are pursuing because they believe them to be drug dealers, fraudsters, paedophiles or wife-batterers". The police could tap telephones, use secret cameras or engage in covert surveillance only if they had a valid warrant "under a law which has been promulgated and publicised as a law designed to permit the invasion of article 8 privacy." It had been suggested, he said, that "it was a bit like sailing in the Titanic toward a legal iceberg. The Lord Justice General and two other judges ruled that it had to be set aside and the appeal re-heard from scratch by three different judges. References to the European convention and the Human Rights Act in challenging the admission of identification evidence obtained in clear breach of PACE codes of evidence were being made too frequently, he said. This could not only delay appeals but might bring the convention and the Act into disrepute.

webTitle: Ex-solider admits defacing statue of Churchill

fields.headline: Ex-solider admits defacing statue of Churchill
fields.standfirst: May 2K: special report
fields.trailText: A former soldier last night confessed to defacing the statue of the wartime leader Sir Winston Churchill during last Monday's May Day demonstrations in London. James Matthews, 25, whose four years of service included time in Bosnia, turned himself in to the police after appeals to identify those who committed criminal offences.
fields.body:
A former soldier last night confessed to defacing the statue of the wartime leader Sir Winston Churchill during last Monday's May Day demonstrations in London. James Matthews, 25, whose four years of service included time in Bosnia, turned himself in to the police after appeals to identify those who committed criminal offences.

Mr Matthews, who climbed on top of the statue of the former prime minister in Parliament Square and sprayed it with red paint so that it looked as if blood was dripping from the mouth, told the Guardian he condemned the vandalism of the Whitehall Cenotaph. He said defacing Churchill was a different matter.

Within days of Mr Matthews' action, a tabloid newspaper asked its readers to call a hotline if they knew "the identities of any of the scum who terrorised the capital". Mr Matthews was photographed spraying Churchill and his picture was the most prominent of those displayed, the caption underneath saying "rucksack-carrying yob uses spray can on statue of wartime leader Winston Churchill. Do you recognise rioter?"

In fact, the "rioter" is a student of English and European literature and philosophy and works part-time on a building site to finance his degree. He now lives in Cambridge but comes from Stoke-on-Trent. In his spare time, Mr Matthews likes to run, practise jujitsu and read.

The May Day demonstration was his first such gathering. He said he had never vandalised anything before.

With close cropped hair and smart clothes, he fits the stereotype of the soldier not the protester or eco-warrior. Yesterday, Mr Matthews said that vandalising Churchill was right but vandalising a war memorial wrong. He wanted to distinguish himself from the others sought by the police for the havoc wreaked.

He claimed that he had not taken part in any of the violence. He said: "I didn't and never would deface the Whitehall Cenotaph - it's a monument to ordinary soldiers and I was an ordinary soldier."

Angered by his depiction as a "mindless rioter", Mr Matthews said: "I don't belong to any anarchist organisation and I am not a thug. The police video footage will establish that I was nowhere near any of the violence that took place later that day. I think what they did to the Cenotaph was a very bad thing."

He added: "The May Day celebrations were in the spirit of free expression against capitalism. Churchill was an exponent of capitalism and of imperialism and anti-semitism. A Tory reactionary vehemently opposed to the emancipation of women and to independence in India. The media machine made this paunchy little man much larger than life - a colossal, towering figure of great stature and bearing with trademark cigar, bowler hat and V-sign. The reality was an often irrational, sometimes vainglorious leader whose impetuosity, egotism and bigotry on occasion cost many lives unnecessarily and caused much suffering that was needless and unjustified."

Last Monday, nursing a hangover, Mr Matthews got up early and caught the coach from Cambridge to London. He went to the May Day protests alone. The student friends who had agreed to go with him had drunk too much the night before and shied off when it came to the alarm call.

Arriving in the capital just after 10am, Mr Matthews soaked up the carnival atmosphere, talked to a few people, climbed up a tree and listened to some music.

He said that when he saw some flower power people spraying flowers on the road with a can of red paint he asked if he could borrow the can for a minute. Soon he was grasping on to Churchill's coat collar and spraying his mouth.

"It wasn't planned. I didn't go down with that in mind. I don't generally go around doing this sort of thing," he said.

After painting Churchill, Mr Matthews changed his shirt, "had a bit of a walk around" and got the coach back to Cambridge around 2.30pm.

webTitle: Now it's over to the unionists

fields.headline: Now it's over to the unionists
fields.standfirst:
Trimble back in win-or-bust mode as party weighs up IRA statement

Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Trimble back in win-or-bust mode as party weighs up IRA statement
fields.body:
An IRA double murderer whistled in amazement yesterday. It all meant, he said, nothing less than the beginning of the IRA's dissolution. He added, with emphasis: "The IRA is in liquidation."

But Ulster Unionists were suspicious. They were poring over the IRA's dramatic statement on Saturday, examining it for caveats, and assessing the risks. They saw many, and were carefully constructing their credit and debit columns.

But the Good Friday agreement, apparently close to expiration last week, may yet be roaring back towards a full and vigorous life. That now depends on the 860 delegates who make up the Ulster Unionist council, who will meet next Friday, May 20, to deliver their verdict.

Persuade his ruling council to accept, and David Trimble will have sealed a political triumph which, even he privately admits, seemed well beyond his wildest dreams just days ago. Fail, and his five-year party leadership is over, and, with it, the agreement.

None of the tumultuous twists of the peace-process rollercoaster has come close to what can be expected over the next fortnight. Unionism will be fighting in public, and it will be a fearsome battle.

Last week the British and Irish governments damped down expectations as they struggled to find a way of sparking a return to devolution after Peter Mandelson, the Northern Ireland secretary, suspended Stormont's power-sharing executive and assembly on February 11. There was no talk of the hand of history or seismic shifts, just modest expressions of hope. It soon became clear a deal was there, with republicans having manoeuvred the IRA much more skilfully than before.

Key in all of this is John Taylor, deputy leader of the Ulster Unionists. Tony Blair and Mr Mandelson concentrated much of their time on him, and they expect him now to back the deal. There may be a little encouragement, perhaps in the form of a pledge to keep the union flag flying from Stormont. It sounds minor enough to outsiders, but in Northern Ireland this is another of those vital symbolic points.

Few outside the negotiations, which even saw Sinn Fein's Gerry Adams and Martin McGuinness invited to Chequers, had anticipated the extent of the IRA statement when it appeared on Saturday. Even Mr Trimble's most virulent critics within his party grudgingly conceded that it represented an important shift.

In the exact terms used earlier by both Mr Blair and Mr Mandelson, it said the IRA leadership would "initiate a process that will completely and verifiably put IRA arms beyond use. We will do it in such a way as to avoid risk to the public and misappropriation by others and ensure maximum public confidence".

Confidence-building

It also said: "The IRA leadership has agreed to put in place within weeks a confidence-building measure to confirm that our weapons remain secure. The contents of a number of our arms dumps will be inspected by agreed third parties who will report that they have done so to the Independent International Commission on Decommissioning. The dumps will be reinspected to ensure that the weapons have remained silent."

The governments quickly announced that the former Finnish president Martti Ahtisaari, a veteran UN diplomat and EU envoy during the Kosovo crisis last year, would team up with Cyril Ramaphosa, one-time secretary general of the African National Congress, to inspect the dumps. Both are popular choices with republicans.

The IRA move falls short of the kind of decommissioning unionists had hoped for: there will be no destruction of weapons. The IRA has also foisted off the agreement's May 22 deadline for the completion of decommissioning, with the governments agreeing to an extension because of the delays in setting up the executive and cross-border institutions last November. The new deadline will be in June next year.

One sceptical member of the Ulster Unionist assembly team said yesterday: "It is a vague statement. There is some hope in it. But the IRA keeps control of its weapons. There is complete spin going on as to what they are prepared to do."

Mr Trimble, who met his assembly team on Saturday, will speak again with them tomorrow. He has so far lost two of his team, originally 20-strong, and at least one other is likely to follow. He is said to be taking the win-or-bust approach. His lieutenants know the council meeting, the fourth in six months, will be close.

Mr Trimble defeated south Belfast MP Martin Smyth's leadership challenge two months ago with a slim margin, similar to the support he had six months ago for entering government with Sinn Fein before a start to IRA decommissioning. He is braced for an even tighter battle this time.

One of Mr Trimble's advisers said yesterday: "There are caveats. It is going to be a really slippery two weeks.

"It is not perfect. But what it does mean is that the IRA's posture with respect to the rest of society in Northern Ireland has been modified so that it is so much less threatening. If people get that into their guts, then everything is possible."

The IRA's statement goes much further than Angel II, the failed initiative it put forward in February, and it is also markedly different from its dump arms order signalling the end of its six-year border campaign in 1962. Then it made it clear that the weapons were to be retained for future conflict.

The two inspectors, who will work closely with General John de Chastelain, head of the decommissioning body, will arrive shortly to discuss modalities. Mr Trimble wants an early meeting.

They will be allowed access to three substantial dumps, which will then be sealed in an as yet unspecified way, and it is believed that others will be opened to them over the next 12 months. But there will be no arms destruction at the end of that time.

The IRA's proclamation is markedly different from recent defensive and petty statements. The confident language indicates republicans are at last adopting their familiar approach to difficulties, turning an intractable problem into triumph.

Moral high ground

The IRA can claim it has successfully foisted off decommissioning, at least on unionist terms, and paint the move as voluntary. It has wrested the moral high ground, leaving unionists the focus of worldwide opprobrium if they scorn the unprecedented offer.

Ulster Unionists, though, now know they will be voting for the return as education minister of Mr McGuinness, the former IRA chief of staff, if they back the move. That appointment came as a surprise last time.

The council has also linked a return to government to retention of the RUC name, with a concession - though relatively minor - expected.

A government minister said last night: "This is as good as it gets. This is it for the agreement. Those who want it to work will back it. For those who don't, nothing would persuade them otherwise."

A leading republican, who believed the IRA would suffer few defections despite internal ructions, said the movement had nowhere else to go. The collapse of the agreement would have signalled that the Adams-McGuinness strategy of 15 years had been a mistake.

"The deal allows unionists to claims there is decommissioning, and us to claim that there is not," he said. "It is an honourable compromise. No one has won.

"What more do they want? I suspect the wilder elements within unionism would not be happy even if the IRA's leaders were led out and publicly executed."

His lieutenants know the council meeting, the fourth in six months, will be close. Mr Trimble defeated south Belfast MP Martin Smyth's leadership challenge two months ago with a slim margin, similar to the support he had six months ago for entering government with Sinn Fein before a start to IRA decommissioning. He is braced for an even tighter battle this time. One of Mr Trimble's advisers said yesterday: "There are caveats. It is going to be a really slippery two weeks. "It is not perfect. But what it does mean is that the IRA's posture with respect to the rest of society in Northern Ireland has been modified so that it is so much less threatening. If people get that into their guts, then everything is possible." The IRA's statement goes much further than Angel II, the failed initiative it put forward in February, and it is also markedly different from its dump arms order signalling the end of its six-year border campaign in 1962. Then it made it clear that the weapons were to be retained for future conflict. The two inspectors, who will work closely with General John de Chastelain, head of the decommissioning body, will arrive shortly to discuss modalities. Mr Trimble wants an early meeting. They will be allowed access to three substantial dumps, which will then be sealed in an as yet unspecified way, and it is believed that others will be opened to them over the next 12 months. But there will be no arms destruction at the end of that time. The IRA's proclamation is markedly different from recent defensive and petty statements. The confident language indicates republicans are at last adopting their familiar approach to difficulties, turning an intractable problem into triumph. It has wrested the moral high ground, leaving unionists the focus of worldwide opprobrium if they scorn the unprecedented offer. A government minister said last night: "This is as good as it gets. This is it for the agreement. Those who want it to work will back it. For those who don't, nothing would persuade them otherwise." The collapse of the agreement would have signalled that the Adams-McGuinness strategy of 15 years had been a mistake. "The deal allows unionists to claims there is decommissioning, and us to claim that there is not," he said. "It is an honourable compromise. No one has won. "What more do they want? I suspect the wilder elements within unionism would not be happy even if the IRA's leaders were led out and publicly executed."

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: The whole world knows that George Stephenson built the first steam locomotive but, as so often happens, the whole world is wrong. As Adam Hart-Davies recalls in Inventors Imperfect (11.0am, Radio 4), the credit should really go to Richard Trevithick, onetime Cornish wrestler. In 1801, 13 years before Stephenson's first unreliable vehicle puffed through Killingworth Colliery, Trevithick's machine had carried passengers up Camborne Hill. But he lacked the business nous to exploit his invention and wound up prospecting for silver in Peru.

fields.trailText:
Virgin team to spruce up NHS
The government has asked consultants from the Virgin Atlantic airline to advise how the NHS can be made more user-friendly.
fields.body:
Virgin team to spruce up NHS
The government has asked consultants from the Virgin Atlantic airline to advise how the NHS can be made more user-friendly.

The team will visit hospitals throughout the country over the next three months and examine how patients can be provided with better food and accommodation. The health secretary, Alan Milburn, said the Virgin team would report in the summer.

Father-friendly jobs 'needed'
A fathers' action group yesterday launched a charter urging firms to adopt father-friendly working practices or face difficulties recruiting men to high-powered jobs. Fathers Direct said employers should introduce more flexible conditions, including working from home.

Eight held after cannabis haul
Detectives were yesterday questioning eight men after the seizure of £8m worth of cannabis. The drugs were found on Saturday during a raid on an industrial estate in New Hey, Greater Manchester.

Protest over human rights
More than 500 protesters yesterday attended a rally in Trafalgar Square, London, calling for an end to Zimbabwe's human rights abuses. The demonstration was organised by the British branch of the Movement for Democratic Change, the main opposition party in Zimbabwe.

£8m lottery win
One ticket scooped the £8,030,633 jackpot in Saturday's lottery draw. The winning numbers were 2, 3, 30, 31, 41 and 45. The bonus ball was 23. No one won the Thunderball top prize.

fields.headline: Alternative politics
fields.standfirst:
International support for the Zimbabwean opposition must be unwavering - but critical

Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: In Bulawayo, Zimbabwe's second city, a former minister with the ruling Zapu-PF party and ex- combatant, has a full collection of Kim Il-sung's works on his bookcase. He sits, hands folded over a demisphere of a girth, extolling the virtues of democracy and the opposition party, the Movement for Democratic Change. "The people must govern," he says. In Bulawayo, Zimbabwe's second city, a former minister with the ruling Zapu-PF party and ex- combatant, has a full collection of Kim Il-sung's works on his bookcase. He sits, hands folded over a demisphere of a girth, extolling the virtues of democracy and the opposition party, the Movement for Democratic Change. "The people must govern," he says. "Not the party and certainly not one man." Without them, he says, the country will descend into ever deeper venality and economic chaos.

Across town, a white farmer, his shorts pulled up high to reveal sinewy legs ruddied by the sun, sits in a cafe tucking into eggs, bacon and beans. He has already had to leave his farm in fear of squatters. Unless the MDC wins the forthcoming elections, he insists, he will have to leave the country.

Around the corner, a former veteran who fought with the liberation movement, Zapu, explains why he is standing as an MDC candidate: "I left my home to vote for land and freedom and 20 years after liberation we are still fighting for both," he says. Three very different stories from one city in one day.

When a political party unites such disparate forces in a country with as many racial, ethnic and economic cleavages as Zimbabwe, it can mean only one of two things. Either what it opposes is so appalling that coming together to defeat it overrides all other social, economic or political differences; or that the party has policies so popular that they cohere what would otherwise be antagonistic groups in the common interest.

In the case of the MDC, it is the former. As Zanu-PF degenerates into armed thuggery, money grabbing, greed and economic illiteracy, Zimbabwe is in desperate need of an alternative. Zanu-PF, and its leader, President Robert Mugabe, once had strong Marxist roots; but all traces of ideology have withered, leaving it with only one purpose - staying in power. The MDC is the only party that can stop it.

It is for this reason that the international community's support for the MDC must be unwavering, but critical. Unwavering because the stakes are high and in such unfavourable circumstances it will need all the support it can get. Critical because it is untested in office, uncertain in opposition and unconvincing in some of its policy pledges.

Born a year ago from a peculiar alliance of trade unions, churches and big business, the MDC comprises mostly black members. It is, however, heavily reliant both politically and financially on the white minority. Its promise to pull Zimbabwe's troops from the war in the Congo would be a huge contribution to the economy and the nation as a whole. But its pledge to impose a 100-day IMF-style stabilisation programme and privatise all state-owned companies within two years would give as much pleasure to foreign bankers as it would inflict pain on the poor. Its northern neighbour, Zambia, has pursued similar plans with disastrous consequences.

Yet for all that, the MDC is the only viable alternative. A Zanu-PF victory in the upcoming elections would deliver a critical blow to democracy in Zimbabwe. Not only would it confirm the party leaders' mistaken belief that power is theirs by right, but it could also establish political violence and intimidation as indispensable elements in the country's electoral culture.

The prospect of such a victory, even if the violence stopped tomorrow, is by no means absurd. Thanks to its record in the liberation struggle and its achievements in education, health and infrastructure during the early years, Zanu-PF retains a strong core of support, particularly in rural areas. Zanu-PF has the state-owned media on its side, receives state funds and President Mugabe has the right to appoint 30 of the 150 parliamentary seats.

If that's not enough, the constituencies are gerrymandered in his favour. And that is before they start cheating and bullying. According to one report, about a quarter of those on the electoral roll are dead. Moreover, election monitors have been beaten up, repressive police laws against political activity invoked and the MDC leader, Morgan Tsvangirai, was detained over the weekend. The climate of fear and repression which Mugabe has unleashed makes it even more difficult for the MDC to participate in the electoral process.

The MDC leadership apparently understand this, but as yet its reaction has lacked political logic. Its supporters are being killed and beaten for wearing, and even owning, MDC T-shirts. The response has been to tell them to put away their T-shirts for their own safety. The trade union movement, which is fully behind the MDC, called off the traditional May Day celebrations for fear of political violence. Instead it told its supporters to stay home and pray for peace. Tsvangirai freely admits the election will be neither free nor fair; but he will contest it anyway. In short, he keeps saying he does not like the way things are going but he refuses to do anything substantive about it.

He has two other feasible options. Neither is without fault, but both are better than the course of action which he is following at the moment. He can withdraw from the elections altogether and declare the process bankrupt. This would, in effect, hand the election to Zanu-PF, but it is well on the way to strong-arming itself into power anyway. A pathetically low turnout and the lack of opposition would strip the government of all democratic legitimacy.

Or he can up the ante and lead a campaign of civil disobedience, demonstrations and strikes. This would cause further disruption in an already unsettled country and risk an escalation of violence if Mugabe were to retaliate in kind. But, since the violence is continuing and the economy is in freefall, this would be only a difference by degrees. And it would present a fully blown political challenge to Mugabe that he would not be able to undermine by picking off individuals in ones and twos and making examples of them.

But the MDC continuing on its present course would culminate in its both losing elections it could never win and legitimising a tainted victory.

The MDC's strengths and weaknesses are in its name. The fact that it stands for democracy and change are what make it such a vital political force. But so far it has proved itself to be less a movement than a holder of press conferences and rallies. This is partly the result of political repression, but partly due to an incoherent strategy for combating it.

Despite its faults, the challenge the MDC is posing to Mugabe's despotism is impressive even if much of its programme is not. For the time being, what it represents is more important than what it promises to do. If the MDC wins, and Zimbabweans don't like what it does, they will always be able to vote it out.

If Zanu-PF wins, it may not matter if Zimbabweans like what it does or not - for they may then lose the right to vote altogether.

webTitle: Europe warned of Iranian missile threat

fields.headline: Europe warned of Iranian missile threat
fields.standfirst:
Pentagon highlights danger to win support for 'son of star wars'

More about Iran
fields.trailText: The CIA is nearing completion of a secret report for President Bill Clinton on the state of European political and public opinion towards Washington's controversial plan for a national missile defence shield.
fields.byline: Martin Kettle in Huntsville,  Ian Traynor  in Moscow and  Richard Norton-Taylor
fields.body:
The CIA is nearing completion of a secret report for President Bill Clinton on the state of European political and public opinion towards Washington's controversial plan for a national missile defence shield.

Mr Clinton will decide this summer whether to give the go-ahead to the shield - dubbed the "son of star wars" - for which planning and testing are almost finished.

"We are looking at reactions in different countries, allies as well as potential enemies," Robert Walpole, the top US inteligence officer dealing with missile defence, told journalists in Huntsville, Alabama.

Mr Walpole said he believed Europeans were less convinced than Americans that the threat of an attack on the US by "rogue states" such as North Korea, Iran and Iraq, was a credible one. France, in particular, was sceptical.

But opinion could change, he said, when Europeans became more aware that Iran would shortly be able to develop an intermediate range missile capable of hitting any country in Europe, but not the US.

"US allies are going to be the first to be targeted. A range of 4,000 kilometres [2,500 miles] would give them [Iran] most of Europe," he said.

Assessments by the CIA show that Iran has the capability to develop larger missile systems than the Shahab-3, which has already been tested. It could be in a position to upgrade to an inter-continental ballistic missile system capable of hitting the US by 2010.

"We assess these capabilities as indicative of intentions to develop longer-range missiles and space launch vehicles," Mr Walpole said.

The US plan for a 100-interceptor missile defence shield would not protect Europe against a missile attack from Iran. "Our interceptors simply don't have the legs," said Keith Englander, a senior Pentagon missile planner.

The CIA's warnings come as the US military prepares for a crucial test next month in which a prototype interceptor rocket will again attempt to shoot down a test missile over the Pacific. The test on June 26 will be the third intercept attempt.

A first test last year was successful, but a second this year was not, though the scientists claim to have fixed the cooling system failure which they say caused the interceptor to miss the incoming missile by about 100 metres.

The US tests involve an attack missile launched from Vandenberg air force base in California and an interceptor fired from Kwajalein atoll in the Marshall islands.

"I am confident this system works. We have the technology today," said Lieutenant-General John Costello, commander of the army's space and missile defence command.

If, as expected, Mr Clinton approves the system, the US will be able to deploy 20 interceptors at Fort Greeley, Alaska, by the end of 2005, and the remaining 80 by the end of 2007, Mr Englander said.

The initial deployment also involves the construction of two x-band radar sites in North Dakota and one on Shemya island off the Alaska coast. Five other early-warning radar sites, including Fylingdales in Yorkshire to detect missiles from the Middle East, and another at Thule in Greenland, would require upgrading.

Gen Costello made clear that the initial 100 interceptor missiles under discussion by the Pentagon are likely to be only the start.

"The growth of the rogue nation threat would lead you to consider more ground-based interceptors," as well as sea-and space-based options, he said.

A central political difficulty for Mr Clinton is that a decision to deploy the national missile shield would violate the 1972 anti-ballistic missile treaty between the US and Russia.

The treaty rules out the building of national missile defence systems, on the grounds that they would upset the nuclear balance.

Washington's push to amend the ABM treaty is expected to dominate Mr Clinton's first summit with President Vladimir Putin next month.

Colonel-General Leonid Ivashev, head of the Russian armed forces' diplomatic service, last week accused the US of dishonesty in claiming its plans were aimed solely at "rogue" states such as North Korea.

"These [US] proposals are not constructive and cannot be a subject of further consultations," Gen Ivashev said.

"What is actually meant here is a system with such control and target-acquisition means, including space-based, which can easily be expanded by a simple increase in the number of anti-missiles."

America's European allies are also deeply sceptical about the US project. The International Institute for Strategic Studies, a leading London-based thinktank, said: "The US has had little success in convincing its European critics that its plans for deployment are sensible, or useful".

It added: "There are few in Europe who believe that the so-called 'rogue' states are led by men so irrational that they would threaten the US with weapons of mass destruction carried on ballistic missiles - even if they were able to do so."

It pointed out that many Europeans do not believe the system will ever work as intended. Even if it did, they believe it would be destabilising and provoke China - with a much smaller nuclear arsenal than Russia - into producing many more long-range ballistic missiles.

US officials touring Europe in their attempt to drum up support for the missile shield project admit that their Nato allies have a very different perception of the threat posed by so-called rogue states.

fields.headline: Maritime intrigue case for Booth
fields.trailText: Just days before her fourth baby is due, Cherie Booth QC will be on her feet in the court of appeal on Friday to ask for a hearing for a Nigerian chief accused of what he claims are "crimes against humanity" - charges included in legal submissions that led to a high court judgment without a trial.
fields.body:
Just days before her fourth baby is due, Cherie Booth QC will be on her feet in the court of appeal on Friday to ask for a hearing for a Nigerian chief accused of what he claims are "crimes against humanity" - charges included in legal submissions that led to a high court judgment without a trial.

The case has all the ingredients of an international thriller - mysteriously missing oil rigs, an alleged attempt to strangle the Russian ambassador to Nigeria, and claims of sightings of headless corpses floating down the country's Sapele river.

Ms Booth represents Chief Humphrey Idisi and his companies, Lonestar Drilling Nigeria Ltd and Lonestar Overseas Limited. He is trying to persuade the court of appeal to set aside a high court judgment against him, obtained by a Ukrainian shipping firm without a trial.

In 1997 Lonestar bought two secondhand oil rigs in India, which the shipping firm, Gulf Azov, agreed to send to Sapele on its vessel the Dubai Valour. But when the ship arrived vital parts were missing from the oil rigs.

Crew members said the parts had been lost overboard in stormy weather, but an independent report by a Lloyd's investigator noted that no chains or locks were broken and that the ship's rail was found intact.

Lonestar got a Nigerian court order in August 1997 to hold the ship. After that, the facts are in dispute. Gulf Azov's lawyers claim there was an agreement to release the vessel after production of an insurer's undertaking. The court ordered the ship released, but Lonestar appealed.

When the boat attempted to leave in September 1997, it was seized and forced to return to Sapele. Mr Justice Langley, who gave judgment for Gulf Azov in the high court in London last November, said that, according to the written evidence from the shipowners, the crew were held in "appalling" conditions. Most had only been able to leave in July 1998, and the master and three other officers finally left in May 1999. The boat and remaining crew were finally released after Gulf Azov agreed to pay $3m (£2m) to Chief Idisi.

That agreement gave the English courts jurisdiction. The money was held in an account at Citibank in London to be transferred to Chief Idisi's London account when the ship left Nigeria. Gulf Azov and its insurers also sued Lonestar for $8m damages concerning the boat and wrongful arrest.

Gulf Azov claims that the boat's crew were starved of food and had to sell their watches for water, that armed guards from Lonestar prevented supplies being delivered to the vessel, and that Chief Idisi tried to strangle the Russian ambassador to Nigeria and the claimants' lawyers.

The shipowners also claim that headless corpses floated on the river Sapele, though they have not stated that Chief Idisi was responsible.

fields.headline: The love train
fields.standfirst: What on earth would Tolstoy have thought? Channel 4 have upped the raunch factor in Anna Karenina, his heavyweight morality tale. But it's a good move, reckons  Mark Lawson
fields.trailText: What on earth would Tolstoy have thought? Channel 4 have upped the raunch factor in Anna Karenina, his heavyweight morality tale. But it's a good move, reckons Mark Lawson
fields.body:
Tolstoy can't have known, when writing a novel back in the 1870s, that trains rushing into tunnels would become a cinematic euphemism for sex. But his book about a Moscow political wife's passion for a soldier - in which the speed of trains is a metaphor for the dangers and consequences of sexual passion - has consistently attracted film-makers. David Selznick cast Garbo in 1935, while Alexander Korda chose Vivien Leigh for the role in 1947. More recently, the writer-director Bernard Rose made a movie version with Sophie Marceau. Now Helen McCrory stars in a new four-part TV adaptation of Anna Karenina (Tuesday, 9pm, Channel 4).

Penelope Fitzgerald - a fine novelist who died last week - once expressed the hope that television would soon run out of great novels to adapt, and return literature to readers. But, although there are the inevitable losses - authorial tone and psychological complexity - Anna Karenina is, at the basic but crucial level of plot, the perfect book for TV.

Among the great novels, Anna Karenina is, action terms, the closest to soap opera. Not simply because the central themes of adultery and the destiny of a child are the main narrative motors of the daily serial, but because the tragic events develop from relationships within a family.

The book begins with a sister-in-law coming home to sort out a family crisis but in fact complicating the arrangements by stealing her sister's suitor. Tolstoy's plot has been unconsciously borrowed on numerous occasions by every soap opera from Coronation Street to Dallas. In EastEnders, the Mitchell brothers would frequently growl: "It's family." The Russian equivalent might be spoken at several points in this story.

The Russian landscape and the Russian language are both so capacious and distinctive that the risk with adaptations of Anna Karenina is that they will be visually over-nourished but (because of the difficulties of translation) verbally under-fed. With Poland standing in for Russia, this version (directed by David Blair) looks stunning - at a key moment, Karenin sees tracks in a rolling snowscape - but takes its biggest risks with the script.

Although Karenin speaks with a college pedantry which establishes his emotional coldness, writer Alan Cubitt generally uses brisk, idiomatic English of a kind often heard in Albert Square or Brookside Close: "I'm all ears"; "You should know there's talk". At the horse race where Anna's concern for Vronsky becomes public, a punter with a race card asks: "Who do you fancy?" Like Alan Bleasdale in his recent ITV Oliver Twist, Cubitt is keener on a script with kick than footnotes.

This approach will certainly draw audiences. Critics and academics will question how much of Tolstoy's sensibility survives. It's the third major infidelity novel to come to the screen in the last few months, along with BBC2's recent Madame Bovary and Neil Jordan's film of Greene's The End Of The Affair. The taking of lovers has always been fiction's most popular plot, but directors and producers are perhaps drawn to these classic triangles at the moment because of high levels of divorce and fragmentation of families.

But, although the central events invite contemporary identification, the original authorial attitudes may have dated - especially Tolstoy's idiosyncratic religious moralism. In the new visualisations of Madame Bovary, The End Of The Affair and now Anna Karenina, stories of social scandal - a woman risking status and reputation - have undergone at least some degree of feminist renovation. It's explicitly shown that orgasm is the reward (perhaps even the justification) for the risks Emma and Anna take. In interviews, Stephen Dillane, who plays Karenin, has stressed the dignity and decency of this apparently sinister man. But this isn't how it will play to most contemporary viewers. Karenin - like Dr Bovary in the recent TV version - seeds the tragedy by being bad in bed.

The danger of this emphasis is that it might trivialise the book, implying that the story might have become a novella with a happy ending if Anna had left a few copies of the Moscow edition of Cosmopolitan on her husband's bedside table. But it's a sensible decision for a peak-time audience in the year 2000, which will respond more to a central character who is a victim of erotic inequality than of social shame.

In fact, though heavily publicised (as was Madame Bovary) on its sexual content, this Anna Karenina is more explicit to the ear (the ecstatic breathlessness of lovers) than the eye. The first episode opens with a trick image of physicality - steamed windows, a naked male back rising and falling - which is revealed to be Levin (Douglas Henshall) exercising, in a routine somewhere between a work-out and a crucifixion, before pressing his suit with Kitty. Anna's first dangerous afternoon with Vronsky is shot in fragmented soft focus.

Channel 4 is a rare entrant to a classic serial field dominated by the BBC, and what's impressive is that you never feel that Lord Reith's grandson is itching uncomfortably in the old man's suit. The style feels freer, younger, moulded to the network. Advertisers should be happy with it, although it would perhaps be tactful not to approach Virgin Trains. If they'd held the St Petersburg-Moscow franchise in 1878, Anna and Vronsky might never have met.

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Swing Time
fields.body:
Swing Time

(George Stevens, 1936)

7pm, Carlton Cinema

Prime Astaire and Rogers, at their peak in one of their best movies together. OK, so it's from an era when "comedy timing" meant waiting five minutes for every joke to sink in, but who cares when every time Fred and Ginger take to the floor, you forget what the plot was anyway. From Fred's Mr Bojangles number, done in blackface but possibly his best-ever solo, to a finale on symmetrical staircases, filmed practically all in one take, not to mention songs like A Fine Romance and Just The Way You Look Tonight.

The Last Days Of Disco

(Whit Stillman, 1998)

11.50pm, Sky Premier

Final instalment, after Metropolitan and Barcelona, of Whit Stillman's yuppie-love trilogy. Like the others, it wafts gently around the lives of a group of upper-crust young Americans, dispensing satirical stabs of wit. The focus here is on Chloë Sevigny and an astonishingly adept Kate Beckinsale as the junior publishing editors hanging out at a posh disco with the local Harvard set. A perceptive and sophisticated comedy.

Body And Soul

(Robert Rossen, 1947)

12.10am, FilmFour

A champ among fight movies, with John Garfield giving a heavyweight performance as boxer Charley Davis. On the eve of his latest bout, a long flashback takes us through his hard-hitting career, up until the mob leans on him to throw the fight. Charley's made plenty of compromises - he's swapped sweetheart Lilli Palmer for floozy Hazel Brooks, and he drinks heavily; will he go all the way? Brilliantly shot and edited.

Working Girl

(Mike Nichols, 1988)

1.15am, Carlton Cinema

Witty, very deft romantic comedy with its heart firmly in the 30s. Melanie Griffith is the secretary trying to go places in the company, but is being exploited by imperious corporate woman, Sigourney Weaver. Harrison Ford is the other point in the triangle, shifting allegiance from Weaver to Griffith: but the women are very much the bosses. Kevin Wade's script sparkles and there's hilarious comic support from Joan Cusack's secretary.

webTitle: Work experience: The stars before they were famous

fields.headline: Work experience: The stars before they were famous
fields.standfirst: William H Macy in Homicide (David Mamet, 1991)
fields.trailText: William H Macy in Homicide (David Mamet, 1991)
fields.body:
Who? A latecomer to acting, Macy studied theatre with David Mamet in Chicago and the two later formed the St Nicholas Theatre group, as well as working together on a number of films (including this one). Macy's big TV break came playing the objectionable Dr Morganstern in ER, and his cinematic career took off after the Coen Brothers' Fargo. And, although it took him a while to get that far, he hasn't looked back since. Last seen in Paul Thomas Anderson's Magnolia and the underrated Mystery Men, Macy recently appeared on the West End stage in a revival of Mamet's American Buffalo and his next movie is State And Maine - a film by, you guessed it, David Mamet.

The role: Tim Sullivan, half of a bad cop/bad cop partnership with Bobby Gold (Joe Mantegna).

Best line: A typically understated Mamet classic. When Gold gets into an altercation with another officer, Sullivan steps in to defend him, exclaiming "Step into the alley? You fucking faggot, I'll kill your ass right here."

Cringe factor: Nil. Macy's worked with Mamet for so long, and on so many occasions, that he's totally comfortable with his performance, and therefore so is the viewer.

Other wannabes:

Ving Rhames; and Rebecca Pidgeon, another frequent Mamet collaborator (who just happens to be his wife).

Critical judgement:

Roger Ebert, in the Chicago Sun-Times, said Mamet's film "crackles with energy and life" and that he avoided "a cast of ageing teen idols". Instead, "These are men, middle-aged, harassed, run down."

Also not starring in: The Boy Who Loved Trolls in 1984, and as a "Radio Voice" in Woody Allen's Radio Days in 1987.

Homicide, Sky Cinema, Sunday May 14, 9pm.

fields.headline: A cheeky little vintage
fields.standfirst: Weekend TV
fields.trailText: "Ooh, I've never been inducted before," giggled Barbara Windsor towards the end of a painful yet fabulous hour in which celebrity friends (she has many) queued up to pay homage to "the nation's favourite bubbly blonde". For Barbara Windsor (real mates call her "Bar", by the way) is the first star to enter the BBC Hall Of Fame (Saturday BBC1), once a modest corridor beneath Broadcasting House, now part of the dreaded BBC Experience.
fields.body:
"Ooh, I've never been inducted before," giggled Barbara Windsor towards the end of a painful yet fabulous hour in which celebrity friends (she has many) queued up to pay homage to "the nation's favourite bubbly blonde". For Barbara Windsor (real mates call her "Bar", by the way) is the first star to enter the BBC Hall Of Fame (Saturday BBC1), once a modest corridor beneath Broadcasting House, now part of the dreaded BBC Experience.

You always know you're onto a Saturday night winner when the opening credits feature that sparkly special effect scintillating across the screen. And this was no disappointment. A hybrid of This Is Your Life and An Audience With..., BBC Hall Of Fame cherry-picked through the subject's illustrious career and avoided any personal stuff. Dale Winton was our rather breathless host, and next to Miss Windsor he seemed unusually subdued. There was no point in competing, really, for camper than "Bar" they do not get. The screens drew back and there she was, beaming in a heliotrope gown, her cheekbones and poitrine awash with glitter. The smile didn't leave her face all evening, prompting worries that she'd undergone the same surgical procedure that left Marlene Dietrich incapable of doing anything other than grinning in her later years - but a few clips from EastEnders was enough to reassure us that "Bar" does the whole gamut.

Well might she smile: the testimonials from her peers were heartfelt, if forced, and the collective warmth finally won out over the cheesiness of the proceedings. This is saying something, when one of the featured numbers was an updated rendition of early Windsor hit Fings Ain't Wot They Used T'Be - performed by Keith Chegwin and Vanessa Feltz. Dressed in camouflage and combats, they delivered a new set of lyrics (by Esther Rantzen, no less) that really nailed this so-called modern world we live in. "Once we danced to Abba," sang Cheggers, "but now - whoo! - respect the rapper." "Are you male or female?" asked Feltz, "I just can't tell by email." It was that up-to-date, there was even a joke about nouvelle cuisine.

It wasn't all fromage, though. Windsor's mentor, Joan Littlewood, made a rare public appearance to cheer on her favourite protégée, and there was real emotion in the reunion. "You look beautiful," said the frail director. "I've tried," choked the star. Like the diamond she is, Windsor shone brightly despite the awfulness of the setting.

It was impossible not to well up a little during Last Of The Summer Wine (Sunday BBC1). Most long-running series break up the tedium with the occasional wedding special; appropriately, Last Of The Summer Wine fielded a funeral special. The beloved Bill Owen died halfway through making the series, leaving writer Roy Clarke with the unenviable task of handling the character's death. He, and the surviving cast, managed with magnificent aplomb, sending Compo to meet his maker in a coffin garnished with Wellington boots. Peter Sallis (Clegg) and Frank Thornton (Truly) made a downbeat double-act of mourning, while the chorus of comic women (Kathy Staff, Thora Hird, Jean Alexander) was swelled by the addition of Liz Fraser as Reggie, Compo's secret girlfriend. Of course there were lapses into mushiness (not least the egregious version of the theme tune, with lyrics promising to "salute his summer wine"), but the laughs were never far behind. Compo, no doubt, would have wanted it that way.

The second episode of Hearts And Bones (Sunday) introduced BBC1 audiences to the delights of the gay club and even dallied with the idea of extra-marital lesbianism. For a series that could so easily have been all about people needing personal space and learning to respect each other, this is shaping up to be very tasty indeed. Last night, the spotlight was on downtrodden Michael (Andrew Scarborough), whose recent failure with women may be linked to a brief homosexual experience at college. Despite his protests, he found himself getting off with a willing young man on the dancefloor and, seconds later, speeding homewards in a cab. It came to naught, and the potential boyfriend's loss was the horny (female) neighbour's gain. Meanwhile, evil ballbreaker Amanda (Sarah Parish) claimed to have undergone a lightning conversion to women, but it was only a ruse to get Emma (Dervla Kirwan) out of trouble with her husband. At this rate there'll be knickers flying at random by week four. Can't wait.

For a series that could so easily have been all about people needing personal space and learning to respect each other, this is shaping up to be very tasty indeed. Last night, the spotlight was on downtrodden Michael (Andrew Scarborough), whose recent failure with women may be linked to a brief homosexual experience at college. Despite his protests, he found himself getting off with a willing young man on the dancefloor and, seconds later, speeding homewards in a cab. It came to naught, and the potential boyfriend's loss was the horny (female) neighbour's gain. Meanwhile, evil ballbreaker Amanda (Sarah Parish) claimed to have undergone a lightning conversion to women, but it was only a ruse to get Emma (Dervla Kirwan) out of trouble with her husband. At this rate there'll be knickers flying at random by week four. Can't wait.

fields.headline: Two of a kind
fields.trailText: A new comedy this week - Coupling (Friday, 9.30pm, BBC2) - serves as a kind of Vronsky to Anna Karenina: a fascinating companion-piece. It deals with the emotional and sexual etiquette of London in 2000.
fields.body:
A new comedy this week - Coupling (Friday, 9.30pm, BBC2) - serves as a kind of Vronsky to Anna Karenina: a fascinating companion-piece. It deals with the emotional and sexual etiquette of London in 2000.

Coupling is written by Steven Moffat, responsible for two previous sitcoms, which made their small number of viewers very happy: Joking Apart on BBC2 and Chalk on BBC1. The former was a kind of English Seinfield about a stand-up comedian with relationship problems. The latter was set in a large comprehensive school ruled by John Wells as insane headteacher Richard Nixon. Neither did the business their commissioners wished and their main effect was to showcase actors (Robert Bathurst, David Bamber) used to flashier effect elsewhere.

Moffat, though, has long seemed to me one of the most original TV writers and it's good that ratings-crazed television has persevered with him. His particular talent is for intricately plotted sexual farce. The best episodes of Joking Apart and Chalk manouevred their unwitting participants towards a climax of terrible sexual humiliation or violence.

Coupling centres on the attempts of Steve (Jack Davenport) to break up with (or "flush" in Moffat's vernacular) his possessive girlfriend Jane (Gina Bellman). This plot-line couples with another in which Patrick (Ben Miles) is being flushed by his free-spirited squeeze Susan (Sarah Alexander). In the first episode, the events which result in new loves and old arriving in the same restaurant are perfunctory by Moffat's previous standards, but there is one brilliantly filthy linguistic misunderstanding, and his feel for farce shows in one particular moment with an answering machine.

Coupling deserves to make its viewers come again.
