webTitle: Philippines hostages in plea to army

fields.headline: Philippines hostages in plea to army
fields.standfirst:
Sabah Ministry of Tourism Development
Institute for Counter-Terrorism: Abu Sayyaf
fields.trailText: The 21 hostages in the Philippines, who were allowed to speak to journalists at the weekend, have begged the Philippine government to pull back its troops from the hills.
fields.body:
The 21 hostages in the Philippines, who were allowed to speak to journalists at the weekend, have begged the Philippine government to pull back its troops from the hills.

The captives - including three Germans, two French, two South Africans, two Finns and one Lebanese - were snatched from a Malaysian diving resort two weeks ago by Muslim separatists and taken by boat to Jolo. They are being held in a cage by more than 100 guerrillas from the Abu Sayyaf group.

They are fighting for a separate Islamic state on Mindanao island. Guerrillas have been fighting the predominantly Catholic Philippines for 28 years.

The hostages urged the military to stop all operations near Talipao, on Jolo island, so that negotiations can begin. Every new battle means they are taken to another hideout, they said.

The rebels have clashed repeatedly with government soldiers since Tuesday, when the military encircled the guerrillas inside a tight cordon.

Yesterday, the rebels and troops traded mortar and automatic weapons fire, a government official said. A rebel and a soldier were killed.

"We are hoping for release in the coming week," said Risto Mirko Jahanen, one of the Finnish hostages, his face drawn. "If that will not take place, I think our mental state will be quite low."

Many of the captives appeared exhausted. They said they needed clothing, clean water and personal care items.

Several appealed for urgent efforts to free them because of the poor health of the German hostage Renate Wallert, 57, who they said had collapsed twice. Rebels refused a request for her to be allowed to leave with the journalists.

Abu Sayyaf is holding another group of Filipino hostages seized on the nearby island of Basilan. Fifteen of those hostages were rescued by the military last week and four were killed. About eight are still being held captive.

The rebels have rejected Manila's choice of negotiator, Nur Misuari - a former rebel who signed a peace treaty in 1996. They demanded to speak to the presidential executive secretary, Ronald Zamora, the ambassadors of all the hostages' countries and representatives of Libya, the UN and the Organisation of the Islamic Conference.

Javier Solana, a former secretary general of Nato and one of the European Union's highest ranking diplomats, plans to leave for Manila today to underline European concern for the safety of the hostages.

Other countries have offered their assistance, but Manila insists the kidnapping is a domestic issue.
AP

fields.headline: Cuban baseball player 'missing' from tour
fields.trailText: A member of a Cuban baseball team visiting the United States disappeared and possibly defected shortly after arriving at Minneapolis/St Paul international airport.
fields.body:
A member of a Cuban baseball team visiting the United States disappeared and possibly defected shortly after arriving at Minneapolis/St Paul international airport.

The team arrived on Saturday afternoon at the airport's Hubert Humphrey terminal, which is used by charter planes. After welcoming ceremonies at the airport, a member of the Cuban team apparently got into a car which then sped off.

The University of St Thomas which sponsored the trip has not released the name of the missing player.

Local newspapers yesterday identified him as second baseman Mario Miguel Chaoui Menendez-Cuesta.

"We are not calling it a defection because we don't know the circumstances. We're saying that it is an unauthorised departure from the team.

"He's considered a missing person at this time," the university's spokesman Doug Hennes told CBS radio.

The Cubans are in Minneapolis and St Paul for six days. About half the 60-strong group are players and coaches from the University of Havana and the Polytechnic Institute Jose Antonio Echeverria.

Both Cuban and local players said the man's disappearance took them completely by surprise. Mr Chaoui had been exchanging emails with American students but had never hinted at being unhappy with his life in Cuba.

Authorities were prepared for a possible defection. Mr Hennes said he had called the immigration and naturalisation service as soon as the player left the airport.

"We were told by the INS that if something like this happened, to get in touch with them right away and provide as much information as possible," Mr Hennes said.

The Cuban trip follows a visit by the St Thomas baseball team to Cuba in January. The two teams are scheduled to play each other tomorrow at the Metrodome in Minneapolis.

In a press release the university said the game would be only the second time since 1959 that Cuban and US university baseball teams had faced each other in the United States.

The Cuban team had a practice session scheduled for yesterday afternoon, and both the practice and tomorrow's game were to go ahead as scheduled.

webTitle: Sierra Leone deal shows limits of British power

fields.headline: Sierra Leone deal shows limits of British power
fields.standfirst: Background: Sierra Leone's troubled times
fields.trailText: For the foreign secretary, Robin Cook, the former British West African colony of Sierra Leone has been a problem almost from the word "go".
fields.body:
For the foreign secretary, Robin Cook, the former British West African colony of Sierra Leone has been a problem almost from the word "go".

In his first year in office, Mr Cook fought to survive a parliamentary inquiry into Sierra Leone sanctions-busting, with alleged Foreign Office connivance, by a British firm of mercenaries called Sandline.

The country's civil war has constantly - and embarrassingly - underscored the limits of British and Commonwealth ability to influence events.

Widespread atrocities, in particular gruesome mutilations and child sex slavery rackets undertaken by the Revolutionary United Front (RUF) rebels, caused public revulsion which Mr Cook was powerless to assuage.

The peace deal worked out with British help and signed in Togo last July was criticised for effectively pardoning the RUF leader, Foday Sankoh, and his cronies for their numerous crimes. Indeed, Mr Sankoh was rewarded with the post of vice-president.

Many felt the RUF leaders should have been brought before a war crimes tribunal, as in Rwanda after the 1994 genocide. But Britain went along with the fix.

Nor did the Togo accord make proper provision for the many refugees - some say as many as 3m people have been displaced - and RUF fighters would regularly hijack food aid convoys.

Africa watchers warned last year that Mr Sankoh would not honour the Togo deal. When the UN began to deploy last December, replac ing a Nigerian-led West African force, it rapidly became clear that the demobilisation camps at which RUF fighters were expected to disarm would be impossible to organise.

Disputes developed over UN "incursions" into RUF-held territory, especially the diamond-producing areas which hold the key to Sierra Leone's wealth - and its misery.

Now, as the UN peacekeeping mission appears to be losing control of the situation, and amid desperate appeals from Kofi Annan, the UN secretary general, Mr Cook and Geoff Hoon, the Defence Secretary, have decided to send in 700 British paratroopers. But, Whitehall was at pains to stress, the deployment is only to secure any evacuation of European Union, US and other foreign nationals.

Even though the predominantly African, Indian-led UN force is involved in direct combat with the RUF rebels, Britain's soldiers are under orders not to get involved.

There will be no East Timor-style peace enforcement or Kosovo-like talk of moral principle, whatever the possible toll in local civilian lives. For Mr Cook, who prides himself on a pro-active foreign policy, this all falls far short of glorious.

The US has also ordered its nationals to leave Sierra Leone and may send soldiers to secure Freetown airport. Like Britain, it argues that western intervention in an "African problem" could be counter-productive. But this disguises the fact that none of the permanent members of the UN security council, have vital strategic or commercial interests at stake.

This may be short-sighted. Washington is currently investing much effort in trying to put together a UN peacekeeping force for the Congo, where a war of even bigger dimensions is raging.

Richard Holbrooke, the US ambassador to the UN, is currently in Zambia, pursuing this end. Such an initiative could benefit several other countries caught up in the Congo conflict. But if the Sierra Leone mission collapses in ignominy, the chances of a Congo force will recede rapidly.

While Mr Cook clearly hopes to avoid further embarrassment over Sierra Leone, it is now highly possible that the British paras may get caught up in the fighting. They will hardly surrender.

And what will Mr Cook and Mr Hoon do then?

webTitle: 'Even when I'm singing my heart out, I'm not celebrating'

fields.headline: 'Even when I'm singing my heart out, I'm not celebrating'
fields.standfirst: Vera Bila, the world's most popular Romany singer, is coming to the Barbican. She talks to  Kate Connolly
fields.trailText: Vera Bila, the world's most popular Romany singer, is coming to the Barbican. She talks to Kate Connolly
fields.body:
When Vera Bila took to the stage for a fee-paying audience for the first time six years ago, she could not believe what happened. "They started clapping, and I hadn't even reached the microphone," says the corpulent Romany diva, one eyebrow raised while she indulges in an ice-cream that smudges her shiny skin. "I was convinced they wouldn't like me, and sometimes I still get that feeling."

Her fears are not altogether unfounded. She is, after all, a Gypsy singer who hails from a country where racist attacks on Gypsies (or Roma) have more than doubled in the past 10 years, and where the sum of Gypsy culture is widely viewed as pickpocketing and late-night carousing to deliberately starve their worker neighbours of sleep.

Since the Czech folk singer Zuzana Navarova discovered Vera Bila and her band Kale (which translates as Vera White and the Blacks), Bila has become the Czech Republic's most important musician abroad and possibly the world's most popular Romany singer. Her music, which she composes with the relatives and friends who make up the band, is a homespun melange of occidental pop and Latin sensuality. Add flamenco and the influence of the Beatles and the Bee Gees and you get the unique blend that Bila calls Roma Pop.

There is something anarchistic in the way occasionally off-key singing is an accepted part of the show, particularly if the band are out of sorts or not being paid as much as they think they deserve. And there is something distant and untouchable about Bila, who sings in a language few understand about a way of life few know. The music sums up the complex character of the wild and passionate Roma: when the music is effervescent and apparently overflowing with joie de vivre, the sparse lyrics lean in totally the opposite direction - mournful, tragic, melancholic. "My hurt is aching, my mother has passed away. I've been abandoned with my father," is a typical lament. Other perennial themes include begging, the value of bread, disappointment in love and imprisonment.

Her popularity has taken Bila to America and venues throughout Europe; on Saturday she will be playing the Barbican as part of the 1000 Year Journey festival. Following her appearance in Paris two years ago, the newspaper Le Matin cooed, "Ah, Vera - quelle présence!" In her own country and in Slovakia - her parents' homeland - she has been booed off the stage by skinheads more than once.

Like many Roma from her home village of Rokycany in the industrial heartland of Bohemia, Bila and her band have considered emigrating. "First our friends and relatives went to Canada, then to Britain, but we don't want to desert our people," she says. "And financially speaking, things are better for us than for most, so we'd be stupid to leave."

Janek Jaros, managing director of BMG records in Prague, which signed Bila and Kale to make the album Rom Pop in 1995, says her audience in the Czech Republic consists only of those open-minded enough to listen to Gypsy music. "Her relationship with the Czech public is very much tinted with this racist stuff."

According to Jaros, Bila goes down best with foreign companies based in Prague, who see it as hip to hire the Romany band for their corporate events. "I can't imagine an advertising party in Prague where Vera Bila was not invited to play," Jaros says. "It shows that the company is different."

It is tempting to assume that the rise of Bila and Kale has sent a message of encouragement to other would-be Romany bands, or to any Romanies, who might feel that they too have a chance to make it "out there" in a hostile world. Jaros thinks it may have had the opposite effect. "As soon as we signed them there was such a lot of jealousy. Demo tapes from other Romany groups started pouring in with notes saying, 'Why the hell did you sign a contract with them? We're much better.' "

A documentary film called Black and White in Colour, which offers a witty, affectionate portrait of Bila, will also be screened at the Barbican. Directed by Mira Erdevicki-Charap, the film deals with Romanies as individuals, rather than as part of the "Romany problem" or as an example of "otherness".

Erdevicki describes coming across Bila performing in a Prague nightclub. "This huge woman came on to the stage and she had the effect of a goddess." The film, she says, is a portrayal of life between two camps and a people who try to negotiate how they might integrate into one culture while preserving their own identity. "It tries to discover how far one can compromise or adapt and how far one should remain true to one's origins, traditions, character and rituals."

Bila, who spends as much time in the film eating as she does singing her haunting ballads, delivers her tristful philosophy between takes. "A good word is worth more than bread - not that I hear one very often. So I stay at home with my family and my musicians and I take refuge in a separate inner life, although I'm neither a Gypsy or a white woman. I'm simply myself and I am alone."

The documentary delights in the singer's quirks. She candidly explains how she trims her husband's toenails with her teeth as a sign of her affection. When he administers cream to the warts on her back, she purrs: "This is divine love-making." And part of her search for freedom through music, we learn, includes performing barefoot, "even in winter".

Cliches about Roma also come to the fore. When the so-called Queen of Romany arrives with her band in Paris, they picnic at the base of the Eiffel Tower and marvel at its grandeur. What interests them is not the structure's aesthetic appeal but the amount of scrap metal it represents. "We could make a fortune out of that," says one band member. She is amazed when she sees couples of mixed ethnic backgrounds, a sight rarely to be seen back home.

Bila's life is not an easy one. She was threatened with prison after the social security office discovered she was claiming dole as well as performing. Her son has been jailed for robbery. And sometimes she feels people regard her as an exotic animal. During her Parisian experience one French newspaper described her as "a midget sumo wrestler with a beautiful voice for singing the blues".

When even music does not help her overcome her melancholy, Bila spends all her earnings in the slot machines of Rokycany's gambling hall. She has pawned her stereo system 17 times so she could cover her debts.

And still she says she remains misunderstood, even among her band members. "Even when I'm singing my heart out I'm not celebrating," she says. "What's there to celebrate when Gypsies die earlier than other people? Sometimes when I'm performing the boys think the tears on my cheeks are because I'm sweating. Actually I'm crying my eyes out."

Black and White in Colour is at the Barbican Screen, London EC2, on Saturday afternoon. Vera Bila plays the Barbican Hall that evening. Box office: 020-7638 8891.

It is tempting to assume that the rise of Bila and Kale has sent a message of encouragement to other would-be Romany bands, or to any Romanies, who might feel that they too have a chance to make it "out there" in a hostile world. Jaros thinks it may have had the opposite effect. "As soon as we signed them there was such a lot of jealousy. Demo tapes from other Romany groups started pouring in with notes saying, 'Why the hell did you sign a contract with them? We're much better.' " A documentary film called Black and White in Colour, which offers a witty, affectionate portrait of Bila, will also be screened at the Barbican. Directed by Mira Erdevicki-Charap, the film deals with Romanies as individuals, rather than as part of the "Romany problem" or as an example of "otherness". Erdevicki describes coming across Bila performing in a Prague nightclub. "This huge woman came on to the stage and she had the effect of a goddess." The film, she says, is a portrayal of life between two camps and a people who try to negotiate how they might integrate into one culture while preserving their own identity. "It tries to discover how far one can compromise or adapt and how far one should remain true to one's origins, traditions, character and rituals." Bila, who spends as much time in the film eating as she does singing her haunting ballads, delivers her tristful philosophy between takes. "A good word is worth more than bread - not that I hear one very often. So I stay at home with my family and my musicians and I take refuge in a separate inner life, although I'm neither a Gypsy or a white woman. I'm simply myself and I am alone." The documentary delights in the singer's quirks. She candidly explains how she trims her husband's toenails with her teeth as a sign of her affection. When he administers cream to the warts on her back, she purrs: "This is divine love-making." And part of her search for freedom through music, we learn, includes performing barefoot, "even in winter". Cliches about Roma also come to the fore. When the so-called Queen of Romany arrives with her band in Paris, they picnic at the base of the Eiffel Tower and marvel at its grandeur. What interests them is not the structure's aesthetic appeal but the amount of scrap metal it represents. "We could make a fortune out of that," says one band member. She is amazed when she sees couples of mixed ethnic backgrounds, a sight rarely to be seen back home. Bila's life is not an easy one. She was threatened with prison after the social security office discovered she was claiming dole as well as performing. Her son has been jailed for robbery. And sometimes she feels people regard her as an exotic animal. During her Parisian experience one French newspaper described her as "a midget sumo wrestler with a beautiful voice for singing the blues". When even music does not help her overcome her melancholy, Bila spends all her earnings in the slot machines of Rokycany's gambling hall. She has pawned her stereo system 17 times so she could cover her debts. And still she says she remains misunderstood, even among her band members. "Even when I'm singing my heart out I'm not celebrating," she says. "What's there to celebrate when Gypsies die earlier than other people? Sometimes when I'm performing the boys think the tears on my cheeks are because I'm sweating. Actually I'm crying my eyes out." Black and White in Colour is at the Barbican Screen, London EC2, on Saturday afternoon. Vera Bila plays the Barbican Hall that evening. Box office: 020-7638 8891.

fields.headline: A cosmic cathedral on 81st Street
fields.standfirst: Jonathan Glancey gets lost in space at New York's amazing new hi-tech planetarium, the Rose Centre
fields.trailText: Jonathan Glancey gets lost in space at New York's amazing new hi-tech planetarium, the Rose Centre
fields.body:
Great machines drive great cities, yet we tend to hide them away, as if embarrassed by what we take to be their unsightliness or offended by their steely organisms. But when they do make their presence known, how they invigorate streets and skylines. The Eiffel Tower. The Pompidou Centre. Lloyd's of London. Trams. Chicago's "L", the elevated railroad that rattles like some gigantic model train set around the heart of the windy city. Docks with their cranes and gantries. Power stations. Ocean-going ships berthed beside midtown skyscrapers. The London Eye.

All these happily intrusive designs and structures are heroic things. All catch the eye and stir the soul. Most are despised by the disgusteds of Tunbridge Wells, who prefer a nice bit of neo-geo brickwork, an executive cul-de-sac or a postmodern shopping arcade with split pediments, herringbone brick-tiled floors and brass-veneered handrails.

One of the most unexpected of new city machines is the mellifluously named Frederick Phineas and Sandra Priest Rose Centre for Earth and Space at the American Museum of Natural History in New York. The suddenness, the crispness of this machine for exploring the stars contrast sharply with its lugubrious appellation. The Rose Centre (for short) is a wonderful surprise, launching out of 81st St where it meets Central Park West, a few blocks north of the Addams Family-style Dakota Building where John Lennon died. It stands, foursquare, a box of white-painted steel and glass encasing what appears to be a planet. It lights up spectacularly at night. It is a superb foil to the heavy-handed turn-of-the-century architecture of the existing museum and to the bravura apartment blocks that line these gung-ho streets and imposing avenues. Queues form around this, New York's newest museum, like the rings around some mysterious planet.

The Rose Centre is the first challenging and adventurous new building New York has seen in far too long. Over the past 20 years the city that gave the world the Empire State and Chrysler buildings and the Rockefeller Centre seems to have given up the architectural ghost. Play it safe. Keep it low and dull (I mean "contextual"). And yet if any city has benefited from structural heroism, it is New York. The $210m Rose Centre is a brave building, yet compared with, say, Lloyd's or the Pompidou Centre, it is neat and well mannered, an 87ft diameter sphere, a hi-tech planetarium within a 120ft glass cube.

The architects are the New York-based Polshek Partnership, currently working on the Santa Fe Opera in New Mexico and the William Jefferson Clinton Presidential Library in Little Rock, Arkansas. They have drawn on sources old and new, from such heroic unbuilt projects as Etienne-Louis Boullee's cenotaph to Newton, designed late in the 18th century, through the great Perisphere built for the 1939 New York World's Fair, to the work of the hi-tech architects of today: Norman Foster, Richard Rogers, Jean Nouvel and Nicholas Grimshaw are all echoed, whether as faintly as a distant star or as clearly as a space shuttle shooting heavenwards.

The transparency of the building, says James Stewart Polshek, "makes a clear statement about the accessibility of scientific inquiry and our faith in the future. What I had originally conceived of as an iconic scientific tool evolved into a 'cosmic cathedral', an intensely memorable spatial experience that is intended to awe and inspire visitors and to expand their understanding of the wonders of our universe."

Polshek's cosmic cathedral is a steel-framed glazed box rising from a granite base. It is entered through a trio of swivelling glass doors and is immediately bright, airy and well planned. The sphere at its centre is supported by tubes that double up as walkways, entrances and exits. Floors are made to sparkle like starscapes. A 17ft-diameter model of Saturn appears to orbit the great sphere. Despite the surrounding displays, visitors want to get inside the planetarium sphere as soon as they are able. This is a simple architectural statement, yet quite breathtaking.

It is even more impressive by night, when the sphere appears to float in darkness. During the day, its mysteries are best experienced inside the darkness of the planetarium sphere. The shows offer a 3D trip through space and time into the origins (as far as anyone knows) of the universe. The clever thing about the Rose Center is that, although it is a sensational experience in its own right, it is not cut off from the rest of the museum. It acts, according to its architects, as a "critical bridge for the museum" by linking "immersive environments about the nature of the universe and of our planet" to the museum's 42 permanent exhibition halls, which explore the diversity and history of life on Earth and human culture. Nevertheless, its striking architecture and design have clearly made the new wing of the museum the tail that wags the dog star of this 131-year-old, 20-acre institution.

For one thing, the Rose Centre is big - a quarter of the size of the existing museum. For a second and third, the shows presented in the top and bottom halves of the planetarium or Hayden Sphere are unforgettable. On top is Passport to the Universe, narrated by Tom Hanks; down below is Big Bang, with Jodie Foster doing the honours. Both offer what must be the most convincing journeys through the universe yet taken by earthbound mortals. The virtual universe experienced here is based on astronomical observations and computer models of our galaxy from Nasa, including the Hubble space telescope. It even amazes New York's streetwise, gum-chewing lines of schoolkids who snake through the great arched granite entrance from a new park on 81st St and wind their way up the ramps to the Hayden Sphere.

On their way they can divert through permanent installations outside the sphere that explain how stars are born, what a black hole is and our place in the cosmos. By and large these are well done, although most children under about 60 seem to have the attention span of absent-minded gnats: they press the buttons and move on before they have to absorb any knowledge.

Midway through Passport to the Universe, a disembodied Tom Hanks urges the audience to take a deep breath. "Really," he says. "Everybody do it. Every atom of oxygen you just inhaled was made deep inside a star. The carbon in our muscles, the calcium in our bones, the iron in our blood - in fact, all the heavy elements - were cooked in the heart of stars. As Carl Sagan said, 'We are starstuff'." Just like the Rose Centre.

fields.headline: Demon's advocates
fields.trailText: Last week, the United States supreme court ruled, to the jubilation of American internet service providers, that they could not be held legally responsible for libels which appeared on their sites.
fields.body:
Last week, the United States supreme court ruled, to the jubilation of American internet service providers, that they could not be held legally responsible for libels which appeared on their sites. A few weeks before that, in England, the service provider Demon paid out £15,000 plus legal costs to lecturer and physicist Laurence Godfrey for a libel on one of Demon's bulletin boards, following a high court judge's ruling last year to the effect that Demon was a "publisher" of the offending material and therefore could be legally responsible. The divergence between the US approach - with its far greater emphasis on freedom of expression - and the English, usually anxious to protect individual reputations, is interesting.

But what I'm more concerned is that neither result seems at all satisfactory. Under the American rationale - which treats the internet a bit like a phone line, as a mere transmitter but not a publisher - anyone, anywhere will be able to put anything on the net (not just libel but, presumably, pornography as well) and the service provider can sit back secure in its immunity. But the English solution has its drawbacks too.

It's based on the duty of the service provider to act once an alleged libel has been drawn to its attention and it's been asked to remove it. If it doesn't - as Demon didn't in the Godfrey case - it becomes liable. The consequence of that approach is that the service provider, to save itself the trouble of looking into the merits of every request for removal, will simply accede to all of them. I can't see AOL or whoever having a team of lawyers to assess whether or not the alleged libel has any validity. So it will be open to anyone who doesn't like what's being said about him or her to write a simple letter of warning to the service provider - maybe even a lawyer's phone call will be enough - knowing that the offending stuff will be removed.

In the old days there was a nasty device called the gagging writ, which stopped all unfavourable mention of the complaining party once legal proceedings had been started (Robert Maxwell was a great exponent of it), but the modern internet version is worse, because it is so much easier. You don't even need to issue any formal proceedings, just make the call or send the letter. I'm not blaming the provider for its meek attitude - why should they spend large sums of money investigating every idiotic demand so as to weed out the chancers from the genuinely libelled? But anecdotes are accumulating which make me uneasy. For instance, Kamlesh Bahl, the former Law Society vice-president, opened a website to put her side of the controversy which had led to her resignation. Someone - I don't know who - complained that it contained defamatory material. I don't know whether it did or not but its removal is not good news for freedom of speech.

While I'm on the oddities of libel, a Manchester law firm, Rowe and Cohen, has achieved what I think is a British legal first - an apology on a billboard. They managed this because the original libel was also on a billboard - promoting the Cumbrian News and Star by reprinting a front page which happened to have a large headline libelling the local MP, David MacLean. The newspaper ran an apology in its own pages, but agreed also to advertise on billboards: "Apology to MP MacLean over a report on drugs test".

The excellent appointment of Sir Richard Scott as a law lord makes the cultural-geographical balance of the highest court even more extraordinary. He too, has South African roots, which means that, with Lords Steyn and Hoffmann, a quarter of the court originates from a country which doesn't even have the same system of law as the House of Lords. That's a remarkable proportion. Only six - half - of the law lords are now English, two are Scottish and one is from Northern Ireland. Scott is admittedly not quite as South African as Hoffmann and Steyn. He has no long family history in the country, but his early life was there, including school and university, so he definitely qualifies, even if, unlike the other two, he's lost his accent.

Legal Blunders (Robinson Publishers), by Geoff Tibbals, is one of those entertaining compilations of things that go wrong in the law, risible incompetence, cock-ups etc, although this one is better than most because it deals also with some of the more serious miscarriages of justice. Helena Kennedy QC writes an introduction, to which I am indebted for the following. A Scottish sheriff, on sentencing the defendant: "Although I find you a fecund liar, I will not on this occasion sentence you to prison.". Defendant: "Thank you, your Honour, you're a fecund good judge."

webTitle: The new PM  Reformer tarnished by links with tycoon

fields.headline: The new PM  Reformer tarnished by links with tycoon
fields.standfirst: Russia: special report
fields.trailText: In naming Mikhail Kasyanov as his prime minister, Vladimir Putin yesterday sent out signals that will reassure western officials who know the 42-year-old fluent English speaker as a Russian reformer.
fields.body:
In naming Mikhail Kasyanov as his prime minister, Vladimir Putin yesterday sent out signals that will reassure western officials who know the 42-year-old fluent English speaker as a Russian reformer.

But the nomination, while expected, disappointed those who had hoped Mr Putin would quickly break with the discredited cronyism of the Yeltsin regime.

Mr Kasyanov, a deputy prime minister in the outgoing government, is urbane, polished, and managerial. An economist by training, his early career was spent in Gosplan, the Soviet central planning monolith.

He was a senior finance official under Boris Yeltsin and was identified with the coterie around Boris Berezovsky, whose business empire extends from oil and aluminium to newspapers and television, and who wielded disproportionate influence under Mr Yeltsin's presidency.

Mr Kasyanov rose to become finance minister in the Putin cabinet, and when Mr Putin became acting president in the new year he was made first deputy prime minister, running the government.

The technocrat and manager looks poised to spearhead a quartet of ambitious, young economists playing a central role in Mr Putin's Russia - Andrei Illarionov, a radical free marketeer advising the president on the economy, Alexei Kudrin, a long-time colleague of Mr Putin from St Petersburg who is tipped to be the new finance minister, and German Gref, another St Petersburg pal who is drafting Mr Putin's 10- year development plan and who is expected to take the economics portfolio. All four are 35-45 year olds and are decidedly pro-western.

Mr Kasyanov has impressed western officials in his handling of Russia's foreign debt negotiations, and he will lead a campaign for a resumption of IMF lending to Russia.

In February he renegotiated the terms of Russia's commercial debt to western banks, getting more than one-third of it written off.

But his association with Mr Berezovsky undermines the president's appeal to Russians as Mr Clean.

fields.headline: Answering back
fields.standfirst: In 1969, Nova magazine asked 100 women what bothered them most about living in Britain. Thirty years on, in the relaunch issue, they've done it again and asked Guardian women's editor  Libby Brooks to analyse the results
fields.trailText: In 1969, Nova magazine asked 100 women what bothered them most about living in Britain. Thirty years on, in the relaunch issue, they've done it again and asked Guardian women's editor  Libby Brooks to analyse the results
fields.body:
What's she like, this woman of Britain? How does she live, what does she believe in, who does she love? In 1969, cutting-edge style magazine Nova interviewed 100 women - all achievers in their chosen field and often the first of their gender to do so - about the issues that intimately concerned them as women. What bothered them about Britain: abortion, the pill, education, marriage? The results provided a snapshot of a generation awakening, brought up in the feminine tradition but gradually, gladly, articulating a new language of sexual agency, economic choice and social alternatives.

Fast-forward across three decades that have witnessed the most significant shifts in women's status of the last century, to 100 different women and five different issues. What bothers us about Britain today: sex, drugs, race, politics, success?

There are inevitable differences. The explosion of opportunity has made some of us, but not all, more liberal in outlook, more left-leaning in our politics. The persistence of certain fundamental inequalities has left some bleak, but most of us wiser in the fight. We are proud to bring to our workplace, our lover, our family, the distinctive life experience of being born female; we easily word "I want", "I believe", "I desire".

Many of the women featured on these pages have reaped the benefits of the practical feminism espoused by those original Nova pioneers. As girls, their educational needs were taken seriously and they were encouraged to consider college and career. In relationships, they enjoyed free access to abortion and contraception. In work, equality of salary and opportunity were legislated for. Many of these women entered the workplace expecting it to be equal. The spectre of the lipsticky 80s power-bitch is all but excised: it's no longer about joining the boys' club and it's not a competition. But the pay gap still has plenty spitting blood, while for many it is becoming a mother, rather than being a woman, that proves the flashpoint for gender injustice.

"What is it that still locks women out of power?" writer Natasha Walter says. "I dream of living in a country where women could reach freely for power and men would take an equal share in domestic and caring work."

But beyond the structural inequalities that militate against working mothers, there is another debate about the nature of power itself. There's still concern among older women about "man in a frock" syndrome, but according to Shirley Conran (who was also interviewed in 1969), women just won't accept that power is important. "Women still tend to think power is a nasty, masculine, unfeminine thing and they don't need it. Whereas power is what was called in the nursery getting your own way - and every woman wants that."

"Many women don't want to pay the price of ambition," argues Marjorie Wallace, chief executive of Sane. "They don't want to lead such a one-dimensional life. Relationships count more for them. And for others it's that very emotional literacy that makes women an asset in the workplace."

"In today's world, the qualities that drive business success are classically feminine: nurturing, gut instinct, people skills. It's part of the feminisation of the workplace," says Tamara Ingram, chief executive of Saatchi.

Even so, a residue of old school prejudice remains. "I hate it when people think a woman's got to the top because she's somehow not a real woman," says boxer Jane Couch. "If you're a woman in a position of power, they question your sexuality. People should say: are you doing the job properly? If you are, whether you are a man or a woman isn't relevant."

Given the strength of feeling on working motherhood, it's only fair that the government's childcare policy gets a tick from these women. That's unlike the Dome, or the palaver over London's mayor, which are taken as further evidence of the Blairite preference for style over content.

Tony himself, unsurprisingly, is all things to all women. "A hypnotising hologram" (Rowan Pelling, editor of the Erotic Review), "a leader with a capital L" (Shirley Conran), "a cartoon character" (art dealer Sadie Coles), "a cool fool in charge of a confederacy of dunces"(Julie Burchill).

Responses on the issue of racism are inevitably dictated by theory and practice. Although the majority of white women share a sense that the situation is improving, as Martha Lane Fox neatly puts it: "Is it better than it was? Yes, I would think so. But then I'm a white middle-class girl, sitting in my white middle-class world." Insitutional racism extends far beyond the Metropolitan Police, argues Shaks Ghosh, chief executive of Crisis. "A lot of our systems and ways of dealing with people in society are institutionally racist. Those racist tendencies are built into the system."

Several black women point out a difference in means of expression rather than overall attitude. "People say it's not as bad as it used to be, but I think it is," says DJ Smokin' Jo. "It's just that it's more undercover. If I go into certain shops, I still get looks or I'm followed around by security."

For Doreen Lawrence, it is also a question of class. "Racism exists in all areas of the population but the working-class are more open about it. Among the middle-class, that's where you have the covert racism, in the institutions, universities and schools."

If there is one voice notably absent it's that of the otherwise ubiquitous Bridget Jones. Nor is the consensus that women are better at being single some desperately upbeat response to meals-for-one hell - just a general, genuine joy at being born dick-less.

"Women are pragmatic - children make us like that," says journalist Maggie O'Kane. "How many women have a midlife crisis? They're too busy." MP Claire Ward agrees. "Women seem to be able to juggle a lot more than men and deal with work and home life better."

Many younger women refer to the yet-to-be-concluded battle for sexual territory brought on by their increasing independence. "I see a lot of women who would happily go through life without a partner," observes cellist Natalie Clein. "Women ask much more of a relationship than they did."

When it comes to the drugs debate, these women avoid the slippery slope hysteria that effortlessly conflates the first spliff with the final hit. "It's rubbish that there's no distinction made between different drugs," says Heather Finlay, managing director of Sainted PR. "I have friends who use spliff but wouldn't touch anything else. And what about alcohol and tobacco? They're legal - and the country's biggest killers."

Legalisation of cannabis and reform of drugs classifications are high on these women's agenda; hypocrisy and moral panic are off. "The government knows exactly what it is," argues Dawn Shadforth, director of Ridley Scott Associates. "Something you can't have is desirable. Keep them partying like hell at weekends, keep them depressed during the week and keep them quiet."

Most crucially, there is recognition that drug culture is neither homogenous nor shock-horror. As Rowan Pelling puts it: "There is the adventuring, exploring spirit that made Britain great. Most drug experimentation is exactly that: a little voyage of discovery. British youth dress more interestingly, the pop music is better, the art is better, because they're more open to new ideas. That's something to be proud of."

So what bothers us most about life in Britain today? Where to begin: crime, lack of community, high prices, low standards, money mania ... Inequality, says Helena Kennedy QC: "I am still horrified that we have such disparity between rich and poor." The wastage of people, offers Polly Teale of Shared Experience Theatre: "The huge numbers who fall by the wayside, who never get the chance to fulfil their potential. We need to put massive resources into education.'

For Anna McNamara, co-founder of The Big Issue in the North, it's the class structure. "For centuries, it has been driving out individuals who want to get on and do things. It keeps everyone in their place. You're allowed individuality, but only within the boundaries of your entitlement."

From NHS waiting lists to the price of eggs, the responses are as individual as the women. But you can be damn sure that what bothers them most is not the circumference of their thighs. What's she like, this woman of Britain? She's come a long way, baby. Don't look back, don't look down. This article appears in the current issue of Nova magazine.

fields.headline: What's in a name?
fields.trailText: We are having problems remembering names. Last week, my friend Betty forgot someone's name at a party. She knew the whole of this woman's life, inside out, but the name had disappeared. It was hovering somewhere at the back of the welter of thoughts in her head and she could not get it up on screen.
fields.body:
We are having problems remembering names. Last week, my friend Betty forgot someone's name at a party. She knew the whole of this woman's life, inside out, but the name had disappeared. It was hovering somewhere at the back of the welter of thoughts in her head and she could not get it up on screen.

"What do your stepchildren call you?" asked Betty cleverly and out came the name. But that was a close shave. Luckily, with old friends, you can often dispense with names altogether. Last week, Betty and her chum had a whole conversation with no names at all.

"You know whatshisname who went to your thingumagig?"

"I think so. He was with that whatshername from you-know. With the hair."

"That's right. Well, he's moving in with that woman with the funny wotsit."

Luckily they both understood perfectly and could translate round each other's memory impediment. It is a relief if the person you're trying to speak to can fish your lost words out of the mist and you can tell they have, without either of you having to say anything properly.

Rosemary and I find it helps if we make up our own names for people. They are much easier to remember. We have Mr Wobbly Head, Big-bum, Pork Chop, Mrs Dog Strangler, Floppy Fingers, Mr and Mrs Tadpole, Ms Pissface and the Bobble-hats. But after a while we forget the real names, so I am in trouble if I bump into one of them out shopping and need to introduce him/her to my mother.

Sometimes the names pop up on demand, but some days we can't dredge them up for love nor money and it's helpful to know what sort of a day you're in for, so Betty has started setting herself a little test. Every morning, as soon as she wakes up, she tries to remember the names Hugh Grant and Elizabeth Hurley. If she can remember them both (and she usually can't), she knows she'll be able to have a proper academic conversation during the day.

But tonight we don't need to bother with that. We're going to see a film about whatsherface who got a job as a thingy, found out all that stuff and won zillions for hundreds of people in you-know-what. D'you know the one?

webTitle: Historic milestone for Russia as Putin sworn in

fields.headline: Historic milestone for Russia as Putin sworn in
fields.standfirst:
New president pledges honesty and openness as power passes peacefully at modest but glittering inauguration

Russia: special report
fields.trailText: Vladimir Putin was sworn in as modern Russia's second president yesterday at a dazzling ceremony in the Kremlin which marked the first time the country has seen power transferred peacefully and democratically.
fields.body:
Vladimir Putin was sworn in as modern Russia's second president yesterday at a dazzling ceremony in the Kremlin which marked the first time the country has seen power transferred peacefully and democratically.

Pledging that honesty, clarity and openness would be the signal features of his leadership, Mr Putin swiftly got down to business by naming Mikhail Kasyanov, a technocrat and financial expert, as his new prime minister. The nomination will go to the parliament for endorsement this week.

A military band struck up the national anthem, Russia's flag was raised over the Kremlin, and salvoes from a 30-gun presidential salute resonated across the Moscow river as Mr Putin, at 47 the youngest leader since Stalin, was formally sworn in as head of state in the sumptuous surroundings of the Kremlin's St Andrew's hall.

MPs, foreign ambassadors, members of the supreme court, religious leaders, friends and dignitaries looked on as Mr Putin, laying his right hand on a red leather-bound copy of the constitution, vowed to defend the civil and human rights of all citizens and protect the sovereignty, independence and territorial integrity of Russia.

To hundreds of thousands of scarred and dispossessed Chechens, his words about defending human rights ring hollow, though he sees the Chechen war as redeeming his pledge on Russia's territorial integrity.

Russian warplanes and troops continued to pummel the southern Chechen highlands yesterday as the Kremlin cupolas gleamed in the bright spring sunshine that accompanied the inauguration.

Russia's first president, Boris Yeltsin, and the Soviet Union's last leader, Mikhail Gorbachev, watched as Mr Putin delivered an inclusive, healing message in an eight-minute speech, promising to work "openly and honestly" on "clear" policies, although he has yet to provide even the barest of details about his programme for government.

In a short and shaky speech before the inauguration, Mr Yeltsin took the credit for establishing a political system where Mr Putin was succeeding into office without any "upheavals, putsches or revolutions".

"That is possible only in a free country, in a country which is no longer afraid of others and of itself," Mr Yeltsin said in one of the rare public appearances he has made since dramatically resigning on New Year's Eve.

Mr Putin also asserted that yesterday's spectacular, albeit brief and modest ceremony, marked a constitutional and political milestone.

"The transfer of power is always a test of the constitutional system, a test of its strength," Mr Putin said. "We have passed this test with dignity.

"We have proved that Russia is becoming a truly modern democratic state. The peaceful succession of power is the cru cial element of the political stability of which we have dreamed."

Mr Putin's new cabinet line-up will be closely scrutinised for clues about Russia's policy direction. While espousing liberal pro-market economic policies and a crackdown on crime and corruption, the president, a canny pragmatist and gradualist, is not expected to launch any substantive or dramatic policy departures, but move slowly while consolidating his power.

His government will concentrate on economic management, while he is expected to reinforce and centralise power in the Kremlin, relying on old colleagues from his former 16-year career in the KGB.

"Putin is the stabiliser. He is taking an inventory. His mandate is to put things in order," said Liliya Shevtsova, a political analyst at the Carnegie centre in Moscow.

The 19th century military tunics, the goosestepping, the brass bands and the imperial splendour of the Kremlin all suggested that the inauguration ceremony was suffused with tradition.

But Russia's flawed democracy is only a decade old and yesterday's state rites were carefully planned almost from scratch.

The entire scenario was painstakingly orchestrated to contrast with Mr Yeltsin's inauguration in 1996. While Mr Yeltsin was almost too ill to take part in 1996, Mr Putin was shown striding purposefully up a long staircase and through three Kremlin halls.

Unlike 1996, Patriarch Aleksy II, the head of the Russian Orthodox Church, was not on the podium, underlining the separation of church and state.

In a calculated snub in 1996 Mr Gorbachev was not invited, whereas Mr Putin emphasised continuity and consensus yesterday by having the ex-Russian and ex-Soviet leaders present.

And while grand, the ceremony was brief, the speeches minimised to buttress the message that Mr Putin is a man of action, but of few words.

"The establishment of a democratic state is still far from completion," Mr Putin declared. "I can assure you that in my work I will be guided only by the interests of the state.

"There may well be mistakes, but I can promise you, and do promise you, that I will work openly and honestly."

fields.headline: Heartland blues
fields.standfirst:
Labour may be ahead in the opinion polls, but last week's vote shows it should stop taking victory in the next general election for granted

New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Another mid-term electoral defeat that confirms that Tony Blair is still on course for a second term. That has been the near universal reaction to last Thursday's election results. And it is a dangerous myth.
fields.body:
Another mid-term electoral defeat that confirms that Tony Blair is still on course for a second term. That has been the near universal reaction to last Thursday's election results. And it is a dangerous myth.

It is not that the results show that William Hague is unstoppably on his way towards Downing Street. But they suggest that Labour has work to do if it is to be sure of winning an adequate Commons majority at the next general election.

How has the myth been perpetuated? In part it comes from the observation that voters do not vote the same way in local contests as they would in a general election. Labour consistently underperforms in local elections. So, Labour might be at just 29% in the local count but (it is said) the party can be confident of doing a lot better in a general election.

Previous evidence suggests we can add 10% to Labour's projected share - but it does not indicate that we can safely add the 20% needed to make up the gap between Labour's performance on Thursday and its current opinion poll standing. A plausible reading of Thursday's elections is that Labour's Westminster standing is around 40% - not 50%. And 40% may not be enough to secure an adequate majority.

The second element of the myth is derived from the result in Romsey. Do not worry, it says, about Labour's poor performance in the district elections or London. Voters in Romsey showed Labour and Liberal Democrat supporters are still willing to vote tactically against the Tories. Thus, though the Tory share of the vote fell by just 4%, a 15% slump in the third-placed Labour vote carried the Lib Dems to victory.

The trouble is, the result in Romsey was wholly atypical of what was happening on Thursday. In the rest of the country, the Lib Dem challenge to the Tories was weakening, not strengthening. As the table shows, in local election wards that Labour was defending, the Lib Dem vote rose on average by nearly 6% while it fell on average by 4% where the Tories were defending. A similar pattern can be seen in the London assembly results.

Far from ganging up on the Tories, voters in Tory-held wards were, if anything, reverting to type. In those Tory wards where the Lib Dem were starting off second, the Lib Dem vote was in fact down 8%, while Labour's losses were less than half what they were across the country as a whole. The safer conclusion about Romsey is that it was more the product of local circumstances and personalities than an indication of a new national anti-Tory alliance.

Then of course there is the turnout argument. This claims that Labour's problem was simply that core Labour voters stayed at home in what, apart from Romsey, proved to be another set of elections with disappointingly low turnouts. All that Labour has to do is motivate them to vote in a general election where turnout will anyway be a lot higher.

Labour does indeed have a problem with unenthusiastic traditional supporters. This is clear from the BBC/ICM voter poll which accurately predicted the final outcome in London by going back on polling day to voters whom it had previously interviewed during the final week of the campaign. Those who before polling day said they would vote Labour in the assembly election were, in the event, 5% more likely to have stayed at home than Tory supporters. But this is far from the whole story.

In what was a dramatic swing against Labour in the last few days of the London campaign, Labour supporters did not simply stay at home. They also switched to the Greens and the Lib Dems. Among those who intended to vote Labour beforehand and who did go to the polls, only 77% actually voted Labour. In contrast, more than 90% of Tories stayed loyal to their cause.

Lack of enthusiasm can, it seems, soon turn into defection. Little wonder that Labour's opinion poll leads appear to be so brittle.

Equally, outside London Labour's heartlands rebelled. The table shows that Labour's vote was falling by twice as much in wards it was defending as it was elsewhere. But it was not just abstention that was doing the damage. Again it was the Lib Dems too.

Indeed, just as in last year's local elections, Labour's vote did not fall most where turnout dropped most. Rather the opposite is the case. Labour's vote fell most where the Lib Dems mounted their strongest challenges and in so doing motivated voters to come to the polls.

The final leg of the myth comes from extrapolating Thursday's results into Commons seats, with the suggestions that even on 29% Labour would still be the largest party. But these extrapolations assume that the strong anti-Tory bias exhibited by the electoral system in 1997 remains in place. The absence of anti-Tory tactical voting is, in fact, but one sign that it may not.

In short, there seems little reason why, on the basis of these results, Labour should take success at the next general election for granted. After all, its share of the vote in both these local elections and in last year's European parliament elections are on a par with the calamities suffered by John Major in the last parliament. Then many a commentator refused to believe that they were a portent of the Labour landslide to come. We should avoid making the mistake of ignoring the message from the ballot box now too.

fields.bodyText: Another mid-term electoral defeat that confirms that Tony Blair is still on course for a second term. That has been the near universal reaction to last Thursday's election results. And it is a dangerous myth. It is not that the results show that William Hague is unstoppably on his way towards Downing Street. But they suggest that Labour has work to do if it is to be sure of winning an adequate Commons majority at the next general election. How has the myth been perpetuated? In part it comes from the observation that voters do not vote the same way in local contests as they would in a general election. Labour consistently underperforms in local elections. So, Labour might be at just 29% in the local count but (it is said) the party can be confident of doing a lot better in a general election. Previous evidence suggests we can add 10% to Labour's projected share - but it does not indicate that we can safely add the 20% needed to make up the gap between Labour's performance on Thursday and its current opinion poll standing. A plausible reading of Thursday's elections is that Labour's Westminster standing is around 40% - not 50%. And 40% may not be enough to secure an adequate majority. The second element of the myth is derived from the result in Romsey. Do not worry, it says, about Labour's poor performance in the district elections or London. Voters in Romsey showed Labour and Liberal Democrat supporters are still willing to vote tactically against the Tories. Thus, though the Tory share of the vote fell by just 4%, a 15% slump in the third-placed Labour vote carried the Lib Dems to victory. The trouble is, the result in Romsey was wholly atypical of what was happening on Thursday. In the rest of the country, the Lib Dem challenge to the Tories was weakening, not strengthening. As the table shows, in local election wards that Labour was defending, the Lib Dem vote rose on average by nearly 6% while it fell on average by 4% where the Tories were defending. A similar pattern can be seen in the London assembly results. Far from ganging up on the Tories, voters in Tory-held wards were, if anything, reverting to type. In those Tory wards where the Lib Dem were starting off second, the Lib Dem vote was in fact down 8%, while Labour's losses were less than half what they were across the country as a whole. The safer conclusion about Romsey is that it was more the product of local circumstances and personalities than an indication of a new national anti-Tory alliance. Then of course there is the turnout argument. This claims that Labour's problem was simply that core Labour voters stayed at home in what, apart from Romsey, proved to be another set of elections with disappointingly low turnouts. All that Labour has to do is motivate them to vote in a general election where turnout will anyway be a lot higher. Labour does indeed have a problem with unenthusiastic traditional supporters. webTitle: Spiralling costs of public building projects

fields.headline: Spiralling costs of public building projects
fields.standfirst: The Millennium Bridge across the Thames is behind schedule and getting more expensive - a situation that is par for the course
fields.trailText: The Millennium Bridge across the Thames is behind schedule and getting more expensive - a situation that is par for the course
fields.body:
When the Queen steps forward tomorrow to dedicate the new Millennium Bridge across the Thames she will be looking at a mass of metal rods and scaffolding.

For the low-level suspension bridge, made of stainless steel, wood and aluminium and hailed as a piece of landmark architecture, will not be ready on time for the royal occasion.

The bridge, which has seen costs escalate from £15m to £18m, has hit a number of hurdles, including unexpected work and a strike by staff at a Finnish metal company.

Designed by the architect Sir Norman Foster, construction began in January last year. Now the bridge's real opening has had to be delayed by a month until June 10.

For those involved in the construction of public buildings, the delay is par for the course. For many British buildings - both past and present - come in late and over budget.

In Scotland the new building for the Scottish parliament at Holyrood has been dubbed Dewar's Dome. Cement mixers have been standing idle, costs have escalated almost fourfold to £195m and the estimated time for completion has continued to spin out.

But the politicians in Edinburgh need only look at the home of their London equivalents in the Palace of Westminster for an example of how slow and how expensive it can be to build new seats of democracy.

The cost there rose from a first estimate of £707,104 in 1835 to more than £2.4m when it was eventually completed in 1860.

Sir Charles Barry, the project's senior architect, thought the building would take just six years to finish. Eight years and £1.4m later, Parliament appointed a royal commission to try to find a means of speeding things up. Before the building was finished Barry and fellow architect Augustus Pugin were dead.

Sitting in Holyrood, the MSPs may see a reflection of their own situation in this historic parallel. After weeks of controversy over the escalating costs of the project, an independent architect, Sir John Spencely, was brought in to look for cost savings.

He found that the original team had "lost control of costs" - letting projected cost rise to £230m - and capped the spending on the building at £195m. He set a completion date for the end of 2002.

Architect Roland Paoletti's Jubilee line extension for the London Underground opened last November, 18 months late and, at a cost of at least £3.5bn, almost double the original budget. He commented: "In Britain civil engineering work always comes in late and over-budget. Look at the Channel tunnel, or the Limehouse link or any road."

The £10bn cost of the Channel Tunnel was more than double the £4.8bn forecast in 1987 after being dogged by problems with funding and British railway technology.

The £520m British Library should have opened in 1993 but was not completed until 1996. The foundation stone was laid in 1982 but the project was toyed with by successive governments and it was originally designed for a different site in Bloomsbury. It had to be redesigned to fit the eventual site alongside St Pancras rail station.

In February it emerged that MI5 and MI6 conspired to hide huge overspends on their new headquarters buildings.

Igor Rukuts, managing director of Northcroft, the construction cost consultants, said that "unique buildings in unique locations" often go over budget and not just in Britain. He cites the Sydney Opera House where the architect, Jorn Utzon, won an open competition to design it in 1957. It was 1973 before the building opened.

Rukuts says the reasons for delay and increasing costs can vary from project to project. "For example, the brief from the client for the project might not be as full as it could be.

"Sometimes they have not taken into account exclusions that are made on the overall costs. Sometimes additional space may be required later. There may be inflation. Planning restrictions can often lead to a longer timescale. There may be inappropriate project controls or legislation changes."

Northcroft was appointed by the House of Commons to investigate the spiralling costs of Portcullis House, the new office block for MPs. It said that £100m had been added to the cost of the project in the last six years - making the total £250m - because its designers had failed to take account of a series of factors, including the impact of inflation.

Ken Powell of the Twentieth Century Society, which protects 20th century architecture and design, said: "The basic issue of the cost of buildings going up is absolutely commonplace.

"After the thing has been awarded to the architect, inevitably the client wants to monitor the project, they want twice as many lavatories, more offices or more space.

"The cost of materials may go up. So many projects take longer than anyone imagined, partly through planning delays and construction issues. Sometimes schemes get revised in a more costly direction. And sometimes inflation takes its bite."

Other developments exceeding their original budgets include the Thames barrier, the NatWest tower in the City of London, the refurbished Royal Opera House in Covent Garden, Sadler's Wells, and London's Royal Court theatre.

Yet other buildings manage to come in on time and to budget. Crystal Palace was raised in weeks, the Empire State Building in a year.

Sometimes you can be lucky, explains Mr Rukuts. "But construction is a very difficult thing to put costs on.

"And unique buildings in unique places are the most difficult to predict. Like the Scottish parliament."

Estimated cost: £1.9bn in October 1993

Actual cost: £3.5bn when opened in November 1999

The British Library:

Estimated cost: £164m

Actual cost: £520m

Thames Barrier:

Estimated cost: £23m

Actual cost: £46m

Channel Tunnel:

Estimated cost: £4.8bn in 1987

Actual cost: £10bn

Portcullis House:

Estimated cost: £150m

Current cost (as yet uncompleted): £250m

webTitle: Scientist urges law to boost embryo supply

fields.headline: Scientist urges law to boost embryo supply
fields.standfirst: Medical research hampered by ban on donation of healthy cells
fields.trailText: Couples should be allowed to donate immature embryos to science to help find a treatment for incurable diseases, Britain's leading researcher into growing human cells for transplant has declared.
fields.body:
Couples should be allowed to donate immature embryos to science to help find a treatment for incurable diseases, Britain's leading researcher into growing human cells for transplant has declared.

Austin Smith, of the Centre for Genome Research at Edinburgh University, told the Guardian that attempts to find the Holy Grail of frontier medical research - the key to an unlimited supply of spare human cells for grafts and transplant - were being hampered by the poor quality of embryos available.

At present, researchers can only receive - with donors' consent - surplus human embryos produced by egg donors and people with fertility problems who are trying to have a baby through IVF treatment.

"I would be absolutely delighted if people came forward," said Dr Smith. "If a couple came to me and said they wanted to donate embryos for this research project, that would be very positive.

"There's no system in place, or even a proposal, to go out actually soliciting for that. It's not a trivial thing for women to donate eggs. But it is something that is feasible and we have thought about it."

At 39, Smith, a quiet, intense thinker still with the Liverpool accent of his childhood, finds himself at the centre of some of the fiercest scientific and ethical debates today: when does human life begin?; should limited human cloning be permitted?

Most critically, can a tiny clump of cells called "stem cells", gleaned from the barely larger speck of cells making up an eight-day-old human embryo, be coaxed into becoming a single, large mass of specialised human tissue - nerves, skin, heart, lung, liver?

The Centre for Genome Research is unique. At a time when the government is agonising over whether to change the law to allow scientists to use human embryos for stem cell research, Dr Smith's lab is already doing it, and has been since 1996.

So is the centre breaking the law? Not quite. The rules say British scientists can only attempt to cultivate human cells from embryos for research into fertility or congenital diseases. And that's what Dr Smith's licence from the Human Fertilisation and Embryo Authority allows him to do.

But the licence, and the consent forms potential donors sign, also states that the ability to grow human cells for transplants may emerge from the research as a by-product.

"There is a sense in which it is pushing at the limits of the law. I'm not a lawyer and in the end it wasn't me that made the decision the licence should be granted. What we are doing can and has been justified in the context of the existing law."

The phrase "human embryo" has a powerful emotional resonance, but the embryos employed by scientists such as Dr Smith are human by origin and label rather than by inherent characteristics. They are clumps of cells, ranging in size from a single fertilised egg to a ball of scores of cells. They have no nervous system, no discernible feeling, thoughts, or consciousness.

"You don't have to practise contraception. You don't have to have fertility treatment or abortion. But in a liberal democracy you don't have the right to say other people can't have these things.

"At what point do you say life begins or life is valid? The general public doesn't understand we are talking about a ball of a hundred cells."

The aim of Dr Smith's programme is to cultivate the human embryo from its most primitive, first or second-day stage to that larger ball of cells, which is called a blastocyst. From this, with the skill of long experience and a measure of luck, it is possible to extract stem cells - cells which have the potential to turn into any of the myriad specialist cells, like nerve cells or heart cells, which make up the whole human body.

What scientists hope eventually to be able to do is isolate the stem cells and "instruct" them, as our genes somehow do, to turn into the desired specialist cell. This would allow the manufacture of human spare parts for transplant. The first target: unlimited quantities of human nerve cells to graft into sufferers from Parkinson's and Huntington's disease.

Although scientists in the US have claimed some success, this goal is a long way off. Even in mice, the area where Dr Smith and his colleagues have gained a worldwide reputation, success has been limited. They can isolate mouse stem cells, and make them specialise. But they cannot direct them to become a particular kind of organ: they grow into a kind of cell porridge called an "embryoid body", with millions of nerve, heart and skin cells jumbled up higgledy piggledy.

With the publication imminent of a report by the government's advisory body on whether to make stem cell research with human embryos easier, Dr Smith argues that the media focus on one aspect of the debate - whether to allow scientists to create cloned human embryos - has clouded the most important issues about existing regulations.

Creating human embryos by cloning remains an exotic and unreliable technique, he points out, and for the immediate future stem cell researchers will be reliant on embryos created by conventional means.

For progress, there had to be better availability of human embryos and an increase in the number of teams working on stem cell research. Both these aims would be served by the message a change in the law would send out.

"Most of the fertilised eggs or pairs of cells we get [from the IVF clinics] really can't develop at all. They might divide once or twice and then everything dies. We're starting from a population which has been selected to have fertility problems... we're getting the worst possible set.

"A change in the law, a positive signal from the government and hopefully positive coverage in the media might encourage people to donate embryos for this research more than has hitherto been the case. And if more people are doing this research, the total number of good embryos available might increase the overall chances of success.

"A change in the law would tell the general public that this is something important, that people should be putting resources in to make sure it works. At the moment we have to accept what we can get. We are not getting access to good embryos that are just being thrown away."

fields.headline: Critic of ETA shot dead
fields.standfirst: Bombs in Madrid: special report
fields.trailText: A Basque journalist who had been highly critical of the separatist movement ETA was gunned down yesterday, almost certainly by a member of the banned organisation.
fields.body:
A Basque journalist who had been highly critical of the separatist movement ETA was gunned down yesterday, almost certainly by a member of the banned organisation.

Jose Luis Lopez de la Calle, 62, was shot four times in the head and chest as he left his house in the Basque town of Andoain to buy Sunday papers. He died immediately.

Mr Lopez de la Calle was ETA's third victim since the group renewed its campaign of violence last November after a 14-month ceasefire.

In January an army officer was killed in a car bomb in Madrid. A Basque politician was also killed by a car bomb in the run-up to the Spanish general election in March.

The separatist rebels, who are fighting for an independent Basque state, have claimed 800 victims since their fight began in 1968.

Mr Lopez de la Calle was a columnist for the daily paper El Mundo and sat on the editorial board of its Basque edition. He was also known to be an ETA target.

Last February his home was attacked with a molotov cock tail. At the time he declared that, as a Basque, he had never known true freedom.

In his youth he fought the totalitarian regime of General Franco, both as a member of the Communist party and as a trade union leader. After Spain became a democracy, extreme nationalists and separatists continued to deny Basques their liberty, he said.

Paying tribute to him, the editor of El Mundo, Pedro Ramirez, described him as a relentless campaigner against fascism in all its manifestations.

Yesterday's shooting continues a campaign against journalists launched by ETA in March, when the popular presenter of state radio's morning news programme received a bomb disguised as a box of cigars.

The weight of the package alerted him and it was defused. Last month a parcel bomb was sent to a journalist on a conservative Madrid newspaper.

Media figures have often received threats from ETA but Mr Lopez de la Calle is only the second to have been killed. Another journalist, who was involved in negotiations with the group, was killed in 1978.

The Spanish prime minister, Jose Maria Aznar, who is in Morocco on the eve of a state visit, cancelled all engagements, and the interior minister and the deputy prime minister travelled to the Basque country.

Yesterday's shooting raised the political temperature in north-eastern Spain to boiling point. There were angry calls for the dissolution of the Basque government, led by non-violent nationalists - who have refused to sever their loose links with the separatists' political wing - and for fresh regional elections to be held.

Commentators pointed to the contrast with Northern Ireland where the peace process was once more moving ahead.

"The irony is too great," said one. "There they have set a deadline for giving up arms; here we seem to be in a worse position than ever,"

Protests against the latest killing have been called in Madrid, Barcelona and the Basque country.

Mr Aznar, whose centre-right government was re-elected on March 12, made his tough stand against ETA one of the focal points of his political platform, ruling out negotiations unless the group unconditionally renounced violence. He also denounced its ceasefire as a "trick and a sham".

In a speech to parliament as he took office last week he challenged the mainstream Basque Nationalist Party (PNV) to end its frequently ambiguous attitude towards the terrorists.

"What does ETA have to do for the PNV to make a stand?" he said.
